PREFACE 
    This Code constitutes a recodification of the general and permanent ordinances of the City of Morrison, Illinois. 
    Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the 1977 Code, as supplemented through March 22, 2009, and ordinances subsequently adopted by the city council. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this Code, the reader can locate any section of the 1977 Code, as supplemented, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
    The chapters of the Code have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order, and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage. Notes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant state law have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this Code. 
Chapter and Section Numbering System 
    The chapter and section numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash. The figure before the dash refers to the chapter number, and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the second section of chapter 1 is numbered 1-2, and the first section of chapter 6 is 6-1. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter, and at the same time new sections can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments. For example, if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 6-1 and 6-2 is desired to be added, such new section would be numbered 6-1.5. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject. The next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division. New chapters may be included by using one of the reserved chapter numbers. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. 
Page Numbering System 
    The page numbering system used in this Code is a prefix system. The letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume. The number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion. In the case of a chapter of the Code, the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter. In the case of an appendix to the Code, the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix. The following are typical parts of codes of ordinances, which may or may not appear in this Code at this time, and their corresponding prefixes: 
CHARTER CHT:1 RELATED LAWS RL:1 SPECIAL ACTS SA:1 CHARTER COMPARATIVE TABLE CHTCT:1 RELATED LAWS COMPARATIVE TABLE RLCT:1 SPECIAL ACTS COMPARATIVE TABLE SACT:1 CODE CD1:1 CODE APPENDIX CDA:1 CODE COMPARATIVE TABLES CCT:1 STATE LAW REFERENCE TABLE SLT:1 CHARTER INDEX CHTi:1 CODE INDEX CDi:1  
Index 
    The index has been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the index itself that stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
    A special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication. With this system, the publication will be kept up to date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited, and the affected page or pages will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. 
    Keeping this publication up to date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication. As revised pages are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes.

Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal Adoption of Codes and Records Act, 50 ILCS 220/0.01 et seq.; Illinois Municipal Code, 65 ILCS 5/1-1-1 et seq.; authority for adoption of municipal ordinances, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1; incorporation of cities, 65 ILCS 5/2-3-1; corporate powers and functions of municipalities, 65 ILCS 5/11-1-1 et seq.; strong mayor form of municipal government, 65 ILCS 5/6-1-1 et seq.; municipality defined, 5 ILCS 70/1.27; units of local government defined, 5 ILCS 70/1.28; language limiting or denying power of home rule units, 5 ILCS 70/7; Gender-Neutral Statutes Commission Act, 5 ILCS 90/1 et seq. 

Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
    The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Code of Ordinances, City of Morrison, Illinois," and may be so cited. The Code may also be referred to by the shortened title, "Morrison Municipal Code." 
State Law reference- Revision and codification of ordinances, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-3. 
Sec. 1-2. - Rules of construction and definitions. 
(a)  In the construction of this Code, and of all the city's ordinances and resolutions, the rules and definitions set out in this subsection shall be observed and applied, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the city council: 
    Alderman. The term "alderman" means an elected member of the city council, and may also be referred to as a "councilmember" or "councilman." 
    Bond schedule; city bond schedule. The terms "bond schedule" or "city bond schedule" refer to the comprehensive list of bonds adopted by the city from time to time and included as chapter 20. 
    City and town. The terms "city" and "town" each mean the City of Morrison, Illinois, or the area within the territorial limits of the City of Morrison, Illinois, and such territory outside of the city over which the city has jurisdiction or control by virtue of any constitutional or statutory provision. 
    City council, council, and governing authority. The terms "city council," "council," and "governing authority" mean the city council of the City of Morrison. The term "all its members" or "all councilmen" means the total number of councilmen holding office. 
    Code. The terms "Code" and "this Code" mean the Code of Ordinances of the City of Morrison, Illinois. 
    Computation of time. The time within which any act provided by law is to be done shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the last, unless the last day is Saturday or Sunday or is a holiday as defined or fixed in any statute now or hereafter in force in the state, and then it shall also be excluded. If the day succeeding such Saturday, Sunday, or holiday is also a holiday, a Saturday, or a Sunday, then that succeeding day shall also be excluded. 
    Corporate limits; city limits. The terms "corporate limits" and "city limits" mean the legal boundaries of the City of Morrison, Illinois. 
    County. The terms "the county" and "this county" mean Whiteside County, Illinois. 
    Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears requiring the head of a department or some other city officer to do some act or perform some duty, it is to be construed to authorize the head of the department or other officer to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act or perform the duty. 
    Fee schedule; city fee schedule. The terms "fee schedule" and "city fee schedule" refer to the comprehensive list of fees and other charges adopted by the city from time to time and included as chapter 20. 
    Fiscal year. The fiscal year of the city refers to the period beginning on May 1 of each year and ending on April 30 of each year. 
    Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only shall apply to females and to all other persons, as defined in this section. 
    ILCS. The abbreviation "ILCS" means the Illinois Compiled Statutes, as they now exist or as hereafter amended. 
    Joint authority. All words giving a joint authority to three or more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such persons or officers. 
    Keeper and proprietor. The terms "keeper" and "proprietor" mean persons, firms, associations, corporations, clubs, and copartnerships, whether acting by themselves or as servants, agents, or employees. 
    Land and real estate. The terms "land" and "real estate" mean real property and include rights and easements of an incorporeal nature. 
    Law. The term "law" denotes applicable federal law, the constitution and statutes of the state, the ordinances of the city, and, when appropriate, any and all rules and regulations which may be promulgated thereunder. 
    May. The term "may" is permissive. 
    Mayor. The term "mayor" means the mayor of the city. 
    Month. The term "month" means a calendar month. 
    Nontechnical and technical words. Words and phrases shall be construed according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such meaning. 
    Nuisance. The term "nuisance" means anything offensive or obnoxious to the health and welfare of the inhabitants of the city or any act or thing repugnant to, or creating a hazard to, or having a detrimental effect on the property of another person or to the community. 
    Number. A word importing the singular number only shall apply to several persons and things as well as to one person or thing, and a word in the plural number includes the singular number. 
    Oath, etc. The term "oath" shall be deemed to include an affirmation, and the term "sworn" shall be construed to include the term "affirmed." 
    Offense and violation. The terms "offense" and "violation" mean any act forbidden by any provision of this Code or the omission of any act required by the provisions of this Code. 
    Officers generally. Whenever any officer is referred to by title, such as "clerk," "chief of police" or "president," such reference shall be construed as if followed by the words "of the City of Morrison." 
    Or, and. The term "or" may be read "and" and the term "and" may be read "or" if the sense requires it. 
    Ordinance. The term "ordinance" means a legislative act of the city council of a general and permanent nature. 
    Owner. The term "owner," applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant, or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or of a part of such building or land. 
    Penalty schedule or city penalty schedule. The term "penalty schedule" or "city penalty schedule" refer to the comprehensive list of penalties adopted by the city from time to time and included as chapter 20. 
    Person. The term "person" shall apply to associations, clubs, societies, firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate as well as to individuals. 
    Personal property. The term "personal property" means all property except real property, as defined in this section. 
    Preceding, following. The terms "preceding" and "following" mean next before and next after, respectively. 
    Premises. The term "premises," when used as applicable to property, extends to and includes land and buildings. 
    Property. The term "property" includes real and personal property. 
    Real property. The term "real property" means lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
    Resident. The term "resident" means any person who resides in or within 11/2 miles outside of the city limits. 
    Resolution. The term "resolution" means a legislative act of the city governing authority of a special or temporary character. 
    Shall. The term "shall" is mandatory. 
    Sidewalk. The term "sidewalk" means that portion of a street between the curblines, or the lateral lines of a roadway, and the adjacent property lines, intended for use of pedestrians. 
    Signature and subscription. The terms "signature" and "subscription" mean a mark when the person cannot write. 
    State. The terms "the state" and "this state" mean the State of Illinois. 
    Street. The term "street" means the entire width between boundary lines of every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel. 
    Tenant, occupant. The terms "tenant" and "occupant," applied to a building or land, include any person holding a written or oral lease or who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, either alone or with others. 
    Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. 
    Written, in writing. The terms "written" and "in writing" mean any representation of words, letters or figures, whether by printing or otherwise. 
    Year. The term "year" means a calendar year. 
(b)  In the interpretation and application of any provisions of this Code, they shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. 
(c)  All general provisions, terms, phrases and expressions contained in this Code shall be liberally construed in order that the true intent and meaning of the city council may be fully carried out. 
(d)  The rules of construction and definitions set out herein shall not be applied to any section of this Code which shall contain any express provision excluding such construction, or where the subject matter or context of such section may be repugnant thereto. 
State Law reference- Similar rules of statutory construction, 5 ILCS 70/10.01; month and year defined, 5 ILCS 70/1.10; computation of time, 5 ILCS 70/1.11; liberal construction, 5 ILCS 70/1.01; tense, 5 ILCS 70/1.02; number, 5 ILCS 70/1.03; gender, 5 ILCS 70/1.04; joint authority defined, 5 ILCS 70/1.09; oath defined, 5 ILCS 70/1.12; written and in writing defined, 5 ILCS 70/1.15; Gender-Neutral Statutes Commission Act, 5 ILCS 90/1 et seq. 
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines, references, and notes. 
(a)  The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
(b)  State law references, editor's notes, and history notes are intended for explanation and editorial aid only and shall not be deemed a part of the text of any section. 
Sec. 1-4. - Conflict of provisions. 
(a)  If the provisions of different chapters conflict with each other, the provisions of each individual chapter shall control all issues arising out of the events and persons intended to be governed by that chapter. 
(b)  If the provisions of different sections of the same chapter conflict with each other, the provision which is more specific in its application to the events or persons raising the conflict shall control over the more general provision. 
(c)  If any of the provisions hereof conflict, and the conflict cannot be resolved by application of subsections (a) and (b) of this section, the more stringent regulation shall apply and the specific provision shall prevail over the general. 
State Law reference- Similar provision regarding statutes, 5 ILCS 70/6. 
Sec. 1-5. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    The sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional, invalid or unenforceable by the valid judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality, invalidity or unenforceability shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code. 
State Law reference- Similar provision regarding statutes, 5 ILCS 70/1.31. 
Sec. 1-6. - Unauthorized alteration of or tampering with Code. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to change or amend by additions or deletions any part or portion of this Code, or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented. 
Sec. 1-7. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed to affect: 
(1)  Any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code; 
(2)  Any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation assumed by the city; 
(3)  Any right or franchise granted by any ordinance of the city; 
(4)  Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, vacating, etc., any street or public way; 
(5)  Any appropriation ordinance; 
(6)  Any ordinance consistent with this Code levying or imposing taxes; 
(7)  Any zoning ordinance or any amendments thereto; 
(8)  Any ordinance establishing or prescribing street grades; 
(9)  Any ordinance relating to sewer service, or providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor; 
(10)  Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the city or any other ordinance relating to subdivisions; 
(11)  Any ordinance extending or contracting the boundaries of the city; 
(12)  Any ordinance consistent with this Code prescribing the number, classification or compensation of any city officers or employees; 
(13)  Any ordinance consistent with this Code prescribing vehicle or traffic regulations for specific locations. 
All such ordinances are recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code; they are on file in the city clerk's office and are open to inspection by the public. 
Sec. 1-8. - Amendments to Code. 
(a)  All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion in this Code, or in the case of repealed chapters, sections and subsections or any part thereof, by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby and the subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed or omitted, in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time as this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code by the city council. 
(b)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code should be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section of this Code in substantially the following language: "That section _____ of the Code of Ordinances, City of Morrison, Illinois, is hereby amended to read as follows:...." 
(c)  When the city council desires to enact any ordinance of a general and permanent nature on a subject not heretofore existing in the Code, a section in substantially the following language shall be made a part of the ordinance: "Section _____. It is the intention of the city council and it is hereby ordained that the provisions of this ordinance shall become and be made a part of the Code of Ordinances, City of Morrison, Illinois, and the sections of this ordinance may be renumbered to accomplish such intention." 
(d)  All sections, articles, chapters or provisions of this Code desired to be repealed should be specifically repealed by section number or chapter number, as the case may be. 
Sec. 1-9. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contract or by city personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the city council. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the city council during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit property into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In the preparation of a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified Code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections _____ through _____" (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted in the Code, but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
Sec. 1-10. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
(a)  When any ordinance repealing a former ordinance, clause or provision shall be itself repealed, such repeal shall not be construed to revive such former ordinance, clause or provision unless it shall be in the ordinance so expressly provided. 
(b)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed or cause of action arising under the ordinance repealed. 
State Law reference- Similar provision, 5 ILCS 70/3. 
Sec. 1-11. - Effective date of ordinances. 
(a)  All ordinances of the council required to be published shall take effect ten days after the publication thereof, and all other ordinances, resolutions, and orders shall take effect and be in force from and after their passage unless otherwise therein provided. 
(b)  The ordinances of the city, when published in book form by authority of the council, shall be deposited in the office of the city clerk. He shall deliver one copy thereof to each officer of the city, and to such other persons as the mayor or council shall direct. The mayor, city attorney, or city clerk shall have power to extend to or reciprocate courtesies of other cities, by presenting to them a copy of the ordinances in such manner as may seem suitable. 
State Law reference- Effective date of statutes, 5 ILCS 75/0.01 et seq.; effective date of ordinances, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-4. 
Sec. 1-12. - Publication of penal ordinances. 
    The city clerk shall cause every ordinance making any appropriation or imposing any fine, penalty, forfeiture, or imprisonment to be published at least once in some newspaper printed and published in the city, within one month after the passage thereof, and it shall be his duty to see that the same is correctly printed and published. Nothing in this section shall be deemed to apply to any ordinance included in this Code which may be collectively published in book or pamphlet form by authority of the council. 
State Law reference- Publication of ordinances, effective date, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-4. 
Sec. 1-13. - Recordation and proof of ordinances. 
(a)  All ordinances passed by the city council shall be deposited in the office of the city clerk and shall be duly recorded by the clerk in the record book of ordinances. The city clerk shall file and carefully preserve the originals of all ordinances deposited in his office. 
(b)  The clerk, at the foot of the record of each ordinance recorded shall make a memorandum of the date of its passage, and of the publication of such ordinance when required to be published, which record or memorandum, or a certified copy thereof, shall be prima facie evidence of the passage and legal publication of such ordinance, for all purposes whatsoever. 
State Law reference- Recordation as prima facie evidence, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-5. 
Sec. 1-14. - Proof of ordinances. 
(a)  The contents of all municipal ordinances, the date of passage, and the date of publication or posting, where required, may be proved by the certificate of the city clerk, under the seal of the corporation. 
(b)  Whenever city ordinances are printed in book or pamphlet form and purport to be published by authority of the president and city council, the book or pamphlet shall be prima facie evidence of the contents, passage, and legal publication of the ordinances, as of the dates mentioned in the book or pamphlet, in all courts and administrative tribunals. 
State Law reference- Similar provision, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-6. 
Sec. 1-15. - General penalty for violation of Code; continuing violations. 
    Unless otherwise specified in this Code or limited by state statute: 
(1)  Whenever in this Code or in any ordinance of the city any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or a violation or an offense, or whenever in this Code or ordinance the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is provided, the violation of any provision of this Code or any ordinance shall be a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not less than $75.00 nor more than $750.00. 
(2)  In addition to fine and incarceration as stated in this section, a penalty imposed for violation of a provision of this Code or of an ordinance may consist of or include a requirement that the defendant perform some reasonable public service work, such as, but not limited to, the picking up of litter in public parks or along public highways or the maintenance of public facilities. 
(3)  Whenever in this Code any act or omission is made unlawful, it shall include causing, allowing, permitting, aiding, abetting, suffering, or concealing the fact of such act or omission. 
(4)  Each day any violation of any provision of this Code or of any ordinance shall continue constitutes a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 15-05, § 1, 4-27-2015) 
State Law reference- Penalties authorized for violation of ordinances, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1; penalties for local misdemeanors, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1.1; publication of penal ordinances, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-4; enforcement of ordinances, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-7; adoption of penalty provisions by reference, 65 ILCS 5/1-3-4. 
Sec. 1-16. - Interest and collection fees on fines. 
(a)  Interest on fines. All fines imposed by the city shall bear interest at the rate of two percent per month on the unpaid balance from the date of the imposition of the fine. 
(b)  Default in payment; collection. A default in the payment of a fine and costs or any installment imposed by a court may be collected by any and all means authorized for the collection of money judgments. 
(c)  Liability for collection costs. The city may retain attorneys and private collection agents for the purpose of collecting any default in payment of any fine or installment of that fine. Any expenses incurred by the city or by another governmental entity through an intergovernmental agreement to enforce the judgment, including, but not limited to, attorney's fees, court costs, and costs related to property demolition or foreclosure, shall be a debt due and owing the city after the expenses are fixed by a court and may be collected in accordance with applicable law. 
Sec. 1-17. - Acts punishable under different sections. 
    In all cases where the same offense is made punishable or is created by different clauses or sections of this Code, the prosecuting officer may elect under which to proceed; but not more than one recovery shall be held against the same person for the same offense; provided that the revocation of a license or permit shall not be considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar any other penalty being enforced. 
Sec. 1-18. - Enforcement proceedings. 
    The various chapters of this Code shall be enforced pursuant to the procedures described in this Code. In addition, the city shall have all other legal rights of action, including, but not limited to, injunction, the general penalties found in section 1-15, and all other appropriate forms of legal relief found in the city's ordinances, state or federal statutes, or otherwise by law. 
Sec. 1-19. - Officers, employees failing to perform duties. 
    No provision of this Code designating the duties of any officer or employee shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any fine or penalty provided in this Code for a failure to perform such duty, unless the intention of the city council to impose such a fine or penalty on such officer or employee is specifically clear and expressed in the section creating the duty. 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Time Off for Official Meetings Act, 50 ILCS 115/0.01 et seq.; Local Government Officer Compensation Act, 50 ILCS 145/1 et seq.; Local Records Act, 50 ILCS 205/1 et seq.; Open Meetings Act, 5 ILCS 120/1 et seq.; Freedom of Information Act, 5 ILCS 140/1 et seq.; Election Code, 10 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.; Oaths and Affirmations Act, 5 ILCS 255/0.01; Official Bond Act, 5 ILCS 260/0.01 et seq.; Officials Convicted of Infamous Crimes Act, 5 ILCS 280/0.01; Illinois Governmental Ethics Act, 5 ILCS 420/1-101 et seq.; corporate powers and functions generally, 65 ILCS 5/11-1-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - City seal designated. 
    The corporate seal of the city shall be circular in form, two inches in diameter, with the words, "City of Morrison, Whiteside Co., Illinois," engraved upon the face thereof. 
(Prior Code, § 245; Code 1977, § 1.20.010) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to adopt seal, 65 ILCS 5/2-2-12. 
Sec. 2-2. - Custody and use of city seal. 
    The city clerk shall be the custodian of the corporate seal. The clerk shall affix the impression of the seal to all commissions or other documents required to be issued by the clerk, and attest and countersign the same. The clerk shall affix the seal of all official acts of the mayor requiring it and, if necessary, attest the same. The clerk shall also certify under the corporate seal copies of all records, ordinances, documents, or papers in the clerk's office, when required by any city officer or other person, upon tender of the proper fees and charges therefor, where such fees or charges are authorized by any law or ordinance. In no case shall the impression of the seal be binding upon the city unless it is authorized by the laws or ordinances thereof and is attested by the official signature of the city clerk. 
(Prior Code, § 246; Code 1977, § 1.20.020; Ord. No. 78-14, § 1, 1978) 
State Law reference- Clerk required to keep municipal seal, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-90. 
Sec. 2-3. - City wards established. 
    The territory embraced within the limits of the city shall be divided into four wards, the boundaries of which are available in maps and other data on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Prior Code, § 194; Code 1977, § 1.16.010; Ord. No. 621, 1976) 
State Law reference- Division of city into wards, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-20-15, 65 ILCS 5/5-2-4. 
Secs. 2-4-2-24. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CITY COUNCIL[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- City councilmembers generally, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-45-5 et seq.; election of councilmembers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-25-75 et seq.; powers and duties of councilmembers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-45-15; qualifications for elective office, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-5; qualifications for appointed office, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-5; elected city officers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-25-5; city elections in cities having populations of less than 50,000, 10 ILCS 5/2A-30; primary election in cities, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-25-20; general election, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-25-55; city council in cities having managerial form of government, 65 ILCS 5/5-1-1. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-25-2-51. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ALDERMEN 

Sec. 2-52. - Creation, election, term. 
    There shall be a city council which shall consist of the mayor and eight aldermen, two elected from each of the city's four wards, each of whom shall be elected to the office for a four-year term, according to the method provided by statute. 
State Law reference- City council composition and manner of acting, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-45-5; composition of city board by referendum, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-25-10; city council in cities electing managerial form of government, 65 ILCS 5/5/5-2-3; general municipal elections in cities electing managerial form of government, 65 ILCS 5/5-2-18.6. 
Sec. 2-53. - Compensation. 
    The members of the city council shall receive such compensation as may be provided by ordinance, subject to such limitations as are prescribed by statute. 
State Law reference- Compensation of councilmembers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-50-5. 
Sec. 2-54. - Oath of office. 
    The members of the city council shall take the oath of office prescribed by statute. 
State Law reference- Oath of municipal officers generally, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-25; oath of officers in cities having managerial form of government, 65 ILCS 5/5-3-8. 
Sec. 2-55. - Powers and duties. 
    The city council shall be the legislative department of the city government and shall perform such duties and have such powers as may be delegated to it by statute. The powers of the council shall be purely legislative, except when specifically otherwise provided by state law. The executive and administrative powers of the city shall only be exercised when delegated to the appointive officers as provided herein. 
State Law reference- Powers and duties of city council in managerial form of government, 65 ILCS 5/5-3-6. 
Secs. 2-56-2-83. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - MEETINGS 

Sec. 2-84. - Regular meetings; time. 
    The regularly stated meetings of the city council shall be held at such place within the city as shall be procured for that purpose, on such dates and at such times as are from time to time established by council. The city council may at any regular meeting change or cancel the meeting time and date of any future meeting. When the regular meeting date falls on a legal holiday, the council shall meet on the previous or next day following the holiday at the same hour; provided, that the date and time is announced in its annual publication of meeting dates. The city council may, at any regular meeting, adjourn to such time as may be then and there agreed upon and, at such adjourned meeting, may transact any business which might be transacted at a regular meeting. 
(Prior Code, § 8; Code 1977, § 2.08.010; Ord. No. 00-03, § 1, 2000; Ord. No. 00-19, § 1, 2001; Ord. No. 02-13, § 1, 2002; Ord. No. 03-06, § 1, 2003) 
State Law reference- Regular and special meetings, notice of meetings, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-25. 
Sec. 2-85. - Quorum. 
    A majority of the corporate authorities authorized to be elected, including the mayor, shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business; but a smaller number may adjourn from time to time and may compel the attendance of absentees under such penalties as may be prescribed by ordinance. 
(Prior Code, § 9; Code 1977, § 2.08.020) 
State Law reference- Quorum, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-20. 
Sec. 2-86. - Voting by mayor or mayor pro tempore. 
(a)  The mayor shall not vote on any ordinance, resolution or motion except as follows: 
(1)  Where the vote is tied; 
(2)  Where one-half of all aldermen elected have voted favorably on an ordinance, resolution, or motion, even though there is no tie vote; or 
(3)  Where a vote greater than a majority of the corporate authorities is required to adopt an ordinance, resolution, or motion. 
(b)  An acting mayor, or mayor pro tempore, may vote as an alderman; but he shall not have an additional vote as presiding officer. 
(Prior Code, § 10; Code 1977, § 2.08.030) 
State Law reference- Mayor presides at meeting, voting by mayor and mayor pro tempore restricted, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-30; voting by mayor in managerial government forms, 65 ILCS 5/5-3-5. 
Sec. 2-87. - Passage of ordinances; veto; reconsideration; passage over veto. 
(a)  All ordinances, and all resolutions and motions passed by the council that create any liability against a city, that provide for the expenditure or appropriation of its money, or that provide for the sale of any city or school property shall be deposited with the city clerk. 
(b)  If the mayor approves of them, he shall sign them. Those of which he disapproves he shall return to the council with his written objections at the next regular meeting of the council occurring not less than five days after their passage. 
(c)  The mayor may disapprove of any one or more sums appropriated in any ordinance, resolution, or motion making an appropriation, and, if so, the remainder shall be effective. However, the mayor may disapprove entirely of an ordinance, resolution, or motion making an appropriation. 
(d)  If the mayor fails to return any ordinance or any specified resolution or motion with his written objections, within the designated time, it shall become effective despite the absence of his signature. 
(e)  Every resolution and motion specified in subsection (a) of this section and every ordinance that is returned to the council by the mayor shall be reconsidered by the council. If, after such reconsideration, two-thirds of all the aldermen then holding office on the city council agree to pass an ordinance, resolution, or motion, notwithstanding the mayor's refusal to approve it, then it shall be effective. The vote on the question of passage over the mayor's veto shall be by yeas and nays, and shall be recorded in the journal. 
State Law reference- Approval and veto of ordinances, 65 ILCS 5/5-3-2; reconsideration and passage over veto, 65 ILCS 5/5-3-3. 
Sec. 2-88. - Reconsideration at special meeting prohibited; exception. 
    No vote of the council shall be reconsidered or rescinded at any special meeting thereof, unless at such special meeting there shall be present as many aldermen as were present when such vote was taken. 
(Prior Code, § 11; Code 1977, § 2.08.040) 
State Law reference- Reconsideration, passing over veto, in cities having managerial form of government, 65 ILCS 5/5-3-4; requisites for reconsideration, 65 ILCS 5/5-3-4. 
Sec. 2-89. - Special meetings; notification. 
    Special meetings and notification thereof shall be as follows: 
(1)  Special meetings of the council shall be called by the mayor or any three aldermen, such call to be made in writing. Notice of such meeting shall be given to the mayor and to each alderman by the city clerk at least 24 hours before the time of holding such special meeting. Upon receipt of such request in writing, the city clerk, or in his absence, the mayor, or, in the absence of the city clerk and mayor, any alderman, shall notify the news media pursuant to the requirements of this section as soon as is practicable. Said notices shall state the time and place. 
(2)  Simultaneously, with the notice to the mayor and to the aldermen, the person designated in subsection (1) of this section, giving said notification, shall, also, notify the news media pursuant to the open meeting requirements of the state. Notification of such special meeting shall be directed to those members of the news media requesting such notification. The news media shall make such requests for notification by filing a written request with the city clerk stating the name of the news media, its address, and the telephone number, along with the name, address and telephone number of the reporter covering the report of city council business and an indication as to where notices shall be directed. 
(Prior Code, § 15; Code 1977, § 2.08.080; Ord. No. 78-14, § 1, 1978) 
State Law reference- Regular and special meetings, notice of meetings, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-25. 
Sec. 2-90. - Rules of proceedings. 
    The council shall at all its meetings and in the transaction of all its business be governed by such rules of procedure as usually govern parliamentary and legislative bodies of a similar kind insofar as they are applicable and except as otherwise provided by law or ordinance. 
(Prior Code, § 16; Code 1977, § 2.08.090) 
State Law reference- City council rules, expulsion of members, punishment of members for disorderly conduct, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-15. 
Sec. 2-91. - Record of attendance. 
    At every meeting of the council, the clerk shall proceed to call the roll of members and make and keep a record of their attendance. 
(Prior Code, § 17; Code 1977, § 2.08.100) 
Sec. 2-92. - Order of business. 
    The order of business at all regular council meetings shall be as established from time to time by the city council. 
(Prior Code, § 18; Code 1977, § 2.08.110) 
State Law reference- City council rules, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-15. 
Sec. 2-93. - Compelling attendance. 
    If at any regular, adjourned or special meeting of the council of which due notice has been given as required by law and ordinance, a quorum is not in attendance, the members present at such meeting may, by a majority vote, command the chief of police or any other person designated by them to forthwith arrest and bring the body of any alderman absenting himself from such meeting, before the council, unless he is dangerously sick or detained by circumstances making it impossible for him to be present at such meeting. 
(Prior Code, § 19; Code 1977, § 2.08.120) 
State Law reference- Quorum, compelling attendance of councilmembers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-20. 
Sec. 2-94. - Absence from meetings; penalties. 
(a)  If the mayor, city clerk, city attorney or any alderman willfully neglects or refuses to attend any regular, adjourned or special meeting of the council of which notice as required by law or ordinance has been given without having just cause for so doing, he shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined in the amount provided in the city penalty schedule and any alderman who willfully neglects or refuses to attend, or remains away from the meetings of the council for a period of three months without having any just cause for so doing shall be deemed to have forfeited his office, and the same may be declared vacant, and it shall be filled as in other cases of vacancies. 
(b)  Any person who influences any alderman of the city to remain away from any meeting of the council, or any person who conceals, aids, assists, or abets in concealing, or who attempts to conceal any alderman of the city so that he may not be found when his attendance is desired at any council meeting, shall upon conviction thereof be fined in the sum of $200.00 for each and every offense. 
(Prior Code, § 20; Code 1977, § 2.08.130) 
State Law reference- Fine for failure of councilmember to attend, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-20. 
Sec. 2-95. - No person to address council without consent. 
    No person, other than the mayor or a member of the city council, shall address the city council at any regular or special meeting except upon consent of the mayor or, in his absence, the presiding officer acting on behalf of the mayor. 
Sec. 2-96. - Disturbing council and committee meetings. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to disturb any meeting of the city council or of any committee thereof. 
Sec. 2-97. - Investigation of charges. 
    Whenever any charges are preferred against any alderman, or other officer of the city, upon which action may be taken by the council, the same shall be referred to an appropriate standing committee of that body, whose duty it shall be to examine and report as to whether such charge is well founded or not, and such committee may, when deemed necessary, be empowered to send for persons and papers. 
(Prior Code, § 494; Code 1977, § 2.64.090) 
Sec. 2-98. - Summoning witnesses. 
    It shall be the duty of the city clerk to issue summonses, under the corporate seal, signed by the mayor, for all witnesses and the production of all papers that may be required before the council, or any committee thereof, and deliver the same to the chief of police or any police officer, who shall serve such summons by reading or delivering a copy thereof to the person summoned and make return indicating the manner in which he has executed the same. Any person who neglects or refuses to appear and testify when so summoned, or neglects or refuses to produce any papers in his possession or under his control pertaining to any such investigation by the council, or any committee thereof, shall be guilty of violating this section. 
(Prior Code, § 495; Code 1977, § 2.64.100) 
Sec. 2-99. - Public comment at meetings. 
(a)  Public meetings; public comment. Any person seeking to address the members of the city council, or any commission, committee or other official body of the city at any public meeting will be permitted to speak on any matter listed on the agenda, or on any other matter of public concern, in accord with the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  City council meetings. 
(1)  The agenda for each meeting of the city council shall specify a time during the meeting at which any member of the public may address the council. Any person so addressing the council shall be required, if able, to speak into the microphone provided, and state the name and address of the person and the topic of discussion at the beginning of that person's comments. 
(2)  No person shall speak or address the city council unless first recognized by the mayor or other presiding officer at the appropriate agenda time. 
(3)  Subject to subsection (c), public comment at a city council meeting shall be limited to no more than five minutes per commenter and to no more than one hour, total, per meeting, unless either of said time limits is extended by majority vote of the members present. The mayor may designate the city clerk, chief of police or other officer of the city to monitor the time utilized by each speaker, and to notify the speaker when the allotted time has expired. 
(4)  At any meeting of the city council, the mayor, at his discretion, may request that persons desiring to address the council at that meeting sign in on a "request to comment" form providing the name, address and topic to be discussed or addressed by the speaker. 
(5)  If the mayor recognizes that more than 20 persons desire to address the council at any one meeting, he or she may limit each speaker to comment of no more than three minutes, and, whenever any group of persons wishes to address the members of the city council on the same subject matter, the mayor may ask that a spokesperson be chosen from the group, but provided that if a spokesperson speaks on behalf of multiple members of the group, the mayor may permit the spokesperson to address for a period longer than the otherwise required time limits. In addition, if other matters are to be presented by other persons in the same group, the mayor may request that the group limit the number of such persons, or may request that the additional comment be limited to information which has not already been presented by the group spokesperson or other members of the group, in order that the total comment period for that meeting not be exceeded. 
(6)  Any person invited by the mayor or a member of the city council to address the members of the council at a meeting are subject to such time limitations as the majority of the members of the council present may prescribe. 
(c)  Committees, commissions and other boards. 
(1)  The time limits specified by subsection (b) shall not apply to persons addressing the planning and zoning board, or the historic preservation commission, when either of those bodies is conducting a quasi judicial hearing on a zoning or variance request, or on a request for historic district designation or issuance of a certificate of appropriateness, and in such instances, the usual and customary rules as applied by that body shall govern speech by members of the public. Provided, however, that the planning and zoning board and historic preservation commission may establish reasonable rules and time limits regarding the number and amount of time that persons advocating for or against pending matters must follow, so long as such rules conform to other requirements of law. 
(2)  Committees of the city council or any commission duly appointed or acting pursuant to authority of the city council may establish rules for public comment and persons wishing to address that committee, commission, or body, but provided that no rules shall be adopted by any of such committees or commissions that are more restrictive than the rules established for comment to the city council by the provisions of subsection (b). 
(d)  Publication. The city clerk shall post the provisions of subsection (b) and (c) on the city's official website, and shall provide a copy of this ordinance [to which this section derived] to any person making and submitting a request. In addition, the city clerk shall create and provide a "request to comment" sheet for use for signing in prior to each city council meeting. 
(Ord. No. 12-06, § 1, 2-13-2012) 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 12-06, adopted Feb. 13, 2012, amended the Code by adding new provisions designated as § 2-105. In order to maintain the Code format, and at the discretion of the editor, § 2-105 has been redesignated as § 2-99. 
Secs. 2-100-2-124. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Procedure for adoption of council-managerial form of government, 65 ILCS 5/5-1-1 et seq.; election of officers, 65 ILCS 5/5-2-1 et seq.; function and duties of officers, 65 ILCS 5/5-3-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-125. - Application of article. 
    The provisions of this article shall apply to all officers and employees of the city, unless otherwise provided in this Code, regardless of the time of the creation of the office or position or the time of the appointment of the officer or employee. 
Sec. 2-126. - Personnel policy handbook adopted. 
    The city has compiled and adopts as if fully set forth herein, as it now exists or may from time to time be amended, the City of Morrison Personnel Policy Handbook, a copy of which is on file in the office of the city clerk. 
Sec. 2-127. - Elections. 
    Elections for city officers shall be held as is provided by statute and at the time prescribed by statute. 
State Law reference- Elections generally, 10 ILCS; consolidated schedule of elections, 10 ILCS 5/2A-1.2; time of election generally, 10 ILCS 5/2A-30; election of officers in cities having a managerial form of government, 65 ILCS 5/5-2-1 et seq. 
Sec. 2-128. - Appointment. 
    All officers, other than elective officers, shall be appointed by the mayor, by and with the advice and consent of the city council, as is provided by statute; provided, that all employees, in the absence of any provisions to the contrary, shall be appointed or selected by the mayor. 
Sec. 2-129. - Term; vacancy. 
    Every appointive officer of the city shall hold office until May 1 following his appointment or until his successor is appointed and qualifies, unless it is otherwise provided by this Code. A vacancy in any appointed office shall be filled in the same manner in which appointments or selections are made, in the absence of provision to the contrary. 
Sec. 2-130. - Eligibility. 
    With the exception of the appointed city treasurer and deputy city clerk, no person shall be eligible to any office under the city government who is not a qualified elector of the city and who has not resided within the city for at least one year preceding his election or appointment, except as otherwise provided by law, and no person shall be eligible to any office who is a defaulter to the corporation. 
(Prior Code, § 485; Code 1977, § 2.64.010; Ord. No. 07-04, § 2, 2007; Ord. No. 07-10, § 2, 2007) 
State Law reference- Qualifications for elective office, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-5; qualifications for appointed office, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-5. 
Sec. 2-131. - Certificates of commission. 
    When any person elected or appointed to any city office has qualified as provided herein, the city clerk shall make out and deliver to such officer, except the mayor, clerk, and aldermen, a commission under the corporate seal, signed by the clerk and the mayor, or the presiding officer of the council. The mayor shall issue a certificate of election to the clerk under the seal of the corporation. 
(Prior Code, § 488; Code 1977, § 2.64.020) 
Sec. 2-132. - Oath. 
    Every city officer shall, before entering upon his duties, take and subscribe to the oath prescribed by statute. 
State Law reference- Oath of municipal officers generally, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-25; oath of officers in cities having managerial form of government, 65 ILCS 5/5-3-8. 
Sec. 2-133. - Bond. 
    Every officer and employee of the city shall, if required by the city council, before entering upon the duties of his office, execute a bond in an amount and with such security as provided in the city surety bond schedule in chapter 20 conditioned upon the faithful performance of the duties of his office or position and the payment of all money received by him according to law and the ordinances of the city. 
State Law reference- Bond generally, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-30; bond of officers in cities having managerial form of government, 65 ILCS 5/5-3-9. 
Sec. 2-134. - Records open to inspection. 
    All records kept by any officer of the city shall be open to inspection by the mayor, the city administrator or any member of the city council at all reasonable times, whether or not such records are required to kept by statute or by this Code. 
Sec. 2-135. - Records transmitted to successor in office. 
    Every officer and employee of the city, upon the expiration of his term for any cause whatsoever, shall deliver to his successor all books and records which may be the property of the city, and if no successor has been appointed within one week after the termination of office such property shall be delivered to the city clerk or city treasurer. 
Sec. 2-136. - Liability for losses or negligence. 
    All officers shall be liable to the city for all loss or damage that may result thereto from their negligence or willful misconduct in the discharge of any official duty. The council may, in its discretion, by order, withhold the salary of any such officer in order to secure the city from loss. 
(Prior Code, § 489; Code 1977, § 2.64.030) 
Sec. 2-137. - City officers designated. 
    The designation of city officer shall include the elected officers of mayor, aldermen, city clerk, and city treasurer and the appointed offices of city attorney and city administrator. 
(Prior Code, § 489; Code 1977, § 2.64.040; Ord. No. 92-12, art. 1, 1992) 
State Law reference- Elections generally, 10 ILCS; consolidated schedule of elections, 10 ILCS 5/2A-1.2; time of election generally, 10 ILCS 5/2A-30. 
Sec. 2-138. - Vacancy of office by removal from city or ward. 
    If the mayor or any other city officer, during his official term, removes beyond the limits of the city, his office shall thereby become vacant and if any alderman removes from the ward in and for which he was elected, his office shall thereby become vacant. 
(Prior Code, § 490; Code 1977, § 2.64.050) 
Sec. 2-139. - Delivery of property to successor required. 
    Any person having been an officer of the city shall, within five days after notification and request to do so, deliver to his successor in office all property, books and effects of every description belonging to the city or pertaining to his office; and upon his neglect and refusal to do so, he shall be subject to penalties for violation of this section and shall also be liable in a separate suit for all damages caused by such neglect or refusal. 
(Prior Code, § 491; Code 1977, § 2.64.060) 
Sec. 2-140. - Authority to remove; procedure. 
    The mayor of the city shall have the power to remove any officer appointed by him, or with his consent, upon any formal charge, whenever he is of opinion that the interests of the city demand such removal, but he shall report the reasons therefor to the council at a meeting to be held not more than ten days after such removal and, if the mayor fails to so report to the council or to file with the clerk a statement of his reasons for such removal within ten days after such removal, or if the council by a two-thirds vote of all members authorized by law to be elected, by yeas and nays to be entered upon its journal, disapproves of such removal, such officer shall thereupon become restored to the office from which he was so removed but he shall take a new oath of office and execute a new bond to the city. 
(Prior Code, § 492; Code 1977, § 2.64.070) 
Sec. 2-141. - Salary suspension upon removal. 
    No officer of the city removed from office as provided herein shall receive or draw any salary from and after the date of such removal by the mayor, unless restored to office by vote of the council and, in such case, he shall not be entitled to draw any salary for or during the time of such removal. 
(Prior Code, § 493; Code 1977, § 2.64.080) 
Sec. 2-142. - City officers; compensation. 
    The compensation of city officers shall be as established from time to time by the city council. 
(Code 1977, § 2.64.110; Ord. No. 92-12, art. 1, 1992) 
Sec. 2-143. - Right of entry for inspections. 
(a)  Whenever any officer or employee of the city is authorized to enter any building or premises for the purpose of making an inspection to enforce any ordinance, he may enter such building or premises at all reasonable times to inspect the same; provided, that he shall effect entry in the manner provided in this section, except in emergency situations or when consent of the person having charge or control of such building or premises has been otherwise obtained. 
(b)  If the building or premises to be inspected is occupied, the authorized officer or employee shall first present proper credentials and demand entry; and if such building or premises is unoccupied, he shall first make a reasonable effort to locate the owner or other person having charge or control of the building or premises and demand entry. If consent to such entry is not given, the authorized officer or employee shall have recourse to every remedy provided by law to secure entry, and may apply to any court of competent jurisdiction for such remedy. 
(Code 1977, §§ 1.08.010, 1.08.020; Ord. No. 634, §§ 1, 2, 1977) 
Secs. 2-144-2-169. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MAYOR 

Sec. 2-170. - Creation of office; election; term; compensation; oath. 
    There shall be a mayor who shall be elected for a term of four years, and he shall be the mayor of the city council, as is provided by statute. The mayor shall take the oath of office as prescribed by statute. Compensation for serving as mayor shall be established by the city council no less than six months prior to the end of the term of the mayor. 
State Law reference- Oath of municipal officers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-25; oath of municipal officers in cities having managerial form of government, 65 ILCS 5/5-3-9. 
Sec. 2-171. - Bond. 
    The mayor shall, before entering upon the duties of his office, qualify according to law and execute a bond to the city in the penal sum provided in the city surety bond schedule in chapter 20, with such security as the council shall approve, conditioned for the faithful performance of the duties of his office. 
(Prior Code, § 1; Code 1977, § 2.04.010) 
State Law reference- Bond generally, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-30; bond of officers in cities having managerial form of government, 65 ILCS 5/5-3-9. 
Sec. 2-172. - Licenses; issuance and revocation authority. 
    The mayor shall sign all commissions, licenses, and permits granted by authority of the council, except as otherwise provided, and such other acts and deeds as by law or ordinance shall require his official signature. The mayor shall have power to revoke licenses for cause, except as otherwise provided in this Code. 
(Prior Code, §§ 2, 3; Code 1977, § 2.04.020) 
Sec. 2-173. - Supervision of officers. 
    The mayor shall supervise the conduct of all officers of the corporation, inquire into all reasonable complaints made against them, and cause all of their neglects or violations of official duty to be corrected or reported to the proper tribunal for punishment. 
(Prior Code, § 4; Code 1977, § 2.04.030) 
Sec. 2-174. - Appointment of officers. 
    The mayor shall, within one month after each annual election, appoint by and with the advice and consent of the council, all officers of the city whose appointment is not otherwise provided for by law; and whenever a vacancy occurs in any office, which by law or ordinance he is empowered and required to fill, he shall, within 30 days after the happening of such vacancy, communicate to the council the name of his appointee to such office and, pending the concurrence of the council in such appointment, he may designate some suitable person to discharge the functions of such office. 
(Prior Code, § 5; Code 1977, § 2.04.040) 
Sec. 2-175. - Other duties. 
    In addition to the foregoing and to the duties imposed upon him by law, the mayor shall perform all such other duties pertaining to his office as are or may be required of him by ordinance, and he shall annually inform the council of the condition of the city. 
(Prior Code, § 6; Code 1977, § 2.04.050) 
Sec. 2-176. - Mayor pro tem. 
    During the temporary absence or disability of the mayor, the city council shall elect one of its members to act as mayor pro tem, who, during the absence or disability of the mayor, shall perform the duties and possess all the rights and powers pertaining to the office. 
State Law reference- Similar provision, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-35. 
Secs. 2-177-2-205. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CITY ADMINISTRATOR 

Sec. 2-206. - Creation of office. 
    There is created and established the position of city administrator. The position shall be considered an exempt position rather than a classified position of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 2.24.010; Ord. No. 04-26, art. I, 2004) 
State Law reference- Appointment, powers, and duties of municipal manager, 65 ILCS 5/5-3-7. 
Sec. 2-207. - Appointment; residency; vacancy in office; removal. 
(a)  The mayor and city council hereinafter referred to as the corporate authorities are hereby authorized to employ a city administrator for an indefinite term. Such administrator shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of a majority of the corporate authorities then holding office, without regard to his political beliefs. 
(b)  Within 180 days of appointment, the city administrator shall establish residence within the city. 
(c)  The city administrator shall, before entering upon the duties of his office, qualify according to law and execute a bond to the city in the penal sum provided in the city surety bond schedule in chapter 20, with such security as the council shall approve, conditioned for the faithful performance of the duties of his office. 
(Code 1977, § 2.24.020; Ord. No. 04-26, art. I, 2004; Ord. No. 12-31, § 1, 9-10-2012) 
State Law reference- Appointment, powers, and duties of municipal manager, 65 ILCS 5/5-3-7. 
Sec. 2-208. - Chief administrator. 
    The city administrator, subject to the direction of the corporate authorities, shall be the chief administrator of the city and shall be responsible to the corporate authorities for the proper management of city affairs. The city administrator shall have the powers and duties provided in 65 ILCS 5/5-3-7 in addition to duties assigned to him from time to time by the city council. 
(Code 1977, § 2.24.030; Ord. No. 04-26, art. I, 2004) 
Sec. 2-209. - Compensation. 
    The compensation of the city administrator shall be determined by the corporate authorities as fixed from time to time. 
(Code 1977, § 2.24.040; Ord. No. 04-26, art. I, 2004) 
Sec. 2-210. - Duties and responsibilities. 
    The city administrator shall be the primary nonelected administrative officer of the city in dealing with citizens, service vendors, civic groups, governmental agencies and others as needed. The city administrator shall be the principal intermediary between the corporate authorities and all employees of the city. The city administrator shall be responsible to the corporate authorities for the proper administration of all affairs of the city and shall have the following duties and responsibilities: 
(1)  Direct, supervise, and coordinate the administration of all departments, offices, and agencies of the city, except as otherwise provided by law; 
(2)  Employ and, when necessary for the good of the service, suspend or remove any city employee. All hirings and removals shall be made without discrimination as prohibited by the Illinois Human Rights Act (775 ILCS 5/1-101 et seq.). The city administrator may authorize any department head, subject to the city administrator's direction and supervision, to exercise these powers with respect to subordinates in that officer's department, office or agency; 
(3)  Attend all corporate authority meetings and certain specified meetings of appointed boards and commissions. The city administrator shall have the right to take part in all discussions, but shall not vote; 
(4)  Pursuant to direction from the corporate authorities, provide for the enforcement of all laws and ordinances within the city; 
(5)  Serve as budget officer, and prepare and submit to the corporate authorities, by the date set by the corporate authorities, a recommended annual budget for city operations and a recommended capital program. When the annual budget or capital program has been approved by the corporate authorities, the city administrator shall be responsible for the administration of said budget or capital program; 
(6)  Submit to the corporate authorities and make available to the public a complete report on the administrative activities of the city as of the end of each fiscal year; 
(7)  Aid in the supervision and performance of all contracts and public utility franchises and keep in force and effect and in full performance any and all such contracts and agreements; 
(8)  Make such other reports as the corporate authorities may require concerning the operations of city departments, offices, and agencies; 
(9)  Keep the corporate authorities fully advised as to the present financial condition and future needs of the city; 
(10)  Keep the corporate authorities fully advised as to pending decisions of public policy and recommend to the corporate authorities the adoption of such measures as the city administrator may deem necessary or expedient for the health, safety, or welfare of the community or for the improvement of administrative services; 
(11)  Be responsible for procurement of commodities and services for all city departments, offices, and agencies, and promulgate purchasing rules which shall be followed by employees in the procurement of goods and services; 
(12)  For the purposes of insurance and financial management, keep a current inventory of all real and personal property of the city and its location and be responsible for the care and custody of property which is not by law or ordinance assigned to some other officer or body; 
(13)  Coordinate the management of city hall and other city buildings, facilities, and properties; 
(14)  Propose to the corporate authorities such personnel rules and regulations as the city administrator deems necessary to manage the personnel policies of the city; 
(15)  Be responsible for the conduct of all collective bargaining processes of the city, and recommend to the corporate authority's collective bargaining agreements for consideration and final approval by the council. The city administrator shall be responsible for administering all employee organization contracts reached through the collective bargaining process; 
(16)  Provide staff support services for the mayor and members of the corporate authorities and for the appointed boards and commissions; 
(17)  Coordinate all city operations affecting more than one department, committee, or commission and, if deemed necessary, recommend consolidation or combining of offices, positions, departments, committees, or commissions within the city; 
(18)  Investigate all complaints received in relation to matters concerning the administration of the city and the services maintained and provided by the city; and 
(19)  Perform such other duties as may be specified by law or city ordinance or as may from time to time be requested by the city council. 
(Code 1977, § 2.24.050; Ord. No. 04-26, art. I, 2004) 
State Law reference- Powers and duties of city manager, 65 ILCS 5/5-3-7. 
Sec. 2-211. - Matters directed to city administrator's attention. 
    All offices and departments shall submit all matters requiring consideration or action by the corporate authorities to the city administrator, who shall submit them to the corporate authorities with recommendations as may be deemed necessary. All nonemergency department or employee requests by the corporate authorities shall be submitted to the city administrator, and the requesting party shall receive information as to policy and departmental operation from the administrator. 
(Code 1977, § 2.24.060; Ord. No. 04-26, art. I, 2004) 
Sec. 2-212. - Absence of city administrator. 
    In the event the city administrator is or will be absent from the city or incapacitated from performing the duties of this position, the corporate authorities may appoint an acting city administrator to serve during the administrator's absence or incapacity. 
(Code 1977, § 2.24.070; Ord. No. 04-26, art. I, 2004) 
Secs. 2-213-2-232. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - CITY CLERK 

Sec. 2-233. - Election; term; compensation. 
    The city clerk shall be elected and serve for a four-year term and until his successor is elected and qualified, as provided by statute. The compensation for serving as city clerk shall be established by the city council but in no event less than six months prior to the end of the term of the clerk. 
State Law reference- Election or appointment of clerk, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-25-90. 
Sec. 2-234. - Vacancy; acting clerk. 
    In case the office of city clerk shall become vacant for any reason, the mayor and city council, acting jointly, shall appoint an acting clerk as provided by statute. 
State Law reference- Filling vacancy, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-25-90. 
Sec. 2-235. - Bond. 
    The city clerk, before he enters upon the duties of his office, shall execute a bond to the city in the penal sum provided in the city bond schedule in chapter 20, with such security as shall be approved by the corporate authorities, conditioned for the faithful performance of the duties of his office and the payment of all monies that may be received by him, according to law and the ordinances of the city. The bond shall be filed with the city treasurer. 
(Prior Code, § 21; Code 1977, § 2.12.010) 
State Law reference- Bond generally, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-30; bond of officers in cities having managerial form of government, 65 ILCS 5/5-3-9. 
Sec. 2-236. - Council minutes. 
    The city clerk shall attend all meetings of the council and shall keep in a suitable book, to be styled the "Journal of the City Council," a full and faithful record of its proceedings. He shall issue and cause to be served upon the aldermen notices of all special meetings of the council. 
(Prior Code, § 22; Code 1977, § 2.12.020) 
Sec. 2-237. - Delivery of communications. 
    The clerk shall, within a reasonable time after the adjournment of each meeting of the council, deliver to the committees of that body, and to the officers of the city, upon request, all petitions, communications, resolutions, orders, claims, and other papers, referred to those committees or officers by the council; provided, however, that whenever copies of any of said documents shall answer the purpose fully as well, he may at his option furnish copies thereof and retain the originals among the files in his office. He shall, without delay, deliver to the mayor all ordinances or resolutions in his charge which may be required to be approved or otherwise acted upon by the mayor. 
(Prior Code, § 23; Code 1977, § 2.12.030) 
Sec. 2-238. - Preparation and attestation of documents. 
    The city clerk shall prepare all commissions, licenses, permits, and other official documents required to be issued by him under the laws and ordinances of the city, and shall attest the same with the corporate seal; and he shall, in like manner, attest all deeds for the sale of real estate owned and conveyed by the city. 
(Prior Code, § 24; Code 1977, § 2.12.040) 
Sec. 2-239. - Deputy clerks. 
    The city clerk may, when necessary, and upon being authorized by the council, appoint a deputy who, during the temporary absence or disability of the clerk, shall be empowered to perform all of the duties of the city clerk. The deputy city clerk shall not be required to be a qualified elector of the city nor shall they be required to live within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Prior Code, § 25; Code 1977, § 2.12.050; Ord. No. 07-04, § 1, 2007; Ord. No. 07-10, § 1, 2007) 
State Law reference- Authorization for and powers of deputy, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-45. 
Sec. 2-240. - Custody of records. 
    He shall carefully preserve in his office all books, records, papers, maps, and effects of every description belonging to the city and pertaining to said office; and upon the expiration in any way of his official term, he shall, on demand, deliver all such books, records, papers, and effects to his successor in office. 
(Prior Code, § 26; Code 1977, § 2.12.060) 
Sec. 2-241. - Custody of seal. 
    The city clerk shall have the care and custody of the seal of the city. 
(Prior Code, § 27; Code 1977, § 2.12.070) 
Sec. 2-242. - License recordation. 
    The city clerk shall keep and maintain a license record book, showing to whom, for what purpose or for what time, for what license fee, or for what length of time licenses have been given. 
(Prior Code, § 29; Code 1977, § 2.12.090) 
Sec. 2-243. - Document filing. 
    The city clerk shall file and preserve in a convenient form for use and reference all official bonds, oaths of office, vouchers, papers, and documents pertaining to the city. 
(Prior Code, § 30; Code 1977, § 2.12.100) 
Sec. 2-244. - Order book. 
    The city clerk will keep and maintain a city order book, containing a register of all orders issued by the city, stating the number of the order, the date and amount thereof, on what account and to whom issued and by whom received. He shall issue no orders except in the manner required by law. 
(Prior Code, § 31; Code 1977, § 2.12.110) 
Sec. 2-245. - Election duties. 
    Unless otherwise mandated by state statutes, the city clerk shall open and examine in the presence of the city council the returns of the city elections, entering the same and the results thereof as determined by the council in the journal of its proceedings. He shall give immediate notice to every person elected or appointed to any city office, of the fact; and should any such person neglect or refuse to qualify as required by law or ordinance, he shall notify the council thereof at its first meeting thereafter. 
(Prior Code, § 32; Code 1977, § 2.12.120) 
Sec. 2-246. - Other duties and positions. 
(a)  Other duties. In addition to the duties set forth in this division, the city clerk may perform such other duties pertaining to said office as are now or may be imposed upon such office by law, the city council, or by ordinance. The clerk may serve as collector, if appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council. 
(b)  Compensation. Compensation for serving as city clerk shall be established by the city council, no less than six months prior to the end of the term of the city clerk. If appointed by the mayor and with the advice and consent of the council to the position of collector, the collector salary shall be set as provided for in article VI of this chapter, pertaining to compensation administration, of the city personnel policy manual, as amended and the city position classification and salary plan, as amended. The clerk, when duly appointed as collector, shall be subject to all the terms and conditions of the city personnel policy manual. 
(Prior Code, § 33; Code 1977, § 2.12.130; Ord. No. 78-14, § 1, 1978; Ord. No. 99-10, § 1, 1999) 
State Law reference- Duties of municipal clerk generally, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-90 et seq. 
Sec. 2-247. - Office hours designated. 
    The city clerk shall maintain an office in the municipal building in the city, said office to be provided and designated by the council and furnished and maintained at the expense of the city. The office shall be open for the business of the city at such reasonable business hours as determined from time to time by the city council. 
(Prior Code, § 35; Code 1977, § 2.12.140; Ord. No. 80-5, § 1, 1980) 
Sec. 2-248. - Fees. 
    The city clerk shall charge fees for clerk's services as provided in the city fee schedule. Fees when collected by the city clerk under this section shall be deposited in the general fund of said city. 
(Prior Code, § 259; Code 1977, § 2.12.150; Ord. No. 78-14, § 1, 1978)
