(1)  Note the date the city receives the written request; 
(2)  Compute the day on which the period for response will expire and make a notation of that date on the written request; 
(3)  Maintain an electronic or paper copy of a written request, including all documents submitted with the request until the request has been complied with or denied; and 
(4)  Create a file for the retention of the original request, a copy of the response, a record of written communications with the requester, and a copy of other communications. 
(Ord. No. 10-04, § 2, 3-8-2010) 
Sec. 2-748. - Completion of training curriculum and program. 
    The FOIA officer and deputy FOIA officer shall, within six months after January 1, 2010, successfully complete an electronic training curriculum to be developed by the public access counselor of the state and thereafter successfully complete an annual training program. Whenever a new Freedom of Information officer is designated by the city, that person shall successfully complete the electronic training curriculum within 30 days after assuming the position. 
(Ord. No. 10-04, § 3, 3-8-2010) 
Sec. 2-749. - Retrieval of requested records. 
    Any records which are the subject of a request under the Freedom of Information Act shall be retrieved from such place as they are stored, by the FOIA officer, or by an employee of the city acting under the direction of the FOIA officer. In no event shall records be retrieved by the party requesting them or by any person who is not employed by the city. 
(Ord. No. 10-04, § 4, 3-8-2010) 
Sec. 2-750. - Copies of records; schedule of fees maintained. 
    If copies of records are requested, the fees for such copies, whether certified or not, shall be as determined from time to time by the FOIA officer pursuant to section 6(b) of the Freedom of Information Act. The city clerk shall maintain a written schedule of current fees in the clerk's office. The fees so charged shall reflect the actual cost of copying the records, and the cost of certifying copies, if certification is requested. 
(Ord. No. 10-04, § 5, 3-8-2010) 
Sec. 2-751. - Denial of city records inspection. 
    In the event that a request to inspect city records is denied by the FOIA officer, the denial may be appealed to the public access counselor of the state. 
(Ord. No. 10-04, § 6, 3-8-2010) 
Sec. 2-752. - Clerk to prepare required document information. 
    The city clerk shall prepare: 
(1)  A city information directory; 
(2)  A block diagram of the functional subdivisions of the city; 
(3)  A city records directory; and 
(4)  Types of public records under the city's control; 
all of which shall be substantially in the same form as the documents stated and made a part hereof. This information shall also be posted on the city's website. 
(Ord. No. 10-04, § 7, 3-8-2010) 
Chapter 4 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Liquor Control Act of 1934, 235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.; authority for local control of alcoholic beverages, 235 ILCS 5/4-1; restrictions on sales near churches, schools, and hospitals, 235 ILCS 5/6-11; restrictions on Sunday sales of alcoholic beverages, 235 ILCS 5/6-14; restrictions on sale or delivery of alcoholic beverages to municipally owned buildings, 235 ILCS 5/6-15; prohibited sales and possession generally, 235 ILCS 5/6-16; "happy hours" prohibited, 235 ILCS 5/6-28; Beer Industry Fair Dealing Act, 815 ILCS 720/1 et seq.; alcohops and alcopop advertising, 235 ILCS 5/6-35. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 4-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alcohol means the product of distillation of any fermented liquid, whether rectified or diluted, whatever may be the origin thereof, and includes synthetic ethyl alcohol. The term "alcohol" does not include denatured alcohol or wood alcohol. 
    Alcoholic liquor includes the four varieties of liquor defined in this chapter (alcohol, spirits, wine and beer) and every liquid or solid, patented, or not, containing alcohol, spirits, wine or beer, and capable of being consumed as a beverage by a human being. The term "alcoholic liquor" does not include alcohol used in the manufacture of denatured alcohol, nor to any liquid or solid containing one-half of one percent, or less, of alcohol by volume or flavoring extracts, concentrates, syrups, or medicinal, mechanical, scientific, culinary or toilet preparations, or food products unfit for beverage purposes, but the provisions of this chapter shall not be construed to exclude or not apply to alcoholic liquor used in the manufacture, preparation or compounding of such products. The term "alcoholic liquor" does not include wine intended for use and used by any church or religious organization for sacramental purposes. 
    Auto fuels means any public place kept, used or maintained for the principal business of selling gasoline, oil and related automotive products; the incidental or additional sales of packaged foods shall not be cause for considering such business as other than an auto fuels business. 
    Beer means a beverage obtained by the alcoholic fermentation of an infusion of barley, or other grain, salt and hops in water, and includes among other things, beer, ale, stout, lager beer, porter, and the like. 
    Club means a corporation organized under state law, and not for pecuniary profit, solely for the promotion of some common object other than the sale or consumption of alcoholic liquors, kept, used, and maintained by its members through the payment of annual dues and owning, hiring, or leasing a building space in a building of such extent and character as may be suitable and adequate for the reasonable and comfortable use and accommodation of its members and their guests provided with suitable and adequate kitchen and dining room space and equipment and maintaining a sufficient number of servants and employees for cooking, preparing, and serving food and needs for its members and their guests. 
    Food store means any public place kept, used or maintained for the principal business of selling at retail packaged food, produce, dairy products and related items, and whose annual earnings shall be derived in the majority from the sale of such items. 
    Licensee means any person or club holding a license under the provisions of this chapter. 
    Liquor store means any public place kept, used or maintained for the principal business of selling at retail package alcoholic liquor. 
    Original package means any bottle, flask, jug, can, barrel, keg, hogshead or other receptacles or containers whatsoever, used, corked, or capped, sealed and labeled by the manufacturer of alcoholic liquor, to contain and convey any alcoholic liquor. 
    Resident means a person who resides in and within the corporate limits of the city or resides in or owns at least one-half acre of real estate within one and one-half miles of the corporate limits of the city. 
    Restaurant means any public place, the principal use of which is the serving of prepared meals to public, and whose majority of annual earnings shall be derived from the sale of such meals, such place shall be equipped with adequate and sanitary kitchen facilities and dining room equipment and capacity and having employed therein a sufficient number of employees to prepare, cook and serve suitable foods for its guests. 
    Sale means any transfer, exchange or barter in any manner or by means whatsoever for a consideration, and includes and means all sales made by any person, whether principal, proprietor, agent, servant or employee. 
    Sell include to solicit or receive an order for, to keep or expose for sale and to keep with intent to sell. 
    Spirits means any beverage which contains alcohol obtained by distillation, mixed with water or other substance in solution, and includes brandy, rum, whiskey, gin, or other spirituous liquors, and such liquors when rectified, blended or otherwise mixed with alcohol or other substances. 
    Tavern means any public place kept, used, or maintained for the principal business of selling alcoholic liquors by the package or drink to patrons of such establishment. 
    Wine means any alcohol beverage obtained by the fermentation of the natural contents of fruits or vegetables, containing sugar, including such beverages when fortified by the addition of alcohol or spirits. 
(Code 1977, § 5.12.010; Ord. No. 90-7, § 1, 1990; Ord. No. 85-15, 1985; Ord. No. 18-04, § 2, 4-9-2018) 
State Law reference- Definitions under the cited act, 235 ILCS 5/1-3 et seq. 
Secs. 4-2-4-41. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION 

Sec. 4-42. - Local liquor control commissioner. 
    The mayor shall be the local liquor control commissioner and shall be charged with the administration of this chapter and with the administration of the rules and regulations of the Illinois Liquor Control Commission and the Illinois Liquor Control Act, 235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq. 
State Law reference- Local liquor control commissioner, 235 ILCS 5/4-2; compensation of local liquor control commissioner, 235 ILCS 5/4-3; powers of local liquor commissioner, 235 ILCS 5/4-4. 
Sec. 4-43. - Right of entry for inspection. 
    The local liquor control commissioner hereby is given the power to enter and authorizes any law enforcement officer or other city personnel to enter, at any time upon any premises licensed under this chapter to determine whether any of the provisions of the Liquor Control Act of 1934, 235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq., or any rules or regulations adopted by him or by the state commission have been, or are being, violated, and at such time to examine such premises of such licensee in connection therewith. 
(Ord. No. 18-04, § 3, 4-9-2018) 
Secs. 4-44-4-74. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LICENSING 

Sec. 4-75. - Required. 
    It is unlawful to sell or offer for sale at retail in the city any alcoholic liquor without having a retail liquor dealer's license or to in any way dispense, sell, offer or give alcoholic liquor in violation of the terms of such license. 
(Code 1977, § 5.12.020; Ord. No. 85-15, 1985) 
State Law reference- Municipal authority over retail selling of alcoholic beverages and access of minors to alcoholic beverage establishments, 235 ILCS 5/4-1. 
Sec. 4-76. - Separate license required for each location. 
    Licenses issued under this article apply only to the premises described in the application and in the license issued thereon, and only one location shall be so described in each license. After a license has been granted for a particular premises, the local liquor control commissioner, upon proper showing, may endorse upon said license permission to abandon the premises therein described and remove therefrom to other premises approved by him, but in order to obtain such approval the licensee shall file with state commission and local commissioner a request in writing and a statement under oath which shall show that the premises to which removal is to be made comply in all respects with the requirements of law and this chapter. The local liquor control commissioner may endorse such change upon the license of licensee, if in his discretion he deems such change proper. 
State Law reference- Similar provision, 235 ILCS 5/7-14. 
Sec. 4-77. - Application. 
    Applications for liquor licenses shall be made to the local liquor control commissioner by filing the same with him or his duly appointed agent. Applications shall be in writing, signed by the applicant if an individual, or by a duly authorized agent thereof if a club or corporation, verified by oath or affidavit, and shall contain the following information and statements: 
(1)  The name, age and address of the applicant in the case of an individual; in the case of a copartnership, the persons entitled to share in the profits thereof; and in the case of a corporation for profit, or a club, the date of incorporation, the objects for which it was organized, the names and addresses of the officers and directors and, if a majority in interest of the stock of such corporation is owned by one person or his nominees, the name and address of such person; 
(2)  The type of business of the applicant and, in case of a corporation, the objects for which it was formed; 
(3)  The length of time that the applicant has been in business of that character or, in the case of a corporation, the date on which its charter was issued; 
(4)  The amount of goods, wares and merchandise on hand at the time application is made; 
(5)  The location and description of the premises or place of business to be operated under such license; 
(6)  A statement whether the applicant has made similar application for a similar license on premises other than described in the application, and the disposition of such application; 
(7)  A statement that the applicant has never been convicted of a felony and is not disqualified to receive a license by reason of any matter or thing contained in this chapter, the laws of the state, or the ordinances of the city; 
(8)  Whether a previous license by any state or subdivision thereof, or by the federal government has been revoked, and the reasons therefor; 
(9)  A statement that the applicant will not violate any of the laws of the state, the United States, or any ordinance of the city in the conduct of his place of business. 
(Code 1977, § 5.12.030; Ord. No. 85-15, 1985) 
State Law reference- Application for state license, 235 ILCS 5/7-1. 
Sec. 4-78. - Bond. 
    Each applicant for a license shall present with the application a bond executed by the applicant and a duly licensed surety company, licensed under the laws of the state, in the sum provided in the city bond schedule, conditioned to comply with all ordinances and laws relative to the sale of alcoholic liquor. 
(Code 1977, § 5.12.040; Ord. No. 85-15, 1985) 
Sec. 4-79. - Qualifications for licensure. 
    No such license shall be issued to the following: 
(1)  A person who is not a resident of the 61270 zip code; 
(2)  A person who is not of good character and reputation in the community in which he resides; 
(3)  A person who has been convicted of a felony under state law; 
(4)  A person who has been convicted of being the keeper or in keeping a house of ill fame; 
(5)  A person who has been convicted of pandering or other crime or misdemeanor opposed to decency and morality; 
(6)  A person whose license issued under this chapter has been revoked for cause; 
(7)  A person who at the time of application for renewal of any license issued under this chapter would not be eligible for such license upon a first application; 
(8)  A copartnership, unless all of the members of the copartnership are qualified to obtain a license; 
(9)  A corporation, if any officer, manager, or director thereof, or any stockholder owning in the aggregate more than five percent of the stock of such corporation, would not be eligible to receive a license under this chapter for any reason other than citizenship and residence within the political subdivision; 
(10)  A person whose place of business is conducted by a manager or agent unless the manager or agent possesses the same qualifications required of the licensee; 
(11)  A person who has been convicted of a violation of any federal or state law concerning the manufacture, possession, or sale of alcoholic liquor or who has forfeited his bond to appear in court to answer charges for any such violation; 
(12)  A person who does not own the premises on which a license is sought, or does not have a lease thereon for the full period for which the license is to be issued, or a premises not on street level; 
(13)  Any law-enforcing public official, any mayor, alderman, or member of the city council; and no such official shall be interested in any way, either directly or indirectly, in the manufacture, sale or distribution of alcoholic liquor; 
(14)  Any person not eligible for a state retail dealer's license. 
(Code 1977, § 5.12.050; Ord. No. 85-15, 1985; Ord. No. 18-04, § 4, 4-9-2018) 
State Law reference- Authority of local liquor commissioner to examine application for local license, 235 ILCS 5/4-5; issuance of license to certain persons prohibited, 235 ILCS 5/6-2. 
Sec. 4-80. - Term; fees; proration. 
    Each such license shall terminate on April 30 next following its issuance. The fee for each class of license shall be as provided in the city fee schedule. With the exception of the initial license issuance, the fee to be paid shall be reduced in proportion to the full calendar months which have expired in the year prior to the issuance of the license. For the initial issuance of a license to an applicant under this chapter, such initial applicant shall pay, in addition to the annual license fee, an initial application fee as provided in the city fee schedule. Such initial application fee shall be non-refundable, and there shall be no proration of the initial application fee, regardless of the date upon which application for the license is first made. 
(Code 1977, § 5.12.060; Ord. No. 85-15, 1985; Ord. No. 16-16, § 1, 9-26-2016) 
Sec. 4-81. - Classifications. 
    Retail liquor dealers' licenses shall be and are divided into six general classes and six subclasses, set forth as follows: 
(1)  Class A. Class A shall be issued to liquor stores and shall entitle the licensee to sell alcoholic liquor in the original package only, and not for consumption on the premises. Class A-1 shall be issued to Class A licensees, and shall entitle the licensee to sell at retail any alcoholic liquor in the original package and not for consumption on the premises, between the hours of 12:00 noon and 10:00 p.m. Sunday. 
(2)  Class B. Class B shall be issued to food stores or other non-auto fuel businesses and shall entitle the licensee to sell at retail any alcoholic liquor in the original package and not for consumption on the premises. 
a.  Class B-1 shall be issued to food stores, auto fuels, or other retailing establishments entitling the licensee to sell at retail beer, ale, wine and distilled spirits only in the original package and not for consumption on the premises; provided that any container of distilled spirits containing one pint or less shall only be kept behind a service counter near the cash register and under the control of the clerk. No containers of distilled spirits containing one pint or less shall be stocked with merchandise readily available to customers. The annual fee for such license shall be as provided in the city fee schedule. 
b.  Class B-2 shall be issued to Class B and B-1 licensees and shall entitle the licensee the privilege of Sunday sales between the hours of 12:00 noon and 10:00 p.m. in accordance with the terms of the licensee's primary license. 
(3)  Class C. Class C shall be issued to taverns and shall entitle the licensee to sell at retail any alcoholic liquor in original package or by the drink for consumption on or off the premises where sold. Class C licensees shall be entitled to engage in Sunday sales between the hours of 12:00 noon and 10:00 p.m. 
(4)  Class D. Class D shall be issued to restaurants and shall entitle the licensee to sell at retail alcoholic liquor by the drink only: to be consumed on the premises where sold; and only in conjunction with the availability of food service. Under a Class D license Sunday sales shall be permitted between the hours of 12:00 noon and 10:00 p.m. Class D-1 shall be issued to restaurants and shall entitle the licensee to sell at retail beer, ale and wine only by the drink to be consumed on the premises, and only in conjunction with the availability of food service. Under Class D-1 Sunday sales shall be permitted from 12:00 noon to 10:00 p.m. 
(5)  Class E. Class E shall be issued to only a bona fide club as defined in this chapter, and shall entitle the licensee to sell at retail any alcoholic liquor in the original package or by the drink for consumption on the premises where sold. Sales of alcoholic liquor shall be limited to members and guests of members. Under Class E Sunday sales shall be permitted. 
(6)  Class F. Class F shall be issued to only established bowling alleys having not less than eight usable lanes, and shall entitle the licensee to sell at retail any alcoholic liquor by the drink for consumption on the premises. Class F-1 shall entitle the holder of a Class F license to Sunday sales between the hours of 12:00 noon and 10:00 p.m. 
(7)  Class G. Class G shall be issued to only established public golf courses having a physical structure containing facilities for preparation, storage and delivery of food and alcoholic beverages to the public, in conjunction with a minimum of nine separate golfing holes, containing a minimum of an overall average no less than 200 yards per hole, which golfing holes shall also contain separate tees and greens. Further, all golfing and clubhouse facilities must be within the corporate limits of the city. Such license shall allow such established public golf courses to sell at retail any alcoholic liquor by the drink for consumption with the golfing clubhouse facility and upon the golfing premises. 
a.  G-1 shall entitle the Class G license holder Sunday sales between the hours of noon and 10:00 p.m. 
b.  G-2 shall entitle the Class G license holder Sunday sales between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 12:00 noon. 
(Code 1977, § 5.12.070; Ord. No. 85-15, 1985; Ord. No. 86-11, 1986; Ord. No. 99-17, § 1, 1999; Ord. No. 09-12, § II, 9-28-2009; Ord. No. 13-21, §§ 1, 2, 7-8-2013) 
Sec. 4-82. - Fee payment. 
    All fees shall be paid to the city clerk at the time application is made. In the event the application is denied, the fee shall be returned to the applicant. If the license is granted, then the fee shall be deposited with the city treasurer in such fund as shall have been designated by the council. 
(Code 1977, § 5.12.080; Ord. No. 85-15, 1985) 
State Law reference- State license fee payable with application, 235 ILCS 5/7-2. 
Sec. 4-83. - Beverage tastings. 
    Class A and B licensees may conduct beverage tastings on the licensed premises one day each calendar month but no more frequently than once every four weeks. The licensee shall obtain a tasting license from the city clerk prior to the day on which the tasting occurs. Tastings shall be limited to beer, wine and cordials. The fee for beverage tasting events shall be as provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1977, § 5.12.070; Ord. No. 85-15, 1985; Ord. No. 86-11, 1986; Ord. No. 99-17, § 1, 1999) 
Sec. 4-84. - Special liquor licenses. 
    The mayor, acting as liquor commissioner, may issue a special liquor license. The fee for each special liquor license shall be as provided in the city fee schedule. The license is subject to: 
(1)  Purpose: A special event liquor license may be issued for a period of time not to exceed 14 days for the purpose of allowing a licensee to raise funds for charitable, educational or civic purposes. 
(2)  Eligibility; application generally: A special event license may be issued to not-for-profit corporations organized and operating under the laws of this state for charitable, educational or civic purposes. No license shall be issued unless the applicant can demonstrate that they have been incorporated for a period of not less than six months prior to making application for such license. Application shall be made to the mayor at least 45 days prior to the date of the intended sale or distribution of alcoholic beverages. 
a.  If the organization/group is partnering with a licensed restaurant/bar to host the event, the servers shall remain under the control of the restaurant/bar. 
b.  Special event license fee shall be $50.00 and will be listed as such in section 20-9 (fees) under this code. 
(Code 1977, § 5.12.205; Ord. No. 01-19, § 1, 2001; Ord. No. 18-04, § 5, 4-9-2018) 
Sec. 4-85. - Additional requirements for clubs. 
(a)  Clubs shall, at the time of its application for license under this chapter, submit two copies of a list of names and residences of its members. An amended list must be submitted to the liquor control commissioner within ten days of the election of any additional member. 
(b)  The management of the club must be conducted by a council of directors, executive committee or similar body chosen by the members at their annual meeting. 
(c)  No member or any officer, agent or employee of the club is shall, or directly or indirectly, receive compensation in the form of salary or other compensation or otherwise derive any profit from the distribution or sale of alcoholic liquor to the club or its members or guests, beyond the amount of such salary as may be fixed and voted at any annual meeting by the members of the council of directors or other governing body out of the general revenue of the club. 
(Code 1977, § 5.12.010(C); Ord. No. 90-7, § 1, 1990; Ord. No. 85-15, 1985) 
Sec. 4-86. - Recordkeeping. 
    The city clerk shall keep or cause to be kept a complete record of all such licenses issued, and shall furnish the treasurer and chief of police each with a copy thereof. Upon the issuance of a new license, or the revocation of any old license, the city clerk shall give written notice of such to each of these officers within 48 hours of such action. 
(Code 1977, § 5.12.090; Ord. No. 85-15, 1985) 
State Law reference- Requirement for maintenance of books and records, 235 ILCS 5/6-8; books and records available for investigation and control, 235 ILCS 5/6-10. 
Sec. 4-87. - Nontransferability. 
(a)  A license shall be a personal privilege, good for a period not to exceed one year after issuance unless sooner revoked as provided in this chapter, and shall not constitute property; nor shall it be subject to attachment, garnishment, or execution; nor shall it be alienable or transferable, voluntarily or involuntarily; or subject to being encumbered or hypothecated. 
(b)  A license issued under this chapter shall not descend by the laws of testate or intestate devolution, but it shall cease upon the death of the licensee, provided that executors or administrators of the estate of any deceased licensee, and the trustee of any insolvent or bankrupt licensee, when such estate consists in part of alcoholic liquor, may continue the business of the sale of alcoholic liquor under order of the appropriate court, and may exercise the privileges of the deceased or insolvent or bankrupt licensee after the death of such decedent, or such insolvency or bankruptcy, until the expiration of such license but not longer than six months after the death, bankruptcy or insolvency of such licensee. 
(c)  A refund shall be made of that portion of the license fees paid for any period in which the licensee shall be prevented from operating under such license in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1977, § 5.12.100; Ord. No. 85-15, 1985) 
Sec. 4-88. - Location change. 
    A retail liquor dealer's license shall permit the sale of alcoholic liquor only in the premises described in the application, changed only upon the written permit to make such change issued by the city council. No change of location shall be permitted unless the proposed new location is a proper one for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor under the laws of the state and the ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 5.12.110; Ord. No. 85-15, 1985) 
Sec. 4-89. - Penalty, revocation and suspension. 
(a)  The local liquor control commissioner may revoke or suspend any liquor license issued under this chapter and authorize any law enforcement officer to immediately and temporarily suspend any liquor license for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  Violation of the laws of the United States, the laws of this state, or any of the ordinances of the city where such violations relate to the operation of a licensed premises; 
(2)  Knowingly, permitting without protest, any violation of this chapter, any disorderly practices upon the premises or violations of any law or ordinance, whether upon the control premises or the service premises, where the licensee is licensed to operate under this chapter; for the purposes of this section "protest" shall mean a formal declaration, whether verbal or written, made by a person interested or concerned in some act or course of conduct about to be done, already performed or being presently done, whereby that person expresses his or her dissent or disapproval or affirms the act is against his or her own will; 
(3)  The willful making of any false statement as to a material fact in the application for the license; 
(4)  Failure to comply with the provisions of this chapter; 
(5)  Failure to obtain and keep current at all times at least the minimum amount of dram shop liability insurance requested by this chapter; 
(6)  Failure to comply with any rules and regulations promulgated by the commissioner or any law enforcement officer acting on his (or the city's) behalf; 
(7)  Failure to pay a fine imposed by the commissioner, any law enforcement officer, or costs imposed by this section within 30 days of notice of such costs or fine; 
(8)  Failure to answer under oath all relevant and material questions propounded to the licensee at a hearing conducted by the commissioner. 
(b)  In lieu of or in addition to the suspension or revocation of a license, the commissioner may impose a fine of not less than $75.00 and not more than $750.00 for each such violation. 
(c)  Notice of hearing; emergency closure. 
(1)  Except as provided herein, no such license shall be suspended or revoked or a fine imposed except after a public hearing by the commissioner is held. The licensee shall be given a three-day written notice affording the licensee an opportunity to appear and defend. 
(2)  If the commissioner has reason to believe that the continued operation of a particular licensed premises will immediately threaten the welfare of the community, the commissioner may, upon the issuance of a written order stating the reason for the conclusion and without notice or hearing, order the licensed premises closed for not more than seven days. A hearing shall be held within a seven-day period. Such period shall begin on the date of the closing. The hearing shall give the licensee the opportunity to be heard on the matter. If the licensee is engaged in the conduct of another business on the licensed premises other than the sale of alcoholic liquor, the closure order shall not be applicable to such business. 
(d)  Appeals to the state liquor control commission of decisions, orders or actions of the commissioner shall be provided for as follows: 
(1)  All appeals to the state liquor control commission by a city liquor licensee of a decision, order or action by the commissioner to suspend or revoke the licensee's city liquor license or of the imposition of a fine against such license shall be limited to review of the official record of the formal proceedings before the commissioner; 
(2)  Initial costs and hourly fees for the official reporter's attendance at formal hearings before the commissioner shall be borne and paid by the city. 
(e)  All costs of preparing and transcribing the official record on appeal to the state liquor control commission by the licensee shall be borne by the licensee whose license has been suspended or revoked, or against whom a fine has been imposed. 
(f)  Upon the decision of the commissioner adverse to a licensee being upheld or upon failure of a licensee to appeal within the appeal period, the licensee shall be responsible for the payment of all costs borne by the city in relation to bringing the hearing, including but not limited to initial court reporter cost and hourly fees, witness and mileage fees. 
(g)  When a license has been revoked for any cause, no license shall be granted to any person for the period of up to one year thereafter for the conduct of the business of selling alcoholic liquor at retail in the premises described in such revoked license. 
(Ord. No. 18-04, § 7, 4-9-2018) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 18-04, § 7, adopted April 9, 2018, amended § 4-89 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 4-89 pertained to revocation and suspension and derived from Code 1977, § 5.12.120; and Ord. No. 85-15, adopted in 1985. 
State Law reference- Suspension or revocation of state license, 235 ILCS 5/7-3; suspension or revocation of local license, 235 ILCS 5/7-5. 
Sec. 4-90. - Posting required. 
    Each person licensed under this chapter to sell intoxicating liquors shall immediately cause his license to be and remain posted in some conspicuous part of the room or bar kept and used for such purpose; and no person shall be allowed to sell intoxicating liquors under such license until the same has been posted. 
(Code 1977, § 5.12.130; Ord. No. 85-15, 1985) 
Sec. 4-91. - Limitation on the number of class C, D, and F licenses. 
(a)  Not more than four class C licenses shall be issued by the city; 
(b)  Not more than two class D licenses shall be issued by the city; 
(c)  Not more than one class F/F1 licenses shall be issued by the city. 
(Ord. No. 17-11, § 2, 10-10-2017) 
Secs. 4-92-4-108. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PREMISES REGULATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 4-109. - Location restrictions. 
    No license shall be issued for the sale at retail of any alcoholic liquor within 100 feet of any church, school or hospital; such measurement shall be made from the closest door of the dram shop to the closest door of such church, school or hospital. 
(Code 1977, § 5.12.170; Ord. No. 85-15, 1985) 
State Law reference- Restrictions on sales near churches, schools, and hospitals, 235 ILCS 5/6-11. 
Sec. 4-110. - Peddling prohibited. 
    It is unlawful to peddle alcoholic liquor in the city. 
(Code 1977, § 5.12.140; Ord. No. 85-15, 1985) 
Sec. 4-111. - Sanitary premises required. 
    All premises used for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor, or for the storage of such liquor for such sale, shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition, and shall be kept in full compliance with the ordinances regulating the condition of premises used for the storage or sale of food for human consumption. 
(Code 1977, § 5.12.150; Ord. No. 85-15, 1985) 
Sec. 4-112. - Interior view required; lighting. 
(a)  In premises upon which the sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises is licensed, other than as a hotel, restaurant or club, windows shall be so constructed and placed as to provide a clear view into the interior of such licensed premises from the street, road, or sidewalk at all times; and no screen, blind, curtain, partition, article or thing shall be permitted in the windows or upon the doors of such licensed premises, nor inside such premises, which prevent a clear view into the interior of such licensed premises from the street, road, or sidewalk at all times. 
(b)  No booth, screen, partition or other obstruction nor any arrangements of lighting shall be permitted in or about the interior of such licensed premises which prevent a full view of the interior of such premises and of the patrons therein, from the street, road or sidewalk. 
(c)  All rooms where liquor is sold for consumption upon the premises shall be continuously lighted during business hours by natural light or artificial white light so that all parts of the interior of the premises shall be clearly visible. In case the view into any such licensed premises as herein required is willfully obscured by the licensee or by him willfully suffered to be obscured or in any manner obstructed, then such license shall be subject to revocation in the manner provided in this section. 
(d)  No license shall be granted for the sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption upon any premises which does not meet requirements of this section. 
(Code 1977, § 5.12.200; Ord. No. 85-15, 1985) 
Sec. 4-113. - Certain conduct prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person licensed to conduct a dram shop under the provisions of this chapter to permit any riotous or disorderly conduct, any loud or tumultuous talking, loud singing, drunkenness, gambling other than as permitted under a state gaming license, fighting, or unlawful game or games in the building or premises where such dram shop is conducted. 
(Code 1977, § 5.12.230; Ord. No. 85-15, 1985; Ord. No. 18-04, § 6, 4-9-2018) 
Secs. 4-114-4-139. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - HOURS OF OPERATION 

Sec. 4-140. - Time period regulated. 
(a)  It is unlawful for class C, D, F and F1 to sell or offer for sale at retail any alcoholic liquor in the city between the hours of 1:45 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. of any day; between the hours of 1:45 a.m. and 12:00 noon on Sunday, or between 9:45 p.m. Sunday and 6:00 a.m. the following Monday, except that holders of a class E license may sell alcoholic liquor as provided in section 4-81. No person shall consume any alcoholic liquor on a licensee's premises during the hours which the sale thereof is prohibited. 
(b)  No licensee holding a class C, D, F and/or F1 under this chapter, or his/her agent or employee, shall sell, offer or deliver any alcoholic beverage after 1:45 a.m. on any day of any week other than Sundays which shall be 9:45 p.m. No person shall consume nor a licensee, employee or agent of a licensee permit the consumption of alcoholic beverages after 2:00 a.m. on any day of the week other than Sundays which shall be 10:00 p.m. 
(c)  No person other than a licensee or an employee or agent of a licensee shall remain upon any licensed premises after 2:00 a.m. on any day of any week other than Sundays which shall be 10:00 p.m. 
(d)  No person, including a licensee shall remain upon any licensed premises after 3:00 a.m. on any day of any week other than Sundays which shall be 11:00 p.m. All bars and tables upon the licensed premises shall be cleared and the glasses removed not later than such times. 
(e)  Licensees holding a class D (restaurant), class F (bowling alley) or class G (golf course) license may remain open after the time designated in subsections a-d of this section, but only for the sale of food or food and beverage other than alcoholic liquor, for the purposes of bowling, golfing or food consumption. During any such time, the area of the bar or other area of primary dispensing operation shall be secure from any sale or dispensing or consumption of alcoholic liquor. 
(f)  Exception. Licensees and their agents, employees or independent contractors hired by the licensee to render services to the licensee, not otherwise authorized by exceptions set forth in this code, may be upon the licensed premises for the purpose of other than routine cleaning, redecorating or repairing the licensed premises during prohibited hours. At no time while licensees or their agents, employees or independent contractors employed by the licensees are upon the premises for the purpose of other than routine cleaning, redecorating or repairing shall the licensee, employee, agent or independent contractor consume, sell, deliver, transfer, distribute or give away any alcoholic beverage on the licensed premises. Further, during the prohibited hours, all doors and entrances to the licensed premises shall be continuously locked except to permit ingress and egress to the licensed premises by the authorized person(s). Further the licensee is required to notify the Morrison Police Department prior to the initiation of other than routine cleaning, redecorating or repairing the licensed premises during prohibited hours, that the licensees, their agents, employees or independent contractors hired by the licensee shall be upon the licensed premises for the purpose of other than routine cleaning, redecorating or repairing the licensed premises during prohibited hours, setting forth specifically the time and date for the cleaning, redecorating or repairing the licensed premises. 
(Code 1977, § 5.12.190; Ord. No. 85-15, 1985; Ord. No. 18-04, § 8, 4-9-2018; Ord. No. 18-11, § 1, 5-14-2018) 
Sec. 4-141. - Other exceptions. 
(a)  New Year's Eve. On the evening of December 31 of one year to January 1 of the following year, commonly referred to as New Year's Eve, license holders of classifications C, D, D-1, E, F, F-1, G, G-1 and G-2 may sell alcoholic beverages on the licensed premises from 6:00 a.m. of December 31 of one year until 1:45 a.m. of January 1 of the following year. No person other than a licensee or an employee or agent of a licensee shall remain upon any licensed premises after 2:00 a.m. on January 1. Further, no person, including a licensee shall remain upon any licensed premises after 3:00 a.m. on January 1. All bars and tables upon the licensed premises shall be cleared and the glasses removed not later than such times. 
(b)  Super Bowl Sunday. On the Sunday commonly known and designated as such by the National Football League as Super Bowl Sunday, license holders of classifications C, D, D-1, E, F, F-1, G, G-1 and G-2 may sell alcoholic beverages on the licensed premises from 10:00 a.m. on Super Bowl Sunday until 1:45 a.m. of the day immediately following. No person other than a licensee or an employee or agent of a licensee shall remain upon any licensed premises after 2:00 a.m. on the day immediately following. Further, no person, including a licensee shall remain upon any licensed premises after 3:00 a.m. on the day immediately following. All bars and tables upon the licensed premises shall be cleared and the glasses removed not later than such times. 
(Ord. No. 18-04, § 9, 4-9-2018) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 18-04, § 9, adopted April 9, 2018, amended § 4-141 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 4-141 pertained to exceptions and derived from Code 1977, § 5.12.195; and Ord. No. 00-34, § 1, adopted in 2000. 
Sec. 4-142. - Penalty. 
(a)  The commissioner and/or any law enforcement officer may impose a fine of up to $250.00 for each such violation of section 4-140, hours of operation. The licensee and their agents and employees, found and determined to be individually and actively violating this division may be subject to this penalty. 
(Ord. No. 18-04, § 10, 4-9-2018) 
Secs. 4-143-4-165. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - EMPLOYEE REGULATIONS 

Sec. 4-166. - Employee disease prohibited. 
    It is unlawful to employ in any premises used for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor any person who is afflicted with or who is a carrier of any contagious, infectious or venereal disease. It is unlawful for any person who is afflicted with or a carrier of any such disease to work in or about any premises or to engage in any way in the handling, preparation or distribution of such liquor. 
(Code 1977, § 5.12.160; Ord. No. 85-15, 1985) 
Sec. 4-167. - Age requirements. 
(a)  It shall be illegal for any liquor licensee or for any officer, associate, member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee to employ in any premises used for the sale of alcoholic beverages any person under 21 years of age for the purpose of drawing, pouring or mixing alcoholic beverages or tending bar or to sell or consummate the sale of any such beverages to be consumed off the licensed premises, such as, but not limited to, such sales at a packaged liquor store or a grocery store. It shall be illegal for any person under 21 years of age to be so employed as specified in this subsection. 
(b)  It is lawful for a liquor licensee or for any officer, associate, member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee to employ a person 18 years of age or older to deliver, serve and/or consummate the sale of alcoholic beverages which are to be consumed on the premises, provided that at all times when the employee under 21 years of age is on the premises, another employee 21 years of age or older is working on duty on the premises; the person charged with an offense hereunder shall have the burden of proving that the employee 21 years of age or older was so employed and was working on duty on the premises at the time of any alleged violation. 
(Code 1977, § 5.12.165; Ord. No. 06-02, § 1, 2006) 
Secs. 4-168-4-187. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SALE, SERVING AND CONSUMPTION RESTRICTIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 4-188. - Restrictions upon intoxicated persons. 
    No licensee permitted to sell any alcoholic liquor by the drink for consumption on the premises under any existing or future ordinance of the city shall allow or permit any intoxicated person to frequent or loiter in the place of business occupied by such licensee under such license; nor shall any licensee allow any disorderly conduct in or upon such premises; nor shall such licensee sell or give any intoxicating liquor to an intoxicated person; nor shall such licensee permit any intoxicated person to consume any intoxicating liquor upon such premises. 
(Code 1977, § 5.12.210; Ord. No. 85-15, 1985) 
Sec. 4-189. - Unlawful sale designated; prosecution. 
    The giving away of intoxicating liquors, or other shift or device to evade the provisions of this chapter, shall be held to be an unlawful selling, and any shift or device to evade any of the provisions of this chapter shall be held to be a violation of the same; and in all prosecutions under the provisions of this chapter it shall not be necessary to state the kind of liquor sold or to describe the place where sold, nor to show knowledge of the principal, to convict for the acts of the agent or servant. 
(Code 1977, § 5.12.260; Ord. No. 85-15, 1985) 
Sec. 4-190. - Restricted habitual drinkers. 
    Whenever the spouse or any other relative of any person habitually addicted to the use of intoxicating drink, by notice in writing personally served, shall make a request to any person licensed to deal in malt, vinous, spirituous or intoxicating liquor of any kind, not to sell or in any manner give away such liquor to such person, it shall thereafter be unlawful for such dealer to sell or give away any such liquor to such person. 
(Code 1977, § 5.12.280; Ord. No. 85-15, 1985) 
Sec. 4-191. - Public intoxication prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to be found in any street, avenue, alley, or other public place, or place open to the public view within the city, in an intoxicated condition; and it is unlawful for any intoxicated person to annoy or disturb the peace of his own or another family or of any person, in any building or place within the city. 
(Code 1977, § 5.12.240; Ord. No. 85-15, 1985) 
Sec. 4-192. - Procurement for certain persons prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person, within the limits of the city, to buy for, furnish to, or in any other manner procure any intoxicating liquor for any person who is in the habit of becoming intoxicated or is intoxicated at the time, or for any minor. 
(Code 1977, § 5.12.250; Ord. No. 85-15, 1985) 
Sec. 4-193. - Consumption and possession in streets, churches and schools prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to drink or otherwise consume any intoxicating liquor, beer or wine upon any sidewalk, street, alley, school property or other place within the limits of the city. Violation of this section shall be a fine of no less than $250.00. The provisions of this section shall not apply to any location for which a license under section 4-84 has been issued. 
(Code 1977, § 5.12.270; Ord. No. 85-15, 1985; Ord. No. 11-11, § 1, 8-8-2011) 
Sec. 4-194. - Possession in streets, public places and schools prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to possess, carry, give away, sell or otherwise deliver any intoxicating liquor, beer or wine, except in the original package and with the seal unbroken or otherwise in compliance with section 4-196, upon any sidewalk, street, alley, school property, or other public place within the limits of the city. Violation of this section shall be a fine of no less than $250.00. The provisions of this section shall not apply to any location for which a license under section 4-84 has been issued. 
(Ord. No. 11-11, § 2, 8-8-2011; Ord. No. 17-18, § 3, 12-11-2017) 
Sec. 4-195. - Growlers. 
    The sale of growlers in compliance with this section is authorized for all licensed establishments who are or may become authorized under their state license to sell and dispense the same. The term "growler" means a bottle that is designed for and especially intended to be filled by a licensee or employee of the licensed establishment with beer from a keg. Growlers may be filled only from kegs procured by the licensee from a duly licensed wholesaler or, in the case of a brewpub, from its own production. Only professionally sanitized and sealed growlers may be filled and made available for retail sale. Each growler must be securely sealed and removed from the premises in its original sealed condition. Consumption on the premises is strictly prohibited. The filling of growlers by means of a tapped keg shall not constitute the breaking of a seal and shall not be deemed to violate Section 11-502 of the Illinois Vehicle Code. 
(Ord. No. 17-18, § 2, 12-11-2017) 
Sec. 4-196. - Bottles of wine. 
    Any restaurant which is licensed to sell alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises may permit a patron to remove one unsealed bottle of wine per patron for consumption off the premises if the patron has purchased a meal and consumed a portion of the bottle of wine on the premises with such meal. A partially consumed bottle of wine that is to be removed from the premises must be securely resealed by the licensee or its employees before removal from the premises. The partially consumed bottle of wine shall be placed in a bag or other container that is secured in such a manner that it is visibly apparent if the container has been subsequently opened or tampered with, and a dated receipt for the bottle of wine and meal shall be provided by the licensee and attached to the container. If transported in a motor vehicle, the container with the resealed bottle of wine shall be placed in a locked glove compartment, a locked trunk, or the area behind the last upright seat of a motor vehicle that is not equipped with a trunk. Wine that is resealed in accordance with the provisions of this section and not tampered with and transported in accordance with the restrictions of subsections (a) and (b) of Section 11-502 of the Illinois Vehicle Code shall not be deemed to violate Section 11-502 of the Illinois Vehicle Code. A bottle of wine may be brought into a restaurant holding a liquor license, to be uncorked by wait staff, for a corking fee determined by the restaurant. After uncorking, the wine cannot be shared outside the immediate party, given away or sold to others, or held by the restaurant until the next visit of that party. 
(Ord. No. 17-18, § 4, 12-11-2017) 
Secs. 4-197-4-224. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MINORS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority over retail selling of alcoholic beverages and access of minors to alcoholic beverage establishments, 235 ILCS 5/4-1. 

Sec. 4-225. - Minors prohibited from receiving alcoholic liquor. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any minor person to request, ask for, purchase, receive accept any alcoholic liquor or beverage of any kind, either directly or indirectly, as a gratuity or for a consideration in, on or from any premises licensed for the sale of alcoholic liquor within the city. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any minor person to possess or consume any alcoholic liquor or beverage of any kind within the city. Any person found in violation of this section shall be subject to a fine of up to $250.00. 
(Code 1977, § 5.12.220; Ord. No. 85-15, 1985; Ord. No. 18-04, § 11, 4-9-2018) 
State Law reference- Prohibited sales and possession, 235 ILCS 5/6-16. 
Sec. 4-226. - Minors prohibited from entering licensed premises. 
(a)  It is unlawful and prohibited for any person under the age of 21 years from entering the premises of an establishment whose sales are principally derived from the sale of alcoholic beverages. 
(b)  Principal sales of alcoholic beverages for the purpose of this enactment are defined as being 51 percent of the gross proceeds of said subject licensed establishment being derived from the sale of alcoholic beverages. 
(Code 1977, § 5.12.225; Ord. No. 99-05, § 1, 1999) 
State Law reference- Prohibited entry to a licensed premises, 235 ILCS 5/6-16.2; prohibited sales and possession, 235 ILCS 5/6-16; municipal authority over retail selling of alcoholic beverages and access of minors to alcoholic beverage establishments, 235 ILCS 5/4-1. 
Sec. 4-227. - Persons misrepresenting age. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 21 years to misrepresent his age for the purpose of purchasing or obtaining alcoholic liquor in any tavern, or other place in the city where alcoholic liquor is sold. 
State Law reference- Similar provision, 235 ILCS 5/6-16. 
Sec. 4-228. - Warning displayed. 
    In every tavern or other place in the city where alcoholic liquor is sold there shall be displayed at all times in a prominent place a printed card which shall be supplied by the clerk and which shall read substantially as follows: 
"Warning to persons under the age of 21 years: You are subject to a fine of up to $750.00 under the ordinances of the City of Morrison if you purchase alcoholic liquor or misrepresent your age for the purpose of purchasing or obtaining alcoholic liquor." 
Chapter 6 - AMUSEMENTS AND ENTERTAINMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority for municipal regulation of sellers of tickets for theatricals, shows, amusements, athletic events and other exhibitions, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-1; authority for municipal regulation of theatricals and other exhibitions, shows, and amusements and may license, tax, and regulate all places for eating or amusement, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-5; authority for municipal regulation of all amusements and activities having a tendency to annoy or endanger persons or property on the sidewalks, streets, and other municipal property, 65 ILCS 5/11-80-9; carnival and amusement ride safety regulations, 430 ILCS 85/2-1 et seq.; adult entertainment advertising, 65 ILCS 5/11-80-15; municipal powers as to billiard tables, etc., 65 ILCS 5/11-42-2; certain minors working in poolrooms or billiard rooms, 820 ILCS 205/7; Raffles Act, 230 ILCS 15/0.01 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 6-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Mechanical amusement device means a coin-in-the-slot operated mechanical device played for amusement which rewards the player with the right to replay such mechanical device, which device is so constructed or devised as to make such result of the operation thereof depend in part upon the skill of the player and which returns to the player thereof no money, property or right to receive money or property. 
    Raffle means a form of lottery, as defined in 720 ILCS 5/28-2 conducted by an organization licensed under this chapter in which: 
(1)  The player pays or agrees to pay something of value for a chance represented and differentiated by a number or by a combination of numbers or by some other means, one or more of which chances is to be designated the winning chance; and 
(2)  The winning chance is to be determined through a drawing or by some other method based on an element of chance by an act or set of acts on the part of persons conducting or connected with the lottery, except that the winning chance shall not be determined by the outcome of a publicly exhibited sporting contest. 
    Religious organization means any church, congregation, society, or organization founded for the purpose of religious worship. 
    Veterans organization means an organization or association comprised of members of which substantially all are individuals who are veterans or spouses, widows or widowers of veterans, the primary purpose of which is to promote the welfare of its members and to provide assistance to the general public in such a way as to confer a public benefit. 
(Code 1977, § 5.44.040; Ord. No. 87-11, 1987) 
State Law reference- Definition of "raffle" and "net proceeds," 230 ILCS 15/1; gambling device defined, 720 ILCS 5/28-2. 
Sec. 6-2. - Classifications. 
    All theatricals, shows, and amusements offered, operated, presented, or exhibited for gain, or for admission to which the public is required to pay a fee, are divided into the following 12 classes. Such theatricals, shows, and amusements are, for the purpose of this chapter, referred to by the general term "entertainments," and the theater, opera house, auditorium, hall, park, ground, tent, or other enclosure within which it is intended to produce, offer, or present any such entertainment is, for the purpose of this chapter, referred to by the general term "place." 
(1)  First class. All entertainments of a theatrical, dramatic, operatic, minstrel, and vaudeville nature; and all lectures, readings, recitations, and concerts; and all entertainments of a similar kind or class, held in theater buildings, opera houses, auditoriums, armories, halls or other buildings in the city; 
(2)  Second class. All entertainments consisting of moving pictures, vaudeville, and music, exhibited or held in a permanent place or building; 
(3)  Third class. All roller skating rinks; 
(4)  Fourth class. All wrestling matches; 
(5)  Fifth class. All circuses, menageries or combined circuses and menageries, wild west shows, dog and pony shows, monkey shows, and caravans; 
(6)  Sixth class. All side shows, concerts, vaudeville, variety, musical or minstrel entertainment, dramatic or moving picture shows, given under covering of canvas or within any structure or enclosure intended for temporary use and capable of easy transfer or removal; 
(7)  Seventh class. All entertainments consisting of games of skill and strength, testing devices, including lifting, blowing, striking and pulling machines, knife boards and cane racks, doll racks, ball throwing games, and other games of a similar nature; 
(8)  Eighth class. All shooting galleries; 
(9)  Ninth class. All merry-go-rounds; 
(10)  Tenth class. Exhibitions of natural or artificial curiosities or museums; 
(11)  11th class. All bowling alleys; 
(12)  12th class. All carnivals, as the same are commonly known; 
(13)  13th class. All entertainments, exhibitions, performances, or amusements not included in the foregoing classes. 
(Prior Code, § 145; Code 1977, § 5.08.010) 
Secs. 6-3-6-43. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ENTERTAINMENT LICENSING 

Sec. 6-44. - License required. 
    No person or corporation, either as owner, lessee, manager, officer, or agent, shall give, conduct, produce, present, or offer for gain or profit any of the entertainments enumerated in this chapter without a license issued for that purpose, which license shall be issued in the manner set forth in this chapter. 
(Prior Code, § 146; Code 1977, § 5.08.020) 
State Law reference- Authority for municipal regulation of sellers of tickets for theatricals, shows, amusements, athletic events and other exhibitions, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-1; authority for municipal regulation of theatricals and other exhibitions, shows, and amusements and may license, tax, and regulate all places for eating or amusement, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-5. 
Sec. 6-45. - Application; fees. 
(a)  Any person or corporation desiring a license under this chapter shall make application to the city clerk. The city clerk shall require such application to be made in writing, showing the name and address of the applicant, the description of the place where it is proposed to produce, present, conduct, operate, or offer such entertainment, and a description of the class and kind of entertainment. 
(b)  The clerk shall provide the license application to the city council for consideration. 
(c)  If the council approves the application, it shall direct the city clerk to issue a license to the applicant which shall entitle the licensee to conduct, produce, present, operate, or offer the class of entertainment specified in the license, at the place designated in the application or by the applicant, and for the period of time specified in the license, upon the payment of the license fee and the clerk's permit issuance fee as provided in the city fee schedule. 
(d)  License fees submitted with applications shall be nonrefundable, even in the event of denial of the application. 
(Prior Code, § 147; Code 1977, § 5.08.030) 
Sec. 6-46. - Fees prorated and nonrefundable; license not transferrable. 
    The license fee for any license issued under this chapter after November 1 of any year shall one-half the annual rate. No license fee paid under the provisions of this chapter shall be rebated or returned to the applicant; and the licenses granted under this chapter shall not be transferable. 
(Prior Code, § 150; Code 1977, § 5.08.060) 
Sec. 6-47. - Term of license. 
    Any license issued under this chapter shall expire on the April 30 next after its issuance, or at such sooner time as may be provided by the city council upon issuance of the license, and no such license shall be transferable. 
Sec. 6-48. - Certain entertainment exempted. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to entertainments the total proceeds of which are to be devoted to benevolent or charitable purposes, or to local societies or organizations maintained for the benefit of the public, or to the amusements and entertainments given during the week of the Morrison Fair on its fair grounds in the city, or to baseball games, football games, or public school entertainments and games. 
(Prior Code, § 152; Code 1977, § 5.08.080) 
Sec. 6-49. - Compliance required. 
    Every license granted under the provisions of this chapter shall at all times be subject to the ordinances of the city existing when the same is issued, or which is thereafter passed, so far as the same shall apply. 
(Prior Code, § 151; Code 1977, § 5.08.070) 
Secs. 6-50-6-71. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MECHANICAL AMUSEMENT DEVICES 

Sec. 6-72. - License required. 
    No person shall keep or permit to be kept a coin-operated amusement device or automatic musical instrument without first having applied for and received a license for each such machine. Licenses shall be applied for and issued as provided in article II of this chapter. License fees shall be as provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Prior Code, § 154; Code 1977, § 5.24.020; Ord. No. 82-2, § 3, 1982) 
State Law reference- Coin-Operated Amusement Device and Redemption Machine Tax Act, 35 ILCS 510/1 et seq. 
Sec. 6-73. - Gambling prohibited. 
    Except as permitted by section 6-74, nothing in this article shall be construed to authorize any gambling device of any kind or nature whatsoever. 
(Prior Code, § 157; Code 1977, § 5.24.050; Ord. No. 12-28, § 2, 8-27-2012) 
Sec. 6-74. - Video gaming. 
(a)  No licensee or his agents or employees shall permit any person upon the licensed premises to play any games or participate in any activities for money or other article of value or permit any person to bring on the premises any wheel, machine, video gaming terminal, board, dice, slot machine, punchboard, or other machine or device used for gambling, except video gaming terminals licensed under the Illinois Video Gaming Act. 
(b)  No licensee or his agents or employees shall allow in or about the licensed premises the sale or purchase wherein any part of the article or thing received or to be received, either as to quantity or value, shall in any manner depend upon any chance or hazard, whether by means of checks, cards, envelopes, dice, punchboard or by any means whatever, except at those premises where the licensee obtains (i) applicable state license or permit to conduct or allow others to conduct the game commonly known as "BINGO," or (ii) is a licensed establishment permitting it to do so under the Illinois Video Gaming Act. 
(c)  Every clock, machine, slot machine, video gaming terminal, punchboard or other machine or device for the reception of money or chance or upon the action of which money is staked, hazarded, bet, won or lost is hereby declared a gambling device and the same shall be seized, confiscated and destroyed by the police of the city wherever found upon the licensed premises or place controlled by the licensee, except video gaming terminals licensed and registered under the Illinois Video Gaming Act. 
(d)  Any individual, partnership or corporation intending to place a video gaming terminal in its establishment shall first file an application for a video gaming licensed establishment permit, which application shall include the following information: 
(1)  The location for which the license is sought; 
(2)  A copy of the written, signed lease or rental arrangement or other written authority for use of the equipment at the location; 
(3)  The number of video gaming terminals to be on the location for which a permit is requested; and 
(4)  Each application shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable fee of $100.00. The application fee shall be payable to the city by certified check or money order. 
(e)  All permits issued hereunder shall be issued by the mayor and attested by the city clerk and no permit shall issue until the application therefore shall have been approved by the mayor. 
(f)  An annual fee of $25.00 for each video gaming terminal shall be paid in advance on or before May 1 of each year. Each permit shall expire on the last day of April of each year. There shall be no proration of license fees. 
(g)  Each licensee shall comply with all requirements of the Illinois Video Gaming Act, as amended from time to time. 
(h)  Under no circumstances shall any person under the age of 21 years be permitted to use or play a video gaming terminal. Any licensee who (i) knowingly permits a person under the age of 21 years to use or play a video gaming terminal or (ii) fails to fully comply with the provisions of the Illinois Video Gaming Act or this section, shall have all permits of the licensee suspended, terminated or revoked. All hearings to determine whether said permit shall be suspended, terminated or revoked shall be conducted by the mayor. All appeals from any decision of the mayor shall be limited to a review of the official record of the proceedings of the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 12-28, § 3, 8-27-2012) 
Secs. 6-75-6-104. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - POOL HALLS 

Sec. 6-105. - License required. 
    No person shall, within the limits of the city, keep any billiard, bagatelle, pool, or pigeonhole tables to be used or patronized by others for hire, or with a view to gain or profit, without first having first obtained a license as provided in article II of this chapter. The license fee shall be as provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Prior Code, § 187; Code 1977, § 5.28.010) 
State Law reference- Municipal powers as to billiard tables, etc., 65 ILCS 5/11-42-2; certain minors working in poolrooms or billiard rooms, 820 ILCS 205/7. 
Sec. 6-106. - Hour restrictions. 
    All places or rooms in which any person licensed under this chapter conducts or carries on his business shall be closed and kept closed on Sundays, and on all other days of the week from 11:30 p.m. until 8:00 a.m. of the following day; and during all the time such places or rooms are so required to be kept closed all persons shall be expelled and excluded therefrom. 
(Prior Code, § 189; Code 1977, § 5.28.030) 
Sec. 6-107. - Minors restricted. 
    No minor shall frequent or loiter about the place of business of any licensee under this chapter, nor play at any game in any such place without having the permission of his parent or guardian so to do; nor shall any such licensee suffer or permit any minor to play at any game in his place of business, unless expressly requested so to do by the parent or guardian of such minor. 
(Prior Code, § 190; Code 1977, § 5.28.040) 
Sec. 6-108. - Gambling and intoxicating liquor prohibited. 
    No person licensed under the provisions of this chapter shall allow any betting, gambling, or disorderly conduct in the place of business of said licensee, or keep or sell or handle for sale any intoxicating liquors in or about said place of business, or allow any direct or indoor means of communication between said place of business and any place where intoxicating liquors may be sold. 
(Prior Code, § 191; Code 1977, § 5.28.050) 
Secs. 6-109-6-129. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - STREET FAIRS AND CARNIVALS 

Sec. 6-130. - License required. 
    No person shall exhibit any street carnival, street fair, exhibition, or show of a similar nature upon any of the streets, avenues, or public places of the city without first having obtained a license as provided in article II of this chapter. License fees for licenses issued under this article shall be in the amount provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Prior Code, § 658; Code 1977, § 5.36.010) 
State Law reference- Authority for municipal regulation of sellers of tickets for theatricals, shows, amusements, athletic events and other exhibitions, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-1; authority for municipal regulation of theatricals and other exhibitions, shows, and amusements and may license, tax, and regulate all places for eating or amusement, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-5; carnival and amusement ride safety regulations, 430 ILCS 85/2-1 et seq. 
Sec. 6-131. - Bond. 
    Before any license shall be issued to any applicant to exhibit any street carnival, street fair, exhibition, or show of a similar nature, the city council may require the applicant to file a bond with the city clerk, running to the city in the penal sum provided in the city bond schedule, or such other amount as may be specified by the city council as a condition of issuance of the license, with two sureties, freeholders of the city, or one duly licensed surety company, to be approved by the city clerk, conditioned that the person to whom such license is issued will save, defend, and keep harmless said city from all claims, actions, suits, costs, damages, and expenses whatsoever, including attorney's fees, which shall or may happen to come to it for or on account of any injuries or damages received or sustained by the city or by any person caused by any negligence, carelessness, or default of the person so licensed, or its or their agents or employees, and also any damages that might be lawfully recovered from the city on account of permitting its streets to be used for the purpose of the exhibition, and for the faithful observance of all the ordinances of the city. 
(Prior Code, § 660; Code 1977, § 5.36.030) 
Secs. 6-132-6-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - RAFFLES 

Sec. 6-161. - License requirements. 
    It is unlawful to conduct or operate a raffle or to sell, offer for sale, convey, issue or otherwise transfer for value a chance on a raffle without first obtaining a license as provided in article II of this chapter. The fee for raffle licenses shall be as provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1977, § 5.44.050; Ord. No. 87-11, 1987) 
State Law reference- Raffles Act, 230 ILCS 15/0.01 et seq.; authority for municipal licensing of raffles, 230 ILCS 5/2. 
Sec. 6-162. - Application. 
    In addition to other information required in the license application form, any person seeking to conduct or operate a raffle shall provide the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and type of organization; 
(2)  The length of existence of the organization and, if incorporated, the date and state of incorporation; 
(3)  The name, address, telephone number, social security number and date of birth of the organization's presiding officer, secretary, raffles manager and any other members responsible for the conduct and operation of the raffle; 
(4)  The aggregate retail value of all prizes to be awarded in the raffle; 
(5)  The maximum retail value of each prize to be awarded in the raffle; 
(6)  The maximum price charged for each raffle chance issued or sold; 
(7)  The maximum number of raffle chances to be issued; 
(8)  The area or areas in which raffle chances will be sold or issued; 
(9)  The time period during which raffle chances will be issued or sold; 
(10)  The date, time and location at which winning chances will be determined; 
(11)  A sworn statement attesting to the not-for-profit character of the applicant organization, signed by its presiding officer and secretary; 
(12)  A certificate signed by the presiding officer of the applicant organization attesting to the fact that the information contained in the application is true and correct; and 
(13)  A fidelity bond in the name of the raffle manager in an amount required in this article. 
(Code 1977, § 5.44.060; Ord. No. 87-11, 1987) 
State Law reference- Requirements for municipal raffle licensing systems, 230 ILCS 5/2. 
Sec. 6-163. - Licensee qualifications. 
    Raffle licenses shall be issued only to bona fide charitable, educational, fraternal, labor, religious and veterans organizations that operate without profit to their members and which have been in existence continuously for a period of five years or more immediately before making application for a license and which have had during the entire five-year period a bona fide membership engaged in carrying out their objects. The following are ineligible for any raffle license: 
(1)  Any person who has been convicted of a felony; 
(2)  Any person who is or has been a professional gambler or gambling promoter; 
(3)  Any person who is not of good moral character; 
(4)  Any organization in which a person defined in subsection (1), (2), or (3) of this section has a proprietary, equitable or credit interest, or in which such person is active or employed; 
(5)  Any organization in which a person defined in subsection (1), (2), or (3) of this section is an officer, director or employee, whether compensated or not; and 
(6)  Any organization in which a person defined in subsection (1), (2), or (3) of this section is to participate in the management or operation of a raffle as defined in this chapter. 
(Code 1977, § 5.44.070; Ord. No. 87-11, 1987) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 230 ILCS 15/2. 
Sec. 6-164. - License issuance. 
(a)  The city clerk shall review all raffle license applications for completeness, and shall submit completed applications to the city council or its designees within ten days from the date of application. The city council or its designees shall, within 30 days from the date of application, accept or reject a raffle license application. If an application is accepted, the city clerk shall forthwith issue a raffle license to the applicant. A raffle license shall be valid for a period of 90 days from and after its issuance unless the city board or its designees have specifically authorized a license for a longer period of time. The city council hereby designates the mayor to approve license applications made under this article. 
(b)  A raffle license shall show the following: 
(1)  The area in which raffle chances may be sold or issued; 
(2)  The period of time during which raffle chances may be sold or issued; and 
(3)  The date, time and location on or at which winning chances will be determined. 
Such license shall be prominently displayed at the time and location of the determination of the winning chances. 
(c)  A license shall be valid for one raffle only; however, multiple licenses may be issued to a licensee for multiple raffles. 
(Code 1977, § 5.44.080; Ord. No. 87-11, 1987) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 230 ILCS 15/3. 
Sec. 6-165. - Conduct of raffles. 
    The operation and conduct of raffles are subject to the following restrictions: 
(1)  The entire net proceeds of any raffle must be exclusively devoted to the lawful purpose of the licensee; 
(2)  No person except a bona fide member of the licensee may participate in the management or operation of the raffle; 
(3)  No person may receive remuneration or profit for participating in the management or operation of the raffle; 
(4)  A licensee may rent a premises on which to determine the winning chance or chances in a raffle only from an organization which is also licensed under this chapter; 
(5)  Raffle chances may be sold, offered for sale, conveyed, issued or otherwise transferred for value only within the area specified on the license; and the winning chances may be determined only at location specified on the license; 
(6)  No person under the age of 18 years may participate in the operation or conduct of raffles. A person under the age of 18 years may be within the area where winning chances are being determined only when accompanied by his parent or guardian. 
(Code 1977, § 5.44.090; Ord. No. 87-11, 1987) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 230 ILCS 15/4. 
Sec. 6-166. - Raffles manager. 
    The operation and conduct of a raffle shall be under the supervision of a single raffles manager designated by the licensee. The manager shall give fidelity bond equal in amount to the aggregate retail value of all prizes to be awarded in favor of the organization conditioned upon his honesty in the performance of his duties. The terms of the bond shall provide that notice shall be given in writing to the city not less than 30 days prior to its cancellation. 
(Code 1977, § 5.44.100; Ord. No. 87-11, 1987) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 230 ILCS 15/5. 
Sec. 6-167. - Records. 
(a)  Each licensee shall keep records of its gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds for each single gathering or occasion at which winning chances are determined. All deductions from gross receipts for each single gathering or occasion shall be documented with receipts or other records indicating the amount, a description of the purchased item or service or other reason for the deduction, and the recipient. The distribution of net proceeds shall be itemized as the payee, purpose, amount and date of payment. 
(b)  Gross receipts from the operation of raffles shall be segregated from other revenues of the licensee including bingo gross receipts, if bingo games are also conducted by the same nonprofit organization pursuant to license therefor issued by the department of revenue of the state, and placed in a separate account. Each licensee shall keep separate records of its raffles. The person who accounts for gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds from the operation of raffles shall not be the same person who accounts for other revenues of the licensee. 
(c)  Each licensee shall report to its membership and to the city its gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds from the raffle, and the distribution of net proceeds itemized as required in this chapter. 
(d)  Raffle records shall be preserved for three years, and organizations shall make available their records relating to the operation of raffles for public inspection at reasonable times and places. 
(Code 1977, § 5.44.110; Ord. No. 87-11, 1987) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 230 ILCS 15/6. 
Sec. 6-168. - Prize limitations. 
    The aggregate retail value of all prizes awarded in a single raffle shall not exceed $60,000.00, and the retail value of any one prize awarded in a single raffle shall not exceed $60,000.00. 
(Code 1977, § 5.44.130; Ord. No. 87-11, 1987)
