Sec. 6-169. - Chance limitation. 
    The price which may be charged for each raffle chance sold, offered for sale, conveyed, issued or otherwise transferred for value shall not exceed the following schedule: 
Aggregate Retail Value of Prizes Maximum Price Less than $1,000.00 $10.00 $1,000.00-$60,000.00 $500.00  
(Code 1977, § 5.44.140; Ord. No. 87-11, 1987) 
Sec. 6-170. - Violation; penalty; abatement. 
(a)  Penalties. Failure to comply with any of the requirements of this article shall constitute a violation; and any person upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to a fine as set forth in the city penalty schedule for each offense. Each day the violation continues shall be considered a separate offense. 
(b)  Abatement. The imposition of the penalties prescribed in this article shall not preclude the state's attorney from instituting appropriate action to prevent unlawful raffles or to restrain, correct or abate a violation of this article or of the conditions of a raffle license issued pursuant to this article. 
(Code 1977, § 5.44.150; Ord. No. 87-11, 1987) 
Sec. 6-171. - Reciprocity. 
    In the event that the county or any city located in the county should adopt an ordinance regulating the adoption of raffles, licensees who have obtained licenses from said county or city are authorized and allowed to sell, offer for sale, convey, issue, or otherwise transfer for value, raffle chances within the corporate boundaries of the City of Morrison without first obtaining a license pursuant to this article, provided that said county or city has adopted an ordinance, or part thereof, granting reciprocity to the licensee who has been licensed by the City of Morrison. 
(Code 1977, § 5.44.160; Ord. No. 97-19, § 1, 1997) 
Chapter 8 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Powers of municipalities to regulate dogs and other animals, 510 ILCS 5/24; Animal Welfare Act, 225 ILCS 605/1 et seq.; Illinois Dead Animal Disposal Act, 225 ILCS 610/1.1 et seq.; Animal Control Act, 510 ILCS 5/1 et seq.; Illinois Domestic Animals Running At Large Act, 510 ILCS 55/1 et seq.; Humane Care for Animals Act, 510 ILCS 70/1 et seq.; Humane Euthanasia in Animal Shelters Act, 510 ILCS 72/1 et seq.; Illinois Animal Abuse Fund, 510 ILCS 70/16.4 et seq.; liability of owner for damages caused by dogs, 510 ILCS 5/18.1. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 8-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Animal means any vertebrate species, other than any human being. The term "animal" includes fowl, fish and reptiles. 
    Animal control officer means any person, whether employed directly by the city or provided under a contractual agreement or otherwise, who is authorized to investigate any matter regarding the enforcement of this chapter. 
    Animal nuisance means any nuisance arising out of the keeping, maintaining or owning of, or failure to exercise sufficient control of, an animal. 
    Animal shelter means the place designated and maintained by the city, including any agency or other entity operating any such place under contract with the city, to provide impoundment and animal shelter services. 
    At large means off the premises of the owner and not under the control of a responsible person by means of a leash, or on the premises of the owner and not under restraint. 
    Cat means any member of the feline family. 
    Cruelty means any act of omission whereby unjustifiable physical pain, suffering or death of an animal is caused or permitted, including failure to provide proper drink, air, space, shelter or protection from the elements, a sanitary and safe living environment, veterinary care or nutritious food in sufficient quantity. In the case of activities where physical pain is necessarily caused, such as medical and scientific research, food processing, customary and normal veterinary and agricultural husbandry practices, pest elimination, and animal training and hunting, the term "cruelty" shall mean a failure to employ the most humane method reasonably available. 
    Dangerous animal means any animal that attacks, bites, or physically injures human beings, domestic animals, or livestock without provocation, or which, because of temperament or training, has a known propensity to attack, bite or physically injure human beings, domestic animals, or livestock. Any wild animal or any animal that without provocation has bitten or attacked a human being or other animal shall be prima facie presumed dangerous. 
    Dangerous dog means any dog that, because of its aggressive nature, training or characteristic behavior, presents a risk of serious physical harm or death to human beings, or would constitute a danger to human life, physical well-being, or property if not kept under the direct control of the owner. This definition shall not apply to dogs utilized by law enforcement officers in the performance of their duties. The term "dangerous dog" includes any dog that according to the records of the animal control officer or his designee or any law enforcement agency: 
(1)  Has aggressively bitten, attacked, endangered, or inflicted severe injury on a human being on public or private property, or, when unprovoked, has chased or approached a person upon the street, sidewalks, or any public grounds in a menacing fashion or apparent attitude of attack, provided that the actions are attested to in a sworn statement by one or more persons and dutifully investigated by any of the above-referenced authorities; 
(2)  Has severely injured or killed a domestic animal while off the owner's property; 
(3)  Has been used primarily or in part for the purpose of dogfighting, or is a dog trained for dogfighting; 
(4)  Has been trained as a guard dog or attack dog; or 
(5)  Has been declared by any city, county, state or other governmental entity to be a dangerous or vicious dog. 
    Dog means any member of the canine family. 
    Domestic animal includes dogs, cats, domesticated sheep, horses, cattle, goats, swine, fowl, ducks, geese, turkeys, confined domestic hares and rabbits, pheasants, and other birds and animals raised or maintained in confinement. 
    Exotic animal means any live monkey, alligator, crocodile, cayman, raccoon, skunk, fox, bear, sea mammal, poisonous snake, member of the feline species other than a domestic cat (felis domesticus), member of the canine species other than a domestic dog (canis familiaris), or any other animal that would require a standard of care and control greater than that required for customary household pets sold by commercial pet shops or domestic farm animals. 
    Farm animal means and includes, but is not limited to, any member (including any pygmy or miniature variety) of the bovine (cattle), equine (horse), swine (pig or hog), ovine (sheep) or caprine (goat) families, any poultry (any domesticated bird raised for show, eggs or meat, such as chickens, turkeys, geese or ducks) and any breeding rabbits. 
    Guard or attack dog means a dog trained to attack on command or to protect persons or property, and who will cease to attack upon command. 
    Hearing officer means the administrative officer designated by the city to conduct hearings required or permitted under this chapter. 
    Impoundment means the taking into custody of an animal by any police officer, animal control officer, or any authorized representative thereof. 
    Kennel means any premises wherein any person engages in the business of boarding, breeding, buying, letting for hire, training for a fee, or selling dogs or cats. 
    Leash means a cord, rope, strap or chain securely fastened to an animal by a collar or harness, and of sufficient strength to keep such animal under control. 
    Muzzle means a device constructed of strong, soft materials or of metal, designed to fasten over the mouth of an animal to prevent the animal from biting any person or other animal. 
    Owner means any person who, either permanently or temporarily, has a right of ownership or any property interest in an animal, who keeps or harbors an animal, who has an animal in his care, who acts as the custodian of an animal, who exerts control over an animal, or who knowingly permits an animal to remain on or about any premises owned or occupied by any such person. 
    Public nuisance animal means any animal that unreasonably annoys humans, endangers the life or health of persons or other animals, or substantially interferes with the rights of citizens, other than their owners, to the enjoyment of life or property. The term "public nuisance animal" shall include, but not be limited to: 
(1)  Any animal that is found running at large unattended; 
(2)  Any dog or cat in any section of a park or public hall, restaurant, coffee shop, ice cream parlor, office, store, grocery, meat market, bakery or any store or shop for the sale of food, except shops for the sale of animal pets or upon any school premises or public playgrounds; 
(3)  Any animal that damages, soils, defiles or defecates on any property other than that of its owner; 
(4)  Any animal that makes disturbing noises, including but not limited to, continued and repeated howling, barking, whining, or other utterances causing unreasonable annoyance, disturbance, or discomfort to neighbors or others in close proximity to the premises where the animal is kept or harbored; 
(5)  Any animal that causes fouling of the air by noxious or offensive odors and thereby creates unreasonable annoyance or discomfort to neighbors or others in close proximity to the premises where the animal is kept or harbored; 
(6)  Any animal in heat that is not confined so as to prevent attraction or contact with other animals; 
(7)  Any animal, whether or not on the property of its owner, that without provocation molests, attacks, or otherwise interferes with the freedom of movement of persons in a public right-of-way; 
(8)  Any animal that chases motor vehicles in a public right-of-way; 
(9)  Any animal that attacks domestic animals; 
(10)  Any animal that causes unsanitary conditions in enclosures or surroundings where the animal is kept or harbored; 
(11)  Any animal that is offensive or dangerous to the public health, safety or welfare by virtue of the number of animals maintained at a single residence or the inadequacy of the facilities; and 
(12)  Any animal used in organized fighting to determine its strength or skill in combat against another animal. 
    Rabies threat means that an animal has bitten a human being, has been reported to have bitten a human being or exhibits clinical signs of rabies. 
    Restraint means confined by means of a fence of sufficient height and security (which may be an electronic invisible fence system) to prevent an animal from leaving the area so encompassed, on a leash under the control of a responsible person, or on a leash securely fastened to an inanimate object and of a length which prevents such animal from leaving the premises of the owner. 
    Sanitary means a condition of good order and cleanliness to minimize the possibility of disease transmission. 
    Under restraint means that an animal is secured by a leash, lead under the control of a person physically capable of restraining the animal and obedient to that person's commands, or securely enclosed within the real property limits of the owner's premises. 
    Vicious dog means any individual dog: 
(1)  That when unprovoked inflicts bites or attacks any human being or any domestic animal on public or private property; 
(2)  With a known propensity, tendency, or disposition to attack without provocation, to cause injury or to otherwise endanger the safety of any human being or any domestic animal; 
(3)  That has as a trait or characteristic and a generally known reputation for viciousness, dangerousness or unprovoked attacks upon any human being or any domestic animal; or 
(4)  That has been found a dangerous dog upon three or more separate occasions; 
provided that no dog shall be deemed a "vicious dog" solely because it is a professionally trained dog for law enforcement or guard duties, if it bites, attacks, or menaces any trespasser on the property of its owner or if it harms or menaces anyone who has tormented or abused it, and no dog shall be deemed a "vicious dog" solely because of its breed. 
    Wild animal means any live monkey, nonhuman primate, raccoon, skunk, fox, leopard, panther, tiger, lion, lynx or any other warm-blooded animal that can normally be found in the wild state. The term "wild animal" does not include domestic dogs (excluding hybrids with wolves, coyotes or jackals), domestic cats (excluding hybrids with ocelots or margays), farm animals, rodents, any hybrid animal that is part wild and captive-bred species of common cage birds. 
(Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-1-1, 12-14-2009) 
State Law reference- Similar definitions, 510 ILCS 5/2 et seq.; dogs running at large prohibited, 510 ILCS 5/9; dangerous dog defined, 510 ILCS 5/2.05a; potentially dangerous dog defined, 510 ILCS 5/2.17c; vicious dog defined, 510 ILCS 5/2.19b; dangerous dog determination, 510 ILCS 5/15.1 et seq. 
Sec. 8-2. - Excessive animal noise prohibited; outside restraint of animal in absence of owner. 
(a)  No person shall keep in the city any dog, cow, calf, hog, or any other animal shut up, or tied up in any yard, house, building, or other place, which by barking, howling, or other noises disturbs the peace and quiet of any family, individual, or neighborhood. 
(b)  Between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., no person shall keep, or cause to be kept, in the city any dog or other domestic animal on a leash or chain outside in the absence of its owner or custodian. 
(Code 1977, § 6.05.010; Ord. No. 81-7, § 1, 1981; Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-1-2, 12-14-2009) 
Sec. 8-3. - Dangerous animals running at large. 
    It shall be unlawful to permit any dangerous animal or vicious animal of any kind to run at large within the city. 
(Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-1-3, 12-14-2009) 
State Law reference- Dogs running at large prohibited, 510 ILCS 5/9; dangerous dog defined, 510 ILCS 5/2.05a; potentially dangerous dog defined, 510 ILCS 5/2.17c; vicious dog defined, 510 ILCS 5/2.19b; dangerous dog determination, 510 ILCS 5/15.1 et seq. 
Sec. 8-4. - Diseased animals. 
(a)  No domestic animal afflicted with a contagious or infectious disease shall be allowed to run at large, or to be exposed in any public place whereby the health of man or beast may be affected, nor shall such diseased animal be shipped or removed from the premises of the owner thereof, except under the supervision of the animal control officer, chief of police, or other authorized city officer or official. 
(b)  It is hereby made the duty of the public works department to secure such disposition of any diseased animal and such treatment of affected premises as to prevent the communication and spread of the contagion or infection except in cases where the state department of agriculture is empowered to act. 
(Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-1-4, 12-14-2009) 
Sec. 8-5. - Female animals in heat. 
    The owner or keeper of any female animal shall not permit or suffer the animal, while in heat, to be upon any sidewalk, street, parkway, alley, or other public place, or upon any private premises, other than the premises of the owner or keeper, or, if outdoors, within a fully enclosed fenced area. 
(Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-1-5, 12-14-2009) 
Sec. 8-6. - Animals suffering from rabies declared nuisance. 
    Any animal, dog or cat suffering from rabies as determined by a licensed veterinarian is hereby declared to be a nuisance. It shall be the duty of the owner or keeper of the animal, dog or cat to immediately confine the animal, dog or cat for observation as provided for by the Animal Control Act, 510 ILCS 5/1 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-1-6, 12-14-2009) 
Sec. 8-7. - Penalty. 
    Any violation of this chapter shall be a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not less than $75.00 or more than $750.00. 
(Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-7-1, 12-14-2009) 
Secs. 8-8-8-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DOGS GENERALLY 

Sec. 8-31. - Running at large prohibited. 
(a)  No dog shall be allowed or permitted to run at large within the city. Running at large, when applied to dogs, occurs when the dog is on any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place or the dog is on any private property without the permission and/or supervision of the property owner and the dog, when on one of the described places, either is not securely leashed, confined in an automobile, or under the direct control of the dog's owner. 
(b)  For those dog owners that have installed an invisible detention system, which allows a dog to run at large upon the owner's private property but contains such dog on the private property without being leashed or under direct supervision of the dog, shall have such system posted and visible from any adjacent public property. 
(Prior Code, § 171; Code 1977, § 6.08.010; Ord. No. 554, § 1, 1968; Ord. No. 498, § 1, 1962; Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-2-1, 12-14-2009) 
State Law reference- Dogs running at large prohibited, 510 ILCS 5/9; dangerous dog defined, 510 ILCS 5/2.05a; potentially dangerous dog defined, 510 ILCS 5/2.17c; vicious dog defined, 510 ILCS 5/2.19b; dangerous dog determination, 510 ILCS 5/15.1 et seq. 
Sec. 8-32. - Prohibited from cemetery. 
    No dog shall be allowed or permitted in any city cemetery. 
(Code 1977, § 6.08.030; Ord. No. 01-09, § 1, 2001; Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-2-2, 12-14-2009) 
Sec. 8-33. - Dog feces cleanup required. 
(a)  Every owner or keeper of any dog within the corporate limits of the city and beyond the parameter of the yard of the residence or shelter within which, and upon which, the animal is contained is required to clean up all feces deposited by any dog under their care or control. Cleanup is the removal and depositing of the feces in a trash receptacle. 
(b)  Every owner or keeper of any dog who permits the same to enter a city park is required to clean up all feces deposited by any dog under their care or control. Cleanup is the removal and depositing of the feces in a trash receptacle or removal from the park 
(Code 1977, §§ 6.08.040, 6.08.050; Ord. No. 01-10, § 1, 2001; Ord. No. 04-15, § 1, 2004; Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-2-3, 12-14-2009) 
Sec. 8-34. - Leash or other control methods required. 
    It is unlawful for any owner of any animal or dog to maintain a public nuisance by permitting any animal or dog to leave the premises of its owner when not under control by leash or other recognized control methods. 
(Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-2-4, 12-14-2009) 
Sec. 8-35. - Bites; impoundment; examinations by veterinarian. 
(a)  Whenever any dog bites a person, the owner of the dog shall immediately notify the chief of police who shall order the dog to be held on the owner's premises or shall have it impounded for a period of ten days. The dog shall be examined by a licensed veterinarian immediately after it has bitten anyone and again at the end of the ten-day period. 
(b)  If, at the end of this ten-day period, a veterinarian is convinced that the dog is free from rabies, the veterinarian shall order the dog released from quarantine or the pound, as the case may be. 
(Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-2-5, 12-14-2009) 
State Law reference- Dog and other animal bites, 510 ILCS 5/13; animal attacks or injuries, 510 ILCS 5/16. 
Sec. 8-36. - Dog registration required. 
    Any and all dogs kept within the corporate limits of this city shall be registered and in full compliance with those requirements of the county health department (animal control). Each dog registered, and therefore vaccinated, must be collared with valid tags at all times showing proof of such registration and compliance. 
(Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-2-7, 12-14-2009) 
Secs. 8-37-8-58. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DANGEROUS AND VICIOUS DOGS 

Sec. 8-59. - Purpose and intent. 
    The purpose of this article is to promote the public health, safety, and general welfare of the citizens of the city. It is intended to be applicable to dangerous and vicious dogs by ensuring responsible handling by their owners through registration, confinement, and liability insurance. 
(Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-3-1, 12-14-2009) 
Sec. 8-60. - Vicious dogs prohibited; dangerous dogs restricted. 
(a)  No person shall own, harbor, keep, maintain or otherwise allow to be present on any property owned or controlled by him within the city limits and within 11/2 miles outside the city limits, or upon any public property of the city, any vicious dog as defined in this chapter. 
(b)  No person shall own, harbor, keep, maintain or otherwise allow to be present on any property owned or controlled by him within the city limits and within 11/2 miles outside the city limits, or upon any public property of the city, any dangerous dog, as defined in this chapter, except in full compliance with the rules, regulations, restrictions, and limitations set forth in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-3-2, 12-14-2009) 
Sec. 8-61. - Declaring a dog dangerous. 
(a)  If the animal control officer or any city officer or official has reason to believe that a dog falls within any of the categories that would render it dangerous, the officer or his designee shall investigate the circumstances to determine whether the dog falls within the definition of a "dangerous dog" as provided in this chapter. 
(b)  In the event that following an investigation the officer or his designee determines that the dog is dangerous as defined in this chapter, he may declare the dog is dangerous in accordance with this article. 
(Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-3-3, 12-14-2009) 
State Law reference- Dangerous dog determination, 510 ILCS 5/15.1. 
Sec. 8-62. - Notice of a dangerous dog declaration. 
(a)  Within seven calendar days of a determination by the appropriate officer that a dog is dangerous, the officer making the determination shall notify the dog's owner, if known, in writing, of the declaration. The notice shall identify the requirements and conditions for maintaining a dangerous dog as set forth in this article. 
(b)  If the owner is unknown or cannot be located, the dog may be immediately impounded. If the owner's address is known, but the owner cannot be located, the notice shall be posted on the owner's property, personally served upon the owner or sent by certified mail to the owner's last known address. 
(Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-3-4, 12-14-2009) 
Sec. 8-63. - Request for hearing; waiver for failure to request or to appear at hearing. 
(a)  The owner of a dog that has been declared dangerous in accordance with this article shall have the right to file a written request for a hearing to contest the declaration. Such a request must be filed with the city clerk within seven calendar days after the owner received notice of the dangerous dog declaration. 
(b)  In the event that the owner fails to file a written request for a hearing within the requisite seven-day period, or fails to appear at a scheduled hearing, the owner will be deemed to have waived the right to a hearing on the declaration, and the dog shall be deemed dangerous and the owner shall be required to comply with all of the requirements and conditions for maintaining a dangerous dog as set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-3-5, 12-14-2009) 
Sec. 8-64. - Scheduling and conduct of hearing. 
(a)  Within seven calendar days of the receipt of a written request for a hearing or as soon thereafter as is practical for the mayor, or his authorized representative, a hearing shall be scheduled by the city. The hearing shall be conducted by the city administrator or the mayor or their designee. The hearing will be informal and strict rules of evidence shall not apply. The owner and the city may be represented by counsel, present oral and written evidence, and cross-examine witnesses. 
(b)  The presiding officer shall issue a written decision within seven business days after the conclusion of the hearing. The owner shall be mailed a copy of the written decision. The decision of the officer shall be final. 
(c)  In the event the presiding officer upholds the dangerous dog declaration, the owner shall immediately comply with all of the requirements and conditions for maintaining a dangerous dog as set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-3-6, 12-14-2009) 
Sec. 8-65. - Requirements for keeping a dangerous dog. 
    In order to keep or permit a dangerous dog within or within 11/2 miles outside of the city limits, the owner of a dangerous dog shall be required to do the following: 
(1)  Confinement. All dangerous dogs shall be securely confined indoors or in an enclosed and locked pen or structure upon the premises of the owner. The pen or structure must have minimum dimensions of five feet by ten feet, and must have secure sides and a secure top attached to the sides. If no bottom is secured to the sides, the sides must be embedded into the ground no less than two feet. 
(2)  Leash/muzzle. The owner of a dangerous dog shall not allow the animal to go outside its kennel, pen or structure, unless the animal is muzzled, restrained by a chain or leash not more than three feet long, and under the physical control of a person not less than 18 years of age. 
(3)  Signs. The owner of a dangerous dog shall display a clearly visible warning sign, in a prominent place on his premises, indicating that there is a dangerous dog on the premises. The sign must be legible from the public streets or thoroughfares upon which the owner's property adjoins. The owner shall also display a sign with a symbol warning children of the presence of a dangerous dog. Exact or similar signs shall be posted on the dog's kennel, pen or enclosed structure. 
(4)  Insurance. The owner of a dangerous dog must maintain public liability insurance providing a minimum amount of $500,000.00, insuring the owner for any damage or personal injury that may be caused by his dangerous animal. Upon a declaration that a dog is dangerous, the owner of the animal must provide proof to the city clerk that the owner possesses the required insurance. Upon request of the city, the owner shall be required to present proof of insurance, upon occasion, demonstrating that the owner is maintaining the insurance. 
(5)  Notice of change of status. The owner of a dangerous dog shall notify the city police department immediately upon learning that the dangerous animal is unconfined or on the loose, or if the dog has attacked a human being or domestic animal. 
(6)  Notice of change of ownership. If the owner of a dog declared to be dangerous pursuant to this article sells, gives away or otherwise transfers custody or ownership of the dangerous animal, the owner shall, within three days of the sale or transfer, provide the city police department with the name, address and telephone number of the dangerous dog's new owner or custodian. The owner shall notify the new owner or custodian of the animal's designation as a dangerous dog. If the new owner or custodian resides or keeps the animal within the corporate limits of the city, the owner shall inform the new owner or custodian of the requirements and conditions for keeping a dangerous dog as established in this article. 
(7)  Identifying microchip implanted in dog. All dangerous dogs shall have a microchip implanted in the skin of the dog by a licensed veterinarian. The microchip shall be required to identify the current owner of the dog by name, address and telephone number. The cost of the microchip and the procedure to implant the microchip shall be borne by the owner of the dangerous dog. 
(Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-3-7, 12-14-2009) 
State Law reference- Leash required for dangerous dog, 510 ILCS 5/15.2. 
Sec. 8-66. - Order for impoundment and destruction. 
    The animal control officer or other authorized city official may order the impoundment and destruction of a dangerous dog upon occurrence of one of the following: 
(1)  The dog has attacked, bitten, injured or killed a human being or domestic animal; or 
(2)  The dog has been declared to be dangerous pursuant to this article and the owner has failed to comply with the requirements and conditions for keeping a dangerous dog in accordance with this article; or 
(3)  The dog poses a threat of serious harm to the public health or safety. 
(Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-3-8, 12-14-2009) 
State Law reference- Apprehension of dangerous dog, 510 ILCS 5/17. 
Sec. 8-67. - Notice of impoundment or destruction. 
    Within seven calendar days of an impoundment, the officer ordering the impoundment or destruction of a dog shall notify the animal's owner, if known, in writing, of the impoundment or destruction. 
(Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-3-9, 12-14-2009) 
Sec. 8-68. - Hearing on impoundment or destruction. 
    The known owner of a dangerous dog shall have the opportunity to have a hearing on the impoundment or recommended destruction in the same manner as provided in this article for hearings challenging a dangerous dog declaration. 
(Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-3-10, 12-14-2009) 
State Law reference- Appeal of dangerous dog determination, 510 ILCS 5/15.3. 
Sec. 8-69. - Law enforcement dogs and dogs acting in defense exempted. 
    This article shall not apply to dogs used by the city police department, a private security company, or a law enforcement agency in performance of their duties. In addition, a dog shall not be declared dangerous if it is determined that the conduct of the dog was justified because: 
(1)  The threat or attack was sustained by a person who at the time was committing a crime or offense upon the owner, a member of its household, or custodian of the dog. 
(2)  The threatened person was tormenting, abusing, assaulting, or physically threatening the dog or its offspring. 
(3)  The injured, threatened, or killed domesticated animal was attacking or threatening the dog or its offspring. 
(4)  The dog was responding to pain or injury or was protecting itself, its owner, custodian, or a member of its household, kennel, or offspring. 
(Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-3-11, 12-14-2009) 
Secs. 8-70-8-96. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - LIVESTOCK 

Sec. 8-97. - Running at large prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any domestic animal of the species horse, mule, cattle, sheep, swine, or goat to run or go at large at any time within the limits of the city. 
(Prior Code, § 159; Code 1977, § 6.04.010; Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-4-1, 12-14-2009) 
State Law reference- Dogs running at large prohibited, 510 ILCS 5/9; dangerous dog defined, 510 ILCS 5/2.05a; potentially dangerous dog defined, 510 ILCS 5/2.17c; vicious dog defined, 510 ILCS 5/2.19b; dangerous dog determination, 510 ILCS 5/15.1 et seq. 
Sec. 8-98. - Agricultural livestock prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to keep any agricultural livestock within the city. 
(Code 1977, § 6.12.040; Ord. No. 04-20, § 1, 2004: Ord. No. 03-01, § 1, 2003; Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-4-2, 12-14-2009) 
Sec. 8-99. - Riding of animals restricted. 
    No animal may be ridden at any time of any day from dusk to dawn, except any animal being ridden by any law enforcement officer. No animal at any time may be ridden or led upon any sidewalk or place other than the street or roadbed. 
(Prior Code, § 718a; Code 1977, § 10.16.110; Ord. No. 598, 1972; Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-4-3, 12-14-2009) 
Secs. 8-100-8-126. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - CRUELTY TO ANIMALS 

Sec. 8-127. - Prohibited acts. 
    The following acts are deemed cruelty to animals and are prohibited: 
(1)  Overloading, overdriving, overworking, cruelly beating, torturing, tormenting, mutilating, or cruelly killing any animal or causing or knowingly allowing the same to be done; 
(2)  Cruelly working any old, maimed, infirm, sick, or disabled animal, or causing or knowingly allowing the same to be done; 
(3)  Unnecessarily failing to provide any animal in his charge or custody, as owner or otherwise, with proper food, drink, shelter, and air; 
(4)  Abandoning any old, maimed, infirm, sick or disabled animal; 
(5)  Carrying, driving, or keeping, or causing to be carried, or driven or kept, any animal in an unnecessarily cruel manner; 
(6)  Carrying, causing to be carried, keeping or causing to be kept, any animal bound or tied by its legs, or bound down by the neck, or so that it cannot freely stand in an upright position while being transported, or by carrying, or causing to be carried, keeping or causing to be kept any animal in any crate or cage so constructed as to permit such animal to push its head between the slats, wires or other opening of such crate or cage unless the spaces between such slats or wires are also sufficient to permit such animal to freely withdraw its head wherefrom. 
(Prior Code, § 417; Code 1977, § 6.12.010; Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-5-1, 12-14-2009) 
State Law reference- Authority for municipalities to prohibit cruelty to animals, 65 ILCS 5/11-5-6; description of animal cruelty, 510 ILCS 70/3.03-1; cruel treatment of animals prohibited, 510 ILCS 70/3.01; animal torture prohibited, 510 ILCS 70/3.03; owner's duties for animal care, 510 ILCS 70/3; abandonment prohibited, 510 ILCS 70/3.01. 
Sec. 8-128. - Neglect prohibited; food and drink required. 
    No person shall inhumanely or unnecessarily fail to provide any animal owned or kept by him with proper and sufficient food and drink. 
(Prior Code, 177; Code 1977, § 6.12.020; Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-5-2, 12-14-2009) 
Sec. 8-129. - Confinement in motor vehicle. 
    No owner or person shall confine any animal in a motor vehicle in a manner that places it in a life or health threatening situation by exposure to a prolonged period of extreme heat or cold. In order to protect the life and safety of an animal, a police officer or another designee of the chief of police who has probable cause to believe that this section is violated shall have authority to enter such motor vehicle by any reasonable means under the circumstances, after making a reasonable effort under the circumstances to locate the owner or person. 
(Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-5-3, 12-14-2009) 
Sec. 8-130. - Animal fighting. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner of any animal, including, but not limited to dogs, to intentionally allow such animal to become involved in a fight with any other animal. 
(Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-5-4, 12-14-2009) 
Secs. 8-131-8-158. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - IMPOUNDMENT[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Animal control facility defined, 510 ILCS 70/2.01f; animal shelter defined, 510 ILCS 70/2.0h; impoundment defined, 510 ILCS 5/2.12a; pound defined, 510 ILCS 5/2.18; impoundment and redemption of dogs and cats, 510 ILCS 5/10. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 8-159. - Duty of police officers to impound animals at large. 
    It is made the duty of the chief of police and of the several members of the police department to take up any and every animal known by him or them to be unlawfully at large contrary to the provisions of this chapter, and to confine the same in the pound or other secure place to be provided for such purpose. Impoundment of dogs shall be in accordance with the specific provisions herein applicable to dogs only. 
(Prior Code, § 160; Code 1977, § 6.04.020; Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-6-1.1, 12-14-2009) 
Sec. 8-160. - Impoundment fees. 
    A daily animal care fee shall be due from the owner for each animal for each day or partial day of impoundment, in addition to an administrative impoundment fee, any veterinary costs incurred by the city in providing necessary medical treatment to the impounded animal, and fines for violation of this chapter. The impoundment fee and daily animal care fee shall be in the amounts provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-6-1.2, 12-14-2009) 
Sec. 8-161. - Care of impounded animals. 
    The chief of police shall provide suitable and necessary food, drink, veterinary care, medication, and inoculation for all such animals as may be taken up and impounded, during the time that they may be impounded, and the cost of such sustenance, together with the lawful fees for taking up and impounding, shall be paid to the chief of police before any such animal shall be released. 
(Prior Code, § 161; Code 1977, § 6.04.030; Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-6-1.3, 12-14-2009) 
Secs. 8-162-8-190. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PROCEDURE 

Sec. 8-191. - Complaint; warrant; judgment. 
(a)  When any animal or animals have been impounded as provided in this chapter, and the owner or the person entitled to the possession of the same fails to appear within 24 hours after the impounding and pay the fees and charges required for their redemption, it shall be the duty of the chief of police to make complaint in writing before the associate circuit judge, giving a general description of the animal or animals impounded, the date of such impounding, and the name of the owner thereof, if known to the complainant. 
(b)  The judge shall issue a warrant against the owner or keeper of such animal or animals, for permitting the same to run at large in violation of the provisions of this chapter; and upon the return of the warrant duly executed or the defendant appearing in court, like proceedings shall be had as in other cases for the recovery of fines or penalties under city ordinances. 
(c)  If the defendant is found guilty, judgment shall be rendered against him for the penalty, impounding fee, cost of sustenance, and costs of suit; and an order shall be entered that such animal or animals be sold to satisfy such judgment and costs, unless the same shall be forthwith paid. 
(Prior Code, § 162; Code 1977, § 6.04.040; Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-6-2.1, 12-14-2009) 
Sec. 8-192. - Notice to unknown owner. 
(a)  If the owner of an impounded animal is unknown, the judge, upon filing of the complaint, shall issue a notice to unknown owners in the form prescribed from time to time by the city council. 
(b)  The notice shall include a date for trial that shall not be less than five or more than ten days from the date of issuance of the notice. 
(c)  The chief of police or some member of the police department shall immediately post three copies of the notice as follows: one at the pound where the animal is impounded, one at the front door of the city hall, and one at the office of the judge issuing the notice. The police officer posting the notices shall make due return to the court, showing the time and manner of the posting. 
(d)  The judge issuing the notice shall enter the same upon his docket as follows: City of Morrison vs. The Unknown Owners of (here describe the animal) . Upon the day set for trial and the return of the notice executed as like proceedings shall be had as in the case of personal service and appearance. 
(Prior Code, §§ 163-165; Code 1977, §§ 6.04.050-6.04.070; Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-6-2.2, 12-14-2009) 
Sec. 8-193. - Order of sale; execution. 
(a)  Upon the rendition of any judgment as provided in this article, the judge rendering the same shall issue to the chief of police an order of sale, in the form prescribed from time to time by the city council. 
(b)  The order shall be returned by the chief of police within 30 days from its date to the office of the judge issuing the same, with an endorsement thereon showing when and how the same was executed. 
(Prior Code, § 166; Code 1977, § 6.04.080; Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-6-2.3, 12-14-2009) 
Sec. 8-194. - Notice of sale. 
    Upon the receipt of the order for sale, the chief of police shall immediately post or cause to be posted three notices of sale, in three public places within the city, in the form prescribed from time to time by the city council. 
(Prior Code, § 167; Code 1977, § 6.04.090; Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-6-2.4, 12-14-2009) 
Sec. 8-195. - Time of sale. 
    The day of sale mentioned in the notice of sale shall not be less than three or more than five days after posting the same. If such animal or animals are not redeemed, the chief of police shall sell the same in accordance with the notice. 
(Prior Code, § 168; Code 1977, § 6.04.100; Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-6-2.5, 12-14-2009) 
Sec. 8-196. - Postponement of sale; destruction. 
    The chief of police may, from want of bidders or other good cause, adjourn any such sale from day to day, until the same is completed. If, after two adjournments, no bidder appears, such animal shall be humanely destroyed. 
(Prior Code, § 169; Code 1977, § 6.04.110; Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-6-2.6, 12-14-2009) 
Sec. 8-197. - Proceeds of sale; disposition. 
    The money realized from such sale shall be paid into the city treasury, and the amount remaining over and above the costs, expenses, and legal charges against the same shall be payable to the owner or owners of the animal or animals so sold, upon demand. 
(Prior Code, § 170; Code 1977, § 6.04.120; Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-6-2.7, 12-14-2009) 
Secs. 8-198-8-217. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DOGS 

Sec. 8-218. - Duty of police officers to impound dogs running at large. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police or any other police officer of the city to capture and impound, for a period of five days, each and every dog found running at large contrary to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Prior Code, § 171; Code 1977, § 6.08.020; Ord. No. 554, § 1, 1968; Ord. No. 498, § 1, 1962; Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-6-3.1, 12-14-2009) 
Sec. 8-219. - Notice to owner; redemption. 
    The chief of police shall upon impoundment of a dog notify the owner of the dog so taken, if the owner can be ascertained. The owner shall be permitted to redeem the dog by paying the fine and impoundment fees provided in the city fee schedule, plus any veterinary costs accrued by the city in care of the dog. 
(Prior Code, § 171; Code 1977, § 6.08.020; Ord. No. 554, § 1, 1968; Ord. No. 498, § 1, 1962; Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-6-3.2, 12-14-2009) 
Sec. 8-220. - Failure of owner to redeem dog; destruction. 
    Redemption must be made within five days after the impounding of any dog sought to be redeemed, regardless of notice to the owner. Any dog held in pound and unredeemed may be destroyed after the fifth day. 
(Prior Code, § 171; Code 1977, § 6.08.020; Ord. No. 554, § 1, 1968; Ord. No. 498, § 1, 1962; Ord. No. 09-13, § 6-6-3.3, 12-14-2009) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, 510 ILCS 5/9; impoundment and redemption of dogs and cats, 510 ILCS 5/10. 
Chapter 10 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Local Government Air Rights Act, 50 ILCS 25/0.01 et seq.; Building Code Violation Notice Posting Act, 50 ILCS 810/0.01 et seq.; Contractor Unified License and Permit Bond Act, 50 ILCS ; 830/1 et seq.; Building Authority Act, 20 ILCS 3110/0.01 et seq.; Building Code Violation Notice Posting Act, 50 ILCS 810/0.01 et seq.; procedure regarding municipal removal of abandoned buildings, 735 ILCS 5/2-206; municipal authority over building and construction generally, 65 ILCS 11-13-1 et seq.; municipal authority with regard to construction of buildings and fire escapes, 65 ILCS 5/11-30-4; municipal authority with regard to grading and drainage of lots, 65 ILCS 5/11-30-8; authority to regulate artificial basins of water used for swimming or wading, 65 ILCS 5/11-30-9; municipal authority to regulate demolition, repair, enclosure, or remediation of buildings and other structures, 65 ILCS 5/11-31-1 et seq.; building code violations, 65 ILCS 5/11-31.1-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - Administration by building department and building official. 
    The person designated by the city council to enforce the provisions of this chapter shall be the head of the city's building department and shall be known as the building official. As the title is used in this chapter, the term "building official" includes the duly appointed department head and his designees. 
Secs. 10-2-10-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BUILDING REGULATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 10-21-10-43. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TECHNICAL CODES[2] 

Footnotes:

State Law reference- Authority for adoption of certain construction regulations by municipalities, 65 ILCS 5/1-3-1; Municipal Adoption of Codes and Records Act, 50 ILCS 220/0.01 et seq.

DIVISION 3. - ADDITIONAL PLUMBING REGULATIONS 

Sec. 10-84. - Permits. 
(a)  A permit for the drainage of any building, public or private, or for the alteration in existing systems of drainage shall be obtained from the plumbing inspector before entering upon any work, whether new work or repair work, which permit shall be good for one year from the date of issue and shall be secured by the plumber who does the work. 
(b)  If the work is not completed within that time, the permit shall be returned and a new permit issued. 
(c)  The permits to the property owner for tapping a public sewer and connecting therewith shall be secured from the city clerk, by making application on a form provided by the clerk and paying a permit fee in the amount provided in the city fee schedule. 
(d)  Permits for plumbing will be granted within 24 hours. All permits shall be returned within 24 hours after completion of work. 
(e)  All permits shall be issued in duplicate form, numbered consecutively, and dated. One copy shall be kept on file in the office of the plumbing inspector. 
(Prior Code, § 558; Code 1977, § 15.24.010) 
Sec. 10-85. - Plastic materials. 
    It is lawful to use or cause to be used any and all plastic materials for any plumbing purposes, for any stacks and vents located out of the ground. All other plastic materials are unlawful. 
(Prior Code, § 559; Code 1977, § 15.24.030; Ord. No. 574, § 2, 1969; Ord. No. 593, 1972) 
Secs. 10-86-10-113. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PUBLIC BUILDINGS REGULATIONS 

Sec. 10-114. - Outward opening doors required. 
(a)  All buildings now built or hereafter constructed within the city which may be or are used for churches, schoolhouses, colleges, operas, theaters, lecture rooms, hotels, or public meetings, in whole or in part, or any part or rooms thereof which may be or are used for the purpose of the meeting or assembling of fraternal or other associations, or for dances, or which may be or are used for any purpose whereby a collection of persons may be assembled together for religious worship, amusement, instruction, education, or other purpose, shall be so built and constructed that all doors leading from the main hall or place where said collection of persons may be assembled, or from the principal rooms which may be used for any of the purposes aforesaid, shall be so hung upon their hinges and constructed that the doors open outward. 
(b)  All means of egress from the main hall or principal room and from the building shall be by means or through doors which open outwards from the main hall or building. 
(Prior Code, § 207; Code 1977, § 15.08.050) 
Sec. 10-115. - Public buildings-Exit requirements. 
    All public halls or theaters having a seating capacity of 500 persons or more, within the city and in all such public halls or theaters which are constructed within the city shall be so constructed so as to have three or more exits from the main or principal floor thereof, each of which shall be six feet or more in width and shall extend from the main floor to the surface of the ground or street. 
(Prior Code, § 209; Code 1977, § 15.08.060) 
Sec. 10-116. - Same-Exit marking required. 
    The location of each exit and of each fire escape, as required by this division to be placed, shall be indicated by one or more plain and legible signs in close proximity thereto, having letters thereon at least six inches in height. 
(Prior Code, § 210; Code 1977, § 15.08.070) 
Sec. 10-117. - Same-Seating; unobstructed aisles required. 
    All buildings within the city which may be or are used in whole or in part as churches, theaters, schools, colleges, lecture rooms, or for public meetings, and having fixed and permanent seats therein, shall, when so used, be occupied only to the extent of the number of such fixed and permanent seats. It is declared unlawful to permit the admission into the room or hall used in such buildings for such purposes of more persons than will occupy the full number of such seats. It is further declared unlawful to obstruct the aisles, passageways, or other means of exit from such room or hall by chairs, benches, seats, or in any other manner. 
(Prior Code, § 208; Code 1977, § 15.08.080) 
Sec. 10-118. - Motion picture theaters. 
(a)  No person or corporation shall conduct a moving picture theater in the city unless all walls, floors, and ceilings of every booth or machine house are built of brick, hollow tile, concrete, or other fire-resistive material; or, if of wood, are covered on the inside with fireproof material; the door of the operating room shall be of metal and swing outwards. 
(b)  No person shall operate in any picture show or entertainment any machine or device for showing or projecting moving pictures unless such machine or device, together with all its fittings, wiring, connections, apparatus, and appliances are of the standard of safety and perfection that is now required, or may hereafter be required, by the rules of some recognized board of fire underwriters, or the proper bureau or laboratory thereof. 
(Prior Code, § 204; Code 1977, § 15.08.030) 
Secs. 10-119-10-149. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - REGULATIONS APPLICABLE TO BUILDINGS WITHIN FIRE LIMITS 

Sec. 10-150. - Boundary designated. 
    All currently designated municipal boundaries are hereby declared to be within the fire limits of the city. 
(Prior Code, § 199; Code 1977, § 15.04.010) 
Sec. 10-151. - Dilapidated wooden buildings declared a nuisance; abatement. 
(a)  Any wooden building or part of any building within the fire limits which is located within 20 feet of any other building, and which is so dilapidated or out of repair as to be untenantable, is declared to be a nuisance. When any such nuisance comes to the knowledge of the fire warden or building inspector, such inspector shall forthwith notify the owner or agent of such building to remedy or abate such nuisance, and the owner or agent shall thereupon proceed to abate the same. 
(b)  If the owner fails to abate after directive from the city, the city council may order any such wooden building or part thereof to be taken down or removed by or under the direction of the fire warden or chief of police. 
(c)  The cost of abatement by the city shall be borne by the property owner or agent of the building, or both of them, in the manner permitted by law. 
(Prior Code, § 462; Code 1977, § 15.04.020) 
Sec. 10-152. - Nonflammable exteriors required. 
    It is unlawful to construct any building or structure in the fire limits unless the exterior walls and roof of such building or structure are covered with or constructed of nonflammable material. 
(Prior Code, § 200; Code 1977, § 15.04.030) 
Sec. 10-153. - Repairs to damaged structures. 
    It is unlawful to repair any existing frame building within the fire limits after the same has been damaged by any cause to 50 percent of its value. Any existing frame building in the fire limits may be brick veneered. 
(Prior Code, § 201; Code 1977, § 15.04.040) 
Sec. 10-154. - Wooden appurtenances prohibited. 
    No wooden awning, porch, or outside stairway within all commercially zoned property shall be erected or constructed, or reerected, reconstructed, or repaired, other than minor repairs on the same. 
(Prior Code, § 202; Code 1977, § 15.04.050) 
Secs. 10-155-10-176. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - OTHER BUILDING REGULATIONS 

Sec. 10-177. - Dangerous buildings declared a nuisance; abatement. 
(a)  Any building or part thereof within the city that is in danger of falling, or otherwise in such condition as to be unsafe for persons within or passing under or near the same, or residing adjacent or near thereto, or in such condition as may endanger any property contiguous or near thereto, is declared to be a nuisance. 
(b)  When any such nuisance shall be found by the building inspector, or be reported by any person annoyed or endangered thereby, the building inspector shall forthwith notify the owner or agent of the property to abate the nuisance, and the owner or agent shall thereupon proceed to remedy or abate the same. 
(c)  In case the owner or agent of such building cannot be found, the chief of police shall report the fact to the city council. 
(d)  The city council may, in any case where such nuisance is not remedied or abated within a reasonable time, order the tearing down and removal of such building or part thereof. 
(e)  The cost of abatement by the city shall be borne by the property owner or agent of the building, or both of them, in the manner permitted by law. 
(Prior Code, § 461; Code 1977, § 15.08.010) 
Sec. 10-178. - Smokehouses and kindred structures. 
(a)  All smokehouses and buildings for the deposit of ashes erected within the city shall be strictly prohibited. 
(b)  No person shall be permitted or allowed to smoke meats or fish in the basement or any part of any building in the city in such manner as to endanger, injure, or deface the property of another or to the inconvenience, annoyance, or detriment of any person or his property or any occupant thereof. 
(Prior Code, § 203; Code 1977, § 15.08.020) 
Sec. 10-179. - Fire escapes required. 
(a)  All buildings within the city which are three or more stories in height and used for manufacturing purposes, hotels, dormitories, apartment buildings, mixed-use structures, office buildings, commercial buildings, schools, colleges, hospitals, or theaters shall be provided with one or more metallic ladders or metallic fire escapes attached to the outer walls thereof. 
(b)  Ladders or escapes shall extend from or suitably near the ground to the uppermost story thereof and shall be provided with platforms of such forms and dimensions and in such proximity to one or more windows of each story above the first as to render access to such ladders or stairs from each story easily and safely. 
(c)  The number of such ladders or stairs to be constructed shall be as follows: 
(1)  Upon each theater there shall be at least one of such ladders or stairs to the outer walls of each side of the building which faces upon any street, avenue, alley or other open space or parcel of land; 
(2)  Upon each of the other buildings enumerated in this section, there shall be at least one of such ladders or stairs; 
(3)  In all of such buildings wherein more than 50 persons commonly gather, congregate, sleep, or are employed above the first story thereof, there shall be at least one of such ladders or stairs for every 50 persons for whom working, sleeping, or living accommodations are provided above the first or ground floor. 
(Prior Code, § 206; Code 1977, § 15.08.040) 
Secs. 10-180-10-196. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - SWIMMING POOL FENCING[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 13-30, adopted Aug. 26, 2013, repealed the former div. 7, §§ 10-197-10-199, and enacted a new div. 7 as set out herein. The former div. 7 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the 1977 Code, §§ 8.18.010-8.18.030; and Ord. No. 04-17, § 1, adopted in 2004. 
State Law reference- Authority of municipalities with regard to fences and party walls, 65 ILCS 5/11-30-1. 

Sec. 10-197. - Definitions. 
    [The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] 
    Private outdoor swimming pool is a manmade rigid or semi-rigid receptacle for water having a depth at any point greater than 24 inches, used or intended to be used for swimming, wading, or bathing, and constructed, installed or maintained in or aboveground and which is used exclusively by the owner or occupant of the property on which it is located, his family and his guests. 
    Temporary soft-sided pool is a manmade inflatable or non-inflatable rigid or semi rigid receptacle for water having a depth at any point greater than 24 inches, used or intended to be used for swimming, wading, or bathing and constructed, installed or maintained in or above ground and which is used exclusively by the owner or occupant of the property on which it is located, his family and his guests and which is not permanently attached to the property by any means, such as buried metal support shafts or other like devices. 
(Ord. No. 13-30, § 2, 8-26-2013) 
Sec. 10-198. - Permit-Required; application; approval procedure. 
    No person shall construct or cause to be constructed a private outdoor swimming pool with capacity of 2,500 gallons or more without first obtaining a permit from the building official. An application for a permit to construct and the plans, specifications and pertinent explanatory data shall be submitted to the building official or to the director of public works for approval, and no part of the work shall be commenced until the applicant has been granted such approval by a written permit to construct and has further evidenced his approval by a suitable endorsement upon such plans and specifications. The building official or the director of public works shall review such plans and specifications to determine whether they comply with the provisions of this division and with reasonable standards of swimming pool construction for the protection of the public safety, health and morals. 
(Ord. No. 13-30, § 2, 8-26-2013) 
Sec. 10-199. - Construction; ordinance and code compliance. 
    All construction of private outdoor swimming pools or temporary soft sided pools shall conform to all other ordinances of the city. Temporary soft-sided pools must be able to be secured when not in use, by being covered with a water permeable cover or cover designed to limit water accumulation and by having the access ladder, if any, removed. No pool shall be allowed in either the front or side yards. All pools must be set back six feet from the property lines. 
(Ord. No. 13-30, § 2, 8-26-2013) 
Sec. 10-200. - Surrounding enclosure. 
    Every owner, purchaser under contract, lessee, tenant or licensees of land within the city upon which is situated a private outdoor swimming pool shall at all times maintain, on the lot or premises upon which such private swimming pool is located, a fence or other structure completely surrounding such pool, not less than four feet in height, with no gaps or apertures, other than doors or gates, with any dimensions greater than one and one-half inches. All gates or doors opening through such fence or enclosure shall be equipped with self-closing and self-latching devices placed at the top of such gates or doors and made inaccessible to small children. Such devices shall be so designed as to be capable of keeping such doors or gates securely locked at all times when not in use; however, the door of any dwelling forming a part of the enclosure need not be so equipped. The building official or the director of public works may make modifications in individual cases upon showing of good cause with respect to the height, nature or location of the fence, wall, gates or latches, or the necessity therefor, provided the protection as sought hereunder is not reduced thereby. The building official or the director of public works shall allow a reasonable period no greater than eight months from passing of the ordinance to bring all existing pools into compliance with the requirements of this section. Temporary soft-sided pools are exempt from this requirement, but are subject to the requirements under section 10-199. 
(Ord. No. 13-30, § 2, 8-26-2013) 
Sec. 10-201. - Enforcement authority; right to inspect; abatement of use. 
    The city is charged with the duty of enforcing this division. For this purpose, the city and its inspectors, inclusive of any building official or the director of public works, are authorized to enter any premises in the city to inspect any private outdoor swimming pool or temporary soft-sided pool at any reasonable hour. In the event of the failure of compliance after due notice with the rules and regulations and requirements of this division, the building official or the director of public works shall have the power to abate or cause a suspension of the use of such private outdoor swimming pool or temporary soft-sided pool until such time as the same is, in the opinion of the building official or the director of public works no longer a menace or hazard to health, safety or morals. The city may also cause the institution of an ordinance violation proceeding against the owner or occupant, as the case may be, seeking penalties pursuant to chapter 1, section 1-115 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Morrison, Illinois. 
(Ord. No. 13-30, § 2, 8-26-2013) 
Sec. 10-202. - Nonconforming uses. 
    In the event of conflict between this division and Chapter 3, Section 303, of the Inter national Property Maintenance Code, 2006, presently in force in the city, the requirements of this division shall control. 
(Ord. No. 13-30, § 2, 8-26-2013) 
Secs. 10-203-10-209. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - OUTDOOR WOOD FURNACES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 15-15, § 1, adopted Sep. 14, 2015, set out provisions intended for use as Div. 8, §§ 10-300-10-305. To preserve the style of this Code, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as Div. 8, §§ 10-210-10-216. 

Sec. 10-210. - Definitions. 
(a)  Outdoor wood furnace : Any equipment, device, appliance or apparatus, or any part thereof, which is installed, affixed or situated outdoors for the primary purpose of combustion of fuel to produce heat or energy used as a component of a heating system providing heat for any interior space or water source. An outdoor wood furnace may also be referred to as an outdoor wood boiler or outdoor wood-fired hydronic heater. 
(b)  Chimney: Flue or flues that carries off exhaust from an outdoor wood furnace firebox or burn chamber. 
(c)  EPA OWHH Phase II Program : EPA OWHH (Outdoor Wood-fired Hydronic Heater Program) Phase II Program administered by the United States Environmental Protection Agency. 
(d)  EPA OWHH Phase II Program Qualified Model : An outdoor wood-fired hydronic heater that has been EPA OWHH Phase II Program qualified. The model has met the EPA OWHH Phase II emission level and has the proper qualifying label and hangtag. 
(e)  Existing outdoor wood furnace : An outdoor wood furnace that was installed prior to the initial effective date of this division. 
(f)  Natural wood : Wood which has not been painted, varnished or coated with a similar material, has not been pressure treated with preservatives and does not contain resins or glues as in plywood or other composite wood products. 
(Ord. No. 15-15, § 1, 9-14-2015) 
Sec. 10-211. - Ban on outdoor wood furnaces. 
(a)  No person or business shall from the effective date of this division, install or construct an outdoor wood furnace. 
(Ord. No. 15-15, § 1, 9-14-2015) 
Sec. 10-212. - Regulations for existing outdoor wood furnaces. 
(a)  No person shall, from the effective date of this division, operate or maintain an existing outdoor wood furnace other than in compliance with the provisions of this division. 
(b)  No person shall, from the effective date of this division, operate an existing outdoor wood furnace unless such operation conforms with the manufacturer's instructions regarding such operation and the requirements of this division regarding fuels that may be burned in an outdoor wood furnace as set forth in section 15-702(a) of this division and conforms with chimney height requirements as set forth in section 15-702(d) and (f) of this division. 
(c)  All existing outdoor wood furnaces shall be operated and maintained in conformance with the manufacturer's instructions and the requirements of this division. In the event of a conflict, the requirements of this division apply unless the manufacturer's instructions are stricter, in which case the manufacturer's instructions shall apply. 
(d)  The owner of any replacement outdoor wood furnace shall produce the manufacturer's owner's manual or installation instructions to the building department for review, if requested. 
(e)  All outdoor wood furnaces shall be laboratory tested and listed to appropriate safety standards such as UL, CAN/CSA, ANSI or other applicable safety standards. 
(f)  Individuals using existing non-conforming outdoor wood furnaces, at the time of enactment of this division, shall within 12 months, bring such units into compliance with the standards imposed by this division. 
(g)  Individuals using existing conforming outdoor wood furnaces may in the future replace such units with new units, provided that an appropriate building permit is obtained and any new unit fully complies with all federal, state, or local requirements then applicable to such units. 
(Ord. No. 15-15, § 1, 9-14-2015) 
Sec. 10-213. - Substantive requirements. 
    Existing outdoor wood furnaces shall be operated and maintained pursuant to the following conditions: 
(a)  Fuels. 
(1)  Fuel burned in any existing outdoor wood furnace shall be limited to natural untreated wood, wood pellets, corn products, biomass pellets or other listed fuels specifically permitted by the manufacturer's instructions, such as fuel oil, natural gas or propane backup. 
(2)  The following fuels are strictly prohibited for use and combustion in existing outdoor wood furnaces: 
a.  Wood that has been painted, varnished or coated with similar material and/or which has been pressure treated with preservatives or which contains resins or glues as, for example, in plywood or other composite wood products. 
b.  Rubbish or garbage, including but not limited to food wastes, food packaging, or food wraps. 
c.  Any plastic materials, including but not limited to nylon, PVC, ABS, polystyrene or urethane foam, and synthetic fabrics, plastic films and plastic containers. 
d.  Rubber including tires or other synthetic rubber-like products. 
e.  Newspaper, cardboard, or any paper with ink or dye products. 
f.  Any other items not specifically allowed by the manufacturer or this provision. 
(d)  Chimney heights for existing outdoor wood furnaces. 
(1)  The chimney of any outdoor wood furnace shall extend at least two feet above the peak of any residence not served by the outdoor wood furnace which is located within 300 feet of such outdoor wood furnace, measured from the nearest point on the unit to the nearest point on the structure of the residence. 
(2)  If a residence not served by the outdoor wood furnace is constructed within 300 feet of an outdoor wood furnace previously installed, as measured in subsection 1, then the owner of such outdoor wood furnace shall conform to the chimney height requirements of this division within 30 days of the date construction of the residence is complete and upon written notice from the building official. 
(e)  Setbacks for EPA OWHH Phase II Program qualified models. 
(1)  The outdoor wood furnace shall be maintained at least 25 feet from the property line. 
(2)  The outdoor wood furnace shall be maintained on the property in compliance with manufacturer's recommendations and/or testing and listing agency requirements for clearance from combustible materials. 
(f)  Chimney heights for EPA OWHH Phase II Program Qualified models . 
(1)  The chimney of any EPA OWHH Phase II Program qualified model shall extend to the higher of: (i) at least two feet above the peak of the residence which it serves if neighboring residences not served by such a furnace are located within 100 feet; or (ii) the chimney shall extend at least two feet above the peak of any residence not served by such furnace which is located within 100 feet, measured from the nearest point on the unit to the nearest point on the structure of the residence 
(2)  Outdoor furnaces that use only corn, wood pellets or other pelletized biomass shall meet the same setback and chimney height requirements as EPA OWHH Phase II Program qualified models. 
(Ord. No. 15-15, § 1, 9-14-2015) 
Sec. 10-214. - Appeals. 
    Appeals from any action, decision, or ruling of the building official or a request for a variance from the strict application of the specific requirements of this division shall be made to the city council. Requests for all appeals shall be made in writing to the office of the city clerk not later than 30 days of the act, decision, or ruling from which relief is sought. 
(a)  Appeals fees : Appeals fees shall be established by city council resolution. 
(b)  Public hearing : A hearing shall be scheduled at a regular city council meeting to be held within 60 days following the written request for appeal, with the time to be fixed by resolution of the city council, and notice of the time and place of the hearing shall be given to the appellant and to any residence located within 300 feet of the location of the wood burning furnace to which the appeal relates. The appellant shall be required to notify all such persons, and shall exhibit proof to the city council, at the time of the hearing, that the notice has been given as required by this paragraph. Failure of the appellant to notify necessary parties shall be cause for the city council to dismiss the appeal. The notice shall be given in writing and delivered either personally or by certified mail, return receipt acknowledged. Notice shall be given at least 15 days in advance of the hearing date as scheduled. 
(c)  Decision of city council. The city council shall issue its decision within 14 days of the hearing on the appeal, and such decision shall be deemed a final administrative ruling subject to review under the terms and provisions of the Illinois Administrative Review Act (735 ILCS 5/3-101 et. seq.). 
(d)  Criteria for variances . In making its determination, the city council shall take into consideration the benefit to the applicant if the variance is granted, as weighed against the detriment to the neighborhood or community by such grant. In making such determination the council shall consider: 
(1)  Whether an undesirable change will be produced in the character of the neighborhood or a detriment to nearby properties will be created by the granting of the variance; 
(2)  Whether the benefit sought by the applicant can be achieved by some method, feasible for the applicant to pursue, other than a variance; 
(3)  Whether the requested variance is substantial; 
(4)  Whether the alleged difficulty was self-created, which consideration shall be relevant to the decision of the city council, but shall not necessarily preclude the granting of the variance. 
(Ord. No. 15-15, § 1, 9-14-2015) 
Sec. 10-215. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  Any person who shall violate any provision of this division shall be guilty of a petty offense and shall upon conviction be subject to a fine of not more than $750.00. Each week of continued violation shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(b)  If the building official or other officer or agent with proper authority determines that any outdoor wood furnace has been installed or is being operated in a manner which violates or does not conform to the requirements of this division, then the building official shall order modifications to be made to the unit so that the unit conforms to the requirements of this division, or shall order that the owner cease and desist operating the outdoor wood furnace in the manner which does not comply with the requirements of this division. 
(Ord. No. 15-15, § 1, 9-14-2015) 
Sec. 10-216. - Civil proceedings. 
    Compliance with this division may also be compelled and violations restrained by order or by injunction of a court of competent jurisdiction. Any person who violates any provision of this law shall also be subject to a civil penalty of not more than $750.00, to be recovered by the city in a civil action, and each week of continued violation shall be for this purpose a separate and distinct violation. In the event the city is required to take legal action to enforce this division, the violator shall be responsible for any and all necessary costs relative thereto, including attorneys' fees. 
(Ord. No. 15-15, § 1, 9-14-2015) 
Secs. 10-217-10-221. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BUILDING PERMITS AND CERTIFICATES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-222. - Building permits. 
(a)  Building permit required. 
(1)  No building or structure shall hereafter be erected or structurally altered until a building permit shall be issued by the city stating that the building or structure and use of land comply with the regulations of this chapter and all building and health laws and ordinances of the city. The duration of such permit shall be no more than 12 consecutive months from date of issuance. An extension may be provided if requested in writing and a justifiable cause is demonstrated. Extensions shall be granted in writing by the building official. 
(2)  If the proposed excavation or construction as set forth in the building permit application is in conformity with the provisions of this chapter and other ordinances of the city, the zoning administrator shall issue a building permit for such excavation or construction. If a building permit is refused, the zoning administrator shall state such refusal in writing, with the cause, and shall immediately forward such notice of refusal to the applicant. The zoning administrator shall grant or deny the permit within a reasonable amount of time from the date the application is submitted. 
(b)  Plat must accompany application. All applications for building permit shall be accompanied by a plat, in duplicate, drawn to accurate dimensions, showing the actual dimensions of the lot to be built upon, the height and bulk of the building or structure to be erected or structurally altered, its location on the lot, all off-street parking and loading facilities and access aisles, any and all drainage patterns and landscaping, and such other information as may be necessary to provide for the enforcement of these regulations. A careful record of such applications and plats shall be kept in the office of the city clerk. 
(c)  Permit fee required. To partially defray the expenses of administrating this chapter, a fee shall be charged for each permit issued and shall be collected by the city clerk at the city hall. The amount of the fee shall be as provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1977, § 17.52.020A; Ord. No. 06-04, 2006) 
Sec. 10-223. - Certificate of compliance. 
(a)  Certificate required. No building or structure hereafter erected or structurally altered shall be occupied and used until the zoning administrator has issued a certificate of compliance. The certificate of compliance shall be issued only after the zoning administrator makes a finding that the building or structure has been erected or structurally altered in conformance with the provisions of this chapter and other health and building laws and in accordance with a building permit. 
(b)  Issuing and recording certificates. Certificates of compliance shall be issued within ten days after the erection and alterations of such building shall have been satisfactorily completed. A record of all certificates shall be kept on file in the office of the zoning administrator and copies shall be available to any person having proprietary or tenancy interest in the building affected. 
(c)  Fee. The fee for issuance of certificates of compliance shall be as provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1977, § 17.52.020B; Ord. No. 06-04, 2006) 
Sec. 10-224. - Certificate for change of use. 
(a)  Certificate for change of use. No change shall be made in the use of a building or part thereof, now or hereafter erected or structurally altered, or in the use of land now or hereafter occupied, without a certificate of change of use having first been issued by the zoning administrator. No such certificate shall be issued to make such change unless it is in conformity with the provisions of this chapter and amendments thereto, hereafter duly enacted. 
(b)  Continuance of existing uses. Nothing in this section shall prevent the continuance of the present occupancy or lawful use of any existing building or zoning lot, except as may be necessary for the safety of life and property. 
(c)  Fee. The fee for issuance of certificates of change of use shall be as provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1977, § 17.52.020B; Ord. No. 06-04, 2006) 
Sec. 10-225. - Work begun before issuance of permit. 
    Any person who commences any work on a building, structure, electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing, etc., system before obtaining the necessary permits, shall be subject to a penalty in the amount provided in the city penalty schedule in addition to the required permit fees. 
Sec. 10-226. - Work authorized. 
    A building, electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing permit shall carry with it the right to construct or install the work, provided the same are shown on the drawings and set forth in the specifications filed with the application for the permit. Where these are not shown on the drawings and covered by the specifications submitted with the application, separate permits shall be required. 
Sec. 10-227. - Minor repairs. 
    Ordinary minor repairs may be made with the approval of the building official without a permit, provided that such repairs shall not violate any of the provisions of the technical codes. 
Sec. 10-228. - Application; fee; filing; information required. 
    Each application for a permit, with the required fee, shall be filed with the building official on a form furnished for that purpose, and shall contain a general description of the proposed work and its location. The application shall be signed by the owner, or his authorized agent. The building permit application shall indicate the proposed occupancy of all parts of the building and of that portion of the site or lot, if any, not covered by the building; or structure, and shall contain such other information as may be required by the building official. 
Secs. 10-229-10-251. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DRAWINGS AND SPECIFICATIONS 

Sec. 10-252. - Requirements. 
    When required by the building official, two or more copies of specifications, and of drawings drawn to scale with sufficient clarity and detail to indicate the nature and character of the work, shall accompany the application for a permit. Such drawings and specifications shall contain information, in the form of notes or otherwise, as to the quality of materials, where quality is essential to conformity with the technical codes. Such information shall be specific, and the technical codes shall not be cited as a whole or in part, nor shall the term "legal" or its equivalent be used, as a substitute for specific information. All information, drawings, specifications and accompanying data shall bear the name and signature of the person responsible for the design. 
Sec. 10-253. - Additional data. 
    The building official may require details, computations, stress diagrams, and other data necessary to describe the construction or installation and the basis of calculations.
