(4)  The garage or shed must be on a single family lot and be accessory to an existing principle structure on the same lot. 
(5)  Below the base flood elevation, the garage or shed must be built of materials not susceptible to flood damage. 
(6)  All utilities, plumbing, heating, air conditioning and electrical must be elevated above the flood protection elevation. 
(7)  The garage or shed must have at least one permanent opening on each wall not more than one foot above grade with one square inch of opening for every one square foot of floor area. 
(8)  The garage or shed must be less than $10,000.00 in market value or replacement cost, whichever is greater or less than 500 square feet. 
(9)  The structure shall be anchored to resist floatation and overturning. 
(10)  All flammable or toxic materials (gasoline, paint, insecticides, fertilizers, etc.) shall be stored above the flood protection elevation. 
(11)  The lowest floor elevation should be documented and the owner advised of the flood insurance implications. 
(Ord. No. 10-12, § 7, 10-12-2010) 
Sec. 18-26. - Subdivision requirements. 
    The city shall take into account hazards, to the extent that they are known, in all official actions related to land management use and development. 
(1)  New subdivisions, manufactured home parks, annexation agreements, planned unit developments, and additions to manufactured home parks and subdivisions shall meet the damage prevention and building protections standards of sections 18-24 and 18-25. Any proposal for such development shall include the following data: 
a.  The base flood elevation and the boundary of the floodplain, where the base flood elevation is not available from an existing study, the applicant shall be responsible for calculating the base flood elevation; 
b.  The boundary of the floodway, when applicable; and 
c.  A signed statement by a licensed professional engineer that the proposed plat or plan accounts for changes in the drainage of surface waters in accordance with the Plat Act (765 ILCS 205/2). 
(2)  Streets, blocks lots, parks and other public grounds shall be located and laid out in such a manner as to preserve and utilize natural streams and channels. Wherever possible, the floodplains shall be included within parks or other public grounds. 
(Ord. No. 10-12, § 8, 10-12-2010) 
Sec. 18-27. - Public health and other standards. 
(a)  Public health standards must be met for all floodplain development. In addition to the requirements of sections 18-24 and 18-25, the following standards apply: 
(1)  No development in the floodplain shall include locating or storing chemicals, explosives, buoyant materials, flammable liquids, pollutants, or other hazardous or toxic materials below the flood protection elevation unless such materials are stored in a floodproofed and anchored storage tank and certified by a professional engineer or floodproofed building constructed according to the requirements of section 18-25. 
(2)  Public utilities and facilities such as sewer, gas and electric shall be located and constructed to minimize or eliminate flood damage. 
(3)  Public sanitary sewer systems and water supply systems shall be located and constructed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of floodwaters into the systems and discharges from the systems into floodwaters. 
(4)  New and replacement on-site sanitary sewer lines or waste disposal systems shall be located and constructed to avoid impairment to them or contamination from them during flooding. Manholes or other above ground openings located below the flood protection elevation shall be watertight. 
(5)  Construction of new or substantially improved critical facilities shall be located outside the limits of the floodplain. Construction of new critical facilities shall be permissible within the floodplain if no feasible alternative site is available. Critical facilities constructed within the SFHA shall have the lowest floor (including basement) elevated or structurally dry-floodproofed to the 500-year flood frequency elevation or three feet above the level of the 100-year flood frequency elevation, whichever is greater. Floodproofing and sealing measures must be taken to ensure that toxic substances will not be displaced by or released into floodwaters. Access routes elevated to or above the level of the base flood elevation shall be provided to all critical facilities. 
(b)  All other activities defined as development shall be designed so as not to alter flood flows or increase potential flood damages. 
(Ord. No. 10-12, § 9, 10-12-2010) 
Sec. 18-28. - Carrying capacity and notification. 
(a)  For all projects involving channel modification, fill, or stream maintenance (including levees), the flood carrying capacity of the watercourse shall be maintained. 
(b)  In addition, the city shall notify adjacent communities, in writing, 30 days prior to the issuance of a permit for the alteration or relocation of the watercourse. 
(Ord. No. 10-12, § 10, 10-12-2010) 
Sec. 18-29. - Variances. 
    Whenever the standards of this article place undue hardship on a specific development proposal, the applicant may apply to the zoning board of appeals for a variance. The zoning board of appeals shall review the applicant's request for a variance and shall submit its recommendation to the city. The city may attach such conditions to granting of a variance as it deems necessary to further the intent of this article. 
(1)  No variance shall be granted unless the applicant demonstrates that all of the following conditions are met: 
a.  The development activity cannot be located outside the floodplain; 
b.  An exceptional hardship would result if the variance were not granted; 
c.  The relief requested is the minimum necessary; 
d.  There will be no additional threat to public health, safety or creation of a nuisance; 
e.  There will be no additional public expense for flood protection, rescue or relief operations, policing, or repairs to roads, utilities, or other public facilities; 
f.  The applicant's circumstances are unique and do not establish a pattern inconsistent with the intent of the NFIP; and 
g.  All other state and federal permits have been obtained. 
(2)  The zoning board of appeals shall notify an applicant in writing that a variance from the requirements of the building protection standards of section 18-25 that would lessen the degree of protection to a building will: 
a.  Result in increased premium rates for flood insurance up to $25.00 per $100.00 of insurance coverage; 
b.  Increase the risk to life and property; and 
c.  Require that the applicant proceed with knowledge of these risks and that the applicant acknowledge in writing the assumption of the risk and liability. 
(3)  Variances to the building protection requirements of section 18-25 which are requested in connection with reconstruction, repair, or alteration of a historic site or historic structure, as defined in this article, may be granted using criteria more permissive than the requirements of sections 18-24 and 18-25 subject to the conditions that: 
a.  The repair or rehabilitation is the minimum necessary to preserve the historic character and design of the structure. 
b.  The repair or rehabilitation will not result in the structure being removed as a certified historic structure. 
(Ord. No. 10-12, § 11, 10-12-2010) 
Sec. 18-30. - Disclaimer of liability. 
    The degree of protection required by this article is considered reasonable for regulatory purposes and is based on available information derived from engineering and scientific methods of study. Larger floods may occur or flood heights may be increased by manmade or natural causes. This article does not imply that development either inside or outside of the floodplain will be free from flooding or damage. This article does not create liability on the part of the city or any officer or employee thereof for any flood damage that results from proper reliance on this article or any administrative decision made lawfully thereunder. 
(Ord. No. 10-12, § 12, 10-12-2010) 
Secs. 18-31-18-68. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FLOOD HAZARD AREA REGULATIONS 

Sec. 18-69. - Purpose of provisions; standards adopted. 
    The purpose of this article is to avoid the hazards to persons and damage to property resulting from flooding and to comply with the rules and regulations of the National Flood Insurance Program as promulgated by the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development, Federal Insurance Administration as provided in 44 CFR 31177 et seq., and which are adopted by reference, and filed in the office of the city clerk, pursuant to state law. 
(Code 1977, § 16.20.010; Ord. No. 636, § 1, 1977) 
Sec. 18-70. - Effect on other provisions. 
    The provisions of this article shall be deemed as additional requirements to minimum standards required by other ordinances of the city. In case of conflicting requirements, the most restrictive shall apply. 
(Code 1977, § 16.20.020; Ord. No. 636, § 2, 1977) 
Sec. 18-71. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Base flood means the flood having a one-percent chance of being equaled or exceeded in any given year. The base flood is also known as the 100-year flood. 
    Base flood elevation means the elevation in relation to mean sea level of the crest of the base flood. 
    Development means any manmade change to improved or unimproved real estate, including, but not limited to, construction of or substantial improvements to buildings or other structures, the placement of mobile homes, mining, dredging, filling, grading, paving, excavation, or drilling operations. 
    Flood or flooding means a general and temporary condition of partial or complete inundation of normally dry land areas from the overflow of inland waters, or the unusual and rapid accumulation or runoff of surface waters from any source, all of which renders the inundated area unusable and untenable during said inundation. 
    Mobile home means a structure transportable in one or more sections which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities. For the purpose of this article, the term "mobile home" does not include recreational vehicles or travel trailers. 
    Structure means a walled and roofed building including a gas or liquid storage tank that is principally above ground, as well as a mobile home and a prefabricated building. 
    Substantial improvement means any repair, reconstruction or improvement of a structure the cost of which equals or exceeds 50 percent of the market value of the structure either before the improvement or repair is started or, if the structure has been damaged and is being restored, before the damage occurred. The term "substantial improvement" does not, however, include the following: 
(1)  Any project for improvement of a structure to comply with existing state or local health, sanitary, or safety code specifications which are solely necessary to assure safe living conditions; or 
(2)  Any alteration of a structure or site documented as deserving preservation by the Illinois Department of Conservation or listed on the National Register of Historic Places. 
(Code 1977, § 16.20.030; Ord. No. 636, § 3, 1977) 
Sec. 18-72. - Flood hazard boundary map. 
    The Flood Hazard Boundary Map No. H01, dated November 7, 1975, and amendments thereto, delineating A zones as areas that are susceptible to the base flood as prepared by the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development, Federal Insurance Administration, is adopted for the purpose of this article and filed as a record in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1977, § 16.20.040; Ord. No. 636, § 4, 1977) 
Sec. 18-73. - Permit-Required. 
    No person shall commence any construction, substantial improvement, subdivision of land, placement of mobile homes, or other development in areas located in an A zone without first obtaining a permit from the office of the city clerk. The city clerk shall not issue such permit for any construction, substantial improvement, or other development that does not comply with the provisions of this article or that has been denied a permit required by federal or state law including section 404 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, 33 USC 1334 et seq. 
(Code 1977, § 16.20.050; Ord. No. 636, § 5, 1977) 
Sec. 18-74. - Same-Application; certification. 
(a)  Within areas designated as A zones, each application for development shall be accompanied by elevations, in relation to mean sea level, of the lowest habitable floor, including basement and, in the case of floodproofed structures, the elevation to which it will be floodproofed. 
(b)  The city clerk shall require certification from a registered professional engineer or architect that floodproofing methods are adequate to withstand the flood depths, pressures, velocities, impact and uplift forces, and other factors associated with the base flood. 
(Code 1977, § 16.20.060; Ord. No. 636, § 6, 1977) 
Sec. 18-75. - Base flood elevation data. 
    The city council shall obtain, review, and reasonably utilize base flood elevation data available from federal, state, or other sources until such time as such data has been received from the Federal Insurance Administration. Base flood data received from the Federal Insurance Administration shall take precedence over data from other sources. 
(Code 1977, § 16.20.070; Ord. No. 636, § 7, 1977) 
Sec. 18-76. - Standards of construction and substantial development. 
    All new construction and substantial improvements to structures located in an A zone shall meet the following standards: 
(1)  For residential structures, have the lowest floor, including basement, elevated to one foot above the base flood elevation, unless a variance is granted by the zoning board of appeals; 
(2)  For nonresidential structures, have the lowest floor, including basement, elevated or floodproofed to one foot above the base flood elevation, unless a variance is granted by the zoning board of appeals; 
(3)  Be designed or modified and adequately anchored to prevent flotation, collapse, or lateral movement of the structure; 
(4)  Be constructed with utility equipment resistant to flood damage; 
(5)  Be constructed by methods and practices that minimize flood damage to other properties; 
(6)  Have all structural components below the base flood elevation, designed to be watertight with walls substantially impermeable to the passage of water; and such structural components shall be designed to resist hydrostatic and hydrodynamic loads and the effects of buoyancy. 
(Code 1977, § 16.20.080; Ord. No. 636, § 8, 1977) 
Sec. 18-77. - Mobile home standards. 
    All mobile home parks and mobile home subdivisions located in an A zone shall file evacuation plans indicating vehicular access and escape routes, including mobile home hauler routes, with the appropriate disaster preparedness authorities. All mobile homes to be placed on a site located in an A zone shall meet the following standards: 
(1)  Have the lowest floor elevated one foot above the base flood elevation; 
(2)  In the instance of elevation on pilings, have all piling foundations placed in stable soil no more than ten feet apart; and reinforcement shall be provided for piers more than six feet above ground; 
(3)  Have lots large enough to permit steps to the mobile home, and have adequate surface drainage on all sides of the structure; 
(4)  Be placed to prevent flotation, collapse, or lateral movement of the structure due to flooding; 
(5)  Be anchored according to the following specifications: 
a.  Over-the-top ties shall be provided at each of the four corners of the mobile home, with two additional ties per side at intermediate locations; and mobile homes less than 50 feet long shall require one additional tie per side; 
b.  Frame ties shall be provided at each corner of the mobile home with five additional ties per side at intermediate points; and mobile homes less than 50 feet long shall require four additional ties per side; 
c.  All components of the anchoring system shall be capable of carrying 4,800 pounds; and 
d.  Any additions to the mobile home shall be similarly anchored. 
(Code 1977, § 16.20.090; Ord. No. 636, § 9, 1977) 
Sec. 18-78. - Utilities. 
    All new construction and substantial improvements to utilities located in an A zone shall provide that: 
(1)  All new and replacement water supply systems shall be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of floodwaters into the systems. 
(2)  All new and replacement sanitary sewage systems shall be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of floodwaters into the systems and discharges from the systems into the floodwaters. 
(3)  All new and replacement on-site waste disposal systems shall be located to avoid impairment to them or contamination from them during flooding. 
(Code 1977, § 16.20.100; Ord. No. 636, § 10, 1977) 
Sec. 18-79. - Subdivisions and developments. 
    All subdivisions and other developments located in an A zone shall provide that: 
(1)  All subdivision and other development proposals shall be designed to minimize flood damage to the proposed subdivision or development site as well as to other properties. 
(2)  All public utilities and facilities, such as sewer, gas, electrical, and water systems shall be located, elevated, and constructed to minimize or eliminate flood damage. 
(3)  Adequate drainage shall be provided so as to reduce exposure to flood hazards. 
(4)  For any proposed subdivision or new development greater than 50 lots or five acres, whichever is the lesser, the applicant shall show the base flood elevation data for each lot or platted parcel; provided, that if the base flood elevation data is not available, the applicant shall compute and provide this information for each lot or platted parcel greater than 50 lots or five acres, whichever is less. 
(Code 1977, § 16.20.110; Ord. No. 636, § 11, 1977) 
Sec. 18-80. - Watercourses. 
    The city clerk shall notify adjacent communities and the state department of transportation, division of water resources, and the Federal Insurance Administration prior to any alteration or relocation of a watercourse. The flood-carrying capacity within the altered or relocated portion of any watercourse shall be maintained. 
(Code 1977, § 16.20.120; Ord. No. 636, § 13, 1977) 
Sec. 18-81. - Reports and recordkeeping. 
(a)  The city clerk shall provide the city council, the state department of transportation, division of water resources, and the Federal Insurance Administration with an annual report on forms as provided the city by the Federal Insurance Administration. 
(b)  The city clerk shall maintain the records of first-floor elevations, floodproofing certifications, all variance documents required by the Rules and Regulations of the National Flood Insurance Program, permit applications, and all other records required by the Federal Insurance Administration. 
(Code 1977, § 16.20.130; Ord. No. 636, § 14, 1977) 
Sec. 18-82. - Variances. 
    Upon application and after 15 days' notice of a public hearing, the city council may grant a variance of this article subject to compliance with the provisions of section 1910.6(a) of the Rules and Regulations of the National Flood Insurance Program and such other conditions as the city council deems necessary to comply with the intent of this article. 
(Code 1977, § 16.20.140; Ord. No. 636, § 15, 1977) 
Sec. 18-83. - Nonliability of city. 
    The degree of flood protection required by this article is considered reasonable for regulatory purposes and is based on engineering and scientific methods of study. Larger floods may occur on rare occasions or the flood height may be increased by manmade or natural causes. This article does not imply that development either inside or outside of areas designated as an A zone will be free from flooding or damage. This article does not create liability on the part of the city or any officer or employee thereof for any flood damage that results from reliance on this article or any administrative decision made lawfully thereunder. 
(Code 1977, § 16.20.150; Ord. No. 636, § 16, 1977)

Footnotes:

State Law reference- Illinois Fire Protection Training Act, 50 ILCS 740/1 et seq.; Fire Department Promotion Act, 50 ILCS 742/1 et seq.; Firemen's Disciplinary Act, 50 ILCS 745/1 et seq.; Volunteer Emergency Worker Job Protection Act, 50 ILCS 748/1 et seq.; authority for municipal fire departments, 65 ILCS 5/11-6-1; board of police and fire commissioners, 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-1; hours, wages, and working conditions of police officers and firefighters, 65 ILCS 5/10-3-1; municipal fire safety regulations, 65 ILCS 5/11-8-1 et seq.

ARTICLE IV. - FIRE REGULATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 22-71-22-91. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FLAMMABLES 

Sec. 22-92. - Storage restrictions-Generally. 
    No person shall keep or store within the city any gasoline, coal oil, petroleum, or any of the products thereof, in any greater quantity within one building than five barrels, or tanks of 50 gallons each, except when stored in approved tanks. 
(Prior Code, § 285; Code 1977, § 8.16.010) 
Sec. 22-93. - Same-Within fire limits. 
    No person shall keep or store within the fire limits of the city any gasoline, coal oil, petroleum, or any of the products thereof, in any greater quantity within one building, including the basement or cellar thereof, than one barrel, the same to be kept in a closed metallic can, or outside any building within the fire limits in any greater quantity than five barrels, unless the same be kept in an approved metallic tank, made for that purpose, buried in the ground so that the top thereof is at least two feet under the surface of the ground. Any person selling coal oil in the regular course of trade may keep not to exceed two barrels thereof in good, safe, and substantial metal casks or reservoirs in his building or cellar. 
(Prior Code, § 286; Code 1977, § 8.16.020) 
Sec. 22-94. - Handling restrictions within fire limits. 
    No gasoline, coal oil, petroleum, or any of the products thereof, shall be kept or stored in front of any building within the fire limits of the city, nor on any street or alley, lot, or sidewalk within the fire limits for a longer time than is sufficient to receive and store or deliver the same, provided that such time shall not exceed 24 hours. 
(Prior Code, § 287; Code 1977, § 8.16.030) 
Sec. 22-95. - Permit-When required. 
    If any person desires to store or keep any gasoline, coal oil, petroleum, or any of its products in any greater quantity than five barrels or tanks of 50 gallons each, they shall apply to the city council for a permit, under the regulations in this division. 
(Prior Code, § 288; Code 1977, § 8.16.040) 
Sec. 22-96. - Same-Application. 
    All applications for permits shall be in writing and shall state the place where it is proposed to store the oil, the character of the oil to be stored, the quantity of each kind, and the size and character of the vats or tanks in which it is to be placed. 
(Prior Code, § 291; Code 1977, § 8.16.050) 
Sec. 22-97. - Same-Inspection required. 
    No permit shall be granted unless the proposed installation has been inspected by the fire warden and he has given his report in writing to the council upon the same. 
(Prior Code, § 292; Code 1977, § 8.16.060) 
Sec. 22-98. - Same-Issuance; fee; nontransferability. 
    Upon the granting of the permit by the council, the clerk shall issue a written permit and deliver the same to the applicant upon such applicant paying to the clerk the permit fee and the clerk's administrative fee for issuing such permit in the amounts provided in the city fee schedule. No such permit shall be transferable. 
(Prior Code, § 293; Code 1977, § 8.16.070) 
Sec. 22-99. - Five-barrel limit when. 
    No permit shall be granted for the storage of more than five barrels of said class of oil within the fire limits of the city, unless the same is to be stored in underground tanks as required in this division. 
(Prior Code, § 290; Code 1977, § 8.16.080) 
Sec. 22-100. - Oil stations prohibited in residential areas; exception. 
    No person shall be granted any permit for the storage or sale of gasoline, coal oil, petroleum, or any of its products at a place commonly known as an oil station, within the limits of the city, in any residence district or in any block where the major portion of the real estate is occupied for residence purposes, unless the application for such permit is accompanied by the petition of the owners of the land representing more than one-half of the frontage on each side of the street or avenue where the oil station is to be located, for a distance of not less than 300 feet on each side of the location where the oil station is to be located, agreeing and consenting that the permit may be granted. These requirements shall be in addition to any zoning provisions. 
(Prior Code, § 289; Code 1977, § 8.16.090) 
Sec. 22-101. - Boiling flammable substances prohibited except under certain conditions. 
    No person shall boil any pitch, resin, coal tar, or other flammable liquid or substance, except in a fireproof building or in some open space at least ten feet distant from any building or other property likely to be endangered thereby. 
(Prior Code, § 279; Code 1977, § 8.12.160) 
Sec. 22-102. - Revocation of permit. 
    Permits issued pursuant to this division shall be revoked in the event the permitee violates any provision of this division. 
(Prior Code, § 294; Code 1977, § 8.16.100) 
Secs. 22-103-22-132. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - FIREWORKS 

Sec. 22-133. - Permit required. 
    No person shall fire, discharge or set off any rocket, cracker, torpedo, squib or other fireworks, or any substance of any explosive nature, unless the city council, by order, authorizes the issuance of a permit therefor. Upon authorization by the city council, the city clerk shall issue a fireworks display permit upon such terms and conditions as are directed by the council, upon payment by the permittee of the clerk's administrative fee and permit fee as provided in the city fee schedule. 
State Law reference- Authority of municipalities to regulate storage of fireworks, 65 ILCS 5/11-8-4; Fireworks Regulation Act of Illinois, 425 ILCS 30/1 et seq. 
Chapter 24 - HEALTH AND SANITATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Public health generally, 410 ILCS 2/1 et seq.; Smoke Free Illinois Act, 410 ILCS 82/1 et seq.; Indoor Air Quality Act, 410 ILCS 87/1 et seq.; territorial jurisdiction of health and quarantine ordinances, 65 ILCS 5/7-4-1; municipal authority to promote health and to suppress disease, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-5; municipal regulation as to food, water, disease, etc., 65 ILCS 5/11-20-2 et seq.; municipal authority to license, tax and regulate eating places, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-5. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 24-1-24-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PROHIBITED ACTS AND SUBSTANCES 

Sec. 24-19. - Animal slaughter prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to carry on, maintain, or operate, within the limits of the city, the business of slaughtering animals; and the same is declared to be a nuisance. No person shall maintain or operate any house or place wherein the business of slaughtering animals is carried on. 
(Prior Code, § 430; Code 1977, § 8.12.070) 
Sec. 24-20. - Unwholesome foods prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person, within the limits of the city, to sell or dispose of any flesh of any diseased animal for food, or sell any unwholesome provisions, pernicious, or adulterated food or drink of any kind. 
(Prior Code, § 431; Code 1977, § 8.12.080) 
Sec. 24-21. - Deposits in water prohibited. 
(a)  Polluting waters of local waterways. No person shall throw, place or deposit, or cause to be thrown, placed or deposited, or permit his servant, child or other member of his family to throw, place or deposit into any street, alley, lot, public way or public ground, or upon the margin or banks of or into the waters of any public waterway, within the city any putrid or unsound beef, pork, fish, hides or skins of any kind, or any filth, offal, dung, dead animals, decomposed vegetables or any other unsound, putrid, filthy, decomposed, unwholesome or offensive matter whatsoever, or any substance liable to become unwholesome, filthy, decomposed or offensive or prejudicial or injurious to health. 
(b)  Obstruction or pollution of watercourses or sources of water supply. It is unlawful and a nuisance for any person to obstruct or pollute any watercourse or source of water supply in the city. 
(c)  Stagnant pools of water. Any stagnant pool of water in such city is declared to be a nuisance. It is unlawful for any person to permit any such nuisance to remain or exist on property under his control. 
(Prior Code, § 432; Code 1977, § 8.12.090; Ord. No. 88-2, 1988) 
Sec. 24-22. - Offensive substances prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person, within the city, to suffer any putrid flesh, fish, hides, skins, offal, dung, stable refuse, hog manure, dead animals, decayed vegetables, or other offensive substances to remain upon the premises occupied by him for the period of 24 hours after being notified by the mayor, chief of police, or other officer of the city, to remove the same. Every day that such offensive matter or thing remains unremoved after notice shall constitute a new offense. 
(Prior Code, § 433; Code 1977, § 8.12.100) 
Sec. 24-23. - Unwholesome businesses prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person, within the limits of the city, or within the distance of 11/2 miles outside the limits of the city, by himself or another, either as principal or agent, to locate, carry on, or operate any offensive or unwholesome business or establishment, or to leave or deposit within said prohibited territory any carcass or dead animal which, by putrefaction or decomposition, may be liable to become offensive. Each 24 hours' violation of this section shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Prior Code, § 435; Code 1977, § 8.12.120) 
Chapter 26 - HISTORIC PRESERVATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Historic Preservation Act, 20 ILCS 3405/1 et seq.; conflicts of historic preservation regulations with energy conservation regulations, 50 ILCS 515/4; Local Historian Act, 50 ILCS 130/0.01 et seq.; authority for appointment of local historian, 50 ILCS 130/1; Local Land Resource Management Planning Act, 50 ILCS 805/1 et seq.; Historical Sites Listing Act, 20 ILCS 3415/0.01 et seq.; directional and official signs regarding historical sites, 225 ILCS 440/4.01; authority of municipalities to regulate landmarks and historic sites, 65 ILCS 5/11-13-1; authority of municipalities for preservation of historical and other special areas, 65 ILCS 5/11-48.2-1; municipal planning, zoning and urban rehabilitation, 65 ILCS 5/11-11-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 26-1. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to promote the protection, enhancement, perpetuation, and use of structures of special character or historical interest or value for the quality of life, prosperity, safety, and welfare of the people of the city by: 
(1)  Providing a mechanism to identify and preserve the historic and architectural characteristics of the city which represents elements of the city's cultural, social, economic, political and architectural history; 
(2)  Promoting civic pride in the beauty and noble accomplishments of the past as represented in city's landmarks and historic districts; 
(3)  Stabilizing and improving the economic vitality and value of city's landmarks and historic areas; 
(4)  Protecting and enhancing the attractiveness of the city to draw buyers, visitors and shoppers and thereby supporting business, commerce, industry, and providing economic benefit to the city; 
(5)  Fostering and encouraging preservation, restoration of structures, areas, and neighborhoods and thereby preventing future urban blight. 
(Ord. No. 09-03, § II(2.88.010), 4-13-2009) 
Sec. 26-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Addition means any act or process which changes one or more of the "exterior architectural features" of a structure designated for preservation by adding to, joining with or increasing the size or capacity of the structure. 
    Alteration means any act or process that changes one or more of the exterior architectural, but not purely cosmetic, characteristics or interior stabilization features of a structure, including, but not limited to, the re-erection, construction, reconstruction, or removal of any part or all of a structure. 
    Area means a specified geographic portion of the city. 
    Building means any structure created for the support, shelter or enclosure of persons, animals or property of any kind and which is permanently affixed to the land. 
    Certificate of appropriateness means a certificate from the city historic preservation commission authorizing plans for alterations, construction, removal or demolition of a landmark or site within a designated historic district. 
    City hall means the central offices of the city's administration from where the city administrator, mayor and city council do business. 
    Commission means the city's historic preservation commission. 
    Commissioners mean the voting members of the city's historic preservation commission. 
    Construction means the act of adding an addition to an existing structure or the erection of a new principal or accessory structure on a lot or property. 
    Demolition means any act or process that destroys in part or in whole the significance of a landmark or site within a historic district. 
    Design guideline means a standard of appropriated activity that will preserve the historic and architectural character of a structure or area. 
    Excavation means the act of digging into, or adding upon, the land. 
    Exterior architectural appearance means the architectural and general composition of the exterior of a structure, including, but not limited to the kind, color, and the texture of the building material and the type, design and character of all windows, doors, light fixtures, signs, and appurtenant elements. 
    Historic district means an area designated as an historic district by the city council, pursuant to the procedures prescribed herein. 
    Landmark means any building, structure or site which has been designated as a landmark by the city council, pursuant to procedures prescribed herein. 
    Owner of record means the person, corporation, or other legal entity listed as owner on the records of the county recorder of deeds. 
    Reconstruction means the act of rebuilding a significant portion of an historic structure. 
    Rehabilitation means the process of returning a property to a state of utility, through repair or alteration, which makes possible an efficient contemporary use while preserving those portions and features of the property which are significant to its historic, architectural and cultural values. 
    Removal means any relocation of a structure on its site or to another site. 
    Renovation. See Rehabilitation. 
    Repair means any change that does not require a building permit or that is not construction, relocation, demolition or alteration. The term "repair" does not include cosmetic surface refreshment or regularly recurring and routine maintenance or replacement. 
    Restoration means the process of returning a property to its historic characteristics. 
    Structural change means any change or repair in the supporting members of a building, structure, roof or exterior walls which would expand the building in its height, width or bulk or would affect the structural strength of the building. 
    Structure means anything constructed or erected, the use of which requires permanent or temporary location on or in the ground, including, but without limiting the generality of the foregoing: buildings, fences, gazebos, advertising signs, bill boards, backstops for tennis courts, communication towers and antennas, including supporting towers, swimming pools, satellite dishes, solar panels and wind generation equipment. 
(Ord. No. 09-03, § II(2.88.020), 4-13-2009) 
Sec. 26-3. - Criteria for landmarks. 
    Any property located within the jurisdictional boundaries of the city historic preservation commission may be considered for designation as a landmark. The criteria, whether standing alone or in any combination thereof, for eligibility as a landmark are as follows: 
(1)  Significant value as part of the historic, heritage or cultural characteristics of the community, county, state, nation or world; 
(2)  Identification with a person who significantly contributed to the development of the community, county, state, nation or world; 
(3)  Representative of the distinguishing characteristics of architecture inherently valuable for the study of a period, type, method of construction or use of indigenous materials; 
(4)  Notable work of a master builder, designer, architect or artist whose individual work has influenced the development of the community, county, state, nation or world; 
(5)  Unique location or singular physical characteristics that make it an established or familiar visual feature; 
(6)  Character as a particularly fine or unique example of a utilitarian structure, including but not limited to farmhouses, barns, carriage houses, gas stations, or other commercial structures, with a high level of integrity or architectural significance; 
(7)  An area that has yielded or may be likely to yield, information important in history or prehistory. 
(Ord. No. 09-03, § II(2.88.040), 4-13-2009) 
Sec. 26-4. - Criteria for historic districts. 
    Any property located within the jurisdictional boundaries of the city historic preservation commission may be considered for designation as a historic district. The criteria, whether standing alone or in any combination thereof, for eligibility as a historic district are as follows: 
(1)  A defined geographic area that contains one or more landmarks along with such other buildings, places or areas within its definable geographic boundaries which, while not of such historic significance to be designated as landmarks, nevertheless contribute to the overall visual characteristics of the landmark or landmarks located in such district; 
(2)  A defined geographic area that contains a significant number of structures meeting any of the landmark designation criteria set forth in this article; 
(3)  A defined geographic area that establishes a sense of time and place unique to the city; 
(4)  A defined geographic area that exemplifies or reflects the cultural, social, economic, political or architectural history of the nation, the state, or the community. 
(Ord. No. 09-03, § II(2.88.040), 4-13-2009) 
Secs. 26-5-26-26. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DESIGNATION OF LANDMARKS AND HISTORIC DISTRICTS 

Sec. 26-27. - Authority of commission and persons to apply for designation. 
    Any person, group of persons or association, including, but not limited to the city historic preservation commission, including a member thereof, may apply for a landmark or an historic district designation for any structure, building, site or defined geographic area within the jurisdictional boundaries of the city historic preservation commission which may have historic or architectural significance as defined by this chapter. The commission shall develop and supply the application forms and make the same available at city hall. 
(Ord. No. 09-03, § II(2.88.040), 4-13-2009) 
Sec. 26-28. - Minimum contents of application for landmark designation. 
    At a minimum, the application for landmark designation shall include the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the property owner; 
(2)  The legal description and common street address of the property; 
(3)  A written statement describing the property and setting forth reasons in support of the proposed designation, including appropriate documentation; 
(4)  Documentation that the property owner has been notified or consents to the application for designation; 
(5)  A list of significant exterior architectural features that should be protected; 
(6)  Photographs of the landmark, and, where appropriate, site drawings including those of elevations. 
(Ord. No. 09-03, § II(2.88.040), 4-13-2009) 
Sec. 26-29. - Minimum contents of application for historic district designation. 
    At a minimum, the application for historic district designation shall include the following: 
(1)  A map delineating the boundaries of the area to be designated; 
(2)  The names and addresses of the property owners of all property within the boundaries of the proposed district; 
(3)  A written statement describing the area and properties within the historic district and setting forth reasons in support of the proposed designation, including appropriate documentation; 
(4)  A list and photographs of significant exterior architectural features of all properties in the district that should be protected. 
(Ord. No. 09-03, § II(2.88.040), 4-13-2009) 
Sec. 26-30. - Application processing procedure; fees. 
(a)  Completed forms applying for designation as a landmark or an historic district shall be submitted to the historic preservation commission by delivering the same to a member thereof or the city clerk, deputy clerk or the city's code inspection officer at city hall during regular business hours, together with a filing fee in the amount provided in the city fee schedule in chapter 20. 
(b)  Upon receiving an application duly submitted and in reasonably proper form, the historic preservation commission shall, at its next regularly scheduled meeting occurring at least seven days following the receipt of the application, consider the application and issue a preliminary approval or disapproval as to whether a property, structure, or defined geographic area possesses the qualifications for landmark or historic district designation as set forth in the section outlining the criteria therefor, and notify the applicant thereof. 
(Ord. No. 09-03, § II(2.88.040), 4-13-2009) 
Sec. 26-31. - Public hearing required; notice. 
(a)  Thereafter, the commission shall schedule a public hearing for a final determination within 60 days after the filing of an application. 
(b)  The commission shall take all reasonable efforts to discern all owners of record of a nominated landmark property or of all properties contained within a nominated historic district. Notice of date, time, place and purpose of the public hearing shall be sent by mail to owners of record and to the nominator not less than 15 days prior to the date of the hearing. A public hearing notice also shall be published in a newspaper having general circulation in the city. The notice shall state the location of the property and a statement summarizing how the proposed landmark or defined geographic area meets the criteria set forth in this chapter. 
(c)  During the public hearing, the commission shall review and evaluate the application according to the criteria established in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 09-03, § II(2.88.040), 4-13-2009) 
Sec. 26-32. - Determination; notice. 
(a)  A final decision shall be made within 90 days following the date of the close of the public hearing. 
(b)  At the conclusion of the hearing, if the commission finds that: 
(1)  The application merits further consideration but that more information or deliberation is needed, then the commission may table the request until its next regularly scheduled meeting. In so doing, the commission may advise the applicant of any additional information or material that would aid them in determining the merits of the application. 
(2)  The application is meritorious, it shall recommend landmark or historic district designation in the way of a resolution passed by a majority of the commission. 
(3)  The application is not meritorious, it shall deny the application. 
(c)  All such owners of record and the applicant shall be notified promptly by a letter containing information about the commission's final decision. 
(Ord. No. 09-03, § II(2.88.040), 4-13-2009) 
Sec. 26-33. - Review of commission determination by city council. 
(a)  Immediately following the final decision, the secretary of the commission shall, in addition to the resolution recommending designation, prepare the commission's evaluation, recommendation and all available information for submission to the city council within 30 days. 
(b)  Upon receipt of a resolution from the historic preservation commission recommending the designation of a landmark or historic district, the matter shall be placed on the next available agenda of the city council for action. 
(c)  A simple majority vote by the city council is necessary for approval of a landmark or historic district designation. If the city council approves the application for a designation, a notice will be sent by the city clerk to the applicant, the property owners, the code inspection officer, the city clerk's office, and recorded with the county recorder of deeds. If the city council denies the petition, no petitioner or applicant can file a subsequent application for the same property for 90 days following the council's denial. 
(Ord. No. 09-03, § II(2.88.040), 4-13-2009) 
Sec. 26-34. - Applications for properties for inclusion within or exclusion from established historic district. 
(a)  Any owner of property situated within an established historic district may apply to the historic preservation commission for exclusion of such property from the established historic district within the time limit established elsewhere in this Code, on or before December 31, 2012. Such application for exclusion shall include the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the property owner or owners; 
(2)  Satisfactory documentation of ownership of the property, including, but not limited to, a copy of the deed to the property showing current ownership of the property by the applicant or applicants; 
(3)  The common street address of the property; 
(4)  A written statement containing a general description of the property, including its present use, contemplated use, if applicable, and current photographs of the property illustrative of its condition and use; 
(5)  A written statement setting forth the applicant's reasons or basis for requesting exclusion of the property from the established historic district, with all appropriate documentation; 
(6)  The signature of the property owner, or the signatures of all owners in the event of multiple ownership, in support of the application. 
(b)  Upon receipt of an application duly submitted and in reasonably proper form, the commission shall, at its next regularly scheduled meeting occurring at least seven days following receipt of the application, consider the application and issue a preliminary approval or disapproval as to whether the property is appropriate for exclusion from the established historic district. The commission shall notify all applicants via U.S. mail of the date and time for the regularly scheduled meeting at which the application will be reviewed and discussed. 
(c)  In reaching its decision on the application, the commission may consider the following criteria: 
(1)  The nature and character of the property and structures thereon sought to be excluded, including any significant exterior or architectural features; 
(2)  The character of the area immediately surrounding such property, including the property's architectural and/or historical consistency with the area where situated; 
(3)  Whether the property has historical significance; 
(4)  Whether the property's exclusion from the historic district will have a detrimental impact on the overall purposes of the historic district; 
(5)  Whether the property's productivity or usefulness will be affected if excluded from the historic district; 
(6)  Whether the property otherwise contributes to the overall visual characteristics of the historic district; 
(7)  Any comments from the applicant or applicants or other interested parties in addition to those contained in the application presented at the meeting at which the application is being considered, subject to standing rules for public comment at such meetings. 
(d)  Any owner of property situated adjacent or contiguous to an established historic district may apply to the historic preservation commission for inclusion of such property within the established historic district. Such application shall include the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the property owner or owners; 
(2)  Satisfactory documentation of ownership of the property, including, but not limited to, a copy of the deed to the property showing current ownership of the property by the applicant or applicants; 
(3)  The common street address of the property; 
(4)  A written statement containing a general description of the property, including its present use, contemplated use, if applicable, and current photographs of the property illustrative of its condition and use; 
(5)  A written statement setting forth the applicant's reasons or basis for requesting inclusion of the property within the established historic district, with appropriate documentation; 
(6)  The signature of the property owner, or the signatures of all owners in the event of multiple ownership, in support of the application. 
(e)  Upon receipt of an application duly submitted and in reasonably proper form, the commission shall, at its next regularly scheduled meeting occurring at least seven days following receipt of the application, consider the application and issue a preliminary approval or disapproval as to whether the property is appropriate for inclusion within the established historic district. The commission shall notify the applicant via U.S. mail of the date and time for the regularly scheduled meeting at which the application will be reviewed and discussed. 
(f)  In reaching its decision on the application, the commission may consider the following criteria: 
(1)  The nature and character of the property and structures thereon sought to be included, including any significant exterior or architectural features; 
(2)  The character of the area immediately surrounding such property, including the property's architectural and/or historical consistency with the established historic district; 
(3)  Whether the property has historical significance; 
(4)  Whether the property's inclusion within the historic district will have a beneficial or detrimental impact on the overall purposes of the historic district; 
(5)  Whether the property's productivity or usefulness will be affected by inclusion within the historic district; 
(6)  Whether the property would contribute to the overall visual characteristics of the established historic district; 
(7)  Any comments from the applicant or applicants or other interested parties in addition to those contained in the application presented at the meeting at which the application is being considered, subject to standing rules for public comment at such meetings 
(g)  A decision for recommendation by the historic preservation commission shall be made within 30 days of the date of the meeting at which the application is considered. The secretary of the commission, in addition to the resolution recommending acceptance or denial of the application for exclusion from or inclusion within an historic district, shall prepare the commission's evaluation and recommendation and all related information for submission to the city council within 30 days. Upon receipt of such resolution from the historic preservation commission with its recommendation as to any such application, the matter shall be placed on the next available agenda of the city council for approval or disapproval of any such application. The decision of the city council shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 12-09, § 1, 2-27-2012) 
Secs. 26-35-26-54. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CERTIFICATES OF APPROPRIATENESS 

Sec. 26-55. - Required. 
(a)  A certificate of appropriateness (COA) issued by the commission shall be required: 
(1)  Before any building permit, moving permit, or demolition permit is issued for a designated landmark or any building, structure, site or landscape or part thereof in an historic district; or 
(2)  If a building, moving or demolition permit is not required, before any building, structure or site designated as a landmark or within an historic district will be altered, extended, repaired or excavated in such a manner as to produce a major change in the exterior appearance of such building, structure or site. Such major changes include, but are not limited to: 
a.  Major changes by addition, alteration, reconstruction, rehabilitation, renovation, repair or excavation that are not cosmetic surface refreshment or are not regularly recurring and routine maintenance or replacement; 
b.  Any new construction and demolition in whole or in part requiring a permit from the city; 
c.  Moving a building; 
d.  Any construction, alteration, demolition, or removal affecting a significant exterior architectural feature as specified in the ordinance designating the landmark or historic district. 
(b)  In the case of partial or complete natural destruction of a site or structure within an historic district or of a landmark, the owner will be required to obtain a certificate of appropriateness from the commission prior to reconstruction or repair. 
(c)  A certificate of appropriateness may also be issued if the applicant shows to the commission that the demolition, moving or building permit is necessary to prevent an imminent threat to life, health, or property. 
(Ord. No. 09-03, § II(2.88.050), 4-13-2009) 
Sec. 26-56. - Filing of application; forms; fees. 
(a)  Every application for a demolition, moving or building permit, including plans and specifications, that involves any building, structure or landscape that is either a landmark or within an historic district shall be accompanied by a request for a certificate of appropriateness, and a form for those requests are to be incorporated into all application forms for a building or demolition permit. 
(b)  Applications for demolition, moving or building permit shall be filed with the code inspection officer, and shall be accompanied by an application fee in the amount specified in the city fee schedule in chapter 20. If, as part of an application for demolition, moving or building permit, the application includes a request for a COA, the code inspection officer shall then forward the same to the commission within seven days following receipt of the application. 
(Ord. No. 09-03, § II(2.88.050), 4-13-2009) 
Sec. 26-57. - Contents of application. 
(a)  The application for a demolition, moving or building permit and for issuance of a COA must include: 
(1)  The street address of the property involved; 
(2)  The legal description of the property involved; 
(3)  A brief description of the present improvements situated on the property; 
(4)  A detailed description of the construction, alteration, demolition, excavation, move or use proposed together with any architectural drawings or sketches if those services have been utilized by the applicant and if not, a sufficient description of the construction, alteration, demolition, and use to enable a reasonable person to determine what final appearance and use of the real estate will be; 
(5)  The owner's name; 
(6)  The developer's name, if different than the owner; 
(7)  The architect's name, if applicable. 
(b)  If the request for a COA is being made to alleviate an imminent threat to life, health, or property, the application shall also include: 
(1)  A description of the alternatives for repair, rehabilitation or restoration; and 
(2)  The estimated costs of each such alternative. 
(Ord. No. 09-03, § II(2.88.050), 4-13-2009) 
Sec. 26-58. - Standards for consideration of application. 
    The standards applied by the commission for a certificate of appropriateness shall be: 
(1)  For demolition, addition, alteration, maintenance, rehabilitation, renovation or repair, the federal secretary of the interior's "Standards for Rehabilitation" as follows: 
a.  A property shall be used for its historic purpose or be placed in a new use that requires minimal change to the defining characteristics of the building and its site environment; 
b.  The historic character of a property shall be retained and preserved. The removal of historic materials or alteration of features and spaces that characterize a property shall be avoided; 
c.  Each property shall be recognized as a physical record of its time, place, and use. Changes that create a false sense of historical development, such as adding conjectural features or architectural elements from other buildings, shall not be undertaken; 
d.  Most properties change over time; those changes that have acquired historic significance in their own right shall be retained and preserved; 
e.  Distinctive stylistic features or examples of skilled craftsmanship that characterize a building, structure, or site shall be treated with sensitivity; 
f.  Deteriorated historic features shall be repaired rather than replaced. Where the severity of deterioration requires replacement of a distinctive feature, the new feature shall match the old in design, color, texture, and other visual qualities, and, where possible materials. Replacement of missing features shall be substantiated by documentary, physical, or pictorial evidence; 
g.  Chemical or physical treatments, such as sandblasting, that cause damage to historic materials shall not be used. The surface cleaning of the structures, if appropriate, shall be undertaken using the gentlest means possible; 
h.  Significant archaeological resources affected by a project shall be protected and preserved. If such resources must be disturbed, mitigation measures shall be undertaken; 
i.  New additions, exterior alterations, or related new construction shall not destroy historic materials that characterize the property. The new work shall be differentiated from the old and shall be compatible with the massing, size, scale, and architectural features to protect the historic integrity of the property and its environment; 
j.  New additions and adjacent or related new construction shall be undertaken in such a manner that if removed in the future, the essential form and integrity of the historic property and its environment would be unimpaired. 
(2)  For demolition due to an assertion of an imminent threat to life, health, or property: 
a.  That the property's present condition poses an immediate and impending peril to the safety of people or property within a zone of danger; 
b.  That all reasonable efforts have been made to discern the best available costs of repair, rehabilitation, restoration or movement; and 
c.  That the financial burdens of repair, rehabilitation, restoration or movement presented, when weighed against the inherent worth of perpetuation and the longer term economics of preservation, clearly and convincingly favor demolition. 
(3)  For reconstruction due to partial or complete natural destruction of a site or structure within a historic district or of a landmark, although exact duplication of the previous structure may not be required, the exterior design of the property shall be in harmony with the exterior design of the structure prior to damage, and, if applicable, the character of the historic district. 
(Ord. No. 09-03, § II(2.88.050), 4-13-2009) 
Sec. 26-59. - Architectural design criteria. 
    The standards provided in section 26-58 shall be, at a minimum, interpreted in light of the following architectural design criteria: 
(1)  Height. The height of any proposed alteration or construction should be compatible with the style and character of the landmark and with surrounding structures in a historic district. 
(2)  Proportions of windows and doors. The proportions and relationships between doors and windows should be compatible with the architectural style and character of the landmark. 
(3)  Relationship of building masses and spaces. The relationship of a structure within a historic district to the open space between it and adjoining structures should be compatible. 
(4)  Roof shape. The design of the roof, fascia, and cornice should be compatible with the architectural style and character of the landmark. 
(5)  Landscaping. Landscaping should be compatible with the architectural character and appearance of the landmark. 
(6)  Scale. The scale of the structure after alteration, construction, or partial demolition should be compatible with its architectural style and character and with surrounding structures in a historic district. 
(7)  Directional expression. 
a.  Facades in historic districts should blend with other structures with regard to directional expression. Structures in a historic district should be compatible with the dominant horizontal or vertical expression of surrounding structures. 
b.  The direction expression of a landmark after alteration, construction, or partial demolition should be compatible with its original architectural style and character. 
(8)  Architectural details. Architectural details including types of materials, colors, and textures should be treated so as to make the structure compatible with its original architectural style and character. 
(9)  Architectural styles. New structures within an historic district shall be compatible with the architectural styles of that district. 
(Ord. No. 09-03, § II(2.88.050), 4-13-2009) 
Sec. 26-60. - Public hearing required; time for giving notice. 
    The commission shall set a duly filed application for a certificate of appropriateness for consideration at a hearing, which, unless otherwise mandated by the timing requirements hereinafter, may take place at a regularly scheduled meeting of the commission: 
(1)  Within seven days of the receipt thereof if it contains an assertion that the demolition, moving or building permit is necessary to prevent an imminent threat to life, health, or property, and a public notice shall be given as reasonably as practicable; or 
(2)  Within 45 days of receipt of application if it does not contain an assertion that the demolition, moving or building permit is necessary to prevent an imminent threat to life, health, or property, and public notice for consideration of the application shall be made not less than 15 days nor more than 30 days before hearing, in a newspaper of general circulation published in the city. 
(Ord. No. 09-03, § II(2.88.050), 4-13-2009) 
Sec. 26-61. - Standards and criteria to be applied by commission. 
(a)  At the hearing to consider the application to issue a certificate of appropriateness, if the application contains an assertion that the demolition, moving or building permit is necessary to prevent an imminent threat to life, health, or property: 
(1)  The commission shall determine if, indeed, there is an imminent threat to life, health, or property, and, if so, the feasibility and cost of the reasonable alternatives of repair, rehabilitation or restoration; and 
(2)  Determine whether clearly and convincingly the threat outweighs the feasibility and costs of the inherent value of the preservation alternatives. 
(b)  If the application to issue a certificate of appropriateness does not contain an assertion that the demolition, moving or building permit is necessary to prevent an imminent threat to life, health, or property, the commission shall apply the standards set out in this article interpreting them, when necessary, using the criteria provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 09-03, § II(2.88.050), 4-13-2009) 
Sec. 26-62. - Conduct of hearing; recorded or written transcript required. 
    The hearing to determine whether or not a certificate of appropriateness shall be issued shall be conducted by the presiding officer of the commission. The applicant, the commission and any other interested party shall have the reasonable opportunity to present evidence, cross examine witnesses and make arguments thereto. A recorded or written transcript of the hearing shall be made and maintained by the commission. 
(Ord. No. 09-03, § II(2.88.050), 4-13-2009) 
Sec. 26-63. - Determination by commission. 
(a)  Meritorious application. At the conclusion of the hearing, if the commission finds that the application is meritorious it shall, by way of a resolution passed by a majority of the commission, direct the code inspection officer to issue a signed certificate of appropriateness on a form previously approved by the commission and notify the applicant of the decision within five days following the decision. 
(b)  Application meriting further consideration. If the commission finds that the application merits further consideration but that more information or deliberation is needed, then the commission may table the request until its next regularly scheduled meeting. In so doing, the commission may advise the applicant or other interested party of any additional information or material that would aid them in determining the merits of the application. 
(c)  Non-meritorious application. If the commission finds that the application is not meritorious, it shall deny the application in writing and provide written notification to the code inspection officer of such denial who shall thereupon also deny the effected demolition, moving or building permit. The commission shall also notify the applicant of the decision within five days following the decision which notification may include what changes, if any, in the proposed work that would cause the commission to reconsider its denial. 
(Ord. No. 09-03, § II(2.88.050), 4-13-2009) 
Sec. 26-64. - Submission of amended application. 
(a)  Within 14 days of receipt of the notification of disapproval the applicant may resubmit an amended application for a COA that, if applicable, may take into consideration the recommendations of the historic preservation commission. 
(b)  If no amended application is received within the 14-day period, the application for a COA shall be considered to be withdrawn. 
(c)  If an amended application for a COA is received within the 14-day period, the commission must, within 45 days of the receipt thereof, either issue a COA or hold a hearing in the same manner as provided herein for original applications. 
(Ord. No. 09-03, § II(2.88.050), 4-13-2009) 
Sec. 26-65. - Appeal of denial to city council. 
    In the event of a denial of an application for a certificate of appropriateness by the city historic preservation commission, the applicant may appeal the decision to the city council, whose decision in this matter shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 09-03, § II(2.88.050), 4-13-2009) 
Sec. 26-66. - Term of certificate. 
    A legitimately issued certificate of appropriateness remains valid: 
(1)  As long as its attendant demolition, moving or building permit is valid. If, for any reason, the attendant demolition, moving or building permit becomes invalid, then the certificate of appropriateness issued in conjunction therewith becomes invalid as well; 
(2)  As long as the work being performed on the building, structure or site conforms to that recited in the application for, and described in, the certificate of appropriateness. Should, at any time, the work being performed not conform to that recited in the application for, and described in, the certificate of appropriateness, the certificate of appropriateness becomes, by operation of this article, invalid. 
(Ord. No. 09-03, § II(2.88.050), 4-13-2009) 
Secs. 26-67-26-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CERTIFICATES OF ECONOMIC HARDSHIP 

Sec. 26-91. - Factors considered. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any of the provisions of this chapter to the contrary, the commission may issue a certificate of economic hardship to allow the performance of work for which a certificate of appropriateness has been denied. 
(b)  Applicants claiming economic hardship shall be required to apply to the commission to determine eligibility for a certificate of economic hardship. An applicant for a certificate of economic hardship may submit, and, whether submitted or not, the commission may consider, any or all of the following information in order to assist the commission in making its determination on the application: 
(1)  The amount paid for the property; 
(2)  The date of purchase and the party from whom purchased (including a description of the relationship, if any, between the owner and the person from whom the property was purchased); 
(3)  The assessed value of the land and improvements thereon according to the two most recent assessments; 
(4)  Real estate taxes for the previous two years; 
(5)  Remaining balance on mortgage, if any, and annual debt service, if any, for the previous two years; 
(6)  All appraisals obtained within the previous two years by the owner or applicant in connection with this purchase, financing or ownership of the property; 
(7)  Any listing of the property for sale or rent, price asked and offers received, if any; 
(8)  Any consideration by the owner as to profitable adaptive uses for the property; 
(9)  If the property is income-producing, the annual gross income from the property for the previous two years, itemized operating and maintenance expenses for the previous two years, and annual cash flow before and after debt service, if any during the same period; 
(10)  Form of ownership or operation of the property, whether sole proprietorship, for-profit or not-for-profit corporation, limited partnership, joint venture or other; 
(11)  The eligibility for and availability of public or private financial aid, grants or loans; 
(12)  Any other information, including the income-tax bracket of the owner, applicant, or principal investors in the property, reasonably necessary for a determination as to whether the property can be reasonably used or yield a reasonable return to present or future owners. 
(Ord. No. 09-03, § II(2.88.060(A), (B)), 4-13-2009) 
Sec. 26-92. - Denial of application. 
    If the commission finds that the property owner can obtain a reasonable economic return or realizes a practical value without the proposed work, then it shall: 
(1)  Deny the request for a certificate of economic hardship; 
(2)  Notify the owner of such denial in writing within seven days thereof stating the reasons for the denial; 
(3)  Notify the code inspection officer of the denial. 
(Ord. No. 09-03, § II(2.88.060(C)), 4-13-2009) 
Sec. 26-93. - Delay of application if property value affected; investigation; recommendation. 
(a)  If the commission finds that without approval of the proposed work, the property owner cannot obtain a reasonable economic return or realize a practical value therefrom, then the application shall be delayed for a period not to exceed three months. 
(b)  During this three-month period of delay, the commission shall investigate plans and make written findings and recommendations to the city council to allow for a reasonably beneficial use, a reasonable economic return, or to otherwise preserve the subject property. Such plans and recommendations may include, but not be limited to: 
(1)  A relaxation of the provisions of this chapter; 
(2)  A reduction in real property taxes; 
(3)  Financial assistance; 
(4)  Exceptions to the requirements of any building code; or 
(5)  Variances in zoning regulations. 
The city council may then take any action they feel appropriate to address the recommendations of the commission. 
(c)  If by the end of this three-month period, the commission has found that without approval of the proposed work, even taking into account any action taken by the city council, the property cannot be put to a reasonable beneficial use or the owner cannot obtain a reasonable economic return therefrom, then the commission shall direct the issuance a certificate of economic hardship approving the proposed work and notify the code inspection officer. 
(Ord. No. 09-03, § II(2.88.060(D)), 4-13-2009) 
Sec. 26-94. - Appeal of approval or denial of certificate. 
(a)  When a certificate of economic hardship is approved or denied for either a landmark or a structure or site within an historic district, the applicant or any interested party may, within 30 days, appeal the commission's decision to the city council. The council may receive comments on the contents of the record but no new matter may be considered by the council. The city council may affirm the decision or recommend changes by a majority vote of the council after due consideration of the facts contained in the record submitted to the council by the commission. The council may overturn the commission's decision by a majority vote of a quorum of the council. If the council decides that a certificate of economic hardship should be issued, the secretary shall notify the applicant and the code inspection officer within seven days of the council's decision who shall then issue the permit within 15 days. 
(b)  If the council concurs with the commission's decision not to issue a certificate of economic hardship, the secretary shall notify the applicant and the code inspection officer within seven days. 
(Ord. No. 09-03, § II(2.88.060(E), (F)), 4-13-2009) 
Sec. 26-95. - Penalties and enforcement. 
    Any person who undertakes or causes an alteration, construction, demolition, excavation or removal of any nominated or designated landmark or property within a nominated or designated landmark or designated historic district without a COA shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished by a fine in the amount provided in the city penalty schedule in chapter 20. The city historical preservation commission may also request any appropriate action or proceeding in the name of the city to enjoin, correct, or abate any violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 09-03, § II(2.88.070), 4-13-2009) 
Secs. 26-96-26-118. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - BUILDING IMPROVEMENT PROGRAM 

Sec. 26-119. - Established. 
    There is hereby established the building improvement program which is designed to offer a means of assisting property owners in refurbishing buildings that have been designated either a landmark or are located within an historic district. It is the goal of the program to improve aesthetic appeal and focus on the historic character of a structure thus increasing community pride and awareness of these structures and their relevance to our past, present and future. It is hoped that the outcome will increase property values and benefit the city's economic base. 
(Ord. No. 09-03, § II(2.88.080(A)), 4-13-2009) 
Sec. 26-120. - Purpose; reimbursement to property owners. 
    Under the guidelines of the program which is administered by the Historic preservation commission, the city will reimburse property owners up to 50 percent of the cost of eligible building improvements taking into consideration the budgetary line items allocated to them for that purpose. When warranted by special circumstances, as determined by historic preservation commission, a request for reimbursement that exceeds 50 percent of the eligible building improvements may be referred to the city council for consideration and approval. The historic preservation commission shall have no authority to approve reimbursement above the aggregate annual amount allocated to them for these purposes. 
(Ord. No. 09-03, § II(2.88.080(B)), 4-13-2009; Ord. No. 18-21, § 2, 8-10-2018) 
Sec. 26-121. - Program eligibility and qualification. 
(a)  Any building designated as a landmark or located within an historic district is eligible for program benefits. 
(b)  In order to qualify for the receipt of funds, the proposed improvement must be consistent with the historic characteristics and historic period of the building. 
(c)  Projects such as replacement or new installation of awnings, exterior painting, and general facade improvements will be given priority consideration for participation. 
(d)  Funds may be limited by budgetary constraints and are awarded, after eligibility and qualification are established, on a first-come, first-served basis. 
(Ord. No. 09-03, § II(2.88.080(C)), 4-13-2009) 
Sec. 26-122. - Procedural steps. 
(a)  A property owner must submit a request to participate on the form developed by the commission calling for information the commission deems pertinent and made available at city hall during regular business hours. 
(b)  Upon review and approval of the request to participate by not less than two members, the commission will issue a notice of approval to the property owner which shall state the maximum amount that can be awarded. 
(c)  Following project completion, the property owner must submit a request for reimbursement along with a copy of the paid invoice to a city employee at city hall during regular business hours for processing. 
(d)  The council will include the request for reimbursement at their next meeting immediately following the submission of the request at which the request can be properly included on the agenda. 
(e)  Upon approval by the council, a check to the property owner in the approved amount shall be issued. 
(Ord. No. 09-03, § II(2.88.080(D)), 4-13-2009)

Chapter 30 - LAW ENFORCEMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to provide police protection and public order, 65 ILCS 5/11-1-1; requirement that municipal police department comply with the Minor Identification and Protection Act, 65 ILCS 5/11-1-10. Illinois Police Training Act, 50 ILCS 705/1 et seq.; Peace Officer Firearm Training Act, 50 ILCS 710/0.01 et seq.; Law Enforcement Salary Grant Act, 50 ILCS 715/0.01 et seq.; Uniform Peace Officers' Disciplinary Act, 50 ILCS 725/1 et seq.; auxiliary police officers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-30-20; part-time police officers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-30-21; hours, wages, and working hours of policemen and firemen, 65 ILCS 5/10-3-1; board of police and fire commissioners, 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-1; police defined, 5 ILCS 70/1.20. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 30-1-30-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - POLICE DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 30-19. - Established; personnel. 
(a)  The police department shall consist of the police chief, sergeant, and as many patrol officers as may be deemed necessary to carry out the responsibilities of the department and as are authorized by the council. 
(b)  Police department personnel shall be classified employees of the city and shall be subject to all city personnel policies, regulations and procedures. 
(Code 1977, § 2.28.010; Ord. No. 00-24, § 1, 2000; Ord. No. 92-10, art. 1, 1992; Ord. No. 85-4, §§ 1, 5, 1985) 
Sec. 30-20. - Powers.
