    All personnel within the classified position of the police department shall possess all the powers and authority of a constable at common law under the statutes of the state in preserving the peace, in maintaining order, and in enforcing and executing the ordinances and orders of the council and the orders of the mayor, and the board of health. 
(Code 1977, § 2.28.020; Ord. No. 85-4, §§ 1, 5, 1985) 
State Law reference- Powers and duties of municipal police officers, 65 ILCS 5/11-1-2; police pursuit guidelines, 50 ILCS 705/7.5. 
Sec. 30-21. - Duties. 
    It shall be the duty of the members of the police department to protect and defend the constitutions of the United States and the state; to enforce all laws, statutes, and ordinances of the federal, state, and municipal governments; to investigate all crimes and arrest the perpetrators, to serve all warrants and court documents, when the same have been duly issued; to preserve the peace, dignity, and general safety of the residents of the city; to regulate traffic and the functions thereof within the city; to assist the fire department and all other city departments as may be required. 
(Code 1977, § 2.28.030; Ord. No. 85-4, §§ 1, 5, 1985) 
State Law reference- Powers and duties of municipal police officers, 65 ILCS 5/11-1-2; police pursuit guidelines, 50 ILCS 705/7.5. 
Sec. 30-22. - Selection and appointment of police chief. 
    The police chief shall be selected on the basis of merit from among qualified candidates screened and evaluated by the city administrator and appointed committee. The police chief shall be appointed by the city administrator with advice and consent of the mayor and council. 
(Code 1977, § 2.28.040; Ord. No. 92-10, art. 1, 1992; Ord. No. 85-4, §§ 1, 5, 1985) 
State Law reference- Qualifications for appointment of full-time police officers, 50 ILCS 705/8.1; qualifications for appointment as part-time police officer, 50 ILCS 705/8.2; criminal background investigations of police applicants, 50 ILCS 705/10.2; municipal authority for appointment of part-time police officers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-30-21; mandatory training for police chief and deputy police chief, 50 ILCS 705/10.7; appointment of municipal officers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-30-5. 
Sec. 30-23. - Authority to summon aid. 
    Any member of the police department may at any time, and shall, when necessary, call upon any able-bodied person above the age of 18 years to assist in the arrest, retaking, or holding in custody of any person guilty of having committed an unlawful act, or charged therewith, or to aid such officer or member of the police department in the prevention of an unlawful act. 
(Code 1977, § 2.28.050; Ord. No. 85-4, §§ 1, 5, 1985) 
Sec. 30-24. - Uniforms and badges. 
    All personnel of the police department shall wear uniforms as designated by the council. All members shall wear the appropriate star or badge of office, and shall possess appropriate identification when wearing such. 
(Code 1977, § 2.28.060; Ord. No. 85-4, §§ 1, 5, 1985) 
State Law reference- False law enforcement badges, 720 ILCS 5/3-5.2-5. 
Sec. 30-25. - Employment of part-time police. 
(a)  Employment. The City of Morrison may employ part-time police officers from time to time as is necessary. 
(b)  Duties. A part-time police officer shall have all the responsibilities of a full-time police officer and such specific duties as are delineated in the general orders of the Morrison Police Department. The number of hours a part-time police officer may work within a calendar year should be restricted to less than 1,000. Part-time police officers shall not be assigned to supervise or direct full-time police officers. Part-time police officers shall be trained in accordance with the Illinois Police Training Act (50 ILCS 705/1 et seq.) and the rules and requirements of the Illinois Law Enforcement Training and Standards Board. 
(c)  Hiring standards. Any person employed as a part-time police officer must meet the following standards: 
(1)  Be of good moral character, of temperate habits, of sound health, and physically and mentally able to perform assigned duties. 
(2)  Be at least 21 years of age. 
(3)  Pass a medical examination. 
(4)  Possess a high school diploma or GED certificate. 
(5)  Possess a valid State of Illinois driver's license. 
(6)  Possess no prior felony convictions. 
(7)  Any individual who has served in the U.S. military must have been honorably discharged. 
(d)  Discipline. Part-time police officers shall be under the disciplinary jurisdiction of the chief of police. Part-time police officers serve at the discretion of the chief of police, shall not have any property rights in said employment, and may be removed by the chief of police at any time for any reason. Part-time police officers shall comply with all applicable rules and general orders issued by the Morrison Police Department. 
(Ord. No. 11-1, § 2.28.070, 3-14-2011; Ord. No. 12-17, § 1, 5-14-2012) 
Chapter 32 - MANUFACTURED AND MOBILE HOMES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to regulate mobile homes and other portable dwelling structures, 65 ILCS 5/11-5-8; Mobile Home Park Act, 210 ILCS 115/1 et seq.; requirements for compliance with municipal ordinances, 220 ILCS 115/10.2; municipal authority to remove and disposed of abandoned mobile home, 210 ILCS 117/15; municipal licensing of mobile home parks, 210 ILCS 115/18; requirement for use of municipal sewer system where available, 210 ILCS 115/9.5. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 32-1. - Purpose and intent. 
    For the purpose of promoting the public health, safety, morals, comfort, and general welfare; and providing for adequate water, sanitary sewage facilities, and other necessary facilities for the comfort and convenience of persons occupying mobile homes in the city; and in order to regulate and restrict the location of mobile homes and mobile home parks and to regulate the operation, size, the sanitary facilities and density of mobile home parks and mobile homes in the city, the regulations set forth in this chapter are imposed. 
(Code 1977, § 14.04.010; Ord. No. 581, art. I, § 1, art. III, § 1, 1971) 
Sec. 32-2. - Effect of state law. 
    Any requirements contained in this chapter shall not be less stringent than those required by the state law and the rules and regulations of the state department of public health, adopted pursuant to authority contained therein. 
(Code 1977, § 14.04.020; Ord. No. 581, art. VI, 1971) 
Sec. 32-3. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Administrative office means the office of the city designated to administer. 
    Dependent mobile home means a mobile home which does not have toilet and bath or shower facilities. The same are specifically prohibited in and upon mobile home parks within the city. 
    Independent mobile home means a mobile home with self-contained toilet and bath or shower facilities. 
    Licensee means the mobile home park operator and owner. 
    Manufactured home refers to any home that is not site-built and includes, but is not limited to, mobile homes. 
    Mobile home means a structure designed for permanent habitation and so constructed as to permit its transport on wheels, temporarily or permanently attached to its frame, from the place of its construction to the location, or subsequent locations, at which it is intended to be a permanent habitation and designed to permit the occupancy thereof as a dwelling place for one or more persons, provided that any such structure served by individual utilities and resting on a permanent foundation, with wheels, tongue and hitch permanently removed, shall not be construed as a mobile home. 
    Mobile home lot, space or site means a unit of drained ground of definite size clearly indicated by corner markers and lot numbers for the placing of a mobile home or tow car. 
    Mobile home park means a tract of land or two or more contiguous tracts of lands upon which five or more independent mobile homes are located for permanent habitation either free of charge or for revenue purposes, and shall include any building, structure, tent, vehicle, or enclosure used or intended for use as a part of the equipment of such mobile home park. 
    School district means any district created or operated under the provisions of the school code. 
    Service building means a building housing communal toilet, laundry, or other sanitary facilities necessary for the health and convenience of mobile home occupants. 
Sec. 32-4. - Enforcement and inspection authority. 
    The administrative officer shall enforce the provisions of this chapter and the rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto affecting health, sanitation, water supply, sewage, garbage, and waste disposal; and the administrative officer shall cause to be inspected at least once each year each mobile home park and all the accommodations and facilities connected therewith. Such officials or officers are granted the power and authority to enter upon the premises of such mobile home parks in conformity with the provisions of this Code and by state law. 
(Code 1977, § 14.20.010; Ord. No. 581, art. V, 1971) 
Sec. 32-5. - Regulation promulgation authority. 
    The administrative officer may issue rules and regulations necessary to carry out the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1977, § 14.20.020; Ord. No. 581, art. V, 1971) 
Sec. 32-6. - Compliance with provisions required. 
    Each mobile home park licensed or to be constructed under the provisions of this chapter shall be and remain in full compliance with the provisions of this chapter and with all other applicable provisions of this Code and state and federal law. 
(Code 1977, § 14.16.010; Ord. No. 581, art. III, § 2(G), 1971) 
Sec. 32-7. - Moving of mobile homes older than five years of age prohibited. 
    It is unlawful to move into the city, or to move from one location to another location within the city, any mobile home more than five years of age. 
Secs. 32-8-32-32. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PERMITS AND LICENSES 

Sec. 32-33. - Required permits and licenses; fee generally. 
(a)  Construction. No person shall construct any mobile home park in the city. 
(b)  Alteration. No person shall alter a mobile home park in the city without first obtaining a permit therefor from the city. The fees associated with a permit for alteration of a mobile home park include a nonrefundable application fee and a permit issuance fee. 
(c)  Operation. No person shall establish, maintain, conduct, or operate a mobile home park in the city without first obtaining a license therefor from the city. Fees associated with licenses hereunder, as more specifically provided in this article, include a nonrefundable application fee and annual license and inspection fees. 
(d)  Single application. Where a permit to construct as well as an original license to operate is sought by the applicant, a request therefor shall be made in the same application, and only one nonrefundable application fee shall be required. 
(e)  Fees. All fees referred to in this article shall be in the amounts provided in the city fee schedule in chapter 20. 
(Code 1977, § 14.12.010; Ord. No. 581, art. III, § 2(A), (F), 1971) 
Sec. 32-34. - Application for permit to alter mobile home park; application fee; exceptions. 
(a)  No change in any sanitary facilities, methods of water supply, sewer, drainage, garbage or waste disposal, and no change in the plot shall be made without first making a written application to the administrative office and receiving a written permit therefrom. The application shall be made in the manner set forth in this article. 
(b)  Each application for a permit to alter a mobile home park shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable application fee in the amount provided in the city fee schedule in chapter 20 for each ten acres or fraction thereof used to harbor mobile homes thereon. 
(c)  No application fee shall be required to accompany an application for a permit to alter a mobile home park where such alteration involves only a reduction in the number of mobile home spaces to a number less than such mobile home park is currently licensed for. 
(d)  All changes to mobile home parks shall comply with such safety and sanitary code, building codes, rules and regulations as are applicable thereto. 
(e)  A permit issued pursuant to this section does not relieve the applicant from securing building permits or from complying with any city zoning or other ordinance or resolutions applicable thereto. 
(Code 1977, § 14.12.050; Ord. No. 581, art. III, § 2(C), 1971) 
Sec. 32-35. - Annual license and inspection fees. 
(a)  In addition to application and permits fees, the licensee shall pay to the administrative office on or before April 30 of each year an annual license fee plus an inspection fee for each occupied mobile home space in a mobile home park in the city. 
(b)  Each license fee and inspection fee shall be paid to the administrative office and any license fee or inspection fee or any part thereof, once paid to and accepted by the administrative officer shall not be refunded. 
(c)  The administrative officer shall deposit all funds under this section in the general fund of the city treasury. 
(Code 1977, § 14.12.060; Ord. No. 619, § 1, 1975; Ord. No. 581, art. III, § 2(D), 1971) 
Sec. 32-36. - Application record. 
    When the administrative officer has approved an application for a permit to make alterations upon a mobile home park or the appurtenances thereto or a license to operate and maintain the same, he shall retain the original and keep a file thereof, and one copy shall be returned to the applicant or his agent and one copy to the city clerk. 
(Code 1977, § 14.12.070; Ord. No. 581, art. III, § 2(H), 1971) 
Sec. 32-37. - Suspension and revocation. 
(a)  Any license shall be subject to revocation or suspension by the administrative officer. However, the administrative officer shall first serve or cause to be served upon the licensee a written notice in which shall be specified the way in which such licensee has failed to comply with the statute, or any rules or regulations promulgated by the city pertaining thereto. The notice shall require the licensee to remove or abate such nuisance or insanitary or objectionable condition specified in the notice within five days or within a longer period of time as may be allowed by the administrative office. 
(b)  If the licensee fails to comply with the terms and conditions of the notice within the time specified or such extended period of time, the administrative officer may revoke or suspend such license. 
(Code 1977, § 14.12.100; Ord. No. 581, art. III, § 2(E), 1971) 
Sec. 32-38. - Nontransferability. 
    All licenses to operate and all permits to make alterations therein shall be prominently displayed in the office of the mobile home park. All licenses issued under this chapter are nontransferable without the written consent of the administrative officer; provided, however, that the administrative officer may not withhold such consent where the provisions of this chapter have been met. 
(Code 1977, § 14.12.110; Ord. No. 581, art. III, § 2(F), 1971) 
Sec. 32-39. - Recordkeeping. 
    The administrative office shall keep a record of all mobile home parks. The records shall show the names and addresses of all mobile home parks, names and addresses of the licensees, number of mobile home lots in each park, source of water supply, system of sewage and garbage disposal, and any other information deemed essential by the city. 
(Code 1977, § 14.12.080; Ord. No. 581, art. III, § 2(I), 1971) 
Secs. 32-40-32-66. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MOBILE HOME PARK REGULATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 32-67-32-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - APPLICABILITY OF OTHER REGULATIONS 

Sec. 32-91. - Conflict with zoning regulations. 
    In the event regulations provided in this article conflict with provisions of the zoning provisions contained in this Code, the zoning provisions shall prevail. 
Sec. 32-92. - Compliance with building and zoning regulations required. 
    All buildings constructed or altered, all plumbing, and all electrical and heating installations shall be in accordance with existing city building and zoning ordinances and rules of the administrative office. 
(Code 1977, § 14.16.110; Ord. No. 581, art. III, § 2(G)(9), 1971) 
Sec. 32-93. - Health rules; posting. 
    The city shall supply licensees of all mobile home parks with any and all health rules and regulations pertaining thereto made by the city and any changes that may be made from time to time which shall be posted and kept posted by the management in a protected, conspicuous place within the mobile home park. 
(Code 1977, § 14.12.090; Ord. No. 581, art. III, § 2(I), 1971) 
Secs. 32-94-32-114. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DESIGN AND FACILITIES SPECIFICATIONS 

Sec. 32-115. - Sanitary location required. 
    No mobile home park shall be so located that the drainage of the park area will endanger any water supply. All such parks shall be well-drained and shall be located in areas free from ponds, swamps, and similar places in which mosquitoes may breed. No wastewater from mobile homes shall be deposited on the surface of the ground. 
(Code 1977, § 14.16.030; Ord. No. 581, art. III, § 2(G)(2)(a), 1971) 
Sec. 32-116. - Minimum lot dimensions; off-street parking. 
(a)  Each mobile home shall be allotted a site of not less than 3,600 square feet in area, with a minimum width of 40 feet and a minimum depth of 90 feet. No mobile home shall be parked closer than five feet to the rear lot line of the mobile home lot or closer than ten feet to a public street, alley, or building. Each mobile home parked on or before November 10, 1982, shall have an open space of at least ten feet between the side of every mobile home and at least ten feet between the ends of every mobile home. After November 10, 1982, each mobile home pad constructed shall provide an open space of at least 20 feet between the sides of every mobile home and at least ten feet between the ends of every mobile home. No mobile home shall occupy more than one-fourth of the square footage of each lot. 
(b)  Suitable off-street parking shall be provided at the rate of two auto spaces for each mobile home lot. 
(Code 1977, § 14.16.040; Ord. No. 82-2, 1982; Ord. No. 581, art. III, § 2(G)(2)(b), (c), 1971) 
Sec. 32-117. - Water supply. 
    An adequate supply of water of safe, sanitary quality, approved by the state department of health shall be furnished at each mobile home park. Where water from other sources than that supplied by a city or village is proposed to be used, the source of such supply shall first be approved by the state department of health. If any portion of the mobile home park is located within 300 feet of city water service lines, all homes and facilities in the park shall be required to connect to the city water service. 
(Code 1977, § 14.16.050; Ord. No. 581, art. III, § 2(G)(3), 1971) 
Sec. 32-118. - Laundry room and service buildings. 
    A laundry room shall be provided containing laundry trays to accommodate the patrons of the mobile home park. No laundry trays shall be located in toilet or bathrooms. An adequate supply of hot and cold water shall be provided at all times in the service buildings for all bathing, washing, cleansing and laundry facilities. 
(Code 1977, § 14.16.060; Ord. No. 581, art. III, § 2(G)(4), 1971) 
Sec. 32-119. - Sewage disposal. 
(a)  All sewage and other water-carried wastes shall be disposed of into a municipal sewage system whenever available. In mobile home parks in which such connections are not available, disposal shall be into a private system which includes a sanitary means of disposal, the operation of which creates neither a nuisance nor a menace to health, which shall be approved by the administrative office. 
(b)  When a water carriage system of sewage is used, each mobile home site shall be provided with outlet or outlets of each mobile home. It shall be the duty of the owner or operator of the mobile home park to provide an approved type of water and odor-tight connection from the mobile home water drainage to the sewer connection, and it shall be the duty of the owner or operator to make such connection and keep all occupied mobile homes connected to the sewer while located in a mobile home park. Sewer connections in unoccupied mobile home sites shall be so closed that they will emit no odors or cause a breeding place for insects. No water or waste shall be allowed to fall on the ground from a mobile home. 
(c)  If any portion of the mobile home park is located within 300 feet of city wastewater service lines, all homes and other facilities within the park shall be required to connect to the city sewer system. 
(Code 1977, § 14.16.070; Ord. No. 581, art. III, § 2(G)(5), 1971) 
Sec. 32-120. - Garbage disposal; control of rodents and insects. 
(a)  A sufficient number of adequate fly-proof and watertight containers shall be supplied for the storage of garbage except where an adequate incinerator is provided. 
(b)  Garbage containers shall be emptied at least every seven days and shall not be filled to overflowing or allowed to become foul smelling, or a breeding place for insects. 
(c)  Garbage and rubbish shall be disposed of in a manner which creates neither a nuisance nor a menace to health and which is approved by the administrative officer. 
(d)  Adequate insect-control and rodent-control measures shall be employed. All buildings shall be fly-proof and rodent-proof and rodent harborages shall not be permitted to exist in the park. 
(Code 1977, § 14.16.080; Ord. No. 581, art. III, § 2(G)(6), 1971) 
Sec. 32-121. - Electrical outlets and extensions. 
    Electrical outlets for each individual mobile home site shall be in compliance with all state and local electrical codes and ordinances. No connected electric extension cord shall lie on the ground or be suspended less than seven feet from the ground above sidewalks or pathways. 
(Code 1977, § 14.16.090; Ord. No. 581, art. III, § 2(G)(7), 1971) 
Sec. 32-122. - Porches, canopies, and kindred extensions. 
    Temporary porches, auxiliary rooms, and canopies shall be permitted only when said proposed structures are of manufactured metal, or other fireproofed materials designated for such use and constructed on a foundation at least 12 inches above grade level. 
(Code 1977, § 14.16.100; Ord. No. 581, art. III, § 2(G)(8), 1971) 
Sec. 32-123. - Streets and driveways. 
    All streets and driveways in every mobile home park must be constructed with stormwater drains when necessary and be improved with a minimum of seven inches of compacted crushed rock. 
(Code 1977, § 14.16.130; Ord. No. 581, art. III, § 2(J)(2), 1971) 
Secs. 32-124-32-144. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - REPORTS 

Sec. 32-145. - Reports of health afflictions required. 
    It shall be the duty of every owner, operator, or attendant of any mobile home park to report to the administrative officer or the city health officer the full name, age and address of every person who is infected or suspected of being infected with any reportable or communicable disease. 
(Code 1977, § 14.16.140; Ord. No. 581, art. III, § 2(J)(3), 1971) 
Sec. 32-146. - Report to school boards required. 
    It shall be the duty of each licensee on February 1 and September 1 of each year to file with the school board of the school district wherein the mobile home park is located a report giving the names and ages of all children of school age living in the mobile home park. 
(Code 1977, § 14.16.120; Ord. No. 581, art. III, § 2(J)(1), 1971) 
Sec. 32-147. - Inspection of records by school officials. 
    The governing body of the school district in which a mobile home park is located, by and through its officer, attendance officers, and proper employees, may inspect and visit a mobile home park for the purposes of examining the register, with reference to children of school age for the purpose of enforcing attendance of school children housed in the mobile home park. When a mobile home park is located in two or more school districts, the school district boards of the district, acting jointly, are authorized to proceed under the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1977, § 14.16.170; Ord. No. 581, art. III, § 2(L), 1971) 
Secs. 32-148-32-177. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - MAINTENANCE AND MANAGEMENT RESPONSIBILITIES 

Sec. 32-178. - Maintenance responsibility. 
    The management of every mobile home park shall assume full responsibility for maintaining in good repair and condition all sanitary and safety appliances in the park and shall promptly bring such action as is necessary to prosecute or eject from the park any person who willfully or maliciously damage such appliances, or any person who fails to comply with the regulations of this chapter. 
(Code 1977, § 14.16.150; Ord. No. 581, art. III, § 2(J)(4), 1971) 
Sec. 32-179. - Attendant or caretaker required; duties and responsibility. 
    Every mobile home park shall be in the charge of a responsible attendant or caretaker at all times, whose duty it shall be to maintain the park, its facilities, and equipment in a clean, orderly, and sanitary condition, and who shall be answerable, with the licensee, for any violation of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1977, § 14.16.020; Ord. No. 581, art. III, § 2(G)(1), 1971) 
Sec. 32-180. - Custodian's office required; registration duties. 
(a)  Each mobile home park shall be provided with a custodian's office where each mobile home entering such mobile home park shall be assigned to a lot location, given a copy of the mobile home park rules, and registered according to the prescribed form. Registrations shall include the name and address of every occupant of the mobile home, the license number of all units, the state issuing such licenses, and a statement indicating the exact location at which such mobile home was last parked including the state, city, town or village where such parking occurred. The licensee shall keep a registry of all children of school age occupying mobile homes in the mobile home park. The register shall be signed by the parent or legal guardian of such children. 
(b)  Any person furnishing misinformation for purpose of registration shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(c)  All records shall be neatly and securely maintained, and no registration records shall be destroyed until six years have elapsed following the date of registration. The register shall be available at all times for inspection by city law enforcement officers. 
(Code 1977, § 14.16.160; Ord. No. 581, art. III, § 2(K), 1971) 
Chapter 34 - NUISANCES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal powers as to nuisances, 65 ILCS 5/11-60-2; nuisances generally, 720 ILCS 5/47-25; municipal sanitation code violations, 65 ILCS 5/11-19.2-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 34-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Highway means any street, alley or public way within the city. 
    Inoperable motor vehicle. 
(1)  The term "inoperable motor vehicle" means any motor vehicle from which, for a period of at least seven days, the engine, wheels or other parts have been removed, or on which the engine, wheels or other parts have been altered, damaged or otherwise so treated that the vehicle is incapable of being driven under its own motor power. The term "inoperable motor vehicle" shall also include those motor vehicles not currently licensed, or motor vehicles currently licensed but not displaying the license, by this state or any other state or county exposed to the view of the general public. 
(2)  The term "inoperable motor vehicle" shall not include: 
a.  A motor vehicle which has been rendered temporarily incapable of being driven under its own motor power in order to perform ordinary service or repair operations. 
b.  Any motor vehicle that is kept within a building when not in use. 
c.  Operable historical vehicles over 25 years of age which are currently licensed, and displaying said license, by this state or any other state or county. 
d.  A motor vehicle on the premises of a place of business engaged in the wrecking or junking of motor vehicles and so licensed as a place of business under the ordinances of the city. 
    Nuisance means whatever is injurious to health, indecent or offensive to the senses or an obstacle to the free use of property so as essentially to interfere with the comfortable enjoyment of life or property. 
    Operable historical vehicle means any motor vehicle or other vehicle in an operable condition which is 25 years of age or older and is currently licensed, and displaying said license, by this state or any other state or county. 
    Property owner means the contract purchaser if there is one of record, otherwise the record holder of legal title. 
    Public view means visible from the adjoining property, street or avenue. 
    Rubbish means nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes, such as paper, wrappings, cigarettes, cardboard, tin cans, yard clippings, wood, glass, bedding, crockery and similar materials. 
(Code 1977, § 8.08.020; Ord. No. 04-11, § 1, 2004; Ord. No. 02-10, § 1, 2002; Ord. No. 01-31, 2001) 
Sec. 34-2. - General prohibition. 
    It is unlawful for any person to create, cause or permit a nuisance, to exist or be maintained within the limits of the city. The following are declared to be nuisances; provided, however, that the following shall not be deemed to be exclusive: 
(1)  The unnecessary or unauthorized erecting, continuing or using any building or other place for the exercise of any trade, employment or manufacture, which by occasioning noxious exhalation, offensive smells or other annoyances becomes injurious and dangerous to the health, comfort or property of individuals or the public; 
(2)  The obstructing or impeding without legal authority the passage of any navigable river, harbor or collection of water; 
(3)  The corrupting or rendering unwholesome or impure the water of any river, stream or pond, or unlawfully diverting the same from its natural course or state to the injury or prejudice of others; 
(4)  The obstructing or encumbering by fences, buildings or otherwise the public roads, private ways, streets, alleys, commons, landing places or burying grounds; 
(5)  Billboards, signboards and advertising signs, whether erected and constructed on public or private property, which so obstruct and impair the view of any portion or part of a public street, avenue, highway, boulevard or alley or of a railroad or street railway track as to render dangerous the use thereof; 
(6)  All unnecessary or unauthorized substances which emit or cause foul, obnoxious, unhealthful, putrid, noisome or disagreeable odor or effluvia and which are objectionable or offensive to any person residing near the same or to any person passing along any street, sidewalk or alley near the same; 
(7)  For any person to dump, deposit, store or place any garbage, rubbish, trash or refuse upon property within the city, except as may be allowed by city ordinances or state and federal regulations; 
(8)  To cause or permit any premises within the city to become or remain littered with tin cans, glass jars, bottles, scrap glass, paper cartons, scraps of paper, boxes, ashes, iron, old hot water tanks, oil storage tanks, tin or other metal materials, refuse, rubbish, junk, waste, manure, straw, piles of grass, clippings, lumber, old bricks, concrete blocks, chunks of broken concrete, plaster board, discarded furniture, household appliances, mattresses, bedsprings, portable swimming pools in disrepair, tires or other like matters of things; 
(9)  To create or permit to be created or remain upon any premises within the city for a period of more than 30 days the storing, piling, scattering, accumulating, heaping, amassing or collecting of bricks, concrete materials, straw, lumber, structural iron, pipe, roofing materials or any building materials where the same is in public view and where the same may or does constitute a safety hazard to children playing in the area or so that the same may or does become an attraction to or haven for vermin or rodents; building materials stored outdoors on any site for construction authorized by a building permit shall not be permitted to remain more than 30 days after completion of construction upon a job site; 
(10)  To cause or permit the existence or storage in any place accessible to children of any abandoned or discarded refrigerator, icebox, ice chest, deep freeze or other airtight appliance or container of any kind of a capacity of 11/2 cubic feet or more from which the lids, doors or other covers have not been removed, or which cannot easily by opened by a child, by means of pushing only, from the inside; 
(11)  Permitting or causing the carcasses of animals to remain exposed more than 12 hours after death; 
(12)  To discharge slop, foul or dirty water, filth or refuse or offal in or upon any street, avenue, sidewalk, alley, park, public square or public or private enclosure or allowed to accumulate there or in a pond or pool; 
(13)  To obstruct any water source, ravine or gutter so as to cause water to stagnate therein, or permit foul or stagnant water to stand upon any premises; 
(14)  To allow an unkempt appearance to exist on the parkway immediately adjacent to private property as caused by rubbish, debris or overgrown, uncultivated plant life; 
(15)  Nuisance as stated in sections of this Code; 
(16)  Any abandoned or partially dismantled, derelict, nonoperating, wrecked or junked vehicle; a vehicle in a state of substantial disrepair on any street, highway, or public place within the city; any such vehicle in public view on any private property for more than seven days; any motor vehicle parked in the front yard of a residential or commercial property in the city for more than 24 hours; or more than five motor vehicles parked in public view on private property for a period of more than 24 hours; 
(17)  Any inoperable motor vehicle which is located for seven days or more upon public or private property in the city which is in public view. Each motor vehicle which is permitted to exist as a nuisance shall be considered a separate nuisance and, therefore, also constitutes the basis for a separate offense; 
(18)  Any trailer that is not currently licensed, or currently licensed but not displaying the license, by this state or any other state or county, or in a substantial state of disrepair, exposed to the view of the general public on private property for more than seven days; 
(19)  Any boat, watercraft or snowmobile that is not currently licensed, or currently licensed but not displaying the license, by this state or any other state or county, or in a substantial state of disrepair, exposed to the view of the general public on private property for more than seven days. 
(Code 1977, § 8.08.010; Ord. No. 01-31, 2001) 
State Law reference- Acts constituting public nuisances, 740 ILCS 55/221. 
Sec. 34-3. - Engine brakes and compression brakes. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful and a nuisance for the driver of any vehicle to use or operate or cause to be used or operated within the city, any engine brake, compression brake or mechanical exhaust device designed to aid in the braking or deceleration or any vehicle that results in excessive, loud, unusual or explosive noise from such vehicle, except in the case of a true emergency to avoid damage to property or injury to any person. 
(b)  The usage of an engine brake, compression brake or mechanical exhaust device designed to aid in braking or deceleration in such a manner so as to be audible at a distance of 300 feet from the motor vehicle shall constitute prima facie evidence of a violation of this section. 
(Code 1977, § 8.08.025; Ord. No. 03-19, § 1, 2003) 
Sec. 34-4. - Littering in public places. 
    It is illegal and a public nuisance to discard any items of paper, cardboard, glass, cans, containers or any other materials on a public street, public way, public property, public sidewalk, public park or any other area constituting public property. 
State Law reference- Litter Control Act, 415 ILCS 105/1 et seq. 
Sec. 34-5. - Offensive odors. 
    It is hereby declared to be a nuisance within the city to erect, continue or use any residence, business, building, or other place, including, but not limited to, for the exercise of any trade, employment or manufacture which, by occasion of noxious exhalations, offensive smells, or otherwise, is offensive or dangerous to the health of individuals or of the public. 
Sec. 34-6. - Unsafe scaffolds prohibited. 
    All scaffolds or other structures used in the erection or repair of any building shall be made secure and sufficiently wide to ensure the safety of persons working thereon or passing thereunder against the falling of the same or the falling of materials placed thereon. Any scaffold or other like structure which may be otherwise constructed shall be deemed a nuisance, and whoever erects or uses any insecure or dangerous scaffold or other structure shall be in violation of this section. 
(Prior Code, § 428; Code 1977, § 8.12.050) 
Sec. 34-7. - Noise control. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this section is to establish noise control for the protection of the public health and welfare. Any person causing noise in excess of the established standards is in violation of this section. 
(b)  Definitions . For the purpose of this section, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
    Motor vehicle. Any passenger vehicle, truck, truck-trailer, trailer or semi-trailer or locomotive propelled or drawn by mechanical power. 
    Motorcycle. Every motor vehicle having a seat or saddle for use by the rider and designed to travel with not more than three wheels in contact with the ground, including every motor scooter, motor-driven cycle and minibike, but excluding a tractor. 
    Person. Any individual, firm, association, partnership, joint venture, or corporation. 
    Public right-of-way. Any street, avenue, highway, sidewalk, alley, park, or similar place normally accessible to the public which is owned or controlled by a governmental entity. 
    Public space. Any real property or structures on real property owned by a governmental entity and normally accessible to the public, including but not limited to, parks and other recreational areas. 
    Steady noise. A noise whose level remains essentially constant (i.e., fluctuations are negligibly small) during the period of observation. 
    Zoning district. Those districts established by the zoning regulations of the city. 
(c)  Noise regulation. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to make, continue, or caused to be made or continued any excessive or unusually loud noise which either annoys, disturbs, injures, or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace, or safety of others within the limits of the city. 
(2)  No person shall use or operate a radio, television, "boombox," stereo, MP3 player, speaker, compact disc player, sound amplifying device or similar device that produces or reproduces sound in a manner that is of reasonable discomfort to a person of ordinary sensitivity other than the player(s) or operator(s) of the device, and those who are voluntarily listening to the sound, or which unreasonably disturbs the peace, quiet and comfort of neighbors and passers-by, or is plainly audible at a distance of 50 feet from any person upon a public way. This division shall not apply to loudspeakers/public address systems, emergency signaling devices, car alarms and ice cream trucks. 
(3)  No person shall operate a motor vehicle in a manner, which unreasonably disturbs the peace, quiet and comfort of neighbors and passersby, or is plainly audible at a distance of 300 feet from any person upon a public way. 
(4)  No person shall make or cause, permit or allow to be made, upon a public way, or in close proximity to a public way as to be distinctly and loudly audible upon the public way, any noise of any kind by crying, calling or shouting, or by means of any whistle, rattle, bell, hammer, drum, horn, other musical instrument, wind instrument, mechanical device or other similar device so as to destroy or substantially impair the peace of the neighborhood. 
(d)  Property uses which cause noise prohibited. 
(1)  No person owning or in possession or control of any building or premises shall use the same, permit the use of the same or rent the same to be used for any business or employment or residential use, or for any purpose of pleasure or recreation, if the use shall, by its boisterous, loud, or raucous nature, disturb or destroy the peace of the neighborhood, as determined by a person of ordinary sensitivity, in which the building or premises is situated, or be dangerous or detrimental to health. 
(2)  The factors for determination of whether a sound is unreasonably loud or raucous include, but are not limited to, the following: 
a.  The proximity of the sound to residences; 
b.  The land use, nature, and zoning of the area from which the sound emanates and the area where it is received or perceived; 
c.  The time of night or day the sound occurs and the duration of the sound; 
d.  Whether the sound is recurrent intermittent, or constant. 
(e)  Exemptions. Notwithstanding the term "noise making prohibited", as used in this section, the following emissions of sound shall be exempt from the provisions of this section and shall not constitute a prohibited emission of sound or noise: 
(1)  The emission of sound for the purpose of alerting persons to the existence of an emergency. This is to include public-address systems. 
(2)  The emission of sounds made or caused to be made by law enforcement officials in the performance of their official duties. 
(3)  The emission of sound in the performance of emergency work. 
(4)  Rail and air transportation and public mass transportation vehicles. 
(5)  The emission of sound from church bells, carillons, or chimes. 
(6)  The emission of sounds from an ice cream truck between the hours of 9:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. 
(7)  The emission of sounds made by students, employees or the general public while in attendance at any school-sponsored event or city-approved event. 
(8)  The emission of sounds made by participants and observers of any parade that has been approved by the council. 
(9)  The sound made or caused to be made by city, school or state-owned or hired equipment or facilities for the conduct of city, school or state operations. 
(10)  Lawn and garden equipment. The sound emitted by motor-powered muffler-equipped lawn and garden equipment operated between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. 
(11)  Chain saws. The sound emitted by motor-powered tree-trimming equipment operated between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. 
(12)  Snow removal equipment. The sound emitted by motor-powered, muffler-equipped snow removal equipment operated between the hours of 5:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight and the sound emitted by city-owned or hired snow removal equipment regardless of hours of operation. 
(13)  Alarms. The sound emitted by the intentional sounding outdoors of any fire, burglar or civil defense alarm, siren, whistle or similar stationary emergency signaling device for emergency purpose or for the essential testing of such device. False alarms shall not be exempt under this section but shall be considered a nuisance. 
(14)  Construction noise. The sound emitted by construction work (erection, demolition, excavation, drilling, sawing, hammering etc.) between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m., which is being performed pursuant to a proper and current building permit (if required). 
(15)  Outdoor gatherings, public dances, shows, and other similar outdoor events, provided that a permit has been obtained from the city. 
(f)  Compliance with zoning regulations. Any property use established in a zoning district as defined and designated under the provisions of this code of ordinances shall be so operated as to comply with any performance standards governing noise set forth therein for the district in which the use in located. 
(g)  Impairment of action. Nothing in this section shall be construed to impair any cause of action or legal remedy therefor of any person or the public for injury or damage arising from the emission or release into the atmosphere or ground from any source whatever of noise in a place or manner or at levels so as to constitute a common law nuisance. 
(h)  Disturbing the peace. Every person who unlawfully disturbs the public quiet of any street, alley, public square or any religious or public assembly or building, public or private or any neighborhood, private family or person within the city by giving false alarms of fire, by loud or unusual noise, by loud music, by squealing tires, by ringing bells, blowing horns or other instruments or by quarreling, assaulting, fighting or by any other device or means whatever is in violation of this section. 
(i)  Penalty. Any person in violation of this section is subject to the standard penalty as established in this code of ordinances. The standard penalty is a fine of not less than $75.00 and no more than $750.00. A separate and distinct offense is committed on each day on which the person continues or permits any violation or failure to comply after notification thereof. 
(j)  Enforcement . The following individuals shall enforce this section: 
(1)  The police chief or duly acting members of the police department will have primary responsibility for the enforcement of the noise regulations contained in this section. Nothing in this section shall prevent the police chief or duly acting members of the police department from obtaining voluntary compliance by way of warning, notice, or education. 
(2)  Each occurrence of a violation, or, in the case of continuous violations, each day a violation occurs or continues, constitutes a separate offense and may be punished separately. 
(Ord. No. 18-05, § 2, 3-12-2018) 
Secs. 34-8-34-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LITTERING 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 34-31. - Prohibited; cleanup required. 
    All contractors, truckers, proprietors, and other persons hauling dirt, sand, gravel, brick, stone, feed, ice, ashes, rubbish, or other material on streets or alleys in the city shall so construct, keep, and maintain their wagons and truck boxes so that there shall be no spilling of such material from the same or the scattering of such materials into the air. In case the same fall into the street, or the same are scattered in any street or avenue, they shall cause the same to be forthwith removed. 
(Prior Code, § 447; Code 1977, § 9.48.120) 
State Law reference- Litter Control Act, 415 ILCS 105/1 et seq. 
Secs. 34-32-34-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - HANDBILLS AND OTHER ADVERTISEMENTS 

Sec. 34-51. - Billposting prohibited. 
    No person shall post, paint, or place any advertisement, handbill, or show bill upon any private wall, fence, gate, or door; or upon any wire, post, or pole within the city without first having obtained consent of the owner, occupant, or agent of the property; or upon any building, wall, fence, walk, wire, or post belonging to the city; or in any of the public streets of the city without obtaining permission of the city council. 
(Prior Code, § 183; Code 1977, § 9.52.020) 
Sec. 34-52. - Attaching advertising to vehicles. 
    It is unlawful for any person to place in any automobile, carriage, or other vehicle any handbills or advertising of any kind or character or to fasten or paste on any automobile, carriage, or other vehicle any advertisement of any kind or character. 
(Prior Code, § 440; Code 1977, § 9.48.050) 
Sec. 34-53. - Scattering on streets prohibited. 
    No person shall distribute, scatter, or throw upon the streets, sidewalks, or alleys of the city, any handbill or posters, advertisements or paper. 
(Prior Code, § 182; Code 1977, § 9.52.010) 
Sec. 34-54. - Distributing medicine samples prohibited. 
    No person shall distribute, scatter, throw or cause to be distributed, scattered, or thrown any sample of any drug, patent medicine, mixture or compound, or medicine of any kind, or any advertisement accompanying or concerning same, in any street, avenue, alley, or public place in the city, or in or upon any public or private property or premises within the city. 
(Prior Code, § 185; Code 1977, § 9.52.040) 
Sec. 34-55. - Medical pamphlets and advertisements regarding certain subject matters prohibited. 
    No person shall sell or offer to sell, give away or offer to give away, post or distribute in, or have in his possession with intent to give away, sell, post, or distribute in, upon, or near any street, sidewalk, or public place, or in public view within the city any book, pamphlet, circular, handbill, advertisement, or notice of any kind purporting to treat or treating of any venereal disease; describing or explaining or purporting to describe or explain the genital organs; giving or purporting to give the nature or cause of nervous debility, impotency, sterility, barrenness, gonorrhea, gleets, syphilis, affection of the prostate gland, or remedies therefor; or the cause or remedies for abortion or miscarriage, or articles or means of preventing conception. 
(Prior Code, § 186; Code 1977, § 9.52.050) 
Secs. 34-56-34-83. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 34-84. - Notice of violation. 
(a)  The chief of police, or his designee, shall cause notice to be given to the personal property owner of each violation of this chapter. Such notice shall be in writing, define the violation and describe the location of the violation. 
(b)  The notice shall be served personally or forwarded by the United States mail to the last known address of the person and property owner. Further, the notice shall demand abatement of the nuisance within ten days from the date the notice was served or mailed. 
(c)  If the nuisance is not remedied within such period of time, the city may cause such nuisance to be remedied at the exclusive cost of the person violating this chapter. 
(d)  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary, the chief of police or his designee may charge the owner of any motor vehicle causing a nuisance as any other traffic violation under this Code and no notice is required as herein described, and the penalty for such violation shall be the penalty as described under section 1-15 as it applies to other traffic violations under this Code. 
(Code 1977, § 8.08.030; Ord. No. 01-31, 2001) 
Sec. 34-85. - Lien. 
    In the event that payment of the actual costs of the abatement of any nuisance by the city is not made on demand, such costs shall become a lien upon the property from which such nuisance was abated. 
(Code 1977, § 8.08.040; Ord. No. 01-31, 2001) 
Sec. 34-86. - Violations. 
    Every person who creates, causes or permits a nuisance under this chapter and every owner, occupant, agent or trustee of any premises where such nuisance exists who fails or refuses to abate the same as provided in this chapter shall be deemed guilty of violating this chapter; and each day that such nuisance continues after the date of abatement as set forth in the notice required herein shall constitute and be a separate and distinct violation thereof. 
(Code 1977, § 8.08.050; Ord. No. 01-31, 2001) 
Chapter 36 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Criminal Code of 1961, 720 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.; municipal powers as to police ordinances, 65 ILCS 5/11-1-1; municipal authority to conduct programs and coordinate activities for the prevention, reduction or control of juvenile delinquency, 65 ILCS 5/11-1-8; municipal authority to pass and enforce necessary police ordinances, 65 ILCS 5/11-1-1; municipal authority to suppress bawdy houses, disorderly houses, and houses of ill-fame, 65 ILCS 5/11-5-1; municipal authority to abate nuisances, 65 ILCS 5/11-60-2; municipal powers as to police ordinances, 65 ILCS 5/11-1-1; Lewdness Public Nuisance Act, 740 ILCS 105/0.01 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 36-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Distribution means to give, sell, deliver, dispense, issue or offer to give, sell, deliver, dispense or issue. 
    Employee means any person who may be required to or directed by any employer in consideration of direct or indirect gain or profit, to engage in any employment, or to go, or work, or be at any time in any place of employment. 
    Employer means any person, firm, corporation, agent, manager, representative or other person having control or custody of any employment, place of employment or employee. 
    Establishment means any physical facility operated by a commercial enterprise, nonprofit entity, government agency or other person. 
    Games include, but are not limited to, baseball, football, basketball, hacky-sack, frisbee or like activities. 
    Minor means a person less than 18 years of age. 
    Organization means a corporation for profit, or not-for-profit, partnership, limited partnership, joint venture, unincorporated association, estate, trust, or other commercial legal entity. 
    Public place includes, but is not limited to, the quasi-public area in front of or adjacent to any store, shop, restaurant, luncheonette or other place of business and shall include also any parking lots or other vacant private property not owned or under the dominion of the person charged with a violation of this chapter. 
Sec. 36-2. - Accountability; aiding and abetting. 
    Any person who, either before or during the commission of an offense and with the intent to promote or facilitate such commission, solicits, aids, abets, assists or encourages the commission of any act prohibited by this Code or by an ordinance, or by any indirect means procures any such offense to be committed or who commits an offense through the intervention of any person under his control, shall be deemed guilty to the same extent and may be preceded against in the same manner as though the offense had been committed by him directly and with his own hand. 
State Law reference- Accountability for conduct of another, 720 ILCS 5/5-1. 
Secs. 36-3-36-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION 

Sec. 36-23. - Bribery. 
    It is unlawful to commit bribery. A person commits bribery when: 
(1)  With intent to influence the performance of any act related to the employment or function of any public officer, public employee, juror or witness, he promises or tenders to that person any property or personal advantage which he is not authorized by law to accept; 
(2)  With intent to influence the performance of any act related to the employment or function of any public officer, public employee, juror or witness, he promises or tenders to one whom he believes to be a public officer, public employee, juror or witness, any property or personal advantage which a public officer, public employee, juror or witness would not be authorized by law to accept; 
(3)  With intent to cause any person to influence the performance of any act related to the employment or function of any public officer, public employee, juror or witness, he promises or tenders to that person any property or personal advantage which he is not authorized by law to accept; 
(4)  He receives, retains or agrees to accept any property or personal advantage which he is not authorized by law to accept knowing that such property or personal advantage was promised or tendered with intent to cause him to influence the performance of any act related to the employment or function of any public officer, public employee, juror or witness; or 
(5)  He solicits, receives, retains, or agrees to accept any property or personal advantage pursuant to an understanding that he shall improperly influence or attempt to influence the performance of any act related to the employment or function of any public officer, public employee, juror or witness. 
(Prior Code, § 474; Code 1977, § 9.04.010) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, 720 ILCS 5/33-1; accepting bribe, 720 ILCS 5/29-2. 
Sec. 36-24. - Destruction of public notices prohibited. 
    It is unlawful to obliterate, tear down, or destroy in whole or in part any law, ordinance, or notice of any kind posted any place in the city by authority of law, during the time for which the same is to remain up. 
(Prior Code, § 470; Code 1977, § 9.08.010) 
Sec. 36-25. - Interference and resistance prohibited. 
    No person shall resist any police officer or constable in the lawful discharge of his duties, or willfully refuse to assist any police officer or constable in making an arrest when called upon to do so, or interfere with any person authorized or required to enforce the laws of the city; nor prevent, hinder, or delay such person in the execution of the duties required of him by any of the ordinances or laws of the state, or interfere with any city officer or person employed by the city in the lawful discharge of the duties of his office, or of such employment. 
(Prior Code, § 394; Code 1977, § 9.12.010) 
State Law reference- Resisting or obstructing a peace officer, 720 ILCS 5/31-1; refusing to aid an officer, 720 ILCS 5/31-8. 
Sec. 36-26. - False assumption of office prohibited. 
    No person shall falsely assume or pretend to be a city officer, or take it upon himself to act as such, or fraudulently attempt to require or requires a person to aid or assist him in any matter pertaining to the duty of any city officer. 
(Prior Code, § 472; Code 1977, § 9.12.020) 
State Law reference- Impersonating government officers, 720 ILCS 5/32-5. 
Sec. 36-27. - Obstructing justice. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly obstruct justice. A person obstructs justice when, with the intent to prevent apprehension or to obstruct the prosecution or defense of any person, the person knowingly commits any of the following acts: 
(1)  Destroys, alters, conceals or disguises physical evidence, plants false evidence, furnishes false information; 
(2)  Induces a witness having knowledge material to the subject at issue to leave the state or conceal himself; or 
(3)  Possessing knowledge material to the subject at issue leaves the state or conceals himself. 
State Law reference- Interference with judicial procedure, 720 ILCS 5/32-1. 
Secs. 36-28-36-57. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC SAFETY 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 36-58. - Playing games within the business district. 
    No person shall play any games in any street or avenue in any part of the business district of the city. Nothing in this section shall prohibit games or events that are sponsored by local businesses or organizations, with the permission from the city council. 
(Prior Code, § 426; Code 1977, § 8.12.030; Ord. No. 96-14, § 1, 1996) 
Sec. 36-59. - Open doors and excavations in streets prohibited. 
    No person shall leave open, uncovered, unguarded, or in an unsafe condition any cellar door, hatchway, pit, vault or excavation upon or adjoining any sidewalk, street, or other public place. 
(Prior Code, § 427; Code 1977, § 8.12.040) 
Secs. 36-60-36-76. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - WEAPONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Air Rifle Act, 720 ILCS 535/0.01 et seq. 

Sec. 36-77. - Casting stones and other missiles. 
    It is unlawful for any person to purposely or heedlessly cast or throw any stone or other missile from, at, against, or into any public place, any house, building, vehicle, or person, within the city. 
(Prior Code, § 391; Code 1977, § 9.76.010) 
Sec. 36-78. - Discharging air guns and kindred devices prohibited; exception. 
    No person shall be permitted to fire or discharge upon any public way in the city any air gun, bow, sling, slingshot, spring gun or toy gun, or other similar device which is calculated or intended to propel or project a bullet, arrow, or similar projectile. Nothing in this section shall prevent the use of such weapons in shooting galleries, or in any private grounds or residence where the projectile fired or discharged from any such gun or device will not traverse any space used as a public way. 
(Prior Code, § 392; Code 1977, § 9.76.020) 
Sec. 36-79. - Sale of knuckles and kindred items prohibited. 
    No person shall sell, give, loan, hire, or barter, or offer to sell, give, loan or barter to any person within the city any slingshot, metallic knuckles, or other deadly weapon of like character. 
(Prior Code, § 476; Code 1977, § 9.76.030) 
Sec. 36-80. - Discharge of firearms prohibited; exception. 
    It is unlawful for any person, within the city, to fire or discharge any gun, pistol, or other firearm, except in case of necessity or in the performance of a public act or lawful duty. The discharge of firearms by the members of any military company when on parade, and in accordance with the command of their commanding officer, or by any officer or other person in the discharge and performance of any legal duty or lawful act, or upon the premises used by a duly licensed shooting gallery shall not be deemed violations of this section. 
(Prior Code, §§ 281, 393; Code 1977, § 9.76.060) 
State Law reference- Unlawful use of weapons, 720 ILCS 5/24-1 et seq. 
Sec. 36-81. - Concealed weapons prohibited; exception. 
    It is unlawful for any person in the city to wear under his clothes or concealed about his person any pistol, revolver, billy, slingshot, sling, knuckles of any kind, bowie knife, dirk, razor, dagger, or other dangerous, offensive, or deadly weapon, or to display or flourish any such weapon in a boisterous or threatening manner. This section shall not apply to officers carrying weapons in the discharge of their official duties, or to any person summoned by any such officer to aid him in making an arrest or preserving the peace. 
(Prior Code, § 396; Code 1977, § 9.76.080) 
State Law reference- Unlawful use of weapons, 720 ILCS 5/24-1 et seq. 
Secs. 36-82-36-105. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - EXPLOSIVES 

Sec. 36-106. - Manufacture prohibited. 
    No person, firm, company, or corporation shall make, manufacture, or compound, within the limits of the city, any dynamite, nitrochlorate, or other explosive compound. 
(Prior Code, § 475; Code 1977, § 9.76.040) 
Sec. 36-107. - Storage and sales prohibited. 
    No dynamite, nitrochlorate, or other explosive compound shall be stored or kept within 300 yards of any inhabited dwelling. All sales of any such explosives shall be immediately reported to the chief of police by the person making the same. 
(Prior Code, § 477; Code 1977, § 9.76.050) 
Secs. 36-108-36-127. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - FIREWORKS 

Sec. 36-128. - Sale prohibited. 
    The sale of fireworks within the city is prohibited except to the extent as may be permitted by state law. 
(Prior Code, § 283; Code 1977, § 9.76.090) 
State Law reference- Authority of municipalities to regulate storage of fireworks, 65 ILCS 5/11-8-4; Fireworks Regulation Act of Illinois, 425 ILCS 30/1 et seq. 
Sec. 36-129. - Discharge prohibited; exception. 
(a)  No person shall fire off or discharge within the city any giant or cannon firecracker, any firecracker exceeding two inches in length and one-quarter of an inch in diameter, torpedo exceeding three-fourths of an inch in diameter, rocket, Roman candle, detonating cap, powder, detonating cane, toy pistol, toy gun, toy cannon, cannon, blank cartridge, any substance consisting of chlorate of potash and sulphur, or fireworks containing dynamite; nor shall any person at any time discharge or set off anywhere within the city or have in his possession for such purpose firecrackers of any size, or any fireworks or explosives of a similar nature as enumerated in this section. The mayor or the city council may suspend the operation of this section, where a public display is made under proper supervision and specific approval by the council. 
(b)  Approved discharge of fireworks within the city limits shall require, in addition to specific approval of the city council, a permit as provided in section 22-133. 
(Prior Code, § 284; Code 1977, § 9.76.100) 
Secs. 36-130-36-156. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC PEACE AND ORDER 

Sec. 36-157. - Disorderly conduct. 
    It is unlawful for any person to knowingly: 
(1)  Do any act in such unreasonable manner as to alarm or disturb another and to provoke a breach of the peace; 
(2)  Transmit in any manner to the fire department of any city, town, village, or fire protection district, a false alarm of fire, knowing at the time of such transmission that there is no reasonable ground for believing that such fire exists; 
(3)  Transmit in any manner to another a false alarm to the effect that a bomb or other explosive of any nature is concealed in such place that its explosion would endanger human life, knowing at the time of such transmission that there is no reasonable ground for believing that such bomb or explosive is concealed in such place; 
(4)  Transmit in any manner to any peace officer, public officer or public employee a report to the effect that an offense has been committed, knowing at the time of such transmission that there is no reasonable ground for believing that such an offense has been committed; or 
(5)  Enters upon the property of another and for a lewd or unlawful purpose deliberately looks into a dwelling on the property through any window or other opening in it. 
(Code 1977, § 9.46.010; Ord. No. 81-8, 1981) 
State Law reference- Disorderly conduct, 720 ILCS 5/26-1; municipal authority to regulate intoxication, fighting, and disorderly conduct, 65 ILCS 5/11-5-3. 
Sec. 36-158. - Obstructing aisles in public buildings prohibited. 
    No person shall obstruct or stand in any aisle or doorway of any church, theater, public hall, or other place of public gathering, after being requested to take a seat if one is provided, or after being requested to leave such place if the seats in the same are occupied. 
(Prior Code, § 211; Code 1977, § 8.12.170) 
State Law reference- Public demonstrations, 430 ILCS 70/1; riots and disturbances, 65 ILCS 5/11-5-2; disorderly conduct, 720 ILCS 5/26-1; municipal authority to regulate intoxication, fighting, and disorderly conduct, 65 ILCS 5/11-5-3. 
Sec. 36-159. - Obstructing streets, sidewalks, or access to public buildings; loitering. 
(a)  No person shall loiter, lounge or sleep in or upon any street, park or public place or in any public building, or obstruct the access to any public building or any part thereof, or obstruct passage through or upon any public street, park or public place. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section, the term "obstruct" encompasses, but is not necessarily limited to, one or more of the following acts: 
(1)  Obstruction of the free, unhampered passage of pedestrians or vehicles; 
(2)  Obstructing, molesting or interfering with any person lawfully upon any street, park or other public place; 
(3)  Obstructing or otherwise interfering with the free passage of persons entering or occupying such buildings or premises; 
(4)  Use of language, conversation, or conduct which annoys, insults or disturbs persons passing along the street or other public places, or occupying, residing or doing business in any of said houses or places; 
(5)  Refusing to move on when so requested by a peace officer, provided that the peace officer has exercised his discretion reasonably under the circumstances in order to preserve or promote public peace and order. 
(Code 1977, § 9.40.010; Ord. No. 652, § 1, 1978) 
State Law reference- Public demonstrations, 430 ILCS 70/1; riots and disturbances, 65 ILCS 5/11-5-2; disorderly conduct, 720 ILCS 5/26-1; municipal authority to regulate intoxication, fighting, and disorderly conduct, 65 ILCS 5/11-5-3; municipal authority to prohibit vagrancy and begging, 65 ILCS 5/11-5-4. 
Sec. 36-160. - Mob action. 
    No person shall engage in mob action within the city. Mob action consists of any of the following: 
(1)  The use of force or violence disturbing the public peace by two or more persons acting together and without authority of law; 
(2)  The assembly of two or more persons to do an unlawful act; or 
(3)  The assembly of two or more persons, without authority of law, for the purpose of doing violence to the person or property of anyone supposed to have been guilty of a violation of the law, or for the purposes of exercising correctional powers or regulative powers over any person by violence. 
(Code 1977, § 9.45.010; Ord. No. 81-8, 1981) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, 720 ILCS 5/25-1; municipal authority to prevent or suppress riots, routs, affrays, noises, disturbances, trespasses, and disorderly assemblies, 65 ILCS 5/11-5-2. 
Secs. 36-161-36-188. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC MORALS AND DECENCY 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 36-189. - Decoys prohibited. 
    No person shall, through invitation or device, prevail on any person to visit any room, building, booth, garden, yard, boat, or float kept for the purpose of gambling, prostitution, or fornication in the city. 
(Prior Code, § 413; Code 1977, § 9.28.070) 
Sec. 36-190. - Dogfighting and cockfighting prohibited. 
    No person shall within the city, keep or use or be in any way connected with the management of any place kept or used for the purpose of fighting or baiting any dog, cock, or other animal, or suffer or permit such place to be kept or used on premises owned, rented, or controlled by him, or frequent or be found in any such place. 
(Prior Code, § 416; Code 1977, § 9.28.110) 
State Law reference- Dogfighting, 720 ILCS 5/26-5; authority of municipalities to prohibit cockfighting, 65 ILCS 5/11-5-3. 
Secs. 36-191-36-218. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - GAMBLING[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Similar provision, 720 ILCS 5/28-1; authority of municipality to suppress gaming, gambling houses, lotteries, and all fraudulent devices or practices for the purpose of obtaining money or property, 65 ILCS 5/11-5-1. 

Sec. 36-219. - Gambling houses prohibited. 
    No person shall set up, keep, maintain or support any gambling house or room or place used for the practice of gambling or playing for money or other property, or suffer or permit any building or premises owned or controlled by him to be used for any such purpose, or keep, or use, or permit to be used, in any building or place occupied, controlled, or owned by such person, any keno or faro table, wheel of fortune, roulette, shuffleboard, cards, slot machine, dice, or other instrument or device commonly used for the purpose of gaming. 
(Prior Code, § 407; Code 1977, § 9.28.010) 
Sec. 36-220. - Frequenting gambling houses prohibited. 
    No person shall live in, frequent or visit the same, or play for any money or other valuable thing at any game with cards, checks, dice, billiards, or other game, instrument, or device whatsoever; or bet on any such game when played by others. 
(Prior Code, § 408; Code 1977, § 9.28.020) 
Sec. 36-221. - Gambling in streets prohibited. 
    No person shall set up or expose in any of the streets, avenues, alleys, or other public places within the city, any table or device of any kind upon or by which any game of chance or hazard can be played; nor shall any person play at or upon any such table or device. 
(Prior Code, § 409; Code 1977, § 9.28.030) 
Sec. 36-222. - Games of chance designated, prohibited. 
    Each and every sale or purchase, wherein any part of the article or things received or to be received, either as to quantity or value, in any manner depends upon any chance or hazard, whether by means of checks, cards, envelopes, numbers, dice, or by any means whatsoever, is declared to be gaming within the meaning of the provisions of this division and, as such, to be unlawful, except as authorized by the statutes of the state. 
(Prior Code, § 410; Code 1977, § 9.28.040) 
Sec. 36-223. - Premises for gambling or drinking by minors declared disorderly. 
    All places where intoxicating liquors are sold, in which minors are permitted to play with cards, dice, balls, or any other article or device used in gaming, are declared to be disorderly houses, except where authorized by governmental license. 
(Prior Code, § 411; Code 1977, § 9.28.050) 
Sec. 36-224. - Gambling in taverns prohibited. 
    No tavern keeper or other person shall permit to be kept in any place occupied by him any implements such as are used in gaming, in order that the same may, for hire, gain, or reward, be used for the purpose of amusement, or permit any implement of that kind to be used upon any part of his premises for the purpose of gaming for money or other property, or permit any person to play at any unlawful game or sport therein, except where such activity is licensed or authorized by the statutes of the state. 
(Prior Code, § 412; Code 1977, § 9.28.060) 
Sec. 36-225. - Confiscation of gambling devices. 
    Every clock, tape, machine, slot machine, or other machine or device for the reception of money on chance or upon the action of which money is staked, hazarded, bet, won, or lost is declared a gambling device, and the same shall be subject to seizure, confiscation, and destruction by the police or any other municipal authority of the city whenever and wherever found within the city limits. 
(Prior Code, § 414; Code 1977, § 9.28.080) 
Sec. 36-226. - Slot machines and kindred devices prohibited. 
    No person shall in any room, inn, tavern, shed, booth, building, enclosure, or in any part thereof operate, keep, own, rent, or use any clock, joker, tape, or slot machine, or any other device upon which money is staked or hazarded or into which money is paid or played upon chance, or upon the result of the action of which money or other valuable thing is staked, bet, hazarded, won, or lost. 
(Prior Code, § 415; Code 1977, § 9.28.090) 
Sec. 36-227. - Bookmaking. 
(a)  No person shall: 
(1)  Keep any room, shed, tent, tenement, booth, or building or any part thereof, or occupy any place upon any public or private grounds within the city with any book, instrument, or device for the purpose of recording or registering bets or wagers, or of selling pools; or 
(2)  Record or register bets or wagers or sell pools upon the result of any trial or contest of skill, speed, or power of endurance of man, vehicle, or beast, or upon the result of any political nomination or election. 
(b)  No person being the owner or lessee or occupant of any room, shed, tenement, tent, booth, or building or any part thereof, shall knowingly: 
(1)  Permit the same to be used or occupied for any of the purposes specified in this section; 
(2)  Keep therein, exhibit, or employ any device or apparatus for the purpose of recording or registering such bets or wagers, or selling of such pools; or 
(3)  Become the custodian or depository for hire or privilege, of any money, property, or other thing of value staked, wagered, or pledged upon any such result. 
(Prior Code, § 473; Code 1977, § 9.28.100) 
Secs. 36-228-36-247. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - OBSCENITY AND INDECENCY[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of village to control obscenity, 65 ILCS 5/11-5-1; obscenity generally, 720 ILCS 5/11-20. 

Sec. 36-248. - Indecent behavior prohibited. 
    No person shall appear in any public place or place open to public view in a state of nudity or in any indecent or lewd dress, or any dress not belonging to such person's sex, or make any indecent exposure of his or her person, or utter any lewd or filthy words, or make any obscene gesture to or about any other person publicly, or use any threatening or abusive language in the hearing of other persons. 
(Prior Code, § 400; Code 1977, § 9.32.010) 
Sec. 36-249. - Indecent pictures, shows, and publications prohibited. 
    No person shall, in any public place open to public view in the city, write, draw, cut, or make any obscene or indecent word, design, figure, or exhibit; sell or offer for sale; give away or offer to give away, circulate, or distribute any indecent or lewd publication, print, picture, illustration, or book or article of indecent or immoral use; or exhibit or perform, or permit to be exhibited or performed upon premises under his control, any indecent or immoral play or show or representation of any kind. 
(Prior Code, § 401; Code 1977, § 9.32.020) 
Sec. 36-250. - Restrictions on sale of contraceptives and kindred devices. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person, firm, corporation, copartnership, or association, other than a duly registered pharmacist or a licensed practitioner of medicine, to sell, offer for sale, vend, or give away in any manner whatsoever, prophylactic devices, prophylactic rubber goods, or any other articles of any kind, nature, and description for the prevention of venereal and other diseases, or infections, or any sex-incentive compounds, devices, or contrivances. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to wholesale druggists, jobbers, or manufacturers who sell articles described in wholesale quantities for resale by registered pharmacists at their usual places of business, and by duly licensed practitioners of medicine. No merchandise of the character described in this section shall be offered for sale by any person, firm, corporation, copartnership, or association unless the merchandise is identified by the manufacturer's name on the package. 
(Prior Code, § 402; Code 1977, § 9.32.030) 
Sec. 36-251. - Obscene pictures prohibited. 
    No person shall, within the city, post or cause to be posted, so that the same can be seen from the streets, avenues, alleys, or other public places of the city, any handbill, poster, placard, or advertisement containing pictures or illustrations of any obscene character. 
(Prior Code, § 184; Code 1977, § 9.52.030) 
Secs. 36-252-36-280. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - DRUGS AND DRUG PARAPHERNALIA 

Sec. 36-281. - Adoption of portions of Illinois Drug Paraphernalia Control Act. 
    The city has adopted 720 ILCS 600/2, 600/3.5, and 600/4 of the Illinois Drug Paraphernalia Control Act, 720 ILCS 600/1 et seq., as may be amended or recodified from time to time, to the same extent as though fully set forth in this division. 
(Ord. No. 16-06, § 1, 5-23-2016)
