Editor's note- Ord. No. 16-06, § 1, adopted May 23, 2016, amended § 36-281 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 36-281 pertained to adoption of part of Illinois Drug Paraphernalia Control Act, and derived from Code 1977, § 9.80.020; and Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, adopted in 2001. 
Sec. 36-282. - Adoption of portions of the Cannabis Control Act. 
    The city has adopted 720 ILCS 550/3 and 550/4(a) of the Cannabis Control Act, 720 ILCS 550/l et seq., as may be amended or recodified from time to time, to the same extent as though fully set forth in this division. 
(Ord. No. 16-06, § 2, 5-23-2016) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 16-06, § 2, adopted May 23, 2016, amended § 36-282 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 36-282 pertained to adoption of part of the Cannabis Control Act, and derived from Code 1977, § 9.80.030; and Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, adopted in 2001. 
Sec. 36-283. - Availability to public. 
    Three copies of each of the above-stated provisions of the criminal statutes of the state shall be and remain on file in the office of the city clerk for public inspection. 
(Code 1977, § 9.80.040; Ord. No. 01-05, § 1, 2001) 
Secs. 36-284-36-314. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - FRAUD AND DECEPTION 

Sec. 36-315. - Three-card monte and kindred games prohibited. 
    No person shall by the game of three-card monte, so called, or by any other game, device, sleight of hand, pretense, fortunetelling, trick, or by any other means whatsoever, by use of cards or other instruments or implements, fraudulently obtain or attempt to obtain, or conduct any such game, practice, or device for the purpose of obtaining from another person, property of any description. 
(Prior Code, § 478; Code 1977, § 9.60.010) 
Sec. 36-316. - Confidence games prohibited. 
    No person shall obtain or attempt to obtain, from any other person, any money or property by means or use of any false or bogus checks or by any other means, instrument or device commonly called a confidence game. 
(Prior Code, § 479; Code 1977, § 9.60.020) 
Secs. 36-317-36-335. - Reserved.

Footnotes:

Sec. 36-336. - Assault. 
    It is unlawful for any person to engage in conduct which places another in reasonable apprehension of receiving bodily harm or receiving physical contact of an insulting or provoking nature. Violation of this section shall be a fine of no less than $500.00. 
(Ord. No. 11-10, § 9.20.010, 9-12-2011) 
State Law reference- Assault, 720 ILCS 5/12-1. 
Sec. 36-337. - Battery. 
    It is unlawful for any person to intentionally or knowingly without legal justification and by any means cause bodily harm to a person(s) or make physical contact of an insulting or provoking nature with a person(s). Violation of this section shall be a fine of no less than $500.00. 
(Ord. No. 11-10, § 9.20.011, 9-12-2011) 
State Law reference- Battery, 720 ILCS 5/12-3. 
Sec. 36-338. - Public fighting. 
    It is unlawful for any person to fight in any public place in the city or to use language having the direct tendency to incite immediate acts of violence by the person(s) addressed, or to challenge to fight or urge another to fight or in any threatening manner display any knife, handgun, blackjack, brass, steel or iron knuckles, or any other deadly weapon. Violation of this section shall be a fine of no less than $500.00. 
(Ord. No. 11-10, § 9.20.012, 9-12-2011) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, 720 ILCS 5/12-5.

ARTICLE VII. - OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Offenses directed against property, 720 ILCS 5/15-1 et seq., 720 ILCS 205/0.01 et seq. 

Sec. 36-363. - Trespass. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to commit a trespass. A person commits a trespass when that person: 
(1)  Enters upon the lands or premises, or any part thereof, of another, after receiving prior to such entry, notice from the owner, occupant or authorized person that such entry is forbidden, or remains upon the lands or premises of another after receiving notice from the owner, occupant, or authorized person to depart; or 
(2)  Enters upon any vehicle, aircraft or watercraft of another after receiving immediately prior to such entry, notice from the owner, occupant or authorized person that such entry is forbidden, or remains upon the vehicle, aircraft or watercraft of another after receiving notice from the owner, occupant or authorized person to depart. 
(b)  For the purpose of this section, a person has received notice from the owner, occupant or authorized person if that person has been notified personally, either orally or in writing, or if a printed or written notice forbidding such entry has been conspicuously posted or exhibited at the main entrance to such land, premises, or forbidden part thereof. 
(c)  For the purposes of this section, lands or premises shall include all lands or premises whether publicly or privately owned. 
State Law reference- Criminal trespass to real property, 720 ILCS 5/21-3. 
Sec. 36-364. - Damage to public property prohibited. 
    No person shall break, deface, injure, or destroy any property of the state, county, or city or any private property within the city. Any person violating this section shall, in addition to all other applicable penalties, be liable for the costs of repairing the injuries committed, which may be recovered in a separate suit. 
(Prior Code, § 436; Code 1977, § 9.48.010) 
State Law reference- Criminal damage to property, 720 ILCS 5/21-1; criminal damage to government supported property, 720 ILCS 5/21-4. 
Sec. 36-365. - Trespassing; injury to vegetation. 
    No person shall, within the city, cut, injure, remove, or destroy any fruit, ornamental, or shade tree or the boxing around the same; nor any fence, railing, gate, post, or sign upon any public ground, sidewalk, street, or private premises; nor enter any private premises against the consent of the owner or occupant thereof; nor trespass upon any private premises or public grounds; nor injure, take away, or destroy any tree, shrub, fruit, plant, vegetable, or other thing, which may be therein for ornament or utility. 
(Prior Code, § 437; Code 1977, § 9.48.020) 
State Law reference- Damage and trespass to property, 720 ILCS 5/21-1.3 et seq. 
Sec. 36-366. - Injury to fences, wells, and kindred objects. 
    No person shall cast or throw any stone, brick, or other missile from or into any street or other place or at, against, or into any building, vehicle, shade tree, or other property; nor climb upon or walk upon the top or any part of any fence or railing without the consent of the owner or person in possession thereof; nor in any way injure or deface any building, fence, gate, tree; nor meddle with or injure any well, cistern, hydrant, or pump within the city. 
(Prior Code, § 438; Code 1977, § 9.48.030) 
State Law reference- Criminal damage to property, 720 ILCS 5/21-1; criminal damage to government supported property, 720 ILCS 5/21-4. 
Sec. 36-367. - Destruction-Of posts and wires. 
    No person shall break, deface, injure, or destroy any street lamp, post, telegraph post or wire, telephone post or wire, or electric light post or wire within the city. 
(Prior Code, § 441; Code 1977, § 9.48.060) 
State Law reference- Criminal damage to property, 720 ILCS 5/21-1; criminal damage to government supported property, 720 ILCS 5/21-4; interference with public utility service, 720 ILCS 5/16-14. 
Sec. 36-368. - Same-Of service boxes. 
    No person shall willfully or heedlessly break, deface, injure, destroy, remove, or carry away any cup or lid placed upon any service box of any gas company or of any water service box within the city. 
(Prior Code, § 442; Code 1977, § 9.48.070) 
State Law reference- Criminal damage to property, 720 ILCS 5/21-1; criminal damage to government supported property, 720 ILCS 5/21-4; interference with public utility service, 720 ILCS 5/16-14. 
Sec. 36-369. - Same-Of markers. 
    No person shall willfully or heedlessly change, remove, or destroy any stone, stake, or post set or placed to mark the corners of any lot or parcel of ground, street, or alley or to show the grade of any street, alley, or sidewalk of the city. 
(Prior Code, § 443; Code 1977, § 9.48.080) 
State Law reference- Criminal damage to property, 720 ILCS 5/21-1; criminal damage to government supported property, 720 ILCS 5/21-4. 
Secs. 36-370-36-396. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - OFFENSES BY AND AGAINST MINORS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 36-397. - Delivery of liquor-impregnated goods prohibited. 
    No person shall sell, give away or deliver or have in his possession for the purpose of sale to any minor, any whisky drops or candy or other material saturated with or enclosing any spirituous, vinous or fermented liquors. 
(Prior Code, § 422; Code 1977, § 9.68.010) 
Sec. 36-398. - Possession of firearms by minors prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to permit, suffer, or allow any minor to handle or have in his possession within the city any cannon, gun, pistol, or any toy gun or cannon, or toy pistol or air gun, or any other similar weapon, or any firearm of any description, which is a deadly weapon, or which, if discharged, is of sufficient force or power to inflict bodily injury. No person shall sell, loan or furnish to any minor any gun, pistol, fowling piece, or other firearm. 
(Prior Code, § 282; Code 1977, § 9.76.070) 
Sec. 36-399. - Clinging to railroad cars prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any minor to climb, jump upon, or cling to, or in any way attach himself to any railroad locomotive or car of any kind while the same is in motion. 
(Prior Code, § 395; Code 1977, § 9.68.040) 
Sec. 36-400. - Truancy. 
(a)  [Definitions.] For purposes of this section, unless the context requires otherwise, the following words or phrases shall mean: 
    Community service is a penalty requiring that an offender found in violation of this section perform unpaid work or services beneficial to the community. 
    Custodian means (1) a person who under court order is the custodian of the person of the minor or (2) a public or private agency with which a court has ordered the placement of a minor or (3) a person acting in the role of a parent by reason of a private agreement, arrangement, custom, or habit. 
    Guardian means (1) a parent or (2) a parent who under court order is a guardian of the person of the minor or (3) a public or private agency with which a court has ordered the placement of a minor. 
    Minor means a person who is under 18 years of age. 
    Parent means a person who is a natural parent, adoptive parent, or step parent of another person. 
    Responsible adult means the parent, guardian, or custodian having the care and custody of a minor. 
    Truant means a child subject to compulsory school attendance and who is absent without valid cause from such attendance of a school day or a portion thereof, as defined in the Illinois School Code, 105 ILCS 5/26-2a. 
(b)  Truancy restrictions. 
(1)  It is unlawful for any minor who is subject to compulsory education or to compulsory continuation education by statute or court order to be absent without valid cause from such attendance for a school day or any portion thereof. 
(2)  It is unlawful for any responsible adult to knowingly permit a minor under the age of 13 years to be absent without valid cause from such attendance for a school day or a portion thereof. 
(c)  Defenses. It is defense to a violation under this section that the child was absent from such attendance as a consequence of any of the following: 
(1)  Observance of a religious holiday or being otherwise forbidden from attendance on a particular day or days or a particular time of day because of such religion. For purposes of this section, "religion" includes all aspects of religious observance and practice, as well as belief; 
(2)  Illness; 
(3)  Death in the immediate family; 
(4)  Family emergency; 
(5)  Other situations beyond the control of the student as determined by the board of education, or such circumstances which cause such reasonable concern by a parent, guardian, or custodian, for the safety or health of the student; 
(6)  Participating in, going to, or returning from lawful employment or a school-sanctioned activity. 
(d)  Penalty. Any child subject to compulsory school attendance who is absent without valid cause from such attendance for a school day or a portion thereof shall be a "truant" and shall be guilty of the offense of truancy, and, if of the age of 13 years or older, such a violator will be subject to following penalties: 
(1)  Upon the first conviction, the payment of a fine in an amount not to exceed $50.00, in addition to court costs; 
(2)  Upon the second conviction within a one-year period, the payment of a fine of in excess of $75.00 but not to exceed $100.00, in addition to costs; 
(3)  In lieu of or in addition to any penalty imposed pursuant to subparagraphs (1) or (2) above, the violator may be ordered to perform community service; 
(4)  The fine for any conviction for a violation of this section shall not exceed $100.00, as established by the Illinois Municipal Code, 65 ILCS 5/ 11-5-9; and 
(5)  If the child found to be truant is under the age of 13 years, the parent or custodian of the child is subject to the foregoing fines, or community service, or both, if in violation of subsection (b)(2). 
(6)  Each day upon which a violation occurs constitutes a separate offense under this section. 
(e)  [ Detainment; enforcement; citations .] 
(1)  Every member of the city's police department while on duty is hereby authorized to temporarily detain any minor alleged to be in violation of the provisions of this section regardless of whether a citation is issued. 
(2)  Before taking any enforcement action, a police officer shall ask the apparent offender's age and reason for being in the public place. The officer shall not issue a citation or make an arrest unless the officer reasonably believes an offense has occurred and that, based on any response and other circumstances, no defense under subsection (c) is applicable. 
(3)  A citation issued hereunder shall be in writing and shall: 
a.  State the name of the person being cited and the person's address if known; 
b.  Set forth the specific section of this truancy code that was violated, the date, time and location of the violation and a brief description of the violation; 
c.  Be signed by the issuing city police officer, truant officer or other complaining party. 
In each instance where a citation is issued to a minor for violation of this truancy code, a minor's parent, guardian, or custodian shall be provided a copy of the citation notifying the parent, guardian, or custodian of the charge made against the minor. 
(Ord. No. 11-13, § 1, 9-12-2011) 
Secs. 36-401-36-426. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TOBACCO PRODUCTS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Sale of Tobacco to Minors Act, 720 ILCS 675/0.01 et seq. 

Sec. 36-427. - Delivery, sale and distribution of tobacco products to minors prohibited. 
    No manufacturer, producer, distributor, wholesaler or retailer of cigarettes or other tobacco products, or any agent, employee or representative of a manufacturer, producer, distributor, wholesaler or retailer of cigarettes or other tobacco products shall: 
(1)  Give, sell or otherwise distribute cigarettes or other tobacco products to any minor; 
(2)  Give, sell or otherwise distribute cigarettes or other tobacco products in any place that does not have posted in a conspicuous place a sign stating that giving, selling or otherwise distributing cigarettes or tobacco products to a person under 18 years of age is prohibited by law; 
(3)  Give, sell or otherwise distribute cigarettes or other tobacco products to any person without first verifying, via a photo identification such as a driver's license, that the person is 18 years of age or older. 
Sec. 36-428. - Tobacco product purchase or possession by minors prohibited. 
    No minor shall purchase, possess or consume in any manner any tobacco product. Possession is not an offense under this section if the person under 18 years of age was in possession of an unopened container of the cigarette or other tobacco product while performing their specified duties at a lawful place of employment. 
(Prior Code, § 418; Code 1977, § 9.68.020; Ord. No. 96-18, § 1, 1996; Ord. No. 97-7, § 1, 1997) 
Sec. 36-429. - Parental responsibility. 
    No parent, guardian or caretaker shall permit, allow, condone or facilitate a minor to purchase, possess or consume any tobacco product. 
(Prior Code, § 418; Code 1977, § 9.68.020; Ord. No. 96-18, § 1, 1996; Ord. No. 97-7, § 1, 1997) 
Secs. 36-430-36-456. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CURFEW[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of municipalities to declare and enforce curfews, 65 ILCS 5/11-1-5; authority of municipalities to prevent, reduce, and control juvenile delinquency, 65 ILCS 5/11-1-8; municipal authority to regulate truants, 65 ILCS 5/11-5-9; underage person identification and compliance, 65 ILCS 5/11-1-10; authority of municipalities to control truancy, 65 ILCS 5/11-5-9. 

Sec. 36-457. - Imposed. 
    It is unlawful for any minor person under the age of 17 years (hereinafter referred to as "minor person") to loiter, idle, wander, stroll, walk, run, play in, or be found upon the public streets, alleys, parks, cemeteries, public buildings, places of amusement and entertainment, vacant lots or any public places/properties within the limits of the city, between the hours stated as follows: 
Sunday through Thursday 11:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m.* Friday through Saturday 12:00 midnight to 6:00 a.m.*  
*Time shall be that of the city's official/actual time. 
(Ord. No. 11-12, § 9.68.050(A), 8-8-2011) 
Sec. 36-458. - Defenses. 
    It is a defense to a violation under this division for a minor person engaged in the prohibited conduct while: 
(1)  Accompanied by such minor person's parent, guardian, or other adult person having the care and custody (hereinafter referred to as "custodian") of such minor person; 
(2)  Participating in, going to or returning from: 
a.  An errand or duty directed by such parent, guardian or custodian; 
b.  A school recreational activity such as a school dance, post-prom, function, entertainment, or sports event; 
c.  Employment which the laws of this state authorize a person less than 17 years of age to perform; 
d.  A religious event; 
e.  An emergency involving the protection of a person or property from an eminent threat or serious bodily injury or substantial damage; 
f.  An activity involving the exercise of the minor person's rights protected under the First Amendment of the United States Constitution and/or Illinois Constitution Article I, Sections 3, 4 and 5; 
g.  An activity conducted by a nonprofit or governmental entity that provides recreation, education, training, or other care under the supervision of one or more adults. 
(Ord. No. 11-12, § 9.68.050(B), 8-8-2011) 
Sec. 36-459. - Police officer to make reasonable inquiry regarding defenses. 
    Before taking any enforcement action under this division, a police officer shall attempt to obtain the apparent minor person's age, address and reason for being in the public place. In determining the age of a minor person and in the absence of convincing evidence, a police officer shall use the officer's best judgment in determining age. The police officer shall not issue a citation or make an arrest under this division unless the police officer reasonably believes that an offense has occurred and that, based on any response and other circumstances, no exceptions mentioned in section 36-458 are present. 
(Ord. No. 11-12, § 9.68.050(C), 8-8-2011) 
Sec. 36-460. - Unlawful for parents, guardians or custodians to permit violations. 
    It shall be unlawful for the parent, guardian or custodian of a minor person to permit such minor person to loiter, idle, wander, stroll, walk, run, play in or be found upon the public streets, alleys, parks, cemeteries, public buildings, places of amusement and entertainment, vacant, vacant lots or any public places/properties within the limits of the city, between the hours prescribed in section 36-457; provided, however, that the provisions of this section shall not apply to the exceptions stated in section 36-458. It shall be no defense that a parent, guardian or custodian was indifferent to the activities, conduct or whereabouts of such minor person. 
(Ord. No. 11-12, § 9.68.050(D), 8-8-2011) 
Sec. 36-461. - Owners of amusement places permitting minor persons during prohibited hours. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person operating places of amusement and entertainment to permit any minor persons to enter or remain in such places of amusement and entertainment during the hours prohibited and as prescribed in section 36-457; provided, however, that the provisions of this section do not apply when the minor person is accompanied by such minor person's parent, guardian or custodian. 
(Ord. No. 11-12, § 9.68.050(E), 8-8-2011) 
Sec. 36-462. - Minor persons violating provisions deemed delinquents. 
    Upon the second or any subsequent violation of any of the provisions of this division by any minor person, such minor person shall be deemed a delinquent junenile, and shall be taken and delivered to the proper public authorities to be dealt with according to law. 
(Ord. No. 11-12, § 9.68.050(F), 8-8-2011) 
Sec. 36-463. - Penalties. 
    A violation of any portion of this division is considered an offense by the parent, guardian or custodian of the minor person and may be fined not less than $50.00 or more than $500.00 for each violation. Any minor person who violates any of the provisions of this division more than three times shall be reported to the proper public authorities as a juvenile in need of supervision and the matter shall be referred to the county state's attorney and the state department of children and family services and any other proper public authorities. 
(Ord. No. 11-12, § 9.68.050(G), 8-8-2011) 
Chapter 38 - PARKS, RECREATION AND CULTURAL AFFAIRS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to grant control of parks to local park boards, 70 ILCS 1245/5; maintenance of public streets by park commissions and boards, 65 ILCS 5/11-86-1; authority of municipalities with populations of 15,000 or less to acquire certain property for public parks, 65 ILCS 5/11-100-1; municipal authority to accept dedication of public lands, 65 ILCS 5/11-105-1; Swimming Facility Act, 210 ILCS 125/1 et seq.; Boat Registration and Safety Act, 625 ILCS 45/1-1 et seq.; municipal cultural centers, 65 ILCS 5/11-45.1-1; Campground Licensing and Recreational Area Act, 210 ILCS 95/1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 38-1-38-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARK MANAGEMENT 

Sec. 38-19. - Management and control of parks. 
    The management, care, control, and custody of the city parks and all of the property belonging and pertaining thereto shall be under the supervision of the director of public works to the extent delegated by the city council. 
(Prior Code, § 526; Code 1977, § 12.28.010; Ord. No. 507, § 1, 1963) 
Sec. 38-20. - Destruction of park property prohibited. 
    Whoever removes or carries away, or willfully, maliciously, or negligently breaks, defaces, destroys, or otherwise injures any tree, shrub, plant, vase, flowerpot, railing, fence, gate, structure or other article, property, or thing in, within, or on the city's Waterworks Park, or belonging thereto, or placed or erected therein, or whoever plucks any flowers therein, or trespasses upon or maltreats any flowerbed, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Prior Code, § 527; Code 1977, § 12.28.020) 
Sec. 38-21. - Billposting prohibited. 
    No person shall post or affix any placard, bill, notice, or other paper; or print, paint, stamp, stain, cut, carve, write, inscribe, or mark any sign or inscription upon any structure, sidewalk, or thing within any park in the city; and any person so doing shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Prior Code, § 528; Code 1977, § 12.28.030) 
Sec. 38-22. - Disorderly conduct prohibited. 
    Any person engaging in any disorderly conduct or in any lewd or lascivious conduct or behavior in any park within the city is guilty of violation of this section and may be removed therefrom by any person having police power. 
(Prior Code, § 529; Code 1977, § 12.28.040) 
Secs. 38-23-38-47. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LIBRARY[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Illinois Local Library Act, 75 ILCS 5/0.1 et seq.; authority for establishment of municipal library, 75 ILCS 5/1-2; authority for municipalities to provide penalties for failure to return library books and materials, 75 ILCS 5/1-5; board of library trustees, 75 ILCS 5/4-1 et seq.; requirement for posting of theft warning in public libraries, 720 ILCS 5/16B-3. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 38-48. - Established; name. 
    There is established a public library and reading room for the use and benefit of the inhabitants of the city and such persons residing outside of the city as may desire to use the same upon the terms and conditions prescribed by the library board of directors. The name of the public library shall be the Odell Public Library. 
(Prior Code, §§ 337, 338; Code 1977, § 2.80.010) 
Sec. 38-49. - Tax levy; fund. 
    The council shall in each year levy a tax not to exceed the amount authorized by statute in such case made and provided, the same to be levied and collected in like manner as the general taxes of the city, and to be known as the library fund. 
(Prior Code, § 339; Code 1977, § 2.80.020) 
Sec. 38-50. - Defacing property prohibited. 
    Any person who willfully or maliciously cuts, writes upon, injures, defaces, tears or destroys any book, newspaper, plate, picture, engraving, or other property belonging to or in the custody of the officers of the library shall be liable for a fine of not less than the replacement cost plus labor to repair defacement for each offense. 
(Prior Code, § 343; Code 1977, § 2.80.060; Ord. No. 96-22, § 1, 1996) 
Sec. 38-51. - Injuring grounds or building prohibited. 
    Any person who willfully or maliciously commits any injury to the grounds, buildings, fixtures, or other property of the library, shall be liable to a fine of not less than $5.00 nor more than $100.00 for each offense. 
(Prior Code, § 344; Code 1977, § 2.80.070) 
Sec. 38-52. - Failure to return books; penalty. 
    Any person who fails to return any book belonging to the library according to the requirements of the bylaws, rules and regulations made and adopted by the directors of the library for the government thereof, shall be liable for the replacement cost of material, a processing fee in the amount provided in the city fee schedule in chapter 20, and a fine in the amount provided in the city penalty schedule in chapter 20 for each offense. 
(Prior Code, § 345; Code 1977, § 2.80.080; Ord. No. 96-22, § 1, 1996) 
Secs. 38-53-38-77. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - COMMUNITY ROOM 

Sec. 38-78. - Public use. 
    The community room of the Odell Public Library shall be available for use by the general public at such times as it does not interfere with events scheduled by the city. Use of the community room will be on a first-come, first-served basis. The use of the community room may be applied for up to six months in advance. Rental of the community room shall be processed as follows: 
(1)  The interested party ("applicant") shall obtain an application from the office of the city clerk at city hall, complete the application, and submit same to the city clerk or his designee for consideration of acceptance and dates of availability. 
(2)  Upon determining an available date, the applicant shall submit a deposit in the amount provided in the city fee schedule to reserve use of the community room on the date selected. 
(3)  At the time the applicant requests the key for the community room for the day reserved, they shall make payment in full of the required fee. 
(4)  The deposit shall be returned to the applicant upon receipt of the key to the community room and a report that the facilities were left in a clean and orderly manner without damages. 
(5)  The applicant shall be responsible for payment for repairs to damages to the community room caused by their use of the facility, as determined by the city. 
(Code 1977, § 2.80.090(A); Ord. No. 07-02, § 2, 2007) 
Sec. 38-79. - User fees-Generally. 
    User fees for the rental of the community room shall be in the amounts provided in the city fee schedule in chapter 20. The user fee shall be paid in full and made payable to the City of Morrison and submitted to the city clerk or his designee. 
(Code 1977, § 2.80.090(B); Ord. No. 07-02, § 2, 2007) 
Sec. 38-80. - Same-Exemptions. 
(a)  Organizations recognized as 501(c)(3) organizations by the Internal Revenue Service, other not-for-profit community groups and clubs, and units of government shall be exempt from payment of user fees for use of the community room. 
(b)  Community groups and clubs shall include but not be limited to service organizations incorporated or based in the city whose purpose is for the benefit of the community as a whole, or have memberships open to members of the city's community whose purpose is the furthering of the interest and knowledge of a recreational activity or hobby. 
(Code 1977, § 2.80.090(C); Ord. No. 07-02, § 2, 2007) 
Sec. 38-81. - Same-Political groups. 
    Groups having stated political goals or which are carrying out activities to influence or affect political or legislative issues shall not be exempt from said user fees. 
(Code 1977, § 2.80.090(C); Ord. No. 07-02, § 2, 2007) 
Chapter 40 - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to regulate and tax hawkers, peddlers, pawnbrokers, itinerant merchants, and transient vendors, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-5; solicitation for Charity Act, 225 ILCS 460/0.01 et seq.; Transient Merchant Act of 1987, 225 ILCS 465/1 et seq.; prohibited sales at flea markets, 225 ILCS 465/5.5; offense of solicitation, 720 ILCS 5/8-1. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 40-1-40-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PEDDLERS, HAWKERS AND TRANSIENT MERCHANTS 

Sec. 40-19. - Designated. 
    Every person who travels from place to place in the city who sells, offers for sale, barter, or exchange any personal property, and every itinerant vendor; that is, every person who goes from one city or village to another, stopping transiently in each, for the purpose of selling personal property, shall be deemed a peddler. 
(Prior Code, § 307; Code 1977, § 5.20.010) 
Sec. 40-20. - License-Required. 
    No person shall hawk or peddle any personal property whatever within the city, except as otherwise provided in this chapter, without a license for that purpose. 
(Prior Code, § 306; Code 1977, § 5.20.020) 
Sec. 40-21. - Same-Fee. 
    The fee for a peddler's license shall be as provided in the city fee schedule in chapter 20. 
(Prior Code, § 308; Code 1977, § 5.20.030) 
Sec. 40-22. - Same-Securing. 
    Persons desirous of securing licenses under this article shall receive the same from the city clerk upon payment to him of the license fee required, together with a license fee in the amount provided in the city fee schedule in chapter 20. 
(Prior Code, § 309; Code 1977, § 5.20.040) 
Sec. 40-23. - Same-Nontransferability. 
    No license issued under the provisions of this article shall authorize anyone except the person to whom such license was issued to engage in the business therein named, either as principal or agent; and no person licensed under this chapter shall have any power to authorize any other person in his stead, to engage in such business. 
(Prior Code, § 310; Code 1977, § 5.20.050) 
Sec. 40-24. - Transient merchants. 
    No transient trader or merchant who may come to the city and open a place or store within the city for the purpose of disposing of goods, wares, or merchandise at auction or private sale, as owners or agents, temporarily, not intending to establish a permanent or regular business in the city, shall carry on such business without a license therefor which license may be issued by the city clerk upon the payment by the applicant of the license fee and the clerk's administrative fee provided in the city fee schedule in chapter 20. 
(Prior Code, § 311; Code 1977, § 5.20.060) 
Secs. 40-25-40-51. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SOLICITORS 

Sec. 40-52. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Solicitor means any person who makes it a practice of going in and upon private residential property without having been requested or invited so to do by the owners or occupants thereof, for the following purposes: 
(1)  Selling personal property by sample; 
(2)  Taking orders for the purchase of personal property to be delivered later; 
(3)  Taking subscriptions for magazines or periodical publications or both; 
(4)  Inducing another to sit, or to cause others to sit, for photographs or portraits or both. 
(Code 1977, § 5.20.080; Ord. No. 00-23, 2000) 
Sec. 40-53. - Duty of solicitors entering on residential premises. 
    Any solicitor who has gained entrance to any residence, whether invited or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises when requested to do so by the occupant. 
(Code 1977, § 5.20.090; Ord. No. 00-23, 2000) 
Sec. 40-54. - Soliciting prohibited during certain hours and days. 
    It is declared to be unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance for any person, whether licensed under this article or not, to go upon any premises and ring the doorbell upon or near any door of a residence located thereon, or rap or knock upon any door, or create a sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of such residence, for the purpose of securing an audience with the occupant thereof and engage in soliciting, prior to 9:00 a.m. or after 8:00 p.m. of any weekday, or at any time on a Sunday or on a state or national holiday. 
(Code 1977, § 5.20.100; Ord. No. 00-23, 2000) 
Sec. 40-55. - Posting of notice by occupant. 
    Any solicitor, upon approaching a residence that has conspicuously posted a "No Solicitors" sign, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises. 
(Code 1977, § 5.20.110; Ord. No. 00-23, 2000) 
Sec. 40-56. - License required; fee. 
    All solicitors are required to obtain a license from the city clerk prior to engaging in the practice within the city. The fee for such license shall be as provided in the city fee schedule in chapter 20, including a license fee and an administrative fee. No part of any fee provided for in this section shall be refunded for any reason. 
(Code 1977, § 5.20.120; Ord. No. 00-23, 2000) 
Sec. 40-57. - Manager's license. 
    Any person in charge of, managing, directing, or employing two or more solicitors to work in the city shall also obtain a solicitor's license, whether or not such person actively engages in the practice of soliciting. The fees for managers' licenses shall be as provided in the city fee schedule in chapter 20, and shall include a license and administrative fee. 
(Code 1977, § 5.20.130; Ord. No. 00-23, 2000) 
Sec. 40-58. - License application information. 
    Each applicant for such license shall state his name, date of birth, place of abode while working as a solicitor in the city, his permanent residence, social security number, and the number of days or weeks the applicant expects to be engaged in the practice of soliciting in the city. The city clerk shall keep a record thereof. Each applicant shall display, to the city clerk, a valid identification document, with a photograph, verifying the information on the application. 
(Code 1977, § 5.20.140; Ord. No. 00-23, 2000) 
Sec. 40-59. - Issuance or denial. 
(a)  The city clerk, after consideration of the application and all information obtained relative thereto and upon the recommendation of the chief of police or his designee, shall deny the application if the applicant does not possess the qualifications for such license as required in this section, or if the issuance of a license to the applicant would not be in accord with the intent and purpose of this article. Endorsement shall be made by the city clerk upon the application or the denial of the application. When the applicant is found to be fully qualified, the license shall be issued forthwith. 
(b)  No license shall be issued to any person who has been convicted of the commission of a felony under the laws of this state or any other state or federal law within five years of the date of application, or to any person who has been convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this article, or to any person whose license issued under this division has previously been revoked as provided in this division. 
(Code 1977, § 5.20.150; Ord. No. 00-23, 2000) 
Sec. 40-60. - Revocation. 
    Any license issued under this article shall be revoked by the chief of police, or his designee, if the holder of the license is convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this article, or has made a false material statement in the application, or otherwise becomes disqualified for the issuance of a license under the terms of this article. Immediately upon such revocation, written notice thereof shall be given by the chief of police, or his designee, to the holder of the license in person, or by United States mail addressed to his residence address set forth in the application. Immediately upon the giving of such notice, the license shall become null and void. 
(Code 1977, § 5.20.160; Ord. No. 00-23, 2000) 
Sec. 40-61. - Records. 
    The city clerk shall cause to be kept in his office an accurate record of every application received and acted upon under this article, together with all other information and data pertaining thereto and all licenses issued under the provisions of this article, and the denial of applications. Applications for licenses shall be numbered in consecutive order as filed, and every license issued, and any renewal thereof, shall be identified with the duplicate number of the application upon which it was issued. 
(Code 1977, § 5.20.170; Ord. No. 00-23, 2000) 
Sec. 40-62. - Nontransferability of license. 
    No license issued under this article shall be assignable or transferable; nor shall it authorize anyone except the person to whom such license was issued to engage in soliciting, either as principal or agent; and no person licensed under this article shall have power to authorize any person in his stead, to engage in such business. 
(Code 1977, § 5.20.180; Ord. No. 00-23, 2000) 
Chapter 42 - SECONDHAND GOODS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Junkyard Act, 415 ILCS 95/0.01 et seq.; Pawnbroker Regulation Act, 205 ILCS 510/0.01 et seq.; municipal authority for licensing and regulation of secondhand and junk stores, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-3. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 42-1. - Yard sale restrictions. 
    It shall be unlawful and a nuisance to conduct a yard sale within the city limits in excess of two yard sales per calendar year. Said yard sale shall not exceed a time period of three consecutive days. 
(Code 1977, § 8.08.029; Ord. No. 04-19, § 1, 2004) 
Secs. 42-2-42-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - JUNK DEALERS 

Secs. 42-21-42-43. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PAWNBROKERS 

Sec. 42-44. - Designation of pawnbroker. 
    Whoever loans money on deposit or pledge of personal property, or whoever deals in the purchase of personal property on condition of selling the same back at a stipulated price, is declared to be a pawnbroker. 
(Prior Code, § 543; Code 1977, § 5.16.010) 
State Law reference- Pawnbroker defined, 205 ILCS 510/1. 
Sec. 42-45. - License-Required. 
    No person shall engage in or pursue the business of a pawnbroker within the city without first having obtained a license therefor. All application for pawnbroker's license must be submitted to and specifically approved by the city council. 
(Prior Code, § 544; Code 1977, § 5.16.020) 
Sec. 42-46. - Same-Fee; bond. 
    Any person applying for a license as a pawnbroker shall, before receiving the same, pay to the city clerk an annual license fee in the amount provided in the city fee schedule, and shall give a bond to the city in the penal sum provided in the city bond schedule or in such other amount as may be specified by the city council upon approval of the license application, with sureties to be approved by the city clerk, conditioned for the observance of all ordinances of the city relating to pawnbrokers. 
(Prior Code, § 545; Code 1977, § 5.16.030) 
Sec. 42-47. - Recordkeeping required. 
    Every pawnbroker shall keep a suitable book, in which shall be written in ink, at the time of making each loan, an accurate description of the goods, article, or thing pawned or pledged, the amount of money loaned thereon, the time for which the same is pledged, the rate of interest to be paid on said loan, and the name, residence, and street number of the person pawning or pledging the goods, article, or thing. 
(Prior Code, § 546; Code 1977, § 5.16.040) 
State Law reference- Record requirements, 205 ILCS 510/5. 
Sec. 42-48. - Inspection of records. 
    The book required to be kept under section 42-47 shall, at all reasonable times, be open to inspection by any member of the police department. 
(Prior Code, § 547; Code 1977, § 5.16.050) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, 205 ILCS 510/6. 
Sec. 42-49. - Conducting business with certain persons prohibited. 
    No pawnbroker shall take or receive in pawn or pledge, for money loaned, any property, article, or thing of value from an intoxicated person, or from any person known by him to be a thief or to have been convicted of burglary or larceny, nor from any minor without the written consent of his parent or guardian. 
(Prior Code, § 549; Code 1977, § 5.16.070) 
State Law reference- Property from minors, 205 ILCS 510/8; property from intoxicated person or thief, 205 ILCS 510/9. 
Sec. 42-50. - Duty of chief of police to report to mayor. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police to report to the mayor any failure on the part of any person licensed as under this article to comply with any of the provisions of this article; and the city council may revoke the license of any such person on satisfactory cause appearing to it for so doing. 
(Prior Code, § 550; Code 1977, § 5.16.080) 
State Law reference- Similar provision regarding reports to commissioner, 205 ILCS 510/7.5. 
Chapter 44 - SIGNS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Highway Advertising Control Act, 225 ILCS 440/1 et seq.; municipal authority to regulate all street advertising and adult entertainment advertisements, 65 ILCS 5/11-80-15; authority for removal of unauthorized signs and billboards constituting obstructions, 605 ILCS 5/9-112; auction signs and billboards, 720 ILCS 225/1; financial institution insurance signs, 215 ILCS 5/1414; warning signs required in gambling establishments, 230 ILCS 25/4.3; cigarette health warning signs, 410 ILCS 85/1 et seq.; no smoking signs, 410 ILCS 82/20; deceptive advertising, 720 ILCS 295/1a; no smoking signs required in fireworks sale establishments, 425 ILCS 30/9. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 44-1. - Purpose. 
    The intent of this chapter is to regulate the size, location, type, number, and maintenance of signs within the city and to promote the public's health, safety, and welfare. It strives to provide adequate community identification and advertising while maintaining an attractive appearance. 
(Code 1977, § 17.44.010; Ord. No. 06-04, 2006) 
Sec. 44-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Abandoned sign means a sign which has been discontinued for a period of 90 days, regardless of the intent to resume or not to abandon such use. 
    Advertising sign/billboard means an off-premises sign directing the public attention which displays the business, entertainment, profession, or service offered at a location other than the premises in which the sign is located. 
    Awning, canopy, or marquee sign means any sign made of cloth or other nonrigid material attached to and projecting from a building and including structures which are fixed or so erected as to permit their being raised or retracted to a position against the building when not in use. 
    Banner sign means a temporary sign made of cloth, paper, or plastic attached to a pole or building. 
    Business sign means a sign which directs attention to a business or profession conducted or to a commodity, service, or entertainment sold or offered upon the premises where such sign is located or to which it is affixed. 
    Changeable copy sign means a sign in which a message board can be changed manually or automatically. 
    Contractor sign means a temporary sign on the premises in which construction is taking place indicating the name of a contractor or other firms assisting with the project. 
    Event sign means a temporary sign indicating the location and/or time of an event. 
    Freestanding sign means a sign that is supported by one or more braces, poles, or uprights and is not attached to any building. 
    Garage sale sign means a temporary sign located either on-premises or off-premises indicating the location and hours of a garage sale, yard sale, or open house. 
    Government sign means a sign located either on-premises or off-premises indicating necessary information required by state, local, or federal statute or ordinance. 
    Home occupation sign means a temporary sign containing only the name and occupation of a permitted home occupation. 
    Illumination sign means a sign in which the characters, letters, or figures are illuminated by artificial or natural light, is maintained stationary and constant in intensity and color at all times when such sign is in use, and may contain electronically changing messages. 
    Inflatable sign means a sign which is attached to or painted on a device which can be inflated. 
    Memorial sign means a temporary sign or statute helping to remember a person or event. 
    Monument sign means a ground-mounted detached freestanding sign that sits low to the ground and incorporates architectural detailing. 
    Nameplate sign means an on-premises nonelectric sign identifying only the name and/or address of the occupant on which the sign is located. 
    Neon sign means a sign made of glass tubing, which is electrified to cause fluorescent agents to glow in various colors. 
    Overhanging sign means any sign, signboard, billboard, or advertising device of any kind which extends over any public street, sidewalk, alley, or other public place in the city, or which is so located that it may fall upon any such public place. But the term shall not include any billboard or poster panel constructed entirely on private property and not extending over any such public place provided such billboard or poster panel is constructed and maintained in compliance with the ordinances of the city pertaining thereto. The term also shall not include a projecting sign as defined in this section. 
    Political sign means a temporary sign supporting political candidates for local, county, state, or national elections. 
    Portable sign means a temporary sign not affixed to a building that can be moved from site to site. 
    Projecting sign means any sign, other than an overhanging sign, which is supported by an exterior wall or facade of a building with the exposed face or faces of said sign in a plane perpendicular or approximately perpendicular to the plane of the wall or façade, and projecting 12 inches or more from the wall or façade where attached or anchored. 
    Real estate sign means a temporary sign indicating the sale, lease, or rental on the premises on which it is located. 
    Roof sign means a sign mounted or attached to a roof of a building. 
    Shopping center identification sign means a sign identifying the name of a shopping center and may include the identities of one or more of the businesses located within the development. 
    Sign area means the gross surface area within the sign frame, exclusive of the frame or support structure. The sign area of a sign with back-to-back faces shall be computed using only one face. The sign area of a multiple-faced sign shall be computed using the gross surface area of the nonparallel sign faces. 
    Subdivision identification sign means a monument sign identifying a subdivision, apartment, or other multifamily residential complex. 
    Temporary sign means a sign which is only intended to be displayed for a short period of time. 
    Wall sign means a sign mounted to, attached to, or painted on an exterior wall of a building. 
    Window sign means a sign attached to the inside of a window that is visible from the exterior of a building. 
(Code 1977, § 17.44.020; Ord. No. 06-04, 2006; Ord. No. 14-22, § 1, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 44-3. - Effect of provisions on existing signs. 
    This chapter shall not require the removal of any existing sign, provided that it is firmly secured and does not interfere with the use of any fire escape or window, or with pedestrian or vehicular traffic, and provided that the maintenance fee therefor is paid. 
(Prior Code, § 626; Code 1977, § 15.16.110) 
Sec. 44-4. - Applicability of zoning chapter. 
    The provisions of chapter 62 of the Municipal Code of the City of Morrison regulating zoning shall apply to and govern any request by any person for a variance from or exception to the strict application of the provisions of this chapter 44, including procedures for the granting or denial of variances and appeals from decisions respecting such grant or denial, all to the same extent as though the provisions of chapter 44 were specifically included within the provisions of chapter 62 of the Municipal Code of the City of Morrison. 
(Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-13-2014) 
Secs. 44-5-44-24. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TYPES OF SIGNS ALLOWED AND PROHIBITED 

Sec. 44-25. - Nonconforming signs. 
(a)  Subject to the limitations and termination provisions hereinafter set forth, any lawful existing nonconforming sign may be continued so long as it otherwise remains lawful after the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived. No nonconforming sign shall be: 
(1)  Changed or altered in any manner which would increase the degree of its nonconformity; 
(2)  Expanded; 
(3)  Changed or altered to prolong its useful life; 
(4)  Moved in whole or in part to any other location where it would remain nonconforming. 
(b)  Any nonconforming sign that meets any of the criteria of subsection (a) of this section shall be subject to the provisions provided in this chapter. Should any nonconforming sign be damaged to at least 50 percent of its replacement cost, the sign shall not be replaced except according to the provisions provided in this chapter and shall apply for a sign permit. 
(Code 1977, § 17.44.030; Ord. No. 06-04, 2006) 
Sec. 44-26. - Prohibited signs. 
    The following signs are prohibited in all districts in the city: 
(1)  Abandoned signs which have not been in use for a period of 90 days, regardless of the intent to resume or not to abandon such use. Such signs shall be removed within 30 days of the determination that the sign is abandoned; 
(2)  Flashing or blinking signs, except as provided in this chapter; 
(3)  Portable signs, except as provided in this chapter; 
(4)  Roof signs; 
(5)  Signs displaying indecent, immoral, or obscene matter; 
(6)  Signs displaying words or phrases which may confuse or interfere with pedestrian and vehicular traffic; 
(7)  Signs attached to a tree, utility pole, fire hydrant, or other objects located on or projecting over public property; 
(8)  Signs that because of poor maintenance, structure, or disrepair are deemed unsafe; 
(9)  Permanent signs which must be inflated; 
(10)  Signs mounted or affixed to vehicles or trailers which are parked so as to be visible from a public right-of-way where the apparent primary purpose is to advertise a product or direct people to a business activity located on the same or nearby property. 
(Code 1977, § 17.44.050; Ord. No. 06-04, 2006; Ord. No. 14-22, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 44-27. - Dangerous signs prohibited; abatement. 
    It is unlawful to permit any overhanging sign to be or remain in a dangerous condition so that any part of it is likely to fall upon any public place. After due notice given to the owner or party in control of the same, such sign shall be removed by the owner or party in control of same and, upon his failure to do so, the chief of police shall cause the sign to be removed at the expense of the owner or party in control. 
(Prior Code, § 627; Code 1977, § 15.16.120) 
Sec. 44-28. - Billboards; declaration of nuisance; removal. 
    Whenever a majority of the owners of the real estate upon any block in the city petition the city council to cause the removal of any billboard that may be erected on any part of the block, within 30 feet of the sidewalk, the city council may in its discretion thereupon declare the billboard to be a nuisance and shall direct the city clerk to notify the owner thereof to remove the same within ten days after it is declared to be a nuisance. If the owner of the billboard does not remove the same within ten days after receiving the notice, he shall be deemed guilty of maintaining a nuisance and shall be subject to a penalty as provided in section 1-15. 
(Prior Code, § 463; Code 1977, § 15.16.130) 
Sec. 44-29. - Temporary signs. 
(a)  Temporary signs shall be subject to the provisions provided within this chapter. All temporary signs shall be erected and maintained in a safe manner. 
(b)  No temporary sign with a height of at least four feet and not exceeding six feet shall be located closer than ten feet to a public right-of-way and shall not extend above or beyond any street, alley, sidewalk, or other public thoroughfare, with the exception of event banner signs only after approval from the city council. No temporary sign with a height of less than four feet shall be closer than five feet to a public right-of-way. 
(c)  Event banner signs are permitted for an event only after approval from the city council. Each event is allocated one on- or off-premises banner sign not exceeding a sign area of 100 square feet, not erected more than seven days prior to an event, and shall be removed two days following the event. 
(Code 1977, § 17.44.070; Ord. No. 06-04, 2006) 
Secs. 44-30-44-46. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LOCATION RESTRICTIONS 

Sec. 44-47. - Placement restrictions. 
    No sign shall be erected, hung, or attached so as to obstruct any window, door, fire escape, balcony, platform, stairway, ladder, stack, vent pipe, or ingress to or egress from any building; nor so as to hinder the placing of ladders against such building by the fire department; nor within five feet of the adjoining property if such sign protrudes more than one foot from the property line. 
(Prior Code, § 625; Code 1977, § 15.16.100) 
Sec. 44-48. - Freestanding signs. 
(a)  No freestanding sign shall be located closer than 25 feet from any other sign located on another lot. No freestanding sign shall be located closer than 150 feet from any other sign located on the same lot. 
(b)  No freestanding sign shall be located closer than ten feet from any public right-of-way. 
(Code 1977, § 17.44.080B; Ord. No. 06-04, 2006) 
Sec. 44-49. - Signs allowed-In residential districts. 
    The following signs are allowed in R-1, R-2, R-3, and R-R districts: 
(1)  Exempt signs. Exempt signs not requiring a permit pursuant to the provisions of article V of this chapter. 
(2)  Monument subdivision identification signs. 
a.  One subdivision identification sign shall be permitted per subdivision or multifamily residential complex. 
b.  Only the name and address of the building, complex, or neighborhood shall be permitted on the sign. 
c.  No subdivision identification sign shall exceed 30 square feet in sign area. 
d.  No subdivision identification sign shall be more than six feet above grade level. 
e.  All signs shall be at least six feet from the front, side, or rear lot lines. 
f.  Signs may be illuminated only after approval by the zoning administrator. 
(Code 1977, § 17.44.090; Ord. No. 06-04, 2006) 
Sec. 44-50. - Same-In commercial and industrial districts. 
    A property may incorporate one awning, canopy, or marquee sign or one wall sign in the C-1 district. A property may incorporate one awning, canopy, or marquee sign or one wall sign and one freestanding sign or one monument sign in the C-2, C-3, and I-1, I-2 districts. The following signs are permitted within the C-1, C-2, C-3, I-1, and I-2 districts: 
(1)  Exempt signs. Exempt signs not requiring a permit subject to the provisions provided within article V of this chapter. 
(2)  Awning, canopy, or marquee business signs. 
a.  One awning, canopy, or marquee business sign shall be permitted per lot. 
b.  In the C-1 and C-2 districts, no sign shall exceed 50 square feet in sign area or one square foot per each one foot of frontage, whichever is less. In the C-3, I-1, and I-2 districts, no sign shall exceed 100 square feet or one square foot per each one foot of frontage, whichever is less. 
c.  Each sign shall be at least eight feet above grade level and shall not exceed 20 feet above grade level. 
d.  No sign may extend over a public street or thoroughfare and shall not extend farther than six feet from the wall. 
(3)  Wall business signs. 
a.  One wall business sign shall be permitted per lot. If a property is located on a corner lot, one wall business sign shall be permitted per each side fronting a public street. 
b.  No wall business sign shall exceed 50 square feet or one square foot of sign area per each one foot of building frontage, whichever is less. 
c.  No sign shall exceed 20 feet above grade level. 
d.  All signs shall be affixed firmly to the wall and may not extend over the top or ends of the wall in which they are affixed more than 18 inches. 
e.  Signs may be illuminated in the manner provided in this chapter. 
(4)  Freestanding business signs. 
a.  One freestanding business sign shall be permitted per lot in the C-2, C-3, I-1, and I-2 districts. Two freestanding signs may be permitted for single user lots with more than 300 feet of building frontage on a public street. All freestanding signs shall be at least 150 feet apart from signs located on the same premises. Freestanding signs are not permitted in the C-1 district. 
b.  No freestanding business sign shall exceed 100 square feet or one square foot of sign area per each one foot of building frontage, whichever is less. 
c.  No sign shall exceed 20 feet above grade level in the C-2, I-1, and I-2 districts or 25 feet above grade level in the C-3 district. 
d.  Changeable (manual or automatic) copy is permitted on freestanding signs only after approval by the zoning administrator. 
e.  Signs may be illuminated in the manner provided in this chapter. 
(5)  Monument business signs. 
a.  One monument business sign shall be permitted per lot in the C-2, C-3, I-1, and I-2 districts. Two monument signs may be permitted for single user lots with more than 300 feet of building frontage on a public street. Monument signs are not permitted in the C-1 district. 
b.  No monument business sign shall exceed 75 square feet or one square foot of sign area per each one foot of building frontage, whichever is less. In cases where two monument signs are permitted, the aggregate sign area shall not exceed 150 square feet. 
c.  No sign shall exceed five feet above grade level. No sign shall interfere with the visibility of passing motorists. 
d.  All monument signs shall be securely attached to the ground. 
e.  Whenever possible, monument signs should incorporate similar materials of the surrounding buildings and signs. 
f.  Signs may be illuminated in the manner provided in this chapter. 
(6)  Shopping center identification signs. 
a.  One shopping center identification sign shall be permitted for all joint commercial developments of at least five acres in the C-3 district, not including the permitted signs for the individual business signs located within the development. All shopping center identification signs shall be at least 150 feet from any other signs. 
b.  The shopping center identification sign shall only identify the name and location of the development, though the identities of the individual businesses located within the development may be shown if the sign area of the individual business signs is not more than half of the sign area of the shopping center identification sign. 
c.  No shopping center sign shall exceed 125 square feet or one square foot of sign area per each one foot of building frontage, whichever is less. 
d.  No sign shall exceed 15 feet above grade level. No sign shall interfere with the visibility of passing motorists. 
e.  Shopping center identification signs may be freestanding or monument style, but monument signs are recommended. Whenever possible, shopping center identification signs should incorporate similar materials of the surrounding buildings and signs. 
f.  Signs may be illuminated in the manner provided in this chapter. 
(7)  Temporary inflatable signs. 
a.  One temporary inflatable sign shall be permitted per lot in the C-3 district. 
b.  No sign shall exceed a sign area of 30 square feet. 
c.  Such signs shall not be erected more than 24 hours prior to an event or advertised sale and shall be removed 24 hours following an event or advertised sale. 
d.  No sign or inflatable device shall exceed 20 feet above grade level. 
e.  Only two signs shall be permitted per lot per year. 
f.  All inflatable devices shall be affixed firmly to the ground or a pole and not interfere with the public's health and safety. 
(8)  Projecting sign. 
a.  One projecting sign shall be permitted per building; 
b.  No projecting sign shall exceed six square feet in sign area, to be measured by a single side of the sign; 
c.  A projecting sign shall extend no more than 42 inches from the wall or façade of the building to which it is attached or anchored; 
d.  The sign shall be affixed not lower than eight feet above grade, and no higher than 11 feet above grade, as measured from the bottom edge of the sign; the minimum and maximum dimensions for clearance set forth herein do not apply to any hardware employed to attach or affix the sign to the building wall or façade; 
e.  The projecting sign shall be affixed as close as is reasonably possible to the entrance to the premises; 
f.  The projecting sign shall be affixed below the eave or parapet line of the building; 
g.  The sign shall be compatible in design, color, size, and scale with the wall or façade to which it is affixed, and adjoining structures and surroundings, and, if upon a landmark or within an historic district, it shall be of appropriate historic character; 
h.  Projecting signs shall not contain changeable copy; 
i.  Projecting signs may not be internally illuminated; external lighting is permissible; 
j.  Any projecting sign proposed to be placed on a building within an historic district or upon a building which has been designated a landmark shall be subject to the certificate of appropriateness process of the Morrison Historic Preservation Commission. 
(Code 1977, § 17.44.100; Ord. No. 06-04, 2006; Ord. No. 14-22, § 3, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 44-51. - Advertising signs/billboards; special use permits required. 
    Advertising signs/billboards shall be subject to the following regulations and shall require the issuance of a special use permit by the city: 
(1)  Advertising signs/billboards shall only be permitted on unimproved lots in the C-3, I-1, and I-2 districts. 
(2)  Only one advertising sign/billboard shall be permitted per lot. 
(3)  No advertising sign/billboard shall exceed 200 square feet in area. 
(4)  No advertising sign/billboard shall exceed 20 feet above grade level. 
(5)  No advertising sign/billboard shall be located closer than 15 feet from any public right-of-way. 
(6)  No advertising sign/billboard shall be located closer than 250 feet from any residential district, public park, or recreation area. 
(7)  No advertising sign/billboard shall be located closer than 1,000 feet of another advertising sign/billboard. 
(8)  No advertising sign/billboard shall be located closer than 200 feet to any on-premises freestanding sign. 
(9)  No advertising sign/billboard shall be located closer than 100 feet to any intersection of two or more streets. 
(10)  All advertising signs/billboards shall be firmly attached by braces, poles, or uprights, and shall not be attached to a wall or roof. 
(11)  Advertising signs/billboards may be illuminated in the manner provided in this chapter. 
(Code 1977, § 17.44.110; Ord. No. 06-04, 2006) 
Secs. 44-52-44-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CONSTRUCTION AND MAINTENANCE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 44-76. - Materials and methods of construction. 
    All overhanging signs shall be constructed of galvanized iron, copper, brass, glass, or other noncorrosive incombustible material. All such signs, if placed at a right or other angle to the wall or roof of any building, shall be attached by such noncorrosive metal bolts, anchors, cables, or other metal attachments to ensure permanent and safe construction, and shall be maintained free from rust or other defects. Every means or device used for attaching any such sign shall extend through the walls or roof of the building, and shall be securely anchored by wall plates and nuts to the inside of the walls or to bearings on the underside of two or more ceiling joists. Small signs containing less than ten feet of area may be attached flat to a building by the use of lag bolts or other suitable means. 
(Prior Code, § 625; Code 1977, § 15.16.060) 
Sec. 44-77. - Maintenance-Generally. 
(a)  The owner of a sign shall be required to maintain the sign in good structural condition. The sign and sign supports must be regularly painted to prevent rust and corrosion. 
(b)  The area around the sign, including any landscaping, shall be kept free of debris and weeds and shall not obstruct the view of traffic. 
(Code 1977, § 17.44.080F; Ord. No. 06-04, 2006) 
Sec. 44-78. - Same-Fee. 
    It is unlawful to maintain any overhanging sign or for the owner of any building or property to permit such a sign to remain thereon or be attached thereto, without paying an annual maintenance fee in the amount provided in the city schedule payable to the city on or before January 1 of each year. 
(Prior Code, § 624; Code 1977, § 15.16.050) 
Secs. 44-79-44-99. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DESIGN AND SPECIFICATIONS 

Sec. 44-100. - Illumination. 
(a)  All illuminated signs shall be designed so as to reflect light away from a residential district. Illuminated signs located adjacent to a residential district may only be in operation from 7:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m. 
(b)  No illuminated sign shall cause a traffic hazard for any passing motorists. The signs shall not interfere with a driver's ability to see approaching, merging, or intersecting traffic. 
(c)  The level of illumination shall not be more than 50 footcandles measured perpendicular to the sign face at a distance equal to the narrowest dimension of such sign face. 
(d)  Changeable copy signs (manual or automatic) advertising a product, service, or event are permitted as long as the sign message is not changed more than twice during a 24-hour period, the message remains depicted for a minimum of six seconds, and the sign is attached to the primary sign. The gross surface area of the changeable copy sign shall be considered part of the total permitted sign area for the district in which the sign is located. 
(e)  No flashing or blinking signs or continuously scrolling messages shall be permitted. 
(Code 1977, § 17.44.080A; Ord. No. 06-04, 2006) 
Sec. 44-101. - Electrical components. 
    All signs in which electrical wiring and connections are required shall not endanger the health and safety of the residents of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 17.44.080C; Ord. No. 06-04, 2006) 
Sec. 44-102. - Structural components. 
    All signs and the corresponding structural components shall not endanger the health and safety of the residents of the city. Fire-resistant materials shall be used and all letters and figures shall be securely attached to the sign structure. 
(Code 1977, § 17.44.080D; Ord. No. 06-04, 2006) 
Sec. 44-103. - Sign heights. 
(a)  The bottom of every awning, canopy, or marquee shall be at least eight feet above grade level. 
(b)  Any freestanding sign located within 15 feet of a public right-of-way shall have a clearance between three and eight feet above grade level. 
(c)  Any freestanding sign located within 30 feet of a lot corner formed by an intersection of any two or more streets shall have a clearance between three and eight feet above grade level. 
(d)  The height of each sign shall conform to the regulations provided within each district in which the sign is located. 
(Code 1977, § 17.44.080E; Ord. No. 06-04, 2006) 
Sec. 44-104. - Aluminum canopies. 
    Where aluminum over-the-sidewalk canopies have been installed, all signs shall be of the flexiglass, under-canopy style, 48 inches in length and 12 inches in depth which, when viewed from the end thereof, appear triangular in shape and shall be installed so that the letters thereon are visible to approaching pedestrian and vehicular traffic. All other overhanging signs are specifically prohibited. 
(Prior Code, § 625a; Code 1977, § 15.16.070; Ord. No. 531, § 1, 1966) 
Sec. 44-105. - Rigidity and wind resistance. 
    Every overhanging sign and its support shall be capable of withstanding a wind pressure of 30 pounds to the square foot with a factor of safety of four. All such signs, if attached parallel to a building, shall be placed in close contact to the walls thereof; if offset from the building, the same shall be attached with an open space of not less than eight inches between the portion of the sign and the wall or roof or other portion of the building, in order to avoid the accumulation of combustible substances. Every sign shall be installed so as to be rigid. 
(Prior Code, § 625; Code 1977, § 15.16.080) 
Sec. 44-106. - Elevation and projection. 
    The lowest part of any sign, support, or appurtenance which extends over any street, alley, sidewalk, or other public place or way shall be at least ten feet above grade, or not less than 15 feet above any place used by vehicles. No sign shall project more than 42 inches beyond the property line, except that for the purpose of illumination a hood may be placed not to exceed six inches additional projection. No sign shall be supported from any point outside the property line. 
(Prior Code, § 625; Code 1977, § 15.16.090) 
Sec. 44-107. - Landscaping. 
    All permanent freestanding signs shall contain and be located within a landscaped area. A minimum of one square foot of landscaping area shall be required for every one square foot of sign area, with a minimum of 30 square feet of landscaping per freestanding sign. The proposed landscaping shall be submitted with the sign permit application. 
(Code 1977, § 17.44.080G; Ord. No. 06-04, 2006) 
Secs. 44-108-44-127. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PERMITS 

Sec. 44-128. - Required-Generally; exemption. 
    No sign shall be constructed, erected, originally painted, converted, altered, rebuilt, enlarged, remodeled, relocated, or expanded until a permit for such sign has been obtained in accordance with the standards and procedures set forth in this chapter. No sign shall be installed before a permit is issued. A sign permit is not required for minimal alterations to an existing sign or regular maintenance. 
(Code 1977, § 17.44.040; Ord. No. 06-04, 2006) 
Sec. 44-129. - Same-For overhanging sign. 
    It is unlawful to erect, hang, or construct any overhanging sign in the city without having first secured a permit therefor. 
(Prior Code, § 621; Code 1977, § 15.16.020) 
Sec. 44-130. - Application-Filing; fee; contents. 
    The applicant shall file an application for a sign permit with the city zoning administrator accompanied by a filing fee in the amount provided in the city fee schedule. The application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name, address, and phone number of the applicant, owner, and person or firm erecting the sign. 
(2)  The location of the building or structure for which the sign is proposed. 
(3)  A drawing of the proposed sign to accurate dimensions indicating height, dimensions, wording, and elevation and state specifically the type of sign, location on the lot, and any landscaping of a freestanding sign base. The drawing should show the entire lot complete with setbacks to all property lines, existing building footprint, signs, north arrow, and scale. 
(4)  Each such application shall be signed by the owner of the sign and by the owner of the building or premises to which it is attached, and shall contain an agreement substantially as follows: 
(Code 1977, § 17.44.040B; Ord. No. 06-04, 2006) 
Sec. 44-131. - Same-Review by zoning administrator; inspections. 
    The zoning administrator shall review the sign permit application to determine whether it complies with all of the applicable regulations within this chapter. The zoning administrator shall decide whether the sign permit application should be granted or denied as it relates to the standards and the purposes of the sign classifications of the city. All signs shall be inspected by the zoning administrator to ensure compliance with the application filed with the city. 
(Code 1977, § 17.44.040C; Ord. No. 06-04, 2006) 
Sec. 44-132. - Issuance; terms. 
    Sign permits shall be issued by the zoning administrator upon the approval of the application, the direction of the city council, and the payment of the maintenance fee for the current year in the amount provided in the city fee schedule; provided that all requirements of this chapter, other provisions of this Code, and all other ordinances of the city must be complied with. 
(Prior Code, § 623; Code 1977, § 15.16.040) 
Sec. 44-133. - Certain signs exempt from permit requirement. 
    The following signs shall not require a permit to erect a sign: 
(1)  Temporary contractor signs not exceeding a sign area of 30 square feet per construction project and shall be removed prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy. No temporary contractor sign shall be more than six feet above grade level. 
(2)  Temporary on-premises event signs not exceeding a sign area of 25 square feet per lot, not erected more than seven days prior to an event, and shall be removed two days following an event. No temporary event sign shall be more than four feet above grade level. 
(3)  Temporary garage sale and open house signs not exceeding a sign area of five square feet per lot, not to be erected more than 24 hours prior to an event, and to be removed immediately following the event. No temporary garage sale or open house sign shall be more than four feet above grade level. 
(4)  Temporary political signs not exceeding a sign area of six square feet per sign and 25 square feet per lot, not to be erected more than 60 days prior to an election, and must be removed seven days following an election. 
(5)  Temporary real estate signs not exceeding a sign area of six square feet per lot. The sign shall only be permitted on the property for sale. The sign shall be removed within seven days of the sale or lease of the premises upon which the sign is located. 
(6)  Commemorative plaques located on designated historical or other similar properties. 
(7)  Government or municipal signs pertaining to necessary signs. 
(8)  Signs within completely enclosed buildings and not visible from the outside of the building. 
(9)  Home occupation signs not exceeding a sign area of four square feet per lot and not illuminated. 
(10)  Nameplate signs not exceeding a sign area of two square feet per lot. 
(11)  Temporary inflatable signs permitted in the C-3 district and subject to the provisions provided in section 44-23. 
(12)  Temporary portable signs for the purpose of advertising an event or sale not exceeding a sign area of 30 square feet. No temporary portable sign shall be more than six feet above grade level. Such sign shall not be erected more than seven days prior to an event or sale and shall be removed two days following an event or sale. Such sign may contain manually changeable copy. 
(Code 1977, § 17.44.060; Ord. No. 06-04, 2006) 
Chapter 46 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Local Solid Waste Disposal Act, 415 ILCS 10/1 et seq.; Solid Waste Planning and Recycling Act, 415 ILCS 15/1 et seq.; Illinois Solid Waste Management Act, 415 ILCS 20/1 et seq.; disposal of refuse, garbage and ashes, 65 ILCS 5/11-19-1 et seq.; removal of garbage and debris, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-13; Environmental Protection Act, 415 ILCS 5/1 et seq.; "garbage" defined, 415 ILCS 5/3.200; "solid waste" defined, 415 ILCS 5/3.470; municipal solid waste landfill rules, 415 ILCS 5/22.40. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 46-1. - Penalties. 
    Except as otherwise specifically provided herein, violations of this chapter shall be punishable by a maximum fine of $100.00. 
(Code 1977, § 8.04.050; Ord. No. 90-06, 1990) 
Sec. 46-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bags means plastic sacks designed to store refuse with sufficient wall strength to maintain physical integrity when lifted by the top. Total weight of a bag and its contents shall not exceed 35 pounds. See also Garbage bags. 
    Bulky waste means rubbish such as stoves, refrigerators, water heaters, washing machines, white goods, furniture and other waste materials other than construction debris, dead animals, hazardous waste, automobile parts or stable matter with weights or volumes greater than those allowed for containers. 
    Bundle means yard waste such as trees, shrubs and brush trimmings securely tied together forming an easily handled package not exceeding 48 inches in length, four inches in diameter, or 50 pounds in weight. The diameter of any individual piece must not exceed four inches. 
    Burn barrel means any container of any type used for the containment while burning of any material, substance or thing.
