    Christmas tree program means a once-per-year program offered to all city residents the first or second week of January in which the city will collect Christmas trees placed at the curb for collection. 
    City means the City of Morrison or its authorized contractor. 
    Commercial container or dumpster means a large container of 11/2 yards or more utilized by commercial business for the deposit of commercially generated refuse. 
    Construction debris means waste building materials resulting from construction, remodeling, repair or demolition operations. 
    Container means a container or containers, meeting the requirements of this chapter, in which recyclable materials, refuse, rubbish and garbage can be stored and later placed for curbside collection as approved by the city. 
    Contractor means the person, corporation or partnership performing recycling, refuse and yard waste collection and disposal under contract with the city. 
    Curbside collection means the collection of all recyclables, refuse, rubbish, garbage, yard wastes and bulky items placed in accordance with city ordinances regulating the placement of same. 
    Day means that period of time from sundown on the day preceding trash collection to sundown on the day of trash collection. 
    Dead animals means animals or portions thereof equal to or greater than 20 pounds in weight that have expired from any cause, except those slaughtered or killed for human use or consumption. 
    Disposal site means a refuse depository, including, but not limited to, sanitary landfills, transfer stations, incinerators and waste processing/separation centers licensed, permitted or approved by all governmental bodies and agencies having jurisdiction and requiring such licenses, permits or approvals to receive refuse for processing or final disposal. 
    Garbage means all animal and vegetable matter from the handling, preparation, cooking, consumption, storage, decay or decomposition of food (meats, fish, fowl, fruits, grains) and/or any other animal or vegetable matter whatsoever subject to decay which may putrefy or generate noxious or offensive odors, be a food source for rodents, or may be a breeding or feeding place for insects or vermin, and shall include all dead animals of less than 20 pounds in weight; except yard waste, construction debris, bulky waste, rubbish, stable matter and hazardous waste. 
    Garbage and refuse collection or collection means the taking up and collecting of all garbage and refuse accumulated in containers at residential dwelling units within the corporate limits of the city and the transportation to an approved disposal site by the city. 
    Garbage bags means special plastic bags stamped with the city logo. The bags will be used for city garbage collection. The plastic bags will be sold through retailers to the public. The purchase price of the bag includes collection, processing and disposal costs. 
    Hazardous waste means waste, in any amount, which is defined, characterized or designated as hazardous by the United States Environmental Protection Agency or appropriate state agency by or pursuant to federal or state law, or waste, in any amount, which is regulated under federal or state law. The term "hazardous waste" shall also include motor oil and gasoline. 
    Landscape waste means dry leaves and untreated wood and branches smaller than two inches in diameter but does not include noxious weeds or grass clippings. 
    Litter means any discarded, used or unconsumed substance or waste. The term "litter" may include, but is not limited to, any garbage, trash, refuse, debris, rubbish, yard or garden waste, newspaper, magazines, glass, metal, plastic or paper containers or other packaging construction material, abandoned vehicles, motor vehicle parts, furniture, oil, dead animal, any noxious or offensive matter of any kind, any object likely to injure any person or create a traffic hazard, or anything else of an unsightly or unsanitary nature which has been discarded, abandoned or otherwise disposed of improperly. 
    Producer means occupants of a residential dwelling unit who generate refuse and residential refuse. 
    Receptacle means a container which shall be of such size and form as to permit collection by one man. Garbage cans shall not exceed 32 gallons in capacity and shall be fitted with handles and lids. The term "receptacle" includes all recycling containers and dumpsters placed in accordance with city ordinances. 
    Recyclable materials means newsprint, glass, household metals, plastics and other materials as determined by the city and the contractor. 
    Recycling means the use (collection, remanufacture, etc.) of secondary materials as feedstock for the production of new materials or products. 
    Recycling collection means the collection of all recyclable materials accumulated in recycling containers at residential dwelling units receiving refuse and garbage collection. 
    Recycling containers means a plastic container stamped with the city logo, purchased by the city and distributed by the city to residents receiving residential curbside service. 
    Refuse means all wastes which normally result from the operation of a household, including all garbage, rubbish and bulky wastes. 
    Residential dwelling means any single-family unit or multifamily dwelling (not exceeding eight dwelling units) within the corporate limits of the city occupied by a person or group of persons. A residential dwelling shall be deemed occupied when either water or domestic light and power services are being supplied thereto. Multifamily dwellings and condominiums, whether of single level or multilevel construction, shall be treated as a residential dwelling, except that each single-family unit within any such residential dwelling shall be billed separately as a residential unit. 
    Residential refuse means all garbage and rubbish generated by a producer at a residential dwelling unit. 
    Rubbish means all nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes, including but not limited to, paper, plastics, bottles, glass, cardboard, metal, cans, bricks, ashes, sod, dirt, rocks, cement, trees, wood, leather and any other like materials small enough for one man to handle. The term "rubbish" shall not include yard waste construction debris, bulky waste, dead animals, garbage, stable matter and hazardous wastes. 
    Stable matter means all manure and other waste matter normally accumulated in or about a stable or any animal, livestock or poultry enclosure, and resulting from the keeping of animals, poultry or livestock. 
    Trash means and includes garbage and rubbish. 
    Trash storage facility means a permanent enclosure for the storage of refuse receptacles. 
    Unacceptable recyclable materials means materials not properly prepared, separated and/or located in accordance with this chapter as generally accepted recycling practices established by city ordinances. 
    Yard waste means compostible organic material consisting of dead plants, weeds, Christmas trees, tree or hedge trimmings, grass clippings and leaves but excluding tree limbs over four feet in length and 50 pounds in weight. Yard wastes are further defined as follows: 
(1)  Bulk yard waste means hard yard waste which exceeds the diameter and length standards set forth in this section. 
(2)  Hard yard waste means brown-stemmed branches and shrub prunings with large diameter stems/trunks not to exceed 48 inches in length and four inches in diameter individually. Evergreen Christmas trees fall under this definition; however, their collection and disposal will be defined under the Christmas tree program. 
(3)  Soft yard waste means grass clippings, leaves, prunings of small diameter green-stemmed shrubs and plant stalks. 
(Code 1977, § 8.04.010; Ord. No. 99-21, § 1, 1999; Ord. No. 90-06, 1990; Ord. No. 12-30, § 2, 9-10-2012) 
Sec. 46-3. - Recyclable materials and yard wastes. 
    Recyclable materials and yard waste shall be collected and disposed of in accordance with the terms of the contract between the city and its independent provider of such services, the details of which are available in the office of the city clerk. 
Secs. 46-4-46-24. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STORAGE AND COLLECTION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 46-25. - Collection required. 
    In the interest of community health standards, it shall be required that all residential, commercial, industrial and mixed-use properties within the corporate limits of the city provide for garbage/refuse collection no less frequently than once per week. 
(Code 1977, § 8.04.130; Ord. No. 90-06, 1990) 
Sec. 46-26. - Exclusive rights of city collection. 
    Any garbage, refuse, trash, recyclables or yard waste generated by any residential dwelling unit and placed at the curb for collection shall be collected solely and exclusively by the city or its officially designated solid waste disposal contractor. 
(Code 1977, § 8.04.040; Ord. No. 90-06, 1990) 
Sec. 46-27. - City reserves the right to refuse collection. 
    The city may refuse collection of any solid wastes not prepared in accordance with this chapter. 
(Code 1977, § 8.04.180; Ord. No. 90-06, 1990) 
Sec. 46-28. - Classification of collection types. 
    For purposes of this section, properties within the corporate limits shall be classified as follows: 
(1)  Residential. Single-family dwellings and multifamily dwellings of eight or fewer units. 
(2)  Commercial-industrial. Properties with the principal use being a business enterprise or those properties not being classified as residential. This classification includes, but is not limited to: restaurants, retail sales establishments, hospitals, medical offices, schools, churches and nonmanufacturing facilities. 
(3)  Mixed-use. Properties with the principal use being a business enterprise, which also houses residential dwelling units within the same building. 
(Code 1977, § 8.04.140A; Ord. No. 90-06, 1990) 
Sec. 46-29. - Commercial and industrial trash not collected by city. 
    The city shall provide collection of solid waste from residential properties only. No collection service shall be provided to commercial or industrial properties; all such properties shall provide for refuse collection by an independent hauler. 
(Code 1977, § 8.04.140B; Ord. No. 90-06, 1990) 
Sec. 46-30. - Materials collectible. 
    The materials to be collected include: 
(1)  Garbage and rubbish, when placed in special prepaid city garbage bags; 
(2)  Bulky waste; 
(3)  Yard waste; 
(4)  Christmas trees, under the guidelines of the Christmas tree program; 
(5)  Recyclable materials, including glass, plastic (HDPE and PETE), newspapers and cans, when packaged in accordance with this chapter. 
(Code 1977, § 8.04.140C; Ord. No. 90-06, 1990) 
Sec. 46-31. - Materials not collectible. 
    The city will not collect sod, earth, concrete, refuse from remodeling or construction, automobile parts, hazardous wastes, and large trees. 
(Code 1977, § 8.04.140D; Ord. No. 90-06, 1990) 
Sec. 46-32. - Frequency of collection; preparation of materials. 
(a)  Collection of household refuse will be provided once each week from all residential properties. Refuse must be placed curbside. All refuse shall be prepared for collection in the following manner: 
(1)  Any refuse placed in containers for collection shall be drained of all free liquids and shall be less than 35 pounds; 
(2)  It is unlawful for any container to be filled with materials which may cause injury to any person handling the containers including, but not limited to, explosives, poisons, acids or caustic materials; 
(3)  Fats, oils and grease shall be placed in sealed containers to prevent leakage; 
(4)  Containers shall be free of any landscape (yard) waste materials. 
(b)  Any person violating this section shall be subject to a minimum fine of $100.00 and a maximum fine of $500.00 for the first offense and a fine of $500.00 for the second offense. 
(Code 1977, § 8.04.150; Ord. No. 90-06, 1990) 
Sec. 46-33. - Storage area regulations. 
    No trash storage facilities shall be maintained within the front yard setback area, nor within a minimum of 15 feet of the side lot line. No trash receptacles shall be maintained in view or in plain sight except on collection days. 
(Code 1977, § 8.04.080; Ord. No. 90-06, 1990) 
Secs. 46-34-46-54. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONTAINERS 

Sec. 46-55. - Required; specifications. 
(a)  Every owner, tenant, lessee or occupant of every residential dwelling unit or place of business shall provide or cause to be provided at all times an approved trash container of sufficient number and capacity to accommodate and contain all trash generated and accumulated by occupants of the structure. 
(b)  Containers to be used for the pickup of garbage and rubbish shall be: 
(1)  Tightly covered plastic or metal containers which are watertight, do not exceed 33-gallon capacity, and do not exceed a total weight when filled of 35 pounds. Such containers shall have secure handles for convenient lifting and carrying. 
(2)  One and one/half yard dumpsters, approved by the city, for commercial accounts. 
(c)  Recycling bins shall be 18-gallon containers to be used for the pickup of recyclable materials made available through the city exclusively. The fee for the loss of or damage to a recycling container shall be as provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1977, § 8.04.060; Ord. No. 90-06, 1990; Ord. No. 12-04, § 1, 2-27-2012) 
Sec. 46-56. - Disposal in containers required. 
    It is unlawful to dispose of any garbage and rubbish or yard waste material anywhere except through placement of such material in the types of approved containers described in section 46-55 and placed for collection as prescribed in this article. 
(Code 1977, § 8.04.070; Ord. No. 90-06, 1990) 
Sec. 46-57. - Trash containers to be kept on premises. 
(a)  No trash containers shall be placed within the limits of any street or alley but shall be kept by the adjacent property owner upon his own property. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of all persons occupying or controlling any residential dwelling unit to place trash containers at the curbline of the premises on the day of collection. 
(c)  All trash containers shall be stored and maintained in a neat manner complimentary to the area and the neighborhood. 
(Code 1977, § 8.04.090; Ord. No. 90-06, 1990) 
Sec. 46-58. - Interference with containers. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person, other than the owner, occupant or members of their families, the owner's agent, or the city to deposit, remove, deface, destroy or disturb trash containers, recycling containers or bulky wastes. 
(b)  From time of placement of recyclables at the curb for collection in accordance with the terms of this chapter, items shall be and become the property of the city or its authorized agent. It is a violation of this chapter for any person not authorized by the city to collect or pick up or cause to be collected or picked up any such items. Any and each such collection in violation of this section from one or more locations shall constitute a separate and distinct offense punishable as provided in this chapter. 
(c)  Any person violating this section shall be subject to a minimum fine of $100.00 and a maximum fine of $500.00 for the first offense and a fine of $500.00 for the second offense. 
(Code 1977, § 8.04.100; Ord. No. 90-06, 1990) 
Sec. 46-59. - Placement and storage. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to sweep or deposit any refuse or litter in any public place or public way except in public trash containers provided for such purposes. Persons owning or occupying property shall keep the sidewalk and any right-of-way bordering their property free of litter. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person to deposit any residential refuse in any public place or public trash container. 
(c)  It is unlawful for any person to place or maintain paper, litter, excelsior, garbage, trash or rubbish of any kind whatever in open deposits on the ground or in open containers which do not meet the requirements of this chapter. 
(d)  It is unlawful to use any non-approved container in violation of the provisions of this chapter. Such containers may be confiscated and disposed of by the city. 
(e)  It is unlawful for any person to place or maintain garbage, rubbish, recyclables or trash for curbside collection in violation of this chapter. 
(f)  It is unlawful for any person to place or deposit residential refuse in any commercial container. 
(g)  Any person violating this section shall be subject to a minimum fine of $100.00 and a maximum fine of $500.00 for the first offense and a fine of $500.00 for the second offense. 
(Code 1977, § 8.04.110; Ord. No. 90-06, 1990) 
Sec. 46-60. - Pollution of water and streets. 
(a)  No person shall throw, place, or deposit or cause to be deposited any garbage, refuse, litter, manure, carrion, dead animals, offal, or putrid or unwholesome substance upon the margin, banks or into any stream or water, or upon any street, alley, ditch or public grounds, or upon any property of another within the limits of the city. 
(b)  No person shall allow or permit any litter, other offensive substance, or noxious matter of any kind to run or fall from or out of any building or vehicle into or upon any street or public place, nor allow or permit such litter or other noxious matter to stand or remain on any ground or premises within the limits of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 8.04.120; Ord. No. 90-06, 1990) 
Secs. 46-61-46-78. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BURNING 

Sec. 46-79. - Nuisance declared; prohibited. 
(a)  The burning of any garbage, waste, refuse, rubbish or substance of any kind other than landscape waste, within the city limits is declared a nuisance and prohibited. This prohibition shall also include the burning of any material in a burn barrel or other container used for the purpose of holding garbage, waste, refuse, rubbish or any other thing for the purpose of burning. 
(b)  Other than within the territory of the C-1 Central Business District, the terms of this section shall not be construed to prohibit the burning of fuels for cooking purposes, fuels in a domestic fireplace, campfires, ceremonial bonfires authorized by the corporate authorities and the city fire department; provided that no garbage shall be burned in any such cases. Campfires or recreational fires are expressly prohibited within the territory of the C-1 Central Business District. 
(c)  Open burning shall be prohibited within the corporate limits of the city except as permitted under the conditions in subsection (d) of this section and subject to any other laws adopted by the city. 
(d)  The open burning of landscape waste, which is the combustion of landscape waste in such a way that the product of the combustion is emitted to the open air, shall be permitted but only: 
(1)  Between the hours of 3:00 p.m. prevailing time and sunset on Tuesdays and Thursdays, and from 9:00 a.m. to sunset on Saturdays of each week unless any of these days falls on Halloween and/or days designated by the city council for community-wide trick or treating. 
(2)  On the premises on which such waste is generated; 
(3)  If the burning does not occur within six feet of any street or alley, on any street, sidewalk, alley or public ditch; 
(4)  When the burning is constantly attended by a competent and responsible person until such burning is extinguished; and 
(5)  When such burning does not create a visibility hazard on streets, roadways, alleys, public sidewalks or railroad tracks. 
(e)  Penalty. Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction, be fined in the amount provided in the city penalty schedule for each offense, and each day on which such a violation occurs or continues shall be considered to be a separate offense. In addition, the city may, at its sole discretion, seek any other remedy at law or in equity to restrain or enjoin violations of this section. 
(Code 1977, § 8.04.020; Ord. No. 99-20, §§ 1-3, 5, 1999; Ord. No. 90-06, 1990; Ord. No. 12-30, § 3, 9-10-2012; Ord. No. 13-11, § 2, 5-28-2013; Ord. No. 14-08, § 2, 4-28-2014) 
Sec. 46-80. - Incinerators. 
    Any commercial establishment desiring to burn any trash shall burn the same in an incinerator which conforms to the requirements and standards established, approved and licensed by the state pollution control board. 
(Code 1977, § 8.04.030; Ord. No. 90-06, 1990) 
Secs. 46-81-46-103. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - FEES AND CHARGES 

Sec. 46-104. - Collection charge imposed. 
    The city council shall, by resolution, establish volume-based charges for the collection services provided in this chapter. Established rates for collection shall be as provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1977, § 8.04.190; Ord. No. 90-06, 1990) 
Sec. 46-105. - When due; persons liability; late payment penalties. 
(a)  Refuse collection service charges shall be payable monthly. The owner of the premises, the occupant thereof and the user of the service shall be jointly and severally liable to pay for the service to such premises and the service is furnished to the premises by the city only upon the condition that the owner of the premises, occupant and user of the service are jointly and severally liable therefor to the city. 
(b)  All refuse collection bills are due and payable within 15 calendar days after being rendered. A collection charge in the amount provided in the city fee schedule shall be added to all bills not paid by the 15th calendar day after they have been rendered. 
(Code 1977, § 8.04.200A; Ord. No. 90-06, 1990) 
Sec. 46-106. - Delinquent bills. 
(a)  If the charges for such services are not paid within 90 days after the rendition of the bill for service, the city clerk or his designee shall begin lien proceedings in accordance with this article. In addition thereto, the city clerk and city administrator may submit delinquent accounts over 90 days old to a collection agency for further services and efforts in an attempt to collect such delinquent accounts; the city clerk and city administrator are authorized to enter into a contract with a credit collection agency upon the terms and conditions agreed upon by the city clerk, city administrator and credit collection agency. 
(b)  In the event that such delinquent accounts cannot be collected by the credit collection agency and the amounts of the delinquent accounts are less than $100.00, the city clerk, city administrator and a member of the city council appointed by the mayor may determine to take no further efforts to collect such delinquent account and may write off such delinquent accounts. 
(Code 1977, § 8.04.200B; Ord. No. 90-06, 1990) 
Sec. 46-107. - Lien for delinquent bills. 
    Whenever a bill for refuse collection service remains unpaid for 90 days for monthly service after it has been rendered, the city clerk may file with the county recorder of deeds a statement of lien claim. This statement shall contain the legal description of the premises served, the amount of the unpaid bill, and a notice that the city claims a lien for this amount as well as for all charges subsequent to the period covered by the bill including accrued penalties, monthly service charges and recording fees. 
(Code 1977, § 8.04.200C; Ord. No. 90-06, 1990) 
Secs. 46-108-46-127. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - HAULER'S LICENSE 

Sec. 46-128. - Required. 
    No person shall remove or haul any garbage, refuse or recyclable materials from any lot or tract of real estate or from any street or alley, for hire, without first procuring a license therefor as provided in this article. Possession of a valid county license shall exempt a hauler from the requirements set forth in this article. 
(Code 1977, § 8.04.210; Ord. No. 90-06, 1990) 
Sec. 46-129. - Application. 
    Application for a license under this article shall be made on forms provided by the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1977, § 8.04.220; Ord. No. 90-06, 1990) 
Sec. 46-130. - Bond. 
    Application for a license shall be accompanied by a surety bond in the sum provided in the city bond schedule conditioned upon the observance of this chapter. 
(Code 1977, § 8.04.230; Ord. No. 90-06, 1990) 
Sec. 46-131. - Certificates of workers' compensation insurance and public liability insurance required. 
    Prior to issuance of a license under this article, the applicant shall present a certificate of workers' compensation insurance and a certificate of public liability insurance in the amount provided in the city required insurance limits schedule. 
(Code 1977, § 8.04.240; Ord. No. 90-06, 1990) 
Sec. 46-132. - Fee. 
    Application for a license under this article shall be accompanied by an annual license fee in the amount provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1977, § 8.04.250; Ord. No. 90-06, 1990) 
Sec. 46-133. - Term. 
    All licenses issued under this article shall be valid until the April 30 next succeeding the date of issuance of such license. 
(Code 1977, § 8.04.260; Ord. No. 90-06, 1990) 
Chapter 48 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal street systems, 605 ILCS 5/2-104; municipal administration of streets, 605 ILCS 5/7-101 et seq.; general highway provisions, 605 ILCS 5/9-101 et seq.; municipal authority over streets and public ways, 65 ILCS 5/11-80-1 et seq.; municipal street railways, 65 ILCS 5/11-90-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 48-1-48-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STREET AND SIDEWALK GRADES 

Sec. 48-19. - Benchmarks designated. 
    The datum plane to which shall be referred all grades and levels in the city is located by the following benchmarks, the elevations of which are given in feet and hundredths of a foot: 
(1)  Top of stone water table, northeast corner, First National Bank building, southwest corner of Main and Cherry Streets, 60.00; 
(2)  Top of stone water table at southeast corner of building at the northwest corner of Main and Genesee Streets, 59.858; 
(3)  Top of stone water table at the southwest corner of building at the northeast corner of Main and Genesee Streets, 59.922; 
(4)  West end of windowsill of small window at south side of Morrison Produce Company building, window being near west line of building, 56.559; 
(5)  Southeast corner of stone step in front of Mrs. J.S. Green's residence, northwest corner of Grape and Wall Streets, 45.776; 
(6)  Top of stone water table at the southeast corner of office of Illinois Refrigerator Factory, 31.503; 
(7)  South side of iron rim of cover of flush tank at the intersection of North and Cherry Streets, 81.115; 
(8)  East end of stone windowsill at north side of pumping station near the chimney, 17.946; 
(9)  North side of stone doorstep of Catholic church at southeast corner of North and Base Streets, 91.920; 
(10)  Iron shoulder at the bottom of reservoir at northwest side and directly under overflow pipe, 108.357, said reservoir being at southeast corner of High and Base Streets. 
(Prior Code, § 302; Code 1977, § 12.24.010) 
Sec. 48-20. - Street grades. 
    All grades for streets in the city shall be on the centerline thereof and the fixed points shall be at the center of the intersection of the streets with each other or at the points at which, if they were extended, such streets would intersect, or at other points in the centerlines of said streets authorized or definitely located. All grades between established grade points shall be straight lines drawn from one fixed point to the nearest fixed point thereto. 
(Prior Code, § 303; Code 1977, § 12.24.020) 
Sec. 48-21. - Slope and grade of sidewalks. 
    All grades of sidewalks, unless otherwise determined by the city authorities, shall at the outer edge thereof be at least six inches above the grade of the streets on which the sidewalks are located. The sidewalks shall slope towards the street with a pitch of one inch in every four feet, except as otherwise provided by this Code or other city ordinances. 
(Prior Code, § 304; Code 1977, § 12.24.030) 
Sec. 48-22. - Establishment and alteration of grades. 
    The establishment of any grade by the city council shall fix and determine the permanent grade of that for which it was designated; but such establishment of such grade shall not be construed to authorize any person or company to change or alter the existing grades or conditions of any street or sidewalk or any part thereof, until ordered altered by the corporate authorities. 
(Prior Code, § 305; Code 1977, § 12.24.040) 
Secs. 48-23-48-47. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - EXCAVATIONS AND CONSTRUCTION SPECIFICATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 48-48. - Excavation classes. 
    For the purposes of this article, excavations are divided into the following classes: 
(1)  Concrete street; 
(2)  Brick street; 
(3)  Concrete street with bituminous overlay; 
(4)  Brick street with bituminous overlay; 
(5)  Bituminous hot mix over aggregate base; 
(6)  Bituminous surface treatment; 
(7)  Gravel streets and alleys. 
(Code 1977, § 12.22.010; Ord. No. 91-8, § 1, 1991) 
Sec. 48-49. - Excavation permit-Required; exemptions. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to tunnel under or make any excavation in any street, alley or other public place in the city without having obtained a permit as required in this article, or without complying with the provisions of this article, or in violation of or variance from the terms of any such permit. 
(b)  The provisions of this article related to securing permits shall not apply to officers or employees of the city engaged in doing work for the city; nor to persons or corporations doing work for the city under contract; nor to persons or corporations which are operating under a franchise or grant from the city if such franchise provides for the making of excavations and tunnels without securing a permit therefor. 
(Code 1977, § 12.22.020; Ord. No. 91-8, § 1, 1991) 
Sec. 48-50. - Same-Application; insurance; security deposit; fees. 
(a)  Application for excavation permits shall be made to the city clerk, and shall describe the location of the intended excavation or tunnel, the size thereof, the purpose therefor, and the person for whom or which the work is being done; and shall contain an agreement that the applicant will comply with this Code, all ordinances and laws relating to the work to be done. 
(b)  The permit application shall be accompanied by a certificate of insurance verifying coverages of the type and limit specified by the city's insurance carrier or as provided in the city required insurance limits schedule, whichever is greater. 
(c)  The permit application under this section shall be accompanied by a cash security deposit in the sum provided in the city fee schedule per excavation site to ensure the proper repairs and restoration of the excavation. Upon satisfactory repair and restoration of the excavation the deposit shall be refunded, without interest, to the permittee. Should a project require multiple excavations, the applicant may post a project performance bond in the amount of $5,000.00 in lieu of individual per-site deposits. 
(d)  The permit application shall be accompanied by a permit fee in the amount specified in the city fee schedule. 
(e)  No permit shall be issued until all conditions of this section have been satisfied and an executed general hold-harmless agreement is submitted by the applicant. 
(f)  In case of an emergency excavation, the party doing the excavating must notify the police department before commencing the excavation. The police department shall notify the director of public works of the emergency excavation on the first business day following such emergency excavation. 
(Code 1977, § 12.22.030; Ord. No. 91-8, § 1, 1991) 
Sec. 48-51. - Time limit for completion of excavations. 
    Each application for a permit shall state the length of time it is estimated will elapse from the commencement of the work until the restoration of the surface of the ground. It is unlawful to fail to comply with this time limitation unless permission for an extension of time is granted by the city council. 
(Code 1977, § 12.22.100; Ord. No. 91-8, § 1, 1991) 
Sec. 48-52. - Filling and surface repair. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the person granted a permit for excavation to remove excavated material and to fill such excavation and repair the surface in accordance with the requirements set forth in this article. 
(Code 1977, § 12.22.060; Ord. No. 91-8, § 1, 1991) 
Sec. 48-53. - Traffic control during construction and maintenance. 
    It shall be the duty of any person granted a permit under this article to prosecute all work on any street, alley or public right-of-way expeditiously and without delay, maintain one-way traffic at all times, and to well and sufficiently protect all openings in any street, alley, sidewalk or public right-of-way at all hours in accordance with the requirements of the current state department of transportation Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices. 
(Code 1977, § 12.22.070; Ord. No. 91-8, § 1, 1991) 
Sec. 48-54. - Permittee to indemnify city for damage claims. 
    All permittees shall hold the city harmless from all claims for injuries to persons or property by reason of such excavation and traffic control devices. 
(Code 1977, § 12.22.070; Ord. No. 91-8, § 1, 1991) 
Sec. 48-55. - Excavation methods. 
(a)  It is unlawful to make any excavation or tunnel in any way contrary to or at variance with the terms of the permit therefor. Proper bracing shall be maintained to prevent the collapse of adjoining ground; and in excavations, the excavation shall not have, anywhere below the surface, any portion which extends beyond the opening at the surface. 
(b)  No injury shall be done to any pipes, cables or conduits in the making of such excavation or tunnel, and notice shall be given to the persons maintaining any such pipes, cables or conduits, or to the city department or officer charged with the care thereof, which are or may be endangered or affected by the making of any such excavation or tunnel, before such pipes, cables or conduits shall be disturbed. 
(c)  No unnecessary damage or injury shall be done to any tree or shrub or roots thereof. 
(Code 1977, § 12.22.080; Ord. No. 91-8, § 1, 1991) 
Sec. 48-56. - Temporary sidewalk construction required, when. 
    If any sidewalk is blocked by any such work, a temporary sidewalk shall be constructed or provided which is safe for travel and convenient for users. 
(Code 1977, § 12.22.090; Ord. No. 91-8, § 1, 1991) 
Sec. 48-57. - Backfilling material. 
(a)  In streets or driving areas. After the required repair work has been completed by the permittee, the entire excavation shall be backfilled by depositing sand in even layers not exceeding six inches in thickness and compacting each layer by hand-tamping around the utility. This procedure shall be followed to a depth of 12 inches above the repaired utility. The remainder of the excavation shall be backfilled with a granular material not exceeding one inch in size, all deposited in six-inch layers. Each layer shall be compacted by hand-tamping or mechanical methods before depositing the next layer. This procedure shall extend to the bottom of the street surface material. 
(b)  In parkway or grass areas. The procedure stated in subsection (a) of this section for streets shall apply to all excavations abutting and adjacent to the back of a curb, except that the top four inches of backfill shall be of black dirt, raked free of stones, weeds and debris, and seeded and watered to provide a suitable turf. In cases where the excavation does not abut the curb, the procedure stated for streets shall apply except that the material used from 12 inches above the utility to the surface may be the excavated material and the top four inches shall be of black dirt, raked free of stones, weeds and debris, and seeded and watered to provide a suitable turf. 
(Code 1977, § 12.22.120; Ord. No. 91-8, § 1, 1991) 
Sec. 48-58. - Restoration of surface. 
(a)  Any person making any excavation or tunnel in or under any public street, alley or public place in the city shall restore the surface thereof to its original condition if there is no pavement there. Refills shall be properly tamped down, and any bracing in such tunnel or excavation shall be left in the ground. 
(b)  If the excavation or opening has necessitated an opening in a pavement, the refill shall be properly made so that the surface pavement can be relaid in the same manner and thickness and character as the surrounding pavement. 
(c)  Replacement surfaces for excavations shall be as follows: 
(1)  Concrete: eight inches of concrete level to the road surface; 
(2)  Brick: eight inches of brick level to the road surface; 
(3)  Concrete with hot mix overlay: eight inches of concrete topped with two inches of hot mix compacted to the road surface; 
(4)  Brick with hot mix overlay: eight inches of brick topped with two inches of hot mix compacted to the road surface; 
(5)  Bituminous hot mix over aggregate base: eight inches of aggregate base topped with two inches of hot mix compacted to the road surface; 
(6)  Bituminous surface treatment: compacted three inches of cold patch material leveled to the road surface. 
(Code 1977, § 12.22.130; Ord. No. 91-8, § 1, 1991) 
Sec. 48-59. - Surface materials. 
(a)  In streets or driving areas. All surface materials shall be of the type shown in the city specifications for the various classes of streets or driving areas. Each material shall be as follows: 
(1)  Aggregate base course or surface course means gravel or crushed stone of a gradation suitable for roadway surface material. 
(2)  Concrete means a six-bag mix (a minimum of 564 pounds of cement per cubic yard of concrete), and shall be an acceptable paving mix with aggregate no larger than 11/2 inches in size. All concrete shall be poured with the minimum slump practical for the type of work being performed. All concrete that is surface material shall be troweled smooth and given a broom finish. Concrete that is base material shall be finished with a screed and left with a smooth surface. 
(3)  Bituminous materials. 
a.  Cold patch means and refers to a bituminous mixture intended for use without heating. It shall be pliable and workable in summer and winter weather. 
b.  Hot mix means and refers to a bituminous plant-mix material intended for use at a material temperature between 250 degrees Fahrenheit and 350 degrees Fahrenheit. The mixture may be either a bituminous concrete surface material, Class I, or a bituminous mixture complete, Type B, according to the standard specifications for road and bridge construction published by the state department of transportation, most recent edition. This material shall be laid while hot, raked smooth, and compacted to conform to adjacent street surfaces. 
(b)  In parkway or grass areas. The surface material in parkways and grass areas shall be four inches minimum of black dirt, raked free of stones, weeds and debris, and seeded and watered to provide a suitable turf. 
(Code 1977, § 12.22.140; Ord. No. 91-8, § 1, 1991) 
Sec. 48-60. - Excavated materials. 
(a)  All material excavated shall be placed in such a manner as not to endanger pedestrians or vehicles and with as little inconvenience as possible to those using the streets, public property or adjoining private property. 
(b)  If material being excavated impedes the use of property by the public, the director of public works shall require the person making the excavation to remove the excavated material to a storage site away from the area. 
(c)  The permittee making the excavation shall secure all necessary authority and make all necessary arrangements for all required storage, disposal sites, and for reducing the flow of traffic or pedestrian users across the excavation. 
(Code 1977, § 12.22.150; Ord. No. 91-8, § 1, 1991) 
Sec. 48-61. - Removal of rubble required. 
    The permittee shall clean up the area after the completion of the excavation and filling thereof in accordance with this article, and shall remove all excess rubbish or materials of any sort within 24 hours after the completion of the filling. 
(Code 1977, § 12.22.160; Ord. No. 91-8, § 1, 1991) 
Sec. 48-62. - Protection of watercourses. 
    Permittees making excavations under this article shall maintain all gutters free and unobstructed for the protection of the watercourse and shall make provision for the removal of all surface water, muck, silt, slickings or other runoff pumped from the excavation and shall not deposit same into the sewer system of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 12.22.170; Ord. No. 91-8, § 1, 1991) 
Sec. 48-63. - Replacement of curb and gutter or sidewalk. 
(a)  Permittees must replace curb, gutter or sidewalk to be compatible with the surrounding or adjacent curb, gutter or sidewalk. The same regulations, conditions and specifications that apply to the excavation and backfilling of streets, alleys or public rights-of-way shall apply to excavation and replacement of curbs, gutters, and sidewalks. 
(b)  The permittee must obtain an excavation permit, as required herein for street and alley excavations, before excavating the curb, gutter or sidewalk if a permit has not been issued for the excavation of a street, alley or right-of-way. 
(Code 1977, § 12.22.190; Ord. No. 91-8, § 1, 1991) 
Sec. 48-64. - Curbline specifications. 
    The curbline of all streets and avenues in the city, unless otherwise provided by specific provisions of this article or other city ordinances, shall be not less than 181/2 feet distant from the centerline of the street or avenue, measured from the center of the street or avenue to the inner edge or edge of the curb next to the property line, and at such grade in such streets and avenues as shall be established and designated by the city. No person shall build or construct any curbstone or curbing on any street or avenue in the city except as provided by this section. 
(Prior Code, § 247; Code 1977, § 12.08.010) 
Sec. 48-65. - Inspection. 
(a)  Inspection of the excavation and the backfilling thereof shall be performed by the director of public works or his designated representative. 
(b)  The permittee shall notify the director of public works of his intent to commence backfilling not less than two hours prior thereto and shall not commence backfilling until such time as he is authorized to do so by the director of public works or his authorized representative. 
(c)  If a permittee backfills an excavation without the approval and inspection of the director or his designated representative, the permittee may be required to excavate the backfill for an inspection by the director. 
(Code 1977, § 12.22.110; Ord. No. 91-8, § 1, 1991) 
Sec. 48-66. - Charge to repair by city. 
    If the permittee under this article fails or neglects to comply with the provisions of this article, the city shall cause necessary repairs and restoration of the excavation to be made. The full cost of any such repairs and restoration shall be deducted from the permittee's cash deposit. Should the actual repair and restoration expenses exceed the amount of the deposit the city will bill the permittee for all such excess expense. 
(Code 1977, § 12.22.200; Ord. No. 91-8, § 1, 1991) 
Secs. 48-67-48-91. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION 

Sec. 48-92. - Compliance with provisions required; time limit for construction. 
    All sidewalks ordered to be constructed in the city by the city council, on, along, or upon any street or streets or any part of a street or avenue, shall be constructed by the owners of the respective lots or parcels of land touching upon the line of any such sidewalks, and in accordance with the terms and provisions of this article. The construction shall be completed within 30 days after written notice of the passage of any ordinance requiring the construction of sidewalks in the city in any particular location, has been mailed to any party who paid the last general taxes on the respective lots or parcels of land touching upon the line of such required sidewalks. 
(Prior Code, § 611; Code 1977, § 12.16.010) 
Sec. 48-93. - Grades and widths. 
    Sidewalks shall be laid according to city grades as established by an ordinance ordering the construction of any sidewalks. The grade line for the inner edge of such sidewalks (meaning the edge thereof nearest the property line) shall be a straight line between any given grade points, which grade points so given shall constitute the top of the inner edge of the sidewalks, and the grade for the outer edge of the sidewalks shall be a line parallel with and one-fourth of an inch for each foot in width of the sidewalks, below the grade line of the inner edge of the sidewalks. The elevation of said grade points as given by numbers of feet and hundredths of a foot, shall mean such number of feet and hundredths of a foot above the base line or datum plane, as set forth in article II of this chapter. The minimum width of all sidewalks by order or otherwise (except in the business portion of the city) shall be 42 inches. 
(Prior Code, § 612; Code 1977, § 12.16.020) 
Sec. 48-94. - Supervisory authority. 
    The material for sidewalks and the construction thereof, shall be under the direct supervision of the superintendent of streets of the city. 
(Prior Code, § 613; Code 1977, § 12.16.030) 
Sec. 48-95. - Failure of owner to construct; city responsibility. 
    In default of the construction of any sidewalk ordered by any ordinance of the city, within the time prescribed in this article for construction, by the owners of the respective lots or parcels of land touching upon the line where any such sidewalk is ordered to be constructed, the materials will be furnished by the city and the city shall construct the sidewalk so ordered to be constructed in accordance with the terms, provisions, and specifications of this chapter. The whole cost of such construction and the supervision thereof shall be collected as provided in 65 ILCS 11-84-1 et seq. 
(Prior Code, § 614; Code 1977, § 12.16.040) 
Sec. 48-96. - Sidewalk repairs-Notification; owner responsibility. 
    Whenever any sidewalk is, in the judgment of the director of public works, determined to be inadequate or unsafe for travel thereon, the director shall provide the owner of the abutting property with written notice of sidewalk conditions and the specific repairs required. The owner of the abutting property shall be provided a reasonable period of not more than 30 days to cause necessary repairs to be completed, or to provide the city clerk with written verification that required repairs have been contracted. 
(Code 1977, § 12.16.044; Ord. No. 87-4, § 1, 1987) 
Sec. 48-97. - Same-Authority of city to perform work; assessment of costs. 
(a)  If the owner of the abutting property fails, refuses, or neglects to make repairs within the time allowed after having received notice of required repairs, the city shall cause necessary repairs to be completed. Repairs may be made by force account or by contract and an account of the cost thereof shall be kept and reported to the governing body. 
(b)  The city may by ordinance, or other statutory lien procedures, levy a special assessment against the lot or piece of land abutting the sidewalk so repaired for the cost of repairs, and if the abutting property owner does not pay the assessment within 30 days, upon the city clerk mailing to him or his agent, if known, a printed or written notice of the amount of such repairs, the full amount shall be certified by the city clerk to the county clerk to be put on the tax rolls for collection like other taxes. 
(Code 1977, § 12.16.046; Ord. No. 87-4, § 1, 1987) 
Sec. 48-98. - Condemnation and reconstruction. 
(a)  When any sidewalk, in the opinion of the city council, becomes inadequate or unsafe for travel thereon, the council may adopt a resolution condemning such walk and providing for the construction of a new walk in place of the walk condemned. Such resolution shall be published once in the official city paper. 
(b)  The resolution providing for the construction or reconstruction of a sidewalk shall give the owner of the abutting property not less than 30 days nor more than 60 days after its publication in which to construct or cause to be constructed or reconstructed the sidewalk at his own expense. If the sidewalk is not constructed by the property owner within the time specified, the governing body shall cause the work to be done by contract. 
(c)  All costs incurred as a result of city-contracted reconstruction of the condemned sidewalk shall be the responsibility of the owner of the property abutting said sidewalk, and may be collected in the manner provided in this article. 
(Code 1977, § 12.16.048; Ord. No. 87-4, § 1, 1987) 
Sec. 48-99. - Barriers required; safety lighting. 
    All sidewalk work in progress or newly finished, or for which any excavation has been made, shall be surrounded and efficiently protected by ample and sufficient barriers. Red lights may be required thereon if deemed necessary by the superintendent of streets for the absolute protection of the traveling public. 
(Prior Code, § 615; Code 1977, § 12.16.050) 
Sec. 48-100. - Materials and methods specifications. 
    All sidewalks constructed on the streets, avenues, and public places of the city must be constructed in the manner and form as set forth in the provisions of this article and as required by the provisions of any ordinance ordering the construction of any sidewalk. 
(Prior Code, § 616; Code 1977, § 12.16.060) 
Sec. 48-101. - Unnecessary obstruction by materials prohibited. 
    It shall be the duty of every sidewalk builder to so place the materials and tools and other equipment required for the construction of any sidewalk in such manner and place that the same shall at no time occupy any greater portion of the streets, avenues, or public places of the city than is absolutely necessary in properly carrying on the work. He shall take such means as may be necessary to prevent the obstruction of any gutter in any such street or avenue. 
(Prior Code, § 617; Code 1977, § 12.16.070) 
Sec. 48-102. - Unnecessary occupation by tools and materials prohibited. 
    It shall be the duty of every sidewalk builder, as soon as he has completed the construction of any such sidewalk, to immediately remove his tools, equipment, and all surplus material. He shall not deliver his tools, equipment or materials at the location of any such sidewalk any unnecessary or unreasonable length of time in advance of the commencement of such work. 
(Prior Code, § 618; Code 1977, § 12.16.080) 
Secs. 48-103-48-132. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - STREET AND SIDEWALK USE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 48-133. - Damaging street curbs prohibited. 
    No person shall within the city cut, mar, deface, or in any way break, disfigure, or injure any curbstone, curbing, or any part thereof, along or in any of the streets of the city. 
(Prior Code, § 248; Code 1977, § 12.08.020) 
Sec. 48-134. - Obstruction of streets and sidewalks prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to erect, build, or cause to be erected or built, or suffer to remain in or upon any sidewalk, crosswalk, lane, alley, or highway within the limits of the city any fence, enclosure, or other obstruction. Each and every 24 hours that such obstruction is suffered to remain after notification by any city officer to remove the same shall constitute a new offense. 
(Prior Code, § 445; Code 1977, § 9.48.100) 
Sec. 48-135. - Right-of-way encroachments prohibited. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Encroachment means any building, fence, sign or any other structure or object of any kind (with the exception of utilities and public road signs), which is placed, located or maintained in, on, under or over any portion of the roadway right-of-way. 
    Roadway right-of-way means those areas existing or acquired by dedication or by fee simple for highway purposes; also, the areas acquired by temporary easement during the time the easement is in effect. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person to erect or cause to be erected, to retain or cause to be retained, an encroachment within the limits of the roadway right-of-way. 
(Code 1977, §§ 12.32.010, 12.32.020; Ord. No. 79-4, § 1, 1979) 
Sec. 48-136. - Display of goods prohibited under certain conditions. 
(a)  It is unlawful and a nuisance for any person or corporation to use any street, alley, or sidewalk for the storage or display of goods, wares, or merchandise of any kind or description which occupy a greater space than two feet next to the building or boundary line of the lot adjoining such street, alley or sidewalk (except that on the north side of Market Street the space may be three feet). 
(b)  In case of a conviction under this section, and a refusal to remove any such barrel, box, hogshead, crate, stand, platform, goods, wares, or merchandise, or other things, by the person responsible therefor, the same may be removed by the chief of police at the expense of the owner thereof. 
(Prior Code, § 464; Code 1977, § 12.16.090) 
Secs. 48-137-48-155. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SIDEWALK USE RESTRICTIONS 

Sec. 48-156. - Obstruction of sidewalks prohibited. 
    No person or business entity shall obstruct sidewalks in the city in any manner or with any material, including snow, dirt, sand, rock and gravel, that impedes the flow of pedestrian traffic thereon or that creates any hazardous conditions endangering pedestrian traffic thereon. 
(Code 1977, § 12.16.071; Ord. No. 79-21, 1979) 
Sec. 48-157. - Water runoff on sidewalks. 
    No person shall suffer or permit the water falling or draining from the roof of any building owned, occupied, or controlled by him to flow upon or run over the sidewalk in front of, near to, or adjacent to the same. 
(Prior Code, § 446; Code 1977, § 9.48.110) 
Sec. 48-158. - Fruit and vegetable scraps on sidewalks. 
    No person shall throw, cast, lay, place, or deposit the rind or peel of any orange, banana, apple, or other fruit, or the rind or peel of any watermelon or other vegetable, or any other nasty or filthy substance on any public sidewalk or private sidewalk open to the public in the city. 
(Prior Code, § 420; Code 1977, § 9.48.140) 
Sec. 48-159. - Spitting on sidewalks and in other public places prohibited. 
    No person shall spit on any public sidewalk in the city or upon any private sidewalk in the city open to the public, or upon the stairs or floor in any public building in the city, or upon the stairs or floor of any private building in the city open to the public. 
(Prior Code, § 419; Code 1977, § 9.48.150) 
Secs. 48-160-48-186. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - AWNINGS 

Sec. 48-187. - Height and extension into sidewalk area. 
(a)  All overhanging awnings or any protrusion into the right-of-way within the city's downtown historic district, shall be elevated at least seven feet at the lowest part thereof above the level of the sidewalk and project up to but not exceed five feet over the sidewalk. The roof or covering of all such awnings or protrusions shall be duck, canvas or other suitable material and shall be supported by such framework so as to leave the sidewalk wholly unobstructed thereby. 
(b)  All overhanging awnings or protrusions must be reviewed and approved by the historic preservation commission prior to installation. 
(c)  Applications denied by the historic preservation commission may be appealed to the city council upon application. 
(Code 1977, § 12.04.010; Ord. No. 02-01, § 1, 2002) 
Sec. 48-188. - Dangerous overhanging awnings or protrusions; abatement. 
    It is unlawful to permit any overhanging awning or protrusion to be or remain in a dangerous condition so that any part of it is likely to fall upon any public right-of-way. After due notice given to the owner or party in control of the same, such awning or overhanging protrusion shall be removed by the owner or party in control of same and upon his failure to do so, the zoning administrator shall cause the overhanging awning or protrusion to be removed at the expense of the owner or party in control. 
(Code 1977, § 12.04.015; Ord. No. 02-01, § 1, 2002) 
Secs. 48-189-48-214. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - STREET ADDRESSES AND NUMBERING 

Sec. 48-215. - Adoption of system. 
    The numbering of all lots, tracts or parcels, houses or buildings fronting upon the public streets, avenues, alleys, or thoroughfares within the city shall be in conformity with the decimal system and this article as nearly as may be practicable. 
(Prior Code, § 329; Code 1977, § 15.20.010) 
Sec. 48-216. - North-south division. 
    The right-of-way of the Chicago & Northwestern Railway Company shall, for the purpose of house numbering, be a dividing line, and all numbers on streets and avenues south of said line shall be designated as "south" and all numbers on streets and avenues north of said line shall be designated as "north." 
(Prior Code, § 330; Code 1977, § 15.20.020) 
Sec. 48-217. - East-west division. 
    Genesee Street and Genesee Avenue shall be a dividing line, and all numbers on streets and avenues east of said line shall be designated as "east" and all numbers on streets and avenues west of said line shall be designated as "west." 
(Prior Code, § 331; Code 1977, § 15.20.030) 
Sec. 48-218. - Placement of odd and even numbers. 
    On streets and avenues running north and south, the odd numbers shall be on the west side of the street and the even numbers on the east side of the street. On all streets and avenues running east and west the odd numbers shall be on the south side of the street and the even numbers on the north side of the street. 
(Prior Code, § 332; Code 1977, § 15.20.040) 
Sec. 48-219. - Blocks numbered by hundreds. 
    The numbering of the streets and avenues shall be by series of hundreds, as follows: 
(1)  The first tract or parcel in the northwest corner of Lot 10, Block 27 and abutting Genesee Street shall be numbered 100 South Genesee Street, and the tract or parcel directly opposite in Block 28 and abutting Genesee Street shall be numbered 101 South Genesee Street, and said numbering shall so continue until all tracts or parcels abutting Genesee Street in said blocks have been numbered. 
(2)  The first tract or parcel in the northeast corner of Block 34 and abutting Genesee Street shall be numbered 200 South Genesee Street, and the first tract or parcel directly opposite in Block 33 and abutting Genesee Street shall be numbered 201 South Genesee Street and so on, the entire length of Genesee Street and Genesee Avenue, each new set of blocks commencing with a new series of hundreds. 
(3)  On all streets and avenues south of the right-of-way of the Chicago & Northwestern Railway Company, running parallel or in the same general direction with Genesee Street and Genesee Avenue, the tracts and parcels shall be numbered to correspond with the numbering of the corresponding or opposite tracts or parcels on Genesee Street and Genesee Avenue. 
(Prior Code, § 333; Code 1977, § 15.20.050) 
Sec. 48-220. - Numbers north and south. 
    The first tract or parcel in the southwest corner of the freight depot block or tract, lying south of Market Street and between Genesee and Cherry Streets, and abutting Genesee Street, shall be numbered 100 North Genesee Street; and the tract or parcel directly opposite, in Block 22, abutting Genesee Street, shall be numbered 101 North Genesee Street; and said numbering shall continue until all tracts or parcels abutting Genesee Street in said block have been numbered. The first tract or parcel in the southwest corner of Block 16 and abutting Genesee Street shall be numbered 200, and the first tract or parcel directly opposite in Block 17 and abutting Genesee Street shall be numbered 201, and so on, the entire length of Genesee Street, each new set of blocks beginning with a new series of hundreds, and on all streets and avenues north of the right-of-way of the Chicago & Northwestern Railway Company running parallel or in the same general direction of said Genesee Street, the tracts or parcels shall be numbered to correspond with the numbering of the corresponding or opposite tract or parcel on Genesee Street. 
(Prior Code, § 334; Code 1977, § 15.20.060) 
Sec. 48-221. - Numbers east and west. 
    The numbering of tracts or parcels abutting streets and avenues running east and west and parallel or in the same general direction as the right-of-way of the Chicago & Northwestern Railway Company shall be numbered in a like manner as the streets and avenues running north and south, as set forth in section 48-220; the numbering west shall commence with the tract or parcel in the northeast corner of Block 22, abutting Market Street, which shall be 101 West Market Street; and the numbering east shall commence at the tract or parcel in the northwest corner of the freight depot block or tract abutting Market Street, which shall be 101 East Market Street. 
(Prior Code, § 335; Code 1977, § 15.20.070) 
Sec. 48-222. - Numbers odd and even. 
    All numbers of tracts and parcels abutting the north side of streets and avenues shall take even numbers and all parcels and tracts abutting the south side of streets and avenues shall take odd numbers; all tracts and parcels abutting the east side of streets and avenues shall take even numbers, and all tracts and parcels abutting the west side of streets and avenues shall take odd numbers. 
(Prior Code, § 335; Code 1977, § 15.20.070) 
Sec. 48-223. - Renumbering; reservation of numbers; recordkeeping. 
    Any renumbering of houses in the city shall be done in conformity with the provisions of this article; provided, however, that on every street or avenue one number shall be left for and applied to each 20 feet of distance, as near as can be, abutting thereon; and a record thereof shall be approved by the city council and filed with the city clerk. 
(Prior Code, § 335; Code 1977, § 15.20.080) 
Chapter 50 - SUBDIVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal zoning, 65 ILCS 5/11-13-1 et seq.; Local Land Resource Management Planning Act, 50 ILCS 805/1 et seq.; local plan commissions, 65 ILCS 5/11-12-4 et seq.; fair housing ordinances, 65 ILCS 5/11.1-1; urban rehabilitation, 65 5/11-11-1 et seq.; setback lines, 65 ILCS 5/11-14-1; approval of maps and plats, 65 ILCS 5/11-15-1; community planning and development, 65 ILCS 5/11-39.1-1; flood control and drainage, 65 ILCS 5/11-110-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 50-1. - State laws adopted. 
    All laws of the state pertinent to this chapter are made a part of these regulations as if written in this chapter at length. 
(Prior Code, § 551; Code 1977, § 16.04.010; Ord. No. 649, 1978) 
Sec. 50-2. - Manufactured homes; special provisions. 
    This chapter shall apply to all manufactured home districts insofar as this chapter pertains to the laying out and dimensions of streets. All streets within a trailer court district shall qualify for motor fuel tax purposes and shall be dedicated to the city. Depressed curbs shall be allowed within a trailer court district. 
(Code 1977, § 16.04.020; Ord. No. 649, 1978; Ord. No. 582, § 1, 1971) 
Sec. 50-3. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alley means a strip of land, not less than 20 feet in width, intended to provide rear access to lots. 
    Cul-de-sac means a street having one open end and being permanently terminated by a vehicular turnaround. 
    Building setback line means a line within a lot or other parcel of land, so designated on the plat of the proposed subdivision, between which, and the adjacent boundary of the street upon which the lot abuts, the erection of an enclosed structure or portion thereof is to be prohibited. 
    Easement means a grant by a property owner for the use of a strip of land by the general public, a corporation, or a certain person for a specific purpose. 
    Lot means a portion of a subdivision or other parcel of land intended for transfer of ownership or for building development. 
    Marginal access street means a minor street which is parallel to and adjacent to primary streets and highways, and which provides access to abutting properties and protection to local traffic from fast through-moving traffic on the primary streets. 
    Minor street means a street intended primarily as access to abutting properties. 
    Primary street means a principal street which collects traffic from minor and secondary streets serving large areas, and connecting with state and U.S. highways or extending to principal points of destination. 
    Private street means a minor street, having a minimum right-of-way width of 50 feet, together with a minimum street width of 30 feet, and as otherwise in conformance with the city's street construction specifications, all lying within a subdivision and having direct connection access to any public street, and shall only be permitted after the subdivider submits in writing sufficient evidence and guarantees to the city that there can be no public interest in such street. 
    Public street means all primary and minor streets which are shown on the subdivision plat and are to be dedicated for public use. 
    Secondary street means a street which collects traffic from minor streets and connecting with primary streets or state and U.S. highways or extending to points of destination. 
    Street means the driving surface area which serves or is intended to serve as a vehicular and pedestrian access to abutting lands or other streets. 
    Street width means the shortest distance between lines of lots delineating the public street. 
    Subdivision means the division of a lot, tract or parcel of land into two or more lots, parcels or other divisions of land, for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of transfer of ownership or building development, including all changes in street or lot lines; provided, however, that a division of land for agricultural purposes, in parcels of more than five acres, not involving any new street or easement of access, shall be exempted. 
(Code 1977, § 16.06.010; Ord. No. 649, 1978) 
Secs. 50-4-50-24. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PRELIMINARY PLATS 

Sec. 50-25. - Standards. 
(a)  Prior to making a subdivision of any tract or parcel of land within the city limits, there shall be filed with the city clerk a tentative plat, in triplicate. This tentative plat shall be in accordance with the following requirements: 
(1)  Each plat shall be drawn to a scale of 100 feet to an inch. Variations in scale may be made, however, where necessary for a proper exhibit of a subdivision. 
(2)  All section lines, watercourses, and other existing features pertinent to a proper subdivision shall be shown. 
(3)  Width of existing roads, streets with their names, alleys, lots, easements, building lines on property proposed to be subdivided, and full width of intersecting streets in property adjacent with their names; also the location of existing highways or streets in the subdivision, which may be separated by intervening property, shall be shown. 
(4)  Name of proposed subdivision and name of owner or trustee as owner, or name of sponsor for the plat, are to be shown; a brief description as to location shall be shown as part of the title. 
(5)  Names of all adjoining subdivisions shall be included and adjoining property not subdivided shall be marked not subdivided. 
(6)  The tentative plat shall show all topographic contour, information of existing ground elevations, nearest utility facilities, such as water mains, sanitary sewers, storm sewers, culverts, etc. The contour lines shall extend beyond the limits of the proposed subdivision area to such an extent to indicate any conditions having any effect upon the proposed development or upon the adjacent lands. The contour interval shall not be greater than five feet. 
(7)  The tentative plat shall be dated and each revision shall also be dated. 
(b)  The city clerk shall refer such tentative plats to the city engineer, who is designated by the city council as the examiner of plats, who shall examine same for conformity with the provisions of these regulations. The examiner of plats shall then issue a plat review letter to the city council and developer either approving the plat or noting the points of conflict with these regulations. 
(Prior Code, § 552; Code 1977, § 16.08.010; Ord. No. 649, 1978) 
Sec. 50-26. - Approval. 
    The city council will approve, conditionally approve or reject the tentative plat after the tentative plat and plat review letter are examined. 
(Code 1977, § 16.08.020; Ord. No. 649, 1978) 
Secs. 50-27-50-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DRAINAGE STUDY 

Sec. 50-56. - Submission; certificate. 
(a)  There shall be submitted, simultaneously with the final subdivision plat, a study which shows topographically and/or by profile the elevation of the land prior to the commencement of any change in elevations as a part of any phase or subdividing, as further contained and detailed in House Bill 1082, Public Act 78-567. 
(b)  A certificate shall be made a part of the drainage study. The form of such certificate shall be on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(c)  The drainage study shall not be filed for record, but shall be retained and filed by the city as a permanent public document. 
(Code 1977, § 16.10.010; Ord. No. 649, 1978) 
Secs. 50-57-50-85. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - FINAL PLATS 

Sec. 50-86. - Standards. 
    After completing the layout and the drainage study as required by this chapter, the subdivider shall submit in triplicate the final plat and drainage study with certificate to the city clerk. The final plat, which shall be in accordance with the tentative plat as approved, shall show that the requirements for layout have been complied with, either by means of conventional signs on the plat or by notes or legends thereto attached and, in addition, shall contain the following data and information: 
(1)  All plats for record shall be drawn to a scale of 100 feet to an inch. Variations in scale may be made, however, where necessary for a proper exhibit of a subdivision. 
(2)  Each plat shall show the date of preparation of map and the north sign, section and quarter-section lines; and the distance from, or the location of, at least one section corner, quarter- or eighth-section corner. 
(3)  Each plat shall include a correct survey of property subdivided, including legal description, section, township, and range; location and widths of all roads, streets, alleys, and other lands to be dedicated to public use. All streets in the proposed subdivision shall be named, which names shall conform to those of existing streets and roads unless otherwise permitted by the city; offset streets shall not be permitted except where unavoidable; the line of departure from one street to another shall be shown. 
(4)  All lot lines shall be shown and lots and blocks properly numbered or lettered. Building setback lines and easements shall be shown and determined by measurements. 
(5)  All necessary dimensions, linear and angular, and angles necessary to properly resurvey, shall be shown, linear dimensions to be given in feet and decimals of a foot. 
(6)  The description and location of all survey monuments placed in the subdivision shall be shown upon all maps for record. 
(7)  With the exception of the drainage certificate which shall be part of the drainage study, all proper certificates, seals and signatures as required by law shall be shown on the final plat and not on separate sheets. 
(8)  Evidence that the work prescribed in this chapter has been accomplished prior to the submission of the plat for final approval, the receipt of the duplicate signed contract, and the accompanying surety bond shall be shown on the final plat by a certificate the form of which shall be on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(9)  Evidence that all required subdivision improvements as outlined herein have either been completed or provided for by bonded contract. 
(Prior Code, § 554; Code 1977, § 16.12.010; Ord. No. 649, 1978) 
Sec. 50-87. - Subdivider's responsibility for taxes and special assessments. 
    The subdivider shall make all adjustments relative to any and all taxes and special assessments levied against the property platted by him, before submitting his final plat for approval. Evidence of such adjustments shall be shown on the plat by a certificate signed by the county clerk. In vacating subdivisions previously platted, the petitioner shall submit evidence of the payment of all taxes and special assessments levied against the property in the same manner as is required for subdividing. 
(Prior Code, § 554; Code 1977, § 16.12.010; Ord. No. 649, 1978) 
Secs. 50-88-50-117. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - DESIGN CRITERIA 

Sec. 50-118. - Layout; applicability of rules. 
    After approval of the tentative plat, the subdivision may be laid out. The general rules set forth in this chapter shall apply in such layout. 
(Prior Code, § 553; Code 1977, § 16.16.010; Ord. No. 649, 1978) 
Sec. 50-119. - Lots and blocks. 
(a)  Each lot shall front on a road, street, or parkway. 
(b)  Blocks shall not be of greater length than 800 feet. 
(c)  Whenever possible, the side lines of lots shall be perpendicular to the street line which forms the front of the lots. 
(d)  The minimum frontage of lots shall be 60 feet as measured across said lot at the established setback line, and where possible, the minimum depth shall be 120 feet. 
(Prior Code, § 553(a), (h), (i), (o); Code 1977, § 16.16.020; Ord. No. 649, 1978) 
Sec. 50-120. - Monuments and markers. 
(a)  Permanent monuments at all block corners, points of tangency of curved lines, and points where street lines intersect the exterior lines of the subdivision shall be of iron pins three quarters of an inch in diameter and 36 inches in length. 
(b)  All lot corners shall be marked by five-eighths-inch diameter iron pins 30 inches in length. 
(Prior Code, § 553(j), (k); Code 1977, § 16.16.030; Ord. No. 649, 1978) 
Sec. 50-121. - Setbacks. 
    Building setback lines shall indicate a minimum of 25 feet except where the same would be greater than existing setbacks on such street, in which case the setback line shall conform to the existing setbacks. 
(Prior Code, § 553(p); Code 1977, § 16.16.040; Ord. No. 649, 1978) 
Sec. 50-122. - Streets-Location. 
(a)  Provisions shall be made for direct connections with the principal streets in adjoining subdivisions. Where practicable, streets shall be provided on section and half-section lines. Such streets shall be extended to the boundaries of the subdivision. 
(b)  Where conditions warrant, the subdivider shall provide one-half the width of streets bordering the subdivision. 
(c)  Private roads and streets shall be permitted only when the subdivider submits sufficient written evidence to the city that there can be no public interest in such private road or street. 
(Prior Code, § 553(b)-(d); Code 1977, § 16.16.050; Ord. No. 649, 1978) 
Sec. 50-123. - Same-Width; rights-of-way. 
(a)  The width of streets shall conform to the following: 
(1)  On any existing state bond issue or federal aid road within the city which has been surveyed, laid out, constructed, or reconstructed prior to the time when approval of the tentative plat is given by the city and on which roads the width of the right-of-way has been specifically established by recorded plats and dedications thereof, the new lot or property line adjacent thereto shall be the established right-of-way line, except that in no case shall the lot or property line adjacent thereto be nearer than 50 feet from the survey line or centerline as shown and referred to in the dedication and recorded plat thereof. 
(2)  On any existing state aid roads within the city, the new lot or property line adjacent thereto shall be the established right-of-way line, except that in no case shall the lot or property line adjacent thereto be nearer than 40 feet from the center of the road. 
(3)  Wherever new streets or roads are created or dedicated within the proposed subdivision, and which are not the type of roads specified in subsection (a)(1) or (2) of this section, they shall preferably be located and laid out on or along established section, quarter-section, or one-eighth section lines, and such streets or roads shall have a minimum width as follows, except streets which are extensions of existing streets which shall not be narrower than such existing streets. 
(b)  All rights-of-way shall conform to the following minimum dimensions: 
(1)  Secondary or collector streets shall be 66 feet. 
(2)  Minor streets shall be 60 feet. 
(3)  Streets leading to culs-de-sac shall be 60 feet. 
(4)  Private streets, where allowed, shall be 50 feet. 
(5)  Utility easements shall be ten feet. 
(c)  Minor streets shall be so laid out that their use by through traffic will be discouraged. 
(d)  Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than 125 feet shall be avoided. 
(e)  Clear visibility, measured along the centerline of the street, shall be provided for at least 300 feet on all primary streets, 200 feet on minor streets, and at least 100 feet on all other streets. 
(f)  It must be evidenced that all street intersections and confluences encourage safe traffic flow. 
(g)  Alleys are not permitted, except where deemed necessary, and at the discretion of the council. 
(h)  The maximum length cul-de-sac shall be 500 feet measured along the centerline from the intersection at origin through center of circle to end of right-of-way. Each cul-de-sac shall have a terminus of nearly circular shape with a minimum diameter of 120 feet right-of-way width, with no less than 88 feet diameter as measured from the back edge to back edge of the curb and gutter. 
(i)  Half-streets shall be prohibited, except where essential to the reasonable development of the subdivision in conformity with the other requirements of these regulations, and where the council finds it will be practicable to require the dedication of the other one-half when the adjoining property is subdivided. Wherever a half street is adjacent to a tract to be subdivided, the other one-half of the street shall be planned within such tract. 
(j)  No street names may be used which will duplicate, or be confused with, the names of existing streets. Existing street names must be projected wherever possible. 
(Prior Code, § 553(e); Code 1977, § 16.16.060; Ord. No. 649, 1978) 
Sec. 50-124. - Same-Grading and surfacing. 
    The subdivider shall grade, drain and surface the roadways of all streets shown on his plat so as to provide reasonable access for vehicular traffic to each lot of his subdivision.
