The roadways shall be graded to cross over all drainage ditches, and the center 33 feet or more thereof shall be surfaced with at least eight inches of compacted aggregate base course materials in accordance with the current Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction of the State of Illinois, or of more permanent construction. The roadway shall be surfaced with bituminous surface treatment Class A-3 in accordance with the standard specifications. If the subdivision faces on any existing street or if any of its streets connect with existing streets, the subdivider shall build all culverts or other drainage structures required along existing streets on account of the subdivision and the streets thereof. 
(Prior Code, § 553(l); Code 1977, § 16.16.070; Ord. No. 649, 1978) 
Sec. 50-125. - Same-Curbing and gutters. 
    All streets shall be bounded by concrete curbs and gutters. They shall be of the integral rolled-type unit, not less than 24 inches in overall width and not less than eight inches thick. The minimum width allowed between the back edges of the curb and gutter shall be 37 feet unless otherwise allowed in this chapter. 
(Prior Code, § 553(q); Code 1977, § 16.16.080; Ord. No. 649, 1978; Ord. No. 562, § 1, 1968) 
Sec. 50-126. - Alleys. 
    Where alleys are provided, they shall be not less than 20 feet in width. Where alleys are not provided, easements of not less than five feet in width shall be provided on each side of all rear lot lines for poles, wires, conduits, storm and sanitary sewers, and gas, water, and heat mains; but stipulated regulations of proper authorities shall have precedence. 
(Prior Code, § 553(m); Code 1977, § 16.16.090; Ord. No. 649, 1978) 
Sec. 50-127. - Sewers. 
    The subdivider shall provide sanitary sewer mains, services, and appurtenances to serve each lot in the subdivision, including connection to existing sanitary sewer. Sewer mains shall be of adequate size to serve the area being subdivided as well as any tributary area which may reasonably be expected to require sewer service in the future; but, in no case, will the inside diameter of the sewer main be less than eight inches. Sewer services shall be of not less than four-inch inside diameter and shall be installed to the limits of the proposed street right-of-way, on each side of the centerline of the street. Manholes shall be provided at all junctions, dead ends, changes in direction of flow, changes in grade or size of pipe, and at not more than 400 feet intervals on straight runs. Materials and methods of construction shall comply with the standard specifications on file in the office of the city clerk and with the provisions of this chapter. The subdivider shall obtain any permits required by law and shall submit same, together with plans for the construction, prior to starting work. 
(Prior Code, § 553(m); Code 1977, § 16.16.100; Ord. No. 649, 1978) 
Sec. 50-128. - Storm sewers. 
    Storm sewers shall be constructed where needed throughout the entire subdivision which shall be separate and independent of the sanitary sewer system and which shall provide an adequate outlet or connection with the storm sewer system of the city. Inlets shall be provided in accordance with current design standards at points approved by the city engineer. 
(Prior Code, § 553(q); Code 1977, § 16.16.110; Ord. No. 649, 1978; Ord. No. 562, § 1, 1968) 
Sec. 50-129. - Water. 
    The subdivider shall provide services and appurtenances as required by the city to serve each lot in the subdivision including connection to existing water mains. Water services shall be of not less than three-fourths-inch inside diameter, shall be installed from the water main to the limits of the proposed street right-of-way, shall include a corporation cock at the main and a curb stop and box at the property line. Materials and methods of construction shall comply with the standard specifications on file in the office of the city clerk. The subdivider shall obtain any permits required by law and shall submit same, together with plans for the construction, prior to starting work. 
(Code 1977, § 16.16.120; Ord. No. 649, 1978) 
Sec. 50-130. - Subdivider to perform work; exception. 
    The subdivider shall do grading, draining, surfacing and construction work as required in this chapter in a manner as permanent as the materials used will allow and to the approval of the city. The subdivider shall do the work at his own expense, either previous to the final approval of his subdivision plat by the city, or deliver to the city a duplicate signed contract covering all of said work and an acceptable surety bond in the amount provided in the city bond schedule guaranteeing the completion of the work contracted for within one year from the date of the contract. 
(Prior Code, § 553(n); Code 1977, § 16.16.130; Ord. No. 649, 1978) 
Chapter 52 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Illinois Income Tax Act, 35 ILCS 5/101 et seq.; Use Tax Act, 35 ILCS 105/1 et seq.; Service Use Tax Act, 35 ILCS 110/1 et seq.; Service Occupation Tax Act, 35 ILCS 115/1 et seq.; Retailers' Occupation Tax Act, 35 ILCS 120/1 et seq.; Cigarette Tax Act, 35 ILCS 130/1 et seq.; Cigarette Use Tax Act, 35 ILCS 135/1 et seq.; Property Tax Code; 35 ILCS 635/1 et seq.; Local Tax Collection Act, 35 ILCS 720/0.01 et seq.; General Assistance Tax Act, 65 ILCS 70/0.01 et seq.; Senior Citizen Property Tax Refund Act, 65 ILCS 75/0.01 et seq.; Municipal Tax Compliance Act, 65 ILCS 80/1 et seq.; levy and collection of municipal taxes, 65 ILCS 5/8-3-1 et seq., certain municipal revenue taxes, 65 ILCS 5/8-11-1; Simplified Municipal Telecommunications Tax, 65 ILCS 636/5-1 et seq.; municipal tax on electricity, 65 ILCS 5/8-11-2; foreign fire insurance tax, 65 ILCS 5/11-10-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 52-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Person maintaining a place of business in the state means any person having or maintaining within the state, directly or by a subsidiary or other affiliate, an office, generation, facility, distribution facility, transmission facility, sales office or other place of business, or any employee, agent, or other representative operating within the state under the authority of the person or its subsidiary or other affiliate, irrespective of whether such place of business or agent or other representative is located in the state permanently or temporarily, or whether such person, subsidiary or other affiliate is licensed or qualified to do business in the state. 
    Purchase at retail means any acquisition of electricity by a purchaser for purposes of use or consumption, and not for resale, but shall not include the use of electricity by a public utility, as defined in 65 ILCS 5/8-11-2, directly in the generation, production, transmission, delivery or sale of electricity. 
    Purchaser means any person who uses or consumes, within the corporate limits of the city, electricity acquired in a purchase at retail. 
    Tax collector means the person delivering electricity to the purchaser. 
(Code 1977, § 3.30.010; Ord. No. 98-15, § I(A), 1998; Ord. No. 98-14, § I(A), 1998) 
Secs. 52-2-52-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RETAILERS' OCCUPATION TAX 

Sec. 52-21. - Imposed; amount; statutory authority. 
    A tax is imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of selling tangible personal property at retail in the city at the rate of one percent of the gross receipts from such sales made in the course of such business while the ordinance from which this article is derived is in effect, in accordance with the provisions of 65 ILCS 5/8-11-1. 
(Code 1977, § 3.08.010; Ord. No. 568, § 1, 1969) 
State Law reference- Retailers' Occupation Tax Act, 35 ILCS 120/1 et seq. 
Sec. 52-22. - Report required. 
    Every person engaged in such business in the city shall file on or before the last day of each calendar month the report to the state department of revenue required by the Retailers' Occupation Tax Act, 35 ILCS 120/1 et seq. 
(Code 1977, § 3.08.020; Ord. No. 568, § 2, 1969) 
Sec. 52-23. - Payment required. 
    At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the state department of revenue the amount of tax imposed by this article on account of the receipts from sales of tangible personal property during the preceding month. 
(Code 1977, § 3.08.030; Ord. No. 568, § 3, 1969) 
Secs. 52-24-52-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SERVICE OCCUPATION TAX 

Sec. 52-50. - Imposed; amount; statutory authority. 
    A tax is imposed upon all persons engaged in the city in the business of making sales of service at the rate of one percent of the cost of all tangible personal property transferred by said servicemen, either in the form of tangible personal property or in the form of real estate as an incident to a sale of service, in accordance with the provisions of 65 ILCS 5/8-11-5. 
(Code 1977, § 3.12.010; Ord. No. 569, § 1, 1969) 
State Law reference- Service Occupation Tax Act, 35 ILCS 115/1 et seq. 
Sec. 52-51. - Report required. 
    Every supplier or serviceman required to account for municipal service occupation tax for the benefit of the city shall file, on or before the last day of each calendar month, the report to the state department of revenue required by the Service Occupation Tax Act, 35 ILCS 115/1 et seq. 
(Code 1977, § 3.12.020; Ord. No. 569, § 2, 1969) 
Sec. 52-52. - Payment required. 
    At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the state department of revenue the amount of tax imposed by this article. 
(Code 1977, § 3.12.030; Ord. No. 569, § 3, 1969) 
Secs. 52-53-52-77. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - USE TAX 

Sec. 52-78. - Imposed; rate. 
    A tax is imposed in accordance with the provisions of 65 ILCS 5/8-11-6 upon the privilege of using in the city any item of tangible personal property which is purchased outside the state at retail from a retailer, and which is titled or registered with an agency of state government. The tax shall be at a rate of one percent of the selling price of such tangible property with the term "selling price" to have the meaning as defined in the Municipal Use Tax Act, 65 ILCS 5/8-11-6. 
(Code 1977, § 3.16.010; Ord. No. 610, § 1, 1974) 
State Law reference- Municipal Use Tax Act, 65 ILCS 5/8-11-6. 
Sec. 52-79. - Collection. 
    Such tax shall be collected by the state department of revenue for all municipalities imposing the tax and shall be paid before the title or certificate of registration for the personal property is issued. 
(Code 1977, § 3.16.020; Ord. No. 610, § 2, 1974) 
Secs. 52-80-52-101. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ELECTRICITY TAX 

Sec. 52-102. - Imposed. 
    A tax is imposed on the privilege of using or consuming electricity acquired in a purchase at retail and used or consumed within the corporate limits of the municipality at the following rates, calculated on a monthly basis for each purchaser: 
(1)  For the first 2,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month: 0.448 cents per kilowatt-hour; 
(2)  For the next 48,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month: 0.294 cents per kilowatt-hour; 
(3)  For the next 50,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month: 0.264 cents per kilowatt-hour; 
(4)  For the next 400,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month: 0.257 cents per kilowatt-hour; 
(5)  For the next 500,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month: 0.250 cents per kilowatt-hour; 
(6)  For the next 2,000,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month: 0.235 cents per kilowatt-hour; 
(7)  For the next 2,000,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month: 0.231 cents per kilowatt-hour; 
(8)  For the next 5,000,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month: 0.228 cents per kilowatt-hour; 
(9)  For the next 10,000,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month: 0.224 cents per kilowatt-hour; 
(10)  For all electricity used or consumed in excess of 20,000,000 kilowatt-hours in a month: 0.220 cents per kilowatt-hour. 
(Code 1977, § 3.30.020; Ord. No. 98-14, § I(B), 1998; Ord. No. 98-15, § I(B), 1998) 
State Law reference- Municipal tax on electricity, 65 ILCS 5/8-11-2. 
Sec. 52-103. - Exceptions. 
(a)  None of the taxes authorized by this article may be imposed with respect to any transaction in interstate commerce or otherwise to the extent to which the business or privilege may not, under the federal constitution and federal statutes be made the subject of taxation by the state or any political subdivision thereof. 
(b)  Persons engaged in the business of distributing, supplying, furnishing, or selling or transmitting gas, water, or electricity, or engaged in the business of transmitting messages, or using or consuming electricity acquired in a purchase at retail, shall not be subject to taxation under the provisions of this article for those transactions that are or may become subject to taxation under the provisions of the Municipal Retailers' Occupation Tax Act, 65 ILCS 5/8-11-1. 
(c)  No tax authorized by this article shall be imposed upon any person engaged in a business or on any privilege unless the tax is imposed in like manner and at the same rate upon all persons engaged in businesses of the same class in the city, whether privately or municipally owned or operated, or exercising the same privilege within the city. 
(Code 1977, § 3.30.030; Ord. No. 98-14, § I(C), 1998; Ord. No. 98-15, § I(C), 1998) 
Sec. 52-104. - Additional taxes. 
    The tax levied in this article shall be in addition to other taxes levied upon the taxpayer or its business. 
(Code 1977, § 3.30.040; Ord. No. 98-14, § I(D), 1998; Ord. No. 98-15, § I(D), 1998) 
Sec. 52-105. - Collection. 
(a)  The tax authorized by this article shall be collected from the purchaser by the person maintaining a place of business in the state who delivers the electricity to the purchaser. 
(b)  This tax shall constitute a debt of the purchaser to the person who delivers the electricity to the purchaser and if unpaid, is recoverable in the same manner as the original charge for delivering the electricity. Any tax required to be collected pursuant to this article and any such tax collected by a person delivering electricity shall constitute a debt owed to the municipality by such person delivering the electricity, provided that the person delivering electricity shall be allowed a credit for such tax related to deliveries of electricity the charges for which are written off as uncollectible, and provided further, that if such charges are thereafter collected, the delivering supplier shall be obligated to remit such tax. 
(c)  Persons delivering electricity shall collect the tax from the purchaser by adding such tax to the gross charge for delivering the electricity. 
(d)  Persons delivering electricity shall also be authorized to add to such gross charge an amount equal to three percent of the tax to reimburse the person delivering electricity for the expense incurred in keeping records, billing customers, preparing and filing returns, remitting the tax and supplying data to the city upon request. 
(e)  If the person delivering electricity fails to collect the tax from the purchaser, then the purchaser shall be required to pay the tax directly to the municipality in the manner prescribed by the city. 
(f)  Persons delivering electricity who file returns pursuant to this section shall, at the time of filing such return, pay the city the amount of the tax collected pursuant to this article. 
(Code 1977, § 3.30.050; Ord. No. 98-14, § I(E), 1998; Ord. No. 98-15, § I(E), 1998) 
Sec. 52-106. - Reports to city. 
(a)  On or before the last day of each month, each taxpayer who has not paid the tax imposed by this article to a person delivering electricity as provided in this article and who is not otherwise exempted from paying such tax shall make a return to the city treasurer for the preceding month stating: 
(1)  His name; 
(2)  His principal place of business; 
(3)  His gross receipts and/or kilowatt-hour usage during the month upon the basis of which the tax is imposed; 
(4)  Amount of tax; 
(5)  Such other reasonable and related information as the corporate authorities may require. 
(b)  The taxpayer making the return herein provided for shall, at the time of making such return, pay to the city, the amount of tax herein imposed; provided that in connection with any return, the taxpayer may, if he so elects, report and pay an amount based upon his total billings of business subject to the tax during the period for which the return is made (exclusive of any amounts previously billed) with prompt adjustments of later payments based upon any differences between such billings, and the taxable gross receipts. 
(Code 1977, § 3.30.060; Ord. No. 98-14, § I(F), 1998; Ord. No. 98-15, § I(F), 1998) 
Sec. 52-107. - Credit for overpayment; limitation on commencement of collection actions. 
(a)  If it shall appear that an amount of tax has been paid which was not due under the provisions of this article, whether as the result of a mistake of fact or an error of law, then such amount shall be credited against any tax due, or to become due, under this article from the taxpayer who made the erroneous payment; provided that no amounts erroneously paid more than three years prior to the filing of a claim therefor shall be so credited. 
(b)  No action to recover any amount of tax due under the provisions of this article shall be commenced more than three years after the due date of such amount. 
(Code 1977, § 3.30.070; Ord. No. 98-14, § I(G), 1998; Ord. No. 98-15, § I(G), 1998) 
Sec. 52-108. - Penalty. 
    Any taxpayer who fails to make a return, or who makes a fraudulent return, or who willfully violates any other provision of this article is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined in the amount provided in the city penalty schedule and, in addition, shall be liable in a civil action for the amount of tax due. 
(Code 1977, § 3.30.080; Ord. No. 98-14, § I(H), 1998; Ord. No. 98-15, § I(H), 1998) 
Secs. 52-109-52-129. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE COMPANY TAX 

Sec. 52-130. - Imposed; rate. 
    All corporations, companies, and associations not incorporated under the laws of the state and which are engaged in the city in effecting or soliciting fire insurance shall pay to the city treasurer upon July 15 of each and every year a sum equal to six percent of the gross receipts of premiums received by such corporation, company, or association, or their agency or agents, for business effected or transacted for fire insurance within the city for the year ending July 1, preceding said date. The sum shall be as a tax or license fee upon all such corporations, companies, or associations transacting said business within the city. 
(Prior Code, § 296; Code 1977, § 3.04.010) 
State Law reference- Foreign fire insurance tax, 65 ILCS 5/11-10-1 et seq. 
Sec. 52-131. - Report by agents required. 
    Every person acting as agent or otherwise for or upon behalf of any such corporation, company, or association shall, on or before July 15 of each and every year, render to the city clerk a full, true, and just account, verified by oath, of all the premiums which, during the year ending on July 1, have been received by him or any other person for him, in behalf of any such company, corporation, or association, and shall fully and specifically set out in the report the amount or amounts received as premiums for fire insurance. 
(Prior Code, § 297; Code 1977, § 3.04.020) 
Sec. 52-132. - Payments required. 
    The agent shall also, at the time of the making of the report required in this article, pay to the treasurer of the city the sum of two percent upon the gross receipts of such corporation, company, or association, obtained as premiums for effecting fire insurance in the city as is specified in this article. 
(Prior Code, § 298; Code 1977, § 3.04.030) 
Sec. 52-133. - Failure to make payment; termination of business. 
    If the report required by this article is not filed by the date required or if the rates for the tax or license fee remains unpaid after that day, it shall be unlawful for any such corporation, company, or association to transact any business of fire insurance in the city until the requirements of this article have been fully complied with. This section shall in no way affect the validity of or relieve such corporation, company, or association from the payment of any risk that may be taken in violation of this article between such corporation, company, or association and the person so assured. 
(Prior Code, § 299; Code 1977, § 3.04.040) 
Sec. 52-134. - Disposition of collected funds. 
    Any and all sums received under the provisions of this article shall be by the city treasurer paid over to the treasurer of the city fire department, to be by the fire department kept in a separate fund to be known as the foreign fire insurance tax fund and used only for equipment for the fire department and the maintenance of the same. 
(Prior Code, § 301; Code 1977, § 3.04.050) 
Sec. 52-135. - Failure to report. 
    It is unlawful and a violation of this article for any corporation, company, or association to fail to render an account or report designated in this article by the day required by this article. It is unlawful and a violation of this Code for a tax or license fee to remain unpaid after July 15. In addition to penalties for violation of this article, the city shall recover, in an action in its name and for its use against such corporation, company, or association so failing to make such report, and to pay such license fee or tax, the full amount of the license fee which would be due under the provisions of this article. 
(Prior Code, § 300; Code 1977, § 3.04.060) 
ARTICLE VII. - HOTEL TAX 

Sec. 52-136. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to generate revenue to be placed in a fund to generate tourism through the promotion of lodging, restaurants, attractions, conventions, expositions, and theatrical, sport, cultural, and other similar activities. 
(Ord. No. 16-09, § 2, 6-13-2016) 
Sec. 52-137. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of and as used in this article unless the context otherwise require: 
    City clerk means the City Clerk of the City of Morrison, Illinois. 
    Hotel means any building or buildings in which the public may, for a consideration, obtain living quarters, sleeping, or housekeeping accommodations. The term includes inns, motels, tourist homes, or courts, lodging houses, rooming houses, apartment houses, and bed-and-breakfast houses. 
    Occupancy means the use or possession, or the right to the use or possession, of any room or rooms in a hotel for any purpose, or the right to the use or possession of the furnishings or to the services and accommodations accompanying the use and possession of the room or rooms. 
    Permanent resident means any man or woman who occupies or has the right to occupy any room or rooms in a hotel for at least 30 consecutive days for his or her own personal use unrelated to the conducting of any business or occupation. 
    Person means any natural individual, firm, partnership, association, joint stock company, joint venture, public or private corporation, or a receiver, executor, trustee, conservator, or other representative appointed by order of any court. 
    Rent or rental means the consideration received for occupancy, valued in money, whether received in money or otherwise, including all receipts, cash, credits and property or services of any kind or nature. 
    Renter means any person who pays for the privilege of using or occupying a hotel room for the period for which payment is made. 
    Room or rooms means any living quarters, sleeping or housekeeping accommodations. 
    Treasurer means the city treasurer of the City of Morrison, Illinois. 
(Ord. No. 16-09, § 2, 6-13-2016) 
Sec. 52-138. - Tax imposed. 
(a)  There is hereby levied and imposed a tax upon all persons, firms or corporations engaged in the business of renting, leasing or letting rooms in a hotel which is located within the corporate limits of the City of Morrison, Illinois, at a rate of five percent of the gross rental receipts from such renting, leasing or letting for any purpose for each 24-hour period or portion thereof, excluding, however, from the gross rental receipts the proceeds of such rents, leasing or letting to permanent residents. The tax imposed herein shall be in addition to any and all other taxes and charges applicable to such hotels, but such other taxes and charges shall not be construed to be a part of the gross rental receipts upon which this tax is levied. 
(b)  The ultimate incidents of and liability for payment of the tax levied herein is upon the person engaged in the business of leasing, renting or letting said rooms. Such hotel owners and operators may reimburse themselves for their tax liability for this tax by separately stating such tax as an additional charge to the lessee or renter, which charge may be stated in combination as a single amount, with the State of Illinois tax imposed under "The Hotel Operator's Occupation Tax Act", (as provided for in 35 ILCS 145/1 et. seq.) No tax is imposed based upon receipts from any permanent residents of any hotel. 
(c)  No person engaged in the business of renting, leasing, or letting rooms in a hotel shall reimburse himself or charge for the imposition of this tax at a rate higher than the tax imposed by this article. 
(d)  Except as otherwise provided in this paragraph, on or before the last day of each calendar month, every person engaged in the business of renting, leasing or letting rooms in a hotel within the City of Morrison during the preceding calendar month shall file a return with the treasurer, on forms to be supplied by the city clerk, stating: 
(1)  The name of the operator; 
(2)  His residence address and the address of the principal place of business from which he engages in the business of renting, leasing or letting rooms in a hotel in the city; 
(3)  Total amount of rental receipts received by him during the preceding calendar month from renting, leasing, or letting rooms during such preceding calendar month; 
(4)  Total amount of rental received by him during the preceding calendar month from renting, leasing or letting rooms to permanent residents during such preceding calendar months; 
(5)  Total amount of other exclusions from gross rental receipts as allowed by this ordinance; 
(6)  Gross rental receipts which were received by him during the preceding calendar month and upon the basis of which the tax is imposed; 
(7)  The amount of the tax due; 
(8)  The amount of penalty due, if any; 
(9)  Such other reasonable information as may from time to time be required by the treasurer. 
    The person subject to tax shall also transmit to the treasurer with the return required by this paragraph the amount of the tax and penalties, if any, due as shown by said return required by this paragraph the amount of the tax and penalties, if any, due as shown by said return. Such person shall also file with the treasurer, not later than five business days after said documents are transmitted to the State of Illinois, copies of all hotel operator's occupation tax returns as are required by the provisions of "The Hotel Operators' Occupation Tax Act", 35 ILCS 145/1 et. seq. 
(e)  Any person engaged in the business of renting, leasing, or letting of hotel rooms shall maintain complete and accurate books and records, including a daily sheet showing the gross receipts for the hotel rentals for the day reported. 
(f)  For the purposes of enforcing and administering this article, the treasurer or such agents as are designated by the treasurer shall, after providing reasonable notice, have access during normal business hours to the books and records of persons and businesses subject to this article. The treasurer or such agents as are designated by the treasurer shall at least annually inspect said books and records and shall file a written report of his or her findings with the city council no later than April 1 of each year. 
(g)  Any person who violates any provision of this article, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not less than $200.00 nor more than $500.00 for the first offense, and not less than $300.00 and not more than $750.00 for the second and each subsequent offense during any 180-day period. A separate and distinct offense shall be regarded as having been committed each day upon which said person shall continue any such violation. 
(h)  There is hereby created a "Morrison Tourism and Convention Promotion Fund" into which the treasurer shall, by the twentieth day of each month, place the proceeds resulting from the previous month's collection of this hotel tax. The monies in this fund may be utilized solely and exclusively for the purpose of promoting tourism and conventions or otherwise to attract nonresident visitors to the City of Morrison. 
(i)  This tax shall not in any manner constitute an indebtedness by the City of Morrison subject to any limitation imposed by statute or otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 16-09, § 2, 6-13-2016) 
Chapter 54 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq.; rules of the road, 625 ILCS 5/11-100 et seq.; vehicle equipment, 625 ILCS 5/12-100 et seq.; abandoned, lost, stolen or unclaimed vehicles, 625 ILCS 5/4-201 et seq.; statewide bikeway program, 605 ILCS 30/0.01 et seq.; traffic regulatory powers of local authorities, 625 ILCS 5/11-208. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 54-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Authorized emergency vehicle means vehicles of the fire department, police vehicles, ambulances, and other emergency vehicles as are or shall be designated or authorized by the city council. 
    Central business district (CBD) refers to the area bounded to the north by Knox Street; to the south by the Chicago & Northwestern Railroad right-of-way; to the west by Orange Street; and to the east by Clinton Street; provided, however, that CBD does not include "business district" as applied to recreational vehicles, which means instead those sidewalks existing between the easterly right-of-way of Madison Street on the east; the westerly right-of-way of Orange Street on the west; the northerly right-of-way of U.S. Route 30 on the north and northerly right-of-way of the Union Pacific Railroad on the south. 
    Days. Odd-numbered days and even-numbered days of the month refer to the day as numbered on the calendar of the particular current month and year. 
    Driver means every person who operates or is in actual physical control of a vehicle. 
    Motor vehicle means every vehicle which is self-propelled but not operated upon rails. 
    Operate a recreational vehicle and any form or tense thereafter, when used with regard to recreational vehicles, means and refers to the use, putting into action or causing to function of a recreational vehicle by a person seated, standing, or in any other method mounted thereon or therein. 
    Park means the standing of a vehicle, other than temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading. 
    Pedestrian means any person afoot. 
    Police officer means every officer of the municipal police department or any officer authorized to direct or regulate traffic or to make arrests for violations of traffic regulations. 
    Private road or private driveway means every way or place in private ownership and used for vehicular travel by the owner and those having express or implied permission from the owner, but not by other persons. 
    Public notice means a communication from the director of public works, or his designee, to the public via the news media, informing the public of the existence of a snow emergency or cancellation thereof. Failure of receiving said communication shall not negate the fact that public notice was given. 
    Recreational vehicle includes every device propelled by human power or motorized power upon which any person may ride, to include, but not limited to, bicycles, skateboards, roller skates, in-line skates or like items. 
    Right-of-way means the privilege of the immediate use of the roadway. 
    Roadway means that part of a street ordinarily used for vehicular travel. 
    Sides of streets. Odd-numbered sides and even-numbered sides of the street refer to the usual residence or building street address number assigned by the property authority. Even numbers are on the north and east sides of the streets, odd numbers are on the south and west sides of the streets. 
    Sidewalk is that portion of a street between the curblines or the lateral lines of a roadway and the adjacent property lines intended for use of pedestrians. 
    Snow emergency means a period during which intensive, unobstructed snow and/or ice removal operations shall be necessary due to snowfall, freezing rain, sleet, wind, drifted snow or a combination thereof. 
    Snow routes means those streets specifically designated as such in this chapter. 
    Standing means any stopping of a vehicle, whether occupied or not. 
    Stop means a complete cessation of movement. 
    Stop or stopping means, when prohibited, any stopping of a vehicle except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the direction of a police officer or traffic-control sign or signal. 
    Street or highway means the entire width between property lines of every way or place of whatever nature when any part thereof is open to use of the public, as a matter of right, for purpose of vehicular traffic. 
    Through street means any specially designated street at which all traffic, except authorized emergency vehicles as provided for by the laws of the state, is required to stop before entering or crossing, and at which are erected appropriate stop signs. 
    Traffic means pedestrians, ridden or herded animals, vehicles, and other conveyances while using any street for purpose of travel. 
    Vehicle means every device in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, except devices moved by human power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(Prior Code, § 672(part); Code 1977, § 10.04.010) 
State Law reference- Similar definitions, 625 ILCS 5/101 et seq. 
Secs. 54-2-54-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TRAFFIC REGULATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 54-21. - State statutes adopted. 
    The Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq., as amended and as may be amended, is adopted in by reference in its entirety as if the same were set forth in full in this chapter. Three copies of the adopted code are on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1977, § 10.01.010; Ord. No. 87-12, § 1, 1987; Ord. No. 97-4, § 1, 1997) 
State Law reference- Municipal Adoption of Codes and Records Act, 50 ILCS 220/0.01 et seq.; powers of local authorities regarding traffic, 625 ILCS 5/11-208; local laws, 625 ILCS 5/11-211. 
Sec. 54-22. - Adoption of federal laws and regulations. 
    The provisions of the federal Motor Carrier Safety Act regulating drug and alcohol abuse, 49 CFR 40 through 352, as amended and as may be amended, are adopted by reference in their entirety as if the same were set forth in full in this chapter. Three copies of the adopted provisions are on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1977, § 10.01.020; Ord. No. 01-04, § 1, 2001; Ord. No. 01-07, § 1, 2001) 
State Law reference- Municipal Adoption of Codes and Records Act, 50 ILCS 220/0.01 et seq. 
Sec. 54-23. - Crossing railroad grade prohibited under certain conditions. 
    No driver shall cross a railroad grade crossing when signals or gates indicate the approach of a train or any vehicle upon the tracks of said railroad, unless otherwise directed by a traffic officer or other person in charge of the crossing. 
(Prior Code, § 696; Code 1977, § 10.16.060) 
State Law reference- Obedience to signal indicating approach of train required, 625 ILCS 5/11-1201. 
Sec. 54-24. - Unnecessary noise prohibited. 
    No person shall operate a vehicle, except in cases of emergency, in such manner that loud and disturbing noises are heard; nor shall horns or other warning devices be sounded unnecessarily. 
(Prior Code, § 683; Code 1977, § 10.24.020; Ord. No. 497, § 1, 1961; Ord. No. 570, § 1, 1969) 
State Law reference- Mufflers required for prevention of noise, 625 ILCS 5/12-602; horns and warning devices, 625 ILCS 5/12-601; excessive engine braking noise signs, 625 ILCS 5/12-602.1; prevention and suppression of noise by local authorities authorized, 65 ILCS 5/112-5-2. 
Secs. 54-25-54-51. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TRAFFIC SIGNS, SIGNALS AND MARKINGS[2] 

Footnotes:

State Law reference- Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-301 et seq.; obedience to and effect of traffic laws, 625 ILCS 5/11-201 et seq. 

Sec. 54-52. - Obedience to traffic control devices required. 
    It is a misdemeanor for the driver of any vehicle to disobey any official traffic-control sign or official traffic-control mark placed above or upon the surface of any street. 
(Prior Code, § 684; Code 1977, § 10.24.010) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, 625 ILCS 5/11-305. 
Secs. 54-53-54-77. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DRIVING, TURNING AND PASSING 

Sec. 54-78. - Driving on right-hand side. 
    Vehicles shall be driven on the right side of the street except when lawfully overtaking and passing another vehicle, when the right side is closed for repair, or upon a one-way street. 
(Prior Code, § 1691; Code 1977, § 10.16.010) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, 625 ILCS 5/11-701. 
Sec. 54-79. - Opposing traffic on right-hand side. 
    All vehicles proceeding in opposite directions shall pass each other to the right except as otherwise provided by law. 
(Prior Code, § 1692; Code 1977, § 10.16.020) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, 625 ILCS 5/11-702. 
Sec. 54-80. - Emerging from alleys and driveways. 
    All drivers emerging from an alley or from a private driveway shall yield the right-of-way to all persons on the sidewalk and to all vehicles on the street about to be entered. 
(Prior Code, § 700; Code 1977, § 10.16.100) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, 625 ILCS 5/11-906. 
Sec. 54-81. - Passing-On left. 
    A driver overtaking another vehicle shall pass to the left thereof when such passing can be safely done, and he shall not again drive to the right side of the street until safely clear of the overtaken vehicle. No such passing shall be done unless the same can be done with safety. 
(Prior Code, § 693; Code 1977, § 10.16.030) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, 625 ILCS 5/11-703; limitation on overtaking on the left, 625 ILCS 5/11-705; further limitations on driving to the left of the center of the roadway, 625 ILCS 5/11-706. 
Sec. 54-82. - Same-On right. 
    A driver may overtake and pass another vehicle on the right when the other is making or about to make a left turn, or when on a one-way street. No such passing shall be done unless the same can be done with safety. 
(Prior Code, § 694; Code 1977, § 10.16.040) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, 625 ILCS 5/11-704. 
Sec. 54-83. - Same-When prohibited. 
    No driver shall overtake another vehicle at any time when the same cannot safely be done; when the driver's view of the street is obstructed by the crest of a hill, curve, or other cause; when the driver is in a no-passing zone; or when approaching within 100 feet of or traversing any intersection or railroad grade crossing. 
(Prior Code, § 695; Code 1977, § 10.16.050) 
State Law reference- No passing zones, 625 ILCS 5/11-707. 
Sec. 54-84. - Right-of-way. 
    The right-of-way at intersections shall be as provided by state law. 
(Prior Code, § 697; Code 1977, § 10.16.070) 
State Law reference- Right-of-way regulations, 625 ILCS 5/11-901 et seq. 
Sec. 54-85. - U-turn prohibited at the intersection of North Jackson Street and East Lincolnway. 
    It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to make a U-turn at the intersection of East Lincolnway and North Jackson Street from any direction. For purposes of this section, a U-turn is defined as operating a vehicle by turning so as to proceed in the opposite direction on the same street. 
(Ord. No. 12-10, § 1, 3-12-2012) 
Secs. 54-86-54-111. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - SPEED 

Sec. 54-112. - General restriction. 
    No person shall drive a vehicle upon any public highway in the city at a speed greater than is reasonable and proper, having regard to the traffic and the use of the way or so as to endanger the life or limb or injure any person or property; nor at a speed greater than the applicable maximum speed limit established by law, ordinance, or regulation. 
(Prior Code, § 680; Code 1977, § 10.20.010) 
State Law reference- Speed restrictions, 625 ILCS 5/11-601 et seq.; alteration of speed limits by local authorities, 625 ILCS 5/11-604. 
Sec. 54-113. - Due care required; when speed reduction required. 
    The fact that the speed of a vehicle is lower than the applicable maximum speed shall not relieve the driver from the duty to decrease speed when approaching and crossing an intersection; when approaching and going around a curve; when approaching a hillcrest; or when special hazard exists with respect to pedestrians, other traffic, or by reason of weather or highway conditions. Speed shall be diminished as may be necessary to avoid colliding with any person or property at all times. It is the duty of pedestrians and drivers to at all times use due care. 
(Prior Code, § 680; Code 1977, § 10.20.020) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, 625 ILCS 5/11-601. 
Sec. 54-114. - Maximum speeds designated. 
(a)  The maximum speed limit upon all streets in the city over which the state has maintenance responsibility shall be that fixed by law, or a duly empowered agency or department of the state; otherwise, speed limits are as follows: 
(1)  The maximum speed limit upon all streets where the same pass through the business district of the city is 30 miles per hour. 
(2)  The maximum speed limit upon all streets in residential districts is 25 miles per hour. 
(3)  The maximum speed limit upon all alleys is 15 miles per hour. 
(4)  The maximum speed limit upon Meadowbrook Drive shall be 20 miles per hour. 
(5)  The maximum speed limit in any school speed zone, as designated by the traffic commission pursuant to the powers granted by the traffic commission under this Code, shall be 20 miles per hour. 
(6)  The maximum speed limit in any park or cemetery is ten miles per hour. 
(7)  The maximum speed limit upon Main Street, between Madison and Orange shall be 20 miles per hour. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the provisions of this section, the maximum speed limit of a vehicle equipped with two or more solid tires is ten miles per hour at all times and in all locations. 
(Prior Code, § 680; Code 1977, § 10.20.030; Ord. No. 88-10, § 1, 1988; Ord. No. 90-1, § 2, 1990; Ord. No. 92-6, § 1, 1992; Ord. No. 01-06, § 1, 2001; Ord. No. 12-16, § 1, 5-14-2012; Ord. No. 12-26, § 1, 8-13-2012) 
State Law reference- Alteration of speed limits by local authorities, 625 ILCS 5/11-604. 
Sec. 54-115. - Specifications required on violation notices. 
    In every charge of violation of this chapter, the complaint and the summons or notice to appear shall specify the speed at which the defendant is alleged to have driven, and the speed limit applicable at the location of the alleged violation. 
(Prior Code, § 680; Code 1977, § 10.20.040) 
Secs. 54-116-54-143. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - PEDESTRIANS 

Sec. 54-144. - Right-of-way in crosswalks. 
    All drivers shall yield the right-of-way to all pedestrians lawfully upon any marked or unmarked crosswalk. 
(Prior Code, § 698; Code 1977, § 10.16.080) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, 625 ILCS 5/11-1002, 5/11-1002.5. 
Sec. 54-145. - Outside crosswalks; duty to yield to vehicles. 
    All pedestrians crossing a street at any point other than within a marked or unmarked crosswalk at an intersection shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles. This section shall not be construed to relieve any driver from the duty to exercise due care. 
(Prior Code, § 699; Code 1977, § 10.16.090) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, 625 ILCS 5/11-1003. 
Secs. 54-146-54-173. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFENSES 

Sec. 54-174. - Reckless driving prohibited; misdemeanor declared. 
    Any person who drives any vehicle with a willful or a wanton disregard for the safety of persons or property is guilty of reckless driving, which offense is declared to be a misdemeanor. 
(Prior Code, § 679; Code 1977, § 10.24.030) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, 625 ILCS 5/11-503. 
Sec. 54-175. - Driving under influence of alcohol or drugs declared a misdemeanor. 
    It is a misdemeanor for any person who is an habitual user of narcotic drugs or any person who is under the influence of intoxicating liquor or narcotic drugs to drive any vehicle within the city. 
(Prior Code, § 678; Code 1977, § 10.24.040; Ord. No. 485, § 2, 1961) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, 625 ILCS 5/11-501. 
Sec. 54-176. - Injuries by vehicle, failure to render aid, and giving false identification prohibited. 
    It is unlawful and a violation of this Code for any person while riding, driving, or propelling a bicycle, motor bicycle, automobile, carriage, wagon, or other vehicle to run against, upon, or over any person upon the public highway or the property of any person in his personal possession, or to use any vehicle so as to cause an injury or damage to such person or property, or to fail to stop at once to ascertain the extent of such injury and to render such assistance as may be needed, or to refuse to give his true name and residence when asked for by the person so injured. 
(Prior Code, § 429; Code 1977, § 8.12.060) 
Sec. 54-177. - Unlawful use of vehicles. 
    No person shall wilfully or maliciously take, ride, drive, or use any vehicle, the property of another, without the consent of the owner or other person having legal custody, care, or control of the same. This section shall have no application to any case of taking property with intent to steal the same. 
(Prior Code, § 449; Code 1977, § 9.48.160) 
Secs. 54-178-54-207. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PARKING, STANDING AND STOPPING 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 54-208-54-237. - Reserved.

Sec. 54-238. - When required. 
(a)  When stop signs are erected at intersections, whether erected by local ordinance authority or that of the township, county or state, it is unlawful for any person driving or moving any vehicle or causing any vehicle to be driven or moved along any public street (right-of-way) or from any private drive, lane, alley or street having access to a public street in the city without first bringing such vehicle to a full and complete stop as near the right-of-way line of the intersecting street as possible and, regardless of direction, giving the right-of-way to all vehicles proceeding upon the intersecting street, except when directed otherwise by a police officer or other traffic control device. 
(b)  The requirements of this section shall be effective only after appropriate stop signs or other traffic control devices giving notice thereof are erected in accordance with the state manual and specifications at intersections as stated in this subsection, which are hereby designated and approved pursuant to the city's authority under 625 ILCS 5/11-302:

Sec. 54-239. - Stop intersections-Wall Street and Main Street. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person driving or moving any vehicle or causing any vehicle to be driven or moved along the right-of-way of Wall Street in the city to drive, move, or cause to be driven or moved such vehicle into or across the intersection of Heaton Street with Wall Street, or into or across the intersection of Orange Street with Wall Street, or into or across the intersection of Genesee Street with Wall Street in the city without first bringing such vehicle to a full stop as near the right-of-way line of the intersecting street as possible and, regardless of direction, giving the right-of-way to all vehicles proceeding upon the intersecting streets. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person driving or moving any vehicle or causing any vehicle to be driven or moved in the city to drive, move, or cause to be driven or moved, such vehicle into or across Main Street, in the city, at the intersection of any street in the city with Main Street, except Cherry Street, without first bringing such vehicle to a full stop as near the right-of-way line of Main Street as possible and, regardless of direction, giving the right-of-way to all vehicles proceeding upon Main Street. 
(Prior Code, § 714; Code 1977, § 10.16.130) 
State Law reference- Local authority to establish through highways and stop and yield intersections, 625 ILCS 5/11-302; stop and yield signs, 625 ILCS 5/11-1204. 
Sec. 54-240. - Same-At French Creek Road and Klimstra Court. 
    It is unlawful for any person driving or moving any vehicle or causing any vehicle to be driven or moved in a westerly direction on French Creek Road into or across the intersection of French Creek Road and Klimstra Court without first bringing such vehicle to a full stop, giving the right-of-way to all other vehicles at the intersection. 
(Code 1977, § 10.16.131; Ord. No. 05-01, § 1, 2005) 
State Law reference- Local authority to establish through highways and stop and yield intersections, 625 ILCS 5/11-302; stop and yield signs, 625 ILCS 5/11-1204. 
Sec. 54-241. - Stopping for school buses required. 
    The driver of a vehicle upon any street or alley within the city upon meeting or overtaking, from either direction, any school bus which has stopped on such street or alley for the purpose of receiving or discharging any school children shall stop the vehicle before reaching such school bus when there is in operation on the school bus a visual signal as specified by law; and the driver shall not proceed until such school bus resumes motion, or is signaled by the school bus driver to proceed, or the visual signals are no longer activated. 
(Prior Code, § 681.1; Code 1977, § 10.16.140) 
State Law reference- Approaching, overtaking and passing school bus, 625 ILCS 5/11-1414; school buses stopping, loading and discharging passengers on certain roadways, 625 ILCS 5/11-1415. 
Secs. 54-242-54-260. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PARKING AND STANDING 

Sec. 54-261. - Parking prohibited at certain places. 
    No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic control device in any of the following places: 
(1)  On a sidewalk; 
(2)  Within an intersection; 
(3)  Within 15 feet of a fire hydrant; 
(4)  On a crosswalk; 
(5)  Upon a public or private driveway or extension thereof, public or private roadway or upon undeveloped land lying between the edge of a roadway and the edge of a walkway in such a manner as to obstruct the view of traffic approaching any intersection creating thereby hazardous conditions or condition for pedestrian or vehicular traffic entering into any such intersection; 
(6)  Upon the parkway between the curb and sidewalk in residential areas, unless otherwise designated by police posting; 
(7)  At any place where official signs or markings prohibit parking. 
(Prior Code, § 685; Code 1977, § 10.28.010; Ord. No. 47-16, § 1, 1997; Ord. No. 83-2, 1983; Ord. No. 80-9, § 1, 1980) 
State Law reference- Stopping, standing, and parking prohibited in specified places, 625 ILCS 5/11-1303; unattended vehicles, 625 ILCS 5/11-1401. 
Sec. 54-262. - Parking within lines required. 
    Whenever authorized parallel or angle parking lines are placed upon the surface of the streets, indicating the manner of parking thereon, vehicles shall be parked in the manner indicated, and no vehicle shall be parked upon, over, or across any such line. 
(Prior Code, § 682; Code 1977, § 10.28.020) 
Sec. 54-263. - Blocking driveways prohibited. 
    No person shall stand or park any vehicle in such a manner as to block ingress or egress from any public or private driveway or garage. 
(Prior Code, § 686; Code 1977, § 10.28.030) 
Sec. 54-264. - Obstructing traffic. 
    No vehicle shall be operated or allowed to remain upon any street, alley, or avenue in such a manner as to form an unreasonable obstruction to traffic thereon. 
(Prior Code, § 687; Code 1977, § 10.28.040) 
Sec. 54-265. - Oversized vehicles prohibited. 
    The parking upon any street, alley, or avenue of any vehicle the size, width, or length of which obstructs or unduly hinders the ready flow of traffic is prohibited. 
(Prior Code, § 709; Code 1977, § 10.28.050) 
State Law reference- Size, weight and load restrictions, 625 ILCS 5/15-101 et seq. 
Sec. 54-266. - Twenty-four-hour parking limit-Generally. 
    No motor vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer shall be parked or otherwise allowed to remain upon any street or public way within the city for more than a period of 72 hours, except in cases of emergency. 
(Prior Code, § 713; Code 1977, § 10.28.070; Ord. No. 18-09, § 1, 4-23-2018) 
Sec. 54-267. - Same-Other limitations unimpaired. 
    The 72-hour parking limit established in section 54-266 shall not expand any parking limitation established in this Code. 
(Code 1977, § 10.28.071; Ord. No. 81-13, § 2(b), 1981; Ord. No. 18-09, § 2, 4-23-2018) 
Sec. 54-268. - Overnight parking of certain commercial vehicles prohibited. 
(a)  Single unit commercial vehicles; driving and cargo. Commercial vehicle being a single unit of driving and cargo equipment having a gross vehicle weight of 12,000 pounds or more may not park or stand such equipment on any municipal street unattended overnight from 7:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. 
(b)  Trailer driving unit. Commercial vehicle being a tractor driving unit having a gross vehicle weight of 7,000 pounds or more may not park or stand such equipment on any municipal street unattended overnight from 7:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. 
(c)  Trailer; nondriving cargo unit. Commercial vehicle being a trailer nondriving cargo unit having an overall length of 20 feet may not park or stand such equipment on any municipal street unattended overnight from 7:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. 
(d)  Temporary permit; hardship. Whenever the enforcement of the provisions of this section temporarily causes substantial and unreasonable hardship in the case of any particular operation, the chief of police shall have the power to grant a temporary permit for such operation, and when so doing, the police chief or an authorized agent shall designate the location where such Street between Cherry Street and the west edge of the Farmer's Elevator property. 
(Code 1977, § 10.28.072; Ord. No. 01-30, 2001) 
Sec. 54-269. - Restrictions-On North Heaton Street. 
    It is unlawful for any person or persons to stop, stand, or park any vehicle on the east side of North Heaton Street between the right-of-way of the Union Pacific Railroad and Main Street and for 68 feet south from Lincolnway; or on the west side of North Heaton Street for 150 feet south from Lincolnway. 
(Code 1977, § 10.28.083; Ord. No. 02-05, § 1, 2002) 
Sec. 54-270. - Same-On Winfield Street. 
    It is unlawful for any person or persons to stop, stand, or park any vehicle on the south side of Winfield Street from Portland Avenue to Andy Brands Drive and on the north side of Winfield Street from South Cherry Street to South Genesee Street. 
(Code 1977, § 10.28.084; Ord. No. 05-07, § 1, 2005) 
Sec. 54-271. - Same-On Academic Drive. 
    It is unlawful for any person or persons to stop, stand, or park any vehicle on the south side of Academic Drive between the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday and Friday weekly. Two-hour parking is allowed on the north side of Academic Drive pursuant to section 54-279. 
(Code 1977, § 10.28.085; Ord. No. 02-12, § 1, 2002; Ord. No. 99-22, § 1, 1999; Ord. No. 91-5, 1991; Ord. No. 11-09, § 10.28.085, 8-8-2011) 
Sec. 54-272. - Same-On East Main Street. 
    It is unlawful for any person or persons to stop, stand or park any vehicle on the north side of East Main Street in front of 304 East Main Street for a period of more than 30 minutes on Monday and Friday between the hours of 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. as posted. 
(Code 1977, § 10.28.086; Ord. No. 03-13, § 1, 2003) 
Sec. 54-273. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 16-07, § 2, adopted May 23, 2016, repealed § 54-273, which pertained to parking restrictions in the Market Street city parking lot and derived from Code 1977, § 10.28.087; and Ord. No. 03-25, § 1, adopted in 2003. 
Sec. 54-274. - Same-Within the central business district. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to park any motor vehicle upon any street in that section of the CBD bounded by Lincoln Way (U.S. Route 30), Orange, Clinton, and the Chicago & Northwestern Railroad tracks between the hours of 2:30 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on any day when appropriate signs giving notice of these restrictions are erected; excepting that section of Genesee Street between Lincolnway and Market where it is unlawful to stop and park any vehicle between the hours of 2:30 a.m. and 5:30 a.m. 
(b)  It is unlawful to park any motor vehicle upon Knox Street from Orange Street to Madison Street between the hours of 2:30 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. during the normal snow removal season which is herein defined as being November 1 through March 31 each year. 
(Prior Code, § 708; Code 1977, § 10.28.090; Ord. No. 483, § 1, 1960; Ord. No. 621, § 2, 1976; Ord. No. 645, § 1, 1978; Ord. No. 92-4, § 1, 1992; Ord. No. 93-3A, § 1, 1993) 
Sec. 54-275. - Same-On East High Street. 
    It is unlawful for any person or persons to stop, stand, or park any vehicle on the north side of East High Street, from North Genesee Street to North Jackson Street. 
(Code 1977, § 10.28.091; Ord. No. 08-05, § 2, 2008) 
Sec. 54-276. - Same-On Lincolnway (U.S. Route 30). 
    Automobiles, trucks, and other vehicles shall be prohibited from parking along either side of Lincolnway (U.S. Route 30), between Rock Creek and the east corporate limits, approximately 800 feet east of Jackson Street within the corporate limits of the city as from time to time are established by the city. 
(Code 1977, § 10.28.100; Ord. No. 571, § 1, 1969; Ord. No. 96-7, § 1, 1996) 
Sec. 54-277. - Parking prohibited on designated portions of Illinois Route 78. 
(a)  Automobiles, trucks and other vehicles shall be prohibited from parking along either side of the following city streets, marked Illinois Route 78: 
(1)  On Cherry Street between the Chicago and North Western Railroad and Wall Street; 
(2)  On Wall Street between Cherry Street and Clinton Street; 
(3)  On Clinton Street between Wall Street and Park Street; 
(4)  On Portland Avenue between Park Street and the southern corporate limits. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the restrictions in subsection (a) of this section, there shall be no parking along the east side of Cherry Street between the intersection of Main Street and Cherry Street and the intersections of Cherry Street and Lincoln Highway, also known as U.S. Route 30. 
(c)  Automobiles, trucks and other vehicles shall be prohibited from parking along either side of Cherry Street, marked Illinois Route 78, from Lincoln Way to Main Street. Parking will not be permitted within the limits of intersections as determined by the state from intersection studies. 
(Code 1977, § 10.28.120; Ord. No. 79-5, §§ 1, 2, 1979; Ord. No. 83-1, 1983; Ord. No. 86-1, § 1, 1986; Ord. No. 95-26, §§ 1, 2, 1995) 
Sec. 54-278. - Certain parking regulations not effective on Sundays and holidays. 
    The provisions of this article limiting parking in certain locations to either 15 minutes or two hours shall be in force daily except on Sundays or holidays. As used in this section, holidays shall be construed to include: 
(1)  New Year's Day. 
(2)  President's Day. 
(3)  Memorial Day. 
(4)  Independence Day. 
(5)  Labor Day. 
(6)  Veterans Day. 
(7)  Thanksgiving Day. 
(8)  Christmas Day. 
(Code 1977, § 10.28.130(A); Ord. No. 90-3, § 1, 1990; Ord. No. 94-8, § 1, 1994; Ord. No. 00-30, § 1, 2000; Ord. No. 03-03, § 1, 2003; Ord. No. 03-05, § 1, 2003) 
Sec. 54-279. - Two-hour parking zones. 
(a)  The following are established as two-hour parking zones: 
(1)  8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m.-Main Street between Madison Street and Orange Street; 
(2)  8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m.-Genesee Street between Market Street and Lincolnway. 
(3)  Academic Drive-north side of Academic Drive only at all times. 
(b)  Any person who violates the provisions of this section shall be fined $15.00. 
(Code 1977, § 10.28.130(B); Ord. No. 90-3, § 1, 1990; Ord. No. 94-8, § 1, 1994; Ord. No. 00-30, § 1, 2000; Ord. No. 03-03, § 1, 2003; Ord. No. 03-05, § 1, 2003; Ord. No. 10-15, § 10.28.130, 12-13-2010; Ord. No. 11-09, § 10.28.130, 8-8-2011) 
Sec. 54-280. - Fifteen-minute parking zones. 
(a)  The following are established as 15-minute parking zones from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m.: 
(1)  The second parking space on the North side from the East end of the 200 block of West Main Street; 
(2)  The third parking space on the North side from the West end of the 200 block of East Main Street. 
(b)  Any person who violates the provisions of this section shall be fined $15.00. 
(Code 1977, § 10.28.140; Ord. No. 03-04, § 1, 2003l Ord. No. 10-15, § 10.28.140, 12-13-2010) 
Sec. 54-281. - Loading zones. 
(a)  The following are established as loading zones: The loading zone shall start at a point 30 feet East from the centerline of Orange Street on the North side of the 200 Block of Market Street and end at a point 80 feet from the centerline of Orange Street. 
(b)  Any person who violates the provisions of this section shall be fined $15.00. 
(Code 1977, § 10.28.150; Ord. No. 03-04, § 1, 2003; Ord. No. 10-15, § 10.28.150, 12-13-2010) 
Sec. 54-282. - Right-hand curb-to-wheel parking only. 
(a)  Every vehicle stopped or parked upon a two-way street shall be so stopped or parked with the right-hand wheels parallel to and within 12 inches of the right-hand curb or as close as practicable to the right edge of the right-hand shoulder. 
(b)  Exceptions to curb-to-wheel parking are as follows: 
(1)  Every vehicle stopped or parked upon a one-way street shall be so stopped or parked parallel to the curb or edge of the street in the direction of authorized traffic movement, with its right-hand wheels within 12 inches of the right-hand curb or as close as practicable to the right edge of the right-hand shoulder, or with its left-hand wheels within 12 inches of the left-hand curb or as close as practicable to the left edge of the left-hand shoulder. 
(2)  Where angle parking is permitted by local ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 10-15, § 10.28.121, 12-13-2010) 
Sec. 54-283. - Designation of handicap spaces. 
    The following [are] designated handicap parking spaces: 
(1)  Designate two spots on the west side of Genesee Street, south of Wall Street, more or less adjacent to 201 S. Genesee. 
(2)  Relocate one spot from the east side of Genesee, north of Main Street; to the north side of Main Street, just west of Genesee Street more or less in front of 100 W. Main. 
(Ord. No. 18-10, § I, 5-14-2018) 
Secs. 54-284-54-310. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 54-311. - Posting of parking limitations and prohibitions; compliance required. 
(a)  The chief of police or any other person authorized by the mayor and council shall cause signs to be posted in all areas where parking is limited or prohibited, indicating such limitations or prohibitions. 
(b)  Every driver of a vehicle, except emergency vehicles, shall adhere to the parking lines or markings as are established for vehicles. 
(c)  It is unlawful to permit any vehicle to stand or to park any vehicle in any of the areas designated in this section for a period longer than two hours on the days and during the hours specified in this section. 
(Code 1977, § 10.28.130; Ord. No. 03-05, § 1, 2003; Ord. No. 03-03, § 1, 2003; Ord. No. 00-30, § 1, 2000; Ord. No. 94-8, § 1, 1994; Ord. No. 90-3, § 1, 1990) 
Sec. 54-312. - Tire marking; issuance of citation; failure to appear. 
(a)  Officers of the police department or any other person authorized by the mayor and council may mark a tire of a vehicle in a specific spot with relation to the curb or street surface, noting the time the vehicle is so marked. 
(b)  If, after the permitted parking time has elapsed, the vehicle is still parked in the same parking space, it shall be prima facie evidence that a violation has occurred and a citation may be issued. Police officers, after making note of a license number of the vehicle and the name of the offender, where possible, may issue a ticket for the parking offense under this section, notifying the offender to pay the sum therefor at the city hall. 
(c)  No person shall obliterate or conceal any marking by a police officer on the tire of a vehicle for the purpose of preventing the police officer from determining the length of time the vehicle has been parked. 
(d)  The officer may sign a complaint for the issuance of a warrant if the offender does not appear and pay said sum within the time specified. 
Sec. 54-313. - Penalties for parking, standing, or stopping violations. 
    Any person who violates the provisions of this article shall be fined as provided in the penalty schedule in chapter 20. If the fine is not paid within 30 days, the city shall serve notice of delinquent payment on the violator. If the fine remains unpaid ten days after the date of notice of delinquent payment, then the violator shall be subject to fines as provided in section 1-15. 
(Code 1977, § 10.28.130; Ord. No. 03-05, § 1, 2003; Ord. No. 03-03, § 1, 2003; Ord. No. 00-30, § 1, 2000; Ord. No. 94-8, § 1, 1994; Ord. No. 90-3, § 1, 1990; Ord. No. 14-18, § 1, 7-14-2014) 
Secs. 54-314-54-344. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - VEHICLE WEIGHTS AND LOADS 

Sec. 54-345. - Maximum gross weight. 
    The maximum gross weight to be permitted on the road surface through any axle of any vehicle, when equipped with pneumatic tires, shall not exceed 16,000 pounds; and when equipped with other than pneumatic tires, the gross weight upon any one wheel shall not exceed 800 pounds per inch of width of tire tread. The gross weight, including the weight of the vehicle and maximum load of any vehicle and combination of vehicles, shall not exceed the following: 
Vehicle Maximum 
Gross Weight 
(in pounds) Two-axle 36,000 Three axles or more, with tandem axles 41,000 Three-axle, without tandem axles 45,000 Three axle truck tractor-semitrailer combination 45,000 Four-axle truck tractor-semitrailer combination 59,000 Four-axle truck and trailer combination 63,000  
The gross weight of all other combinations shall not exceed that established by 625 ILCS 5/15-111. 
(Prior Code, § 703(1); Code 1977, § 10.36.020) 
State Law reference- Size, weight and load restrictions, 625 ILCS 5/15-101 et seq. 
Sec. 54-346. - Maximum width. 
    The maximum width of any vehicle and its load shall not exceed eight feet excepting loads of loose hay, straw, corn fodder, or other similar farm products, agricultural implements and threshing machines. 
(Prior Code, § 703(2); Code 1977, § 10.36.030) 
State Law reference- Size, weight and load restrictions, 625 ILCS 5/15-101 et seq. 
Sec. 54-347. - Maximum length. 
    The length of any single vehicle or combination of tractor and semitrailer shall not exceed 42 feet. Where trailers are used, the length of any vehicle or vehicles combined with their trailers shall not exceed 50 feet. Such limits in length shall not apply to fire apparatus nor to the transportation of poles, piling, beams, or other like structural units incapable of dismemberment, and one unit of electrical machinery; provided that no poles, piling, beams, or like structural units incapable of dismemberment shall be transported over the streets of the city between sunset and sunrise, except where needed for emergency repair of telephone, telegraph, electric railway, and electric power and light lines. 
(Prior Code, § 703(3); Code 1977, § 10.36.040) 
State Law reference- Size, weight and load restrictions, 625 ILCS 5/15-101 et seq. 
Sec. 54-348. - Weight restriction on Heaton and Winfield Streets. 
    It is unlawful for any person by himself or by any other person or agent, to operate a motor vehicle having a total gross weight, including both the weight of the motor vehicle and the weight of the load, of more than 5,000 pounds upon Heaton Street at any point between Wall Street and Winfield Street, or upon Winfield Street at any point between Heaton Street and Orange Street, all in the city, except to cross either of said restricted streets at a regular intersection, when appropriate signs giving notice of these restrictions are erected at proper places on said streets. 
(Prior Code, § 705; Code 1977, § 10.36.060) 
Sec. 54-349. - Special permits required to exceed limitations. 
    Upon application, the traffic commission may grant special permits in writing for the operation of vehicles or combinations of vehicles and trailers or semitrailers exceeding the foregoing weights and dimensions. Such permits may be granted in the discretion of the traffic commission when in its opinion an emergency exists warranting the granting of the permit. The permit shall be granted only for limited periods and for trips over designated streets, at specified times and subject to such other conditions as the traffic commission may prescribe, but in no case shall such permit exceed a period of five days. The fee for special permits under this section shall be as provided in the city fee schedule in chapter 20. 
(Prior Code, § 703; Code 1977, § 10.36.050) 
Secs. 54-350-54-371. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - EMERGENCY VEHICLES 

Sec. 54-372. - Exemption from chapter provisions under certain conditions. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to authorized emergency vehicles when in use during emergencies so long as they are operated safely, and so long as their operation does not endanger life or property. This section shall not be construed to relieve the driver of any such vehicle from the consequences of his reckless disregard for the safety of other persons or property. 
(Prior Code, § 677; Code 1977, § 10.44.030) 
State Law reference- Conditions for operating ambulances and rescue vehicles, 625 ILCS 5/11-1421. 
Sec. 54-373. - Fire vehicles-Right-of-way. 
    At the time of any fire in the city, the fire truck and other vehicles of the fire department carrying fire apparatus of the city shall have the right-of-way upon all streets, avenues, and alleys within the city and, upon the approach of any fire truck or any other fire vehicle having such right-of-way, all other automobiles or vehicles shall at once be stopped by the person driving the same at the side of the street, avenue, or alley and remain standing until the fire truck and other fire department vehicles have passed beyond such place. 
(Prior Code, § 271; Code 1977, § 10.16.150) 
State Law reference- Operation of vehicles upon approach of authorized emergency vehicles, 625 ILCS 5/11-907. 
Sec. 54-374. - Same-Following and parking restrictions. 
    No automobile or other vehicle shall be driven by any person following the fire truck and other fire vehicles within a distance of 300 feet, and no automobile or other vehicle shall be parked on any street, avenue, or alley by any person within 300 feet of the place where such fire exists, unless the same belongs to the owner of the premises or property where such fire exists. 
(Prior Code, § 272; Code 1977, § 10.16.160) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, 625 ILCS 5/11-1411. 
Secs. 54-375-54-391. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - SNOW AND ICE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Snow and Ice Removal Act, 745 ILCS 75/0.01 et seq.; deposit of snow and ice on public highway prohibited, 605 ILCS 5/9-130; local authority to prohibit parking during snow removal operations, 625 ILCS 5/11-208. 

Sec. 54-392. - Applicability of article. 
(a)  The provisions of this article shall apply when a snow emergency declaration has been issued by the director of public works or his designee. 
(b)  Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to permit parking on streets where such parking is otherwise prohibited. 
(c)  The provisions of this article shall be in effect during a snow emergency as provided in this article. 
(d)  The parking restrictions imposed by this section shall terminate block by block as soon as the accumulated snow has been removed from the full width of the street. 
(Code 1977, §§ 10.30.020, 10.30.040; Ord. No. 92-1, § 1, 1992; Ord. No. 92-4, § 1, 1992; Ord. No. 94-25, art. 1, 1994) 
Sec. 54-393. - Declaration of snow emergency and notification to the public. 
(a)  Whenever snow, freezing rain, sleet, snowdrifts or other natural phenomena create, or are likely to create, hazardous road conditions, or road conditions impeding, or likely to impede, the free movement of fire, health, police, emergency or other vehicular traffic vital to the health, safety and welfare of the community, the director of public works, or his designee, shall have the authority to declare a snow emergency. Such snow emergency shall exist until the snow has been removed from the full width of the street or until the director of public works declares the snow emergency is over. 
(b)  The director of public works shall request the cooperation of the local news media to announce the declaration of a snow emergency. The provisions of this article prohibiting parking on parts of streets, or designated snow route streets, shall be effective at a specific time to be stated in the announcement, not less than one hour after the initial announcement, and such notice shall constitute notice to the general public of the declaration of the emergency. 
(Code 1977, § 10.30.030; Ord. No. 92-1, § 1, 1992) 
Sec. 54-394. - Posting of snow emergency signs. 
    Signs shall be posted on primary roads at or near those points of intersection with the corporate boundaries of the city stating, "Restricted Parking During Snow Emergencies: Calendar Parking in Effect Until Snow Has Been Removed from the Full Width of the Street." 
(Code 1977, § 10.30.040; Ord. No. 94-25, art. 1, 1994; Ord. No. 92-4, § 1, 1992; Ord. No. 92-1, § 1, 1992) 
Sec. 54-395. - Parking restrictions during snow emergencies. 
    After the effective time specified in the declaration of a snow emergency, it is unlawful for any person to obstruct the orderly removal of snow from the city's streets by parking or otherwise leaving unattended any motor vehicle upon: 
(1)  Snow routes. Any street which has been designated as a snow route. The parking restrictions of this section shall terminate block by block as soon as the accumulated snow has been removed from the full width of the street; 
(2)  Central business district. Any street within the CBD as provided in section 54-274; 
(3)  All other city streets. During the time of a snow emergency, no person shall leave parked or standing any motor vehicle on an even-numbered address side of a street within the city on an odd-numbered day of the month. Nor shall any such vehicle be parked or allowed to stand on the odd-numbered side of a street within the city on an even-numbered day of the month. For purposes of this section, odd- and even-numbered days shall be considered as beginning at 8:00 a.m. 
(Code 1977, § 10.30.040; Ord. No. 94-25, art. 1, 1994; Ord. No. 92-4, § 1, 1992; Ord. No. 92-1, § 1, 1992) 
Sec. 54-396. - Designation of snow routes. 
    Emergency snow routes shall be designated by blue and white "Snow Route" signs. The following streets and avenues are declared to be snow routes: 
(1)  U.S. Route 30 (Lincoln Way) its entire length within the corporate limits of the city; 
(2)  Jackson Street for its entire length within the corporate limits of the city; 
(3)  Heaton Street for its entire length within the corporate limits of the city; 
(4)  Winfield Street for its entire length within the corporate limits of the city; 
(5)  Genesee Street from North Orange Street to Winfield Street; 
(6)  Genesee Avenue/Genesee Court from Winfield Street to the Rock Creek Bridge; 
(7)  Illinois Route 78 from the south corporate limits to Lincoln Way; 
(8)  High Street between Genesee Street and Jackson Street; 
(9)  Academic Drive. 
(Code 1977, § 10.30.050; Ord. No. 92-11, art. 1, 1992; Ord. No. 92-1, § 1, 1992) 
Sec. 54-397. - Towing of vehicles. 
    During the time of a snow emergency, the chief of police or his designee may direct that vehicles parked in violation of this article be removed to an appropriate place, and that the owner of any vehicle so removed shall be responsible for towing and storage costs. Neither the city nor the towing service shall be liable for any damage to any vehicle, device or property so removed. 
(Code 1977, § 10.30.060; Ord. No. 92-1, § 1, 1992) 
Sec. 54-398. - Termination of snow emergency. 
    Whenever the director of public works shall find that the conditions which gave rise to the snow emergency no longer exist, he is authorized to declare the termination of the snow emergency, effective immediately upon announcement. When the snow emergency is terminated, it shall then be lawful to park on those streets in accordance with the regular parking provisions. The director of public works shall request the cooperation of the local media to announce the termination of the snow emergency. 
(Code 1977, § 10.30.070; Ord. No. 92-1, § 1, 1992) 
Sec. 54-399. - Violation; penalty designated. 
    Any violation of this article shall be subject to a fine in the amount provided in the city penalty schedule plus any towing charges and storage charges incurred by the city. For purposes of prosecution under this article, if a vehicle is found parked or left unattended in violation of the provisions of this article, the registered owner thereof shall be responsible for said violation. 
(Code 1977, § 10.30.080; Ord. No. 92-1, § 1, 1992) 
Sec. 54-400. - Scope of authority. 
    Nothing in this article shall limit the authority of the chief of police or his designee to authorize and direct the towing and removal of vehicles from the public street in the event of extraordinary snowfall when necessary for public health and safety or for the removal of snow when the presence of said vehicle constitutes a hazard to the public or hampers snow removal. 
(Code 1977, § 10.30.090; Ord. No. 92-1, § 1, 1992) 
Secs. 54-401-54-428. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - RECREATIONAL VEHICLES[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) ---
