State Law reference- Operation of all terrain vehicles, off-highway motorcycles on streets, roads and highways, 625 ILCS 5/11-1426; operation of neighborhood vehicles, 625 ILCS 5/11-1426.1; operation of all-terrain vehicle and off-highway motorcycle on ice, 625 ILCS 5/11-1427.1; operation of golf cart on streets, roads and highways, 625 ILCS 5/11-1428; riding on motorcycles, 625 ILCS 5/11-1403; operation of personal assistive mobility device on public sidewalk, 625 ILCS 5/11-1412.2; bicycles, 625 ILCS 5/11-1501 et seq.; snowmobiles, 625 ILCS 40/1-1 et seq.; Cycle Ride Safety Act, 625 ILCS 35/1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 54-429. - General restrictions. 
    No person shall operate a recreational vehicle on any of the streets or sidewalks existing in the area between the easterly right-of-way of Madison Street on the east; the westerly right-of-way of Orange Street on the west; the northerly right-of-way of U.S. Route 30 on the north and northerly right-of-way of the Union Pacific Railroad on the south. 
(Code 1977, § 10.40.225; Ord. No. 96-13, § 1, 1996; Ord. No. 88-7, § 3, 1988) 
Sec. 54-430. - Sleds and kindred vehicles on sidewalks prohibited. 
    No person shall draw, propel or ride any sled, sleigh, board, plank, or other vehicles upon any public sidewalk in the city in such a manner as to obstruct or interfere with any person in the use and enjoyment of any sidewalk. This section does not and is not intended to prohibit vehicles used to transport small children, to include strollers, baby buggies and like items. 
(Prior Code, § 424; Code 1977, § 8.12.010; Ord. No. 96-14, § 1, 1996) 
Sec. 54-431. - Bicycles and kindred vehicles on sidewalks prohibited. 
    Except as otherwise provided herein, no person shall run, use or operate any bicycle, motor bicycle, tricycle or velocipede upon any public sidewalk so as to interfere with pedestrian traffic within the city. 
(Prior Code, § 425; Code 1977, § 8.12.020) 
Secs. 54-432-54-460. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BICYCLES 

Sec. 54-461. - Compliance with traffic rules required; exception. 
(a)  Every person riding a bicycle upon any street shall be subject to the provisions of this article except as to special regulations and except as to those provisions which by their nature can have no application. 
(b)  Any person operating a bicycle shall obey the instructions of official traffic-control signals, signs, and other control devices applicable to vehicles unless otherwise directed by a police officer. 
(c)  Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating that no right- or left- or U-turn is permitted, no person operating a bicycle shall disobey the direction of any such sign; except where such person dismounts from the bicycle to make any such turn, in which event such person shall then obey the regulations applicable to pedestrians. 
(Prior Code, § 688; Code 1977, §§ 10.40.010, 10.40.140; Ord. No. 491, § 9, 1961) 
State Law reference- Persons riding bicycle or animal or driving an animal-drawn vehicle required to comply with state traffic code, 625 ILCS 5/11-205; local authority for regulation of bicycles, 625 ILCS 5/11-208. 
Sec. 54-462. - Applicability; violations. 
    These regulations applicable to bicycles shall apply whenever a bicycle is operated upon any street, alley or highway, or upon any path set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles, subject to those exceptions stated in this article. It is a misdemeanor for any person to do any act forbidden or fail to perform any act required in this division. 
(Code 1977, § 10.40.020; Ord. No. 491, § 1, 1961) 
Sec. 54-463. - Parental responsibility. 
    The parent of any child and the guardian of any ward shall not authorize or knowingly permit any such child or ward to violate any of the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1977, § 10.40.020; Ord. No. 491, § 1, 1961) 
Sec. 54-464. - Tampering with frame number prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to willfully or maliciously remove, destroy, mutilate or alter the number of any bicycle frame licensed pursuant to this article. It is unlawful for any person to remove, destroy, mutilate or alter any license sticker, plate, seal or registration card during the time in which such license sticker, plate, seal or registration card is operative; provided, however, that nothing in this article shall prohibit the police department from stamping numbers on the frames of bicycles on which no serial number can be found, or on which said number is illegible or insufficient for identification purposes. 
(Code 1977, § 10.40.100; Ord. No. 491, § 5(8), 1961) 
State Law reference- Sale at retail prohibited unless identifying number is permanently stamped or cast into frame, 615 ILCS 5/11-1508. 
Sec. 54-465. - Seating. 
    A person propelling a bicycle shall not ride other than astride a permanent and regular seat attached thereto. No bicycle shall be used to carry more persons at one time than the number for which it is designed and equipped. 
(Code 1977, § 10.40.150; Ord. No. 491, § 10, 1961) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, 625 ILCS 5/11-1503. 
Sec. 54-466. - Riding on roadways and paths. 
    Every person operating a bicycle upon a roadway shall ride as near to the right side of the roadway as practicable, exercising due care when passing a standing vehicle or one proceeding in the same direction. Persons riding bicycles upon a roadway shall not ride more than two abreast except on paths or parts of roadways set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles. Wherever a usable path for bicycles has been provided adjacent to a roadway, bicycle riders shall use such path and shall not use the roadway. 
(Code 1977, § 10.40.160; Ord. No. 491, § 11, 1961) 
State Law reference- Bicycles on sidewalks, 625 ILCS 5/11-1512. 
Sec. 54-467. - Riding on sidewalks prohibited in business district. 
    No person shall ride a bicycle upon a sidewalk within a business district, specifically including the area delineated in section 54-431. 
(Code 1977, § 10.40.170; Ord. No. 491, § 16, 1961) 
Sec. 54-468. - Emerging from alleys and driveways. 
    The operator of a bicycle emerging from an alley, driveway, or building shall, upon approaching a sidewalk or the sidewalk area extending across any alleyway, yield the right-of-way to all pedestrians approaching on the sidewalk or sidewalk area, and upon entering the roadway shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles approaching on the roadway. 
(Code 1977, § 10.40.180; Ord. No. 491, § 13, 1961) 
Sec. 54-469. - Speed. 
    No person shall operate a bicycle at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the conditions then existing. 
(Code 1977, § 10.40.190; Ord. No. 491, § 12, 1961) 
Sec. 54-470. - Parking. 
    No person shall park a bicycle upon a street other than upon the roadway against the curb or upon the sidewalk in a rack to support the bicycle or against a building or at the curb in such manner as to afford the least obstruction to pedestrian traffic. No space zoned and metered for parking vehicles shall be used to park a bicycle. 
(Code 1977, § 10.40.200; Ord. No. 491, § 15, 1961) 
State Law reference- Parking of bicycles, 625 ILCS 5/11-1513. 
Sec. 54-471. - Equipment. 
(a)  Every bicycle when in use at nighttime shall be equipped with a lamp on the front which shall emit a white light visible from a distance of at least 500 feet to the front, and with a red reflector on the rear of a type which shall be visible from all distances from 50 feet to 300 feet to the rear when directly in front of lawful upper beams of headlamps on a motor vehicle. A lamp emitting a red light visible from a distance of 500 feet to the rear may be used in addition to the red reflector. 
(b)  Every bicycle shall be equipped with a brake which will enable the operator to make the braked wheel skid on dry, level, clean pavement. 
(Code 1977, § 10.40.210; Ord. No. 491, § 17, 1961) 
State Law reference- Bicycle equipment requirements, 625 ILCS 5/11-1507. 
Sec. 54-472. - Carrying articles. 
    No person operating a bicycle shall carry any package, bundle or article which prevents the rider from keeping at least one hand upon the handlebars. 
(Code 1977, § 10.40.220; Ord. No. 491, § 14, 1961) 
Secs. 54-473-54-497. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SNOWMOBILES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 11-18, adopted Nov. 14, 2011, repealed the former div. 3, §§ 54-498-54-500, and enacted a new div. 3 as set out herein. The former div. 3 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the 1977 codification, §§ 10.48.010-10.48.030; and Ord. No. 80-1, §§ 1-3, adopted in 1980. 
State Law reference- Snowmobile Registration and Safety Act, 625 ILCS 40/1-1 et seq.; local authority for regulation of snowmobiles, 625 ILCS 40/1-2.07. 

Sec. 54-498. - State regulations adopted. 
    The provisions contained within the Illinois Compiled Statutes, specifically, 625 ILCS 40/1-1 et seq. commonly known as the Snowmobile Registration and Safety Act ("the Act"), are herein adopted as snowmobile regulations for the city. The provisions of the Act are adopted by reference as if fully set forth at length in this section. 
(Ord. No. 11-18, § 1, 11-14-2011) 
Sec. 54-499. - City rules and regulations. 
    The following city rules and regulations, in addition to those contained in section 54-498, are adopted regarding operation of snowmobiles within the boundaries of the city. 
(1)  All snowmobiles are to follow any and all marked snowmobile route(s) at all times unless otherwise specified herein. 
(2)  All snowmobiles shall not be operated on any public park, cemetery, the Morrison Sports Complex, or public school property. 
(3)  All snowmobiles shall not be operated on a roadway of any public highway, street, or alley within the city, except for city roadways used for the sole purpose of as a way of access to and from commonly used and marked snowmobile routes. During the use of city roadways, the operator of any snowmobile is subject to all city and state traffic laws governing the operation of vehicles on public highways. 
(4)  All snowmobiles shall not be operated on any public sidewalk or the area commonly known as the parkway between the sidewalk and roadway of any public highway within the city. 
(5)  No snowmobile shall be operated on private property without the consent of the owner or lessee thereof. 
(6)  Snowmobiles operated within the city must observe a maximum of 15 miles per hour speed limit. 
(7)  All snowmobiles must operate in single file and as far to the right on the roadway as possible. 
(8)  All snowmobile traffic along the snowmobile route will maintain a straight line of traffic except to avoid an obstacle. 
(9)  Snowmobiles shall not operate after evening curfew hours of: 
Sundays through Thursdays 10:00 p.m.; 
Fridays and Saturdays 12:00 a.m. 
(10)  Snowmobiles shall not operate before morning curfew hours of: 
Sundays 12:00 p.m.; 
Mondays through Saturdays 9:00 a.m. 
(11)  No parking will be allowed off or along the snowmobile route except at a private residence or a designated area. Such designated area must be marked to allow such snowmobile parking. 
(Ord. No. 11-18, § 1, 11-14-2011) 
Sec. 54-500. - Violation and penalty. 
    Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine of not less than $50.00 nor more than $500.00. 
(Ord. No. 11-18, § 1, 11-14-2011) 
Secs. 54-501-54-523. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - EQUIPMENT AND LICENSING 

Sec. 54-524. - State license plates required. 
    Every motor vehicle, trailer, semitrailer, and motor bicycle operated over the streets of the city shall have attached thereto number plates issued by the secretary of state, evidencing payment to the state of proper license fees. 
(Prior Code, § 704; Code 1977, § 10.12.010) 
State Law reference- Vehicle equipment, 625 ILCS 5/11-101 et seq.; certificates of title and registration of vehicles, 625 ILCS 5/3-100 et seq. 
Secs. 54-525-54-541. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 54-542. - Presumption of liability. 
    Proof of registration of a motor vehicle and proof of a violation of this section shall be construed as prima facie proof that the registered owner of such motor vehicle was the user or operator thereof at the time of the violation charged. 
(Code 1977, § 10.28.130; Ord. No. 03-05, § 1, 2003; Ord. No. 03-03, § 1, 2003; Ord. No. 00-30, § 1, 2000; Ord. No. 94-8, § 1, 1994; Ord. No. 90-3, § 1, 1990) 
Sec. 54-543. - Violations deemed misdemeanor. 
    It is a misdemeanor for any person to do any act forbidden or fail to perform any act required by this chapter. 
(Prior Code, § 675; Code 1977, § 10.44.010) 
Sec. 54-544. - Obedience to police required. 
    No person shall willfully fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order or direction of a police officer. 
(Prior Code, § 676; Code 1977, § 10.44.020) 
State Law reference- Obedience to police officers required, 625 ILCS 5/11-203. 
Sec. 54-545. - Failure to obey notice. 
    It is unlawful for any driver of a vehicle to neglect to answer the charges set forth in a notice affixed to his vehicle by a police officer, or to fail to appear as required by notice. 
(Prior Code, § 702; Code 1977, § 10.44.040) 
State Law reference- Penalty for failure to obey police officers, 625 ILCS 5/11-203. 
Sec. 54-546. - Removal of vehicles. 
    The police officers of the city are required and empowered to remove from the streets and alleys thereof any vehicle found standing thereon in violation of the provisions of any ordinance of the city, if and only if the owner or operator thereof cannot be found after reasonable inquiry. In the event any automobile is so removed, the reasonable expenses of such removal shall be taxed as part of the cost in addition to any penalty either voluntarily paid or assessed by a court of competent jurisdiction. Cars so towed away for illegal parking shall be stored in a safe place and shall be returned to the owner or operator of such car upon payment of towing, storage, and administrative charges to the towing agent. 
(Prior Code, § 710; Code 1977, § 10.44.050) 
State Law reference- Officers authorized to remove vehicles, 625 ILCS 5/1-1302. 
Sec. 54-547. - Cash bond-Permitted in lieu of immediate appearance. 
    When a city police officer makes an arrest for a minor traffic violation and there is no associate circuit judge immediately available before whom the accused can be taken, such officer may accept, on behalf of the city, a reasonable sum from the accused, conditioned upon his appearance before a designated judge at a time certain. 
(Prior Code, § 715; Code 1977, § 10.44.060) 
Sec. 54-548. - Same-Receipt required. 
    The officer accepting such reasonable sum shall, in all cases, issue to the accused a receipt therefor, which receipt shall state the date of arrest, the offense alleged to have been committed, the name of the judge before whom the accused shall appear, and the date and time of the appearance. It shall also state that, in case the accused fails to appear as provided therein, without reasonable cause shown to the judge within three days thereafter, the sum shall be forfeited to the city. 
(Prior Code, § 716; Code 1977, § 10.44.070) 
Sec. 54-549. - Same-Form of receipt. 
    The receipt provided for in this chapter may be in the form which is on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Prior Code, § 718; Code 1977, § 10.44.080) 
Sec. 54-550. - Same-Disposition of funds. 
    The officer issuing such receipt shall retain a true and correct copy thereof, and strictly account for all sums so accepted as follows: Should the accused appear as provided in the receipt or, within three days after the time so designated, appear before the judge for the purpose of showing the court good cause for failing to appear at the time designated, said sum shall be paid over to the court to await the decision of the case; otherwise, said sum shall in each case be paid over by the officer to the city treasurer and be by him deposited in the general fund of the city. 
(Prior Code, § 717; Code 1977, § 10.44.090) 
Secs. 54-551-54-603. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - SEIZURE AND IMPOUNDMENT OF VEHICLES 

Sec. 54-604. - Vehicles subject to seizure and impoundment. 
    A motor vehicle used in the commission of any of the following violations or offenses may be seized and impounded by the city: 
(1)  Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the attempt to commit, an offense for which a motor vehicle may be seized and forfeited pursuant to Section 36-1 [720 ILCS 5/36-1] of the Criminal Code of 2012; or 
(2)  Driving under the influence of alcohol, another drug or drugs, an intoxicating compound or compounds, or any combination thereof, in violation of Section 11-501 [625 ILCS 5/11-501] of the Illinois Vehicle Code; or 
(3)  Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the attempt to commit, a felony or in violation of the Cannabis Control Act; or 
(4)  Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the attempt to commit, an offense in violation of the Illinois Controlled Substances Act; or 
(5)  Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the attempt to commit, an offense in violation of Section 24-1, 24-1.5, or 24-3.1 [720 ILCS 5/24-1, 5/24-1.5, 5/24-3.1] of the Criminal Code of 2012; or 
(6)  Driving while a driver's license, permit, or privilege to operate a motor vehicle is suspended or revoked pursuant to Section 6-303 [625 ILCS 5/6-303] of the Illinois Vehicle Code; except that vehicles shall not be subjected to seizure or impoundment if the suspension is for an unpaid citation (parking or moving) or due to failure to comply with emission testing; or 
(7)  Operation or use of a motor vehicle while soliciting, possessing, or attempting to solicit or possess cannabis or a controlled substance, as defined by the Cannabis Control Act or the Illinois Controlled Substances Act; or 
(8)  Operation or use of a motor vehicle with an expired driver's license, in violation of Section 6-101 [625 ILCS 5/6-101] of the Illinois Vehicle Code, if the period of expiration is greater than one year; or 
(9)  Operation or use of a motor vehicle without ever having been issued a driver's license or permit, in violation of Section 6-101 [625 ILCS 5/6-101] of the Illinois Vehicle Code, or operating a motor vehicle without ever having been issued a driver's license or permit due to a person's age; or 
(10)  Operation or use of a motor vehicle by a person against whom a warrant has been issued by a circuit clerk in Illinois for failing to answer charges that the driver violated Section 6-101, 6-303, or 11-501 [625 ILCS 5/6-101, 5/6-303, 5/11-501] of the Illinois Vehicle Code; or 
(11)  Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the attempt to commit, an offense in violation of Article 16 of the Criminal Code of 2012; or 
(12)  Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the attempt to commit, any other misdemeanor or felony offense in violation of the Criminal Code of 2012. 
(Ord. No. 14-12, § 2, 6-9-2014) 
Sec. 54-605. - Administrative fee for towed and impounded vehicles. 
    The registered owner or the agent or agents of the owner shall be liable to the city for an administrative fee of $200.00, in addition to any and all applicable fines, costs, towing, and storage fees. The administrative fee shall be collected by and paid to the city. Additional towing or storage fees, or both, shall be collected by and paid to the person, firm, or entity that tows and stores the vehicle impounded under this chapter or to the city for payment to the appropriate person or entity. The administrative fee provided for in this section shall be waived by the city upon submission of verifiable proof that the vehicle was stolen at the time that the vehicle was impounded. 
(Ord. No. 14-12, § 2, 6-9-2014) 
Sec. 54-606. - Procedure for seizure and impoundment of vehicles. 
    Whenever a city police officer reasonably believes that the driver of a motor vehicle has committed an eligible offense as enumerated in Section 10-15-2, the officer may provide for the towing of the motor vehicle to the city impound lot or a city-approved private lot. 
(Ord. No. 14-12, § 2, 6-9-2014) 
Sec. 54-607. - Notice and opportunity for hearing. 
    At the time that a motor vehicle is towed pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, the city shall notify or make a reasonable attempt to notify the owner, lessee, agent or agents, or person identifying himself or herself as the owner or lessee of the vehicle, or any person who is found to be in control of the vehicle at the time of the alleged offense, of the following: 
(1)  The fact of the seizure and of the vehicle owner's or the lessee's right to an administrative hearing. 
(2)  The notice shall also provide that the seized motor vehicle will remain impounded pending the completion of an administrative hearing, unless the owner or lessee of the vehicle, or a lienholder, posts with the city a bond equal to the administrative fee as set forth in this chapter and pays all towing and storage charges. 
(3)  The registered owner or lessee of the vehicle and any lienholder of record shall also be provided with a written notice of administrative hearing. The notice shall (1) be served upon the owner, lessee, and any lienholder of record either by personal service or by first class mail to the interested party's address as registered with the Secretary of State; (2) be served upon such interested parties within ten days after impoundment of a vehicle by the city; and (3) contain a date, time and location of the administrative hearing. An initial hearing shall be scheduled and convened no later than 45 days after the date of the mailing of the notice of hearing. 
(4)  All administrative hearings conducted pursuant to this chapter shall be conducted by a hearing officer who is an attorney licensed to practice law in the State of Illinois for a minimum of three years. At the conclusion of the administrative hearing, the hearing officer shall issue a written decision either sustaining or overruling the vehicle impoundment. 
a.  If the basis for the vehicle impoundment is sustained by the administrative hearing officer, any administrative fee posted to secure the release of the vehicle as set forth below shall be forfeited to the city. 
b.  Unless the administrative hearing officer overturns the basis for the vehicle impoundment, no vehicle shall be released to the owner, lessee, or lienholder of record until all administrative fees and towing and storage charges are paid. 
c.  Vehicles not retrieved from the towing facility or storage facility within 30 days after the administrative hearing officer issues a written decision shall be deemed abandoned and may be disposed of in accordance with the provisions of Article 2 of Chapter 4 [625 ILCS 5/4-201 et seq.] of the Illinois Vehicle Code, or as elsewhere provided for in this Code. 
d.  Unless stayed by a court of competent jurisdiction, any fee imposed under this chapter which remains unpaid in whole or in part after the expiration of the deadline for seeking judicial review under the Administrative Review Law may be enforced in the same manner as a judgment entered by a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 14-12, § 2, 6-9-2014) 
Sec. 54-608. - Release of vehicle. 
    Motor vehicles seized and impounded under this chapter shall remain impounded until all costs associated with the towing and storage of the motor vehicle are paid and: 
(1)  The registered owner, lessee, or lienholder of the vehicle remits the administrative fee to the city police department. The city police department shall have the right to hold the vehicle until the costs associated with towing, storage, and the administrative fee have been paid in full or until the motor vehicle is released as a result of the administrative review process, or as otherwise provided by state law. 
(Ord. No. 14-12, § 2, 6-9-2014) 
Sec. 54-609. - Administrative review. 
    All final decisions of the administrative hearing officer shall be subject to review under the provisions of the Administrative Review Law. 
(Ord. No. 14-12, § 2, 6-9-2014) 
Chapter 56 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Public Utilities Act, 220 ILCS 5/1-101 et seq.; Illinois Underground Utility Facilities Damage Prevention Act, 220 ILCS 50/1 et seq.; municipal utilities, 65 ILCS 5/11-117-1 et seq.; Municipal Wastewater Disposal Zones Act, 65 ILCS 90/0.01. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 56-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Approving authority means the mayor and city council, acting by and through the water and sewer committee, or the person designated by it, being their duly authorized agent or representative. 
    Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five days at 20 degrees Celsius, expressed in milligrams per liter. 
    Building drain means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste, and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer or other approved point of discharge, beginning ten feet (3.0 meters) outside the inner face of the building wall. 
    Building sewer means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal. 
    Combined sewer means a sewer which is designed and intended to receive wastewater, stormwater, surface water and groundwater drainage. 
    Combined system includes all the system of pipes, boxes, cocks, taps, meters, connections, reservoirs, tanks, engines, mains, manholes, lift stations and all appurtenances thereto, whereby water is or may be supplied to the public or wastewater may be treated, operated and controlled by the city. 
    Compatible pollutant means biochemical oxygen demand, suspended solids, pH and fecal coliform bacteria, plus additional pollutants identified in the NPDES permit. 
    Control manhole means a structure located on a site from which industrial wastes are discharged. Where feasible, the manhold shall have an interior drop. The purpose of a control manhole is to provide access for a city representative to sample and/or measure discharges. 
    Director means the director of public works of the city, or the director's authorized agent or representative. 
    Dwelling unit means one or more rooms in a dwelling or apartment-hotel designed for occupancy by one family for living purposes and having its own cooking and sanitary facilities. 
    Easement means an acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by others. 
    Effluent criteria are defined in any applicable NPDES permit. 
    Fire department refers to any public or private organization established for the protection from fire of public or private property. 
    Floatable oil means oil, fat, or grease in a physical state such that it will separate by gravity from wastewater by treatment in an approved pretreatment facility. A wastewater shall be considered free of floatable fat if it is properly pretreated and the wastewater does not interfere with the collection system. 
    Garbage means solid wastes from the domestic and commercial preparation, cooking, and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage and sale of produce. 
    Grease trap means a device for the interception of grease, oil and sand. 
    House drain means the vitrified sewer which shall be not less than six inches in internal diameter, and which begins three feet outside of the wall of any building and connects the house or building drain with the public sewer in the street or with a septic tank. 
    Incompatible pollutant means any pollutant which is not a compatible pollutant as defined in the definition of compatible pollutant. 
    Industrial waste means any solid, liquid or gaseous substance discharged, permitted to flow or escaping from any industrial, manufacturing, commercial or business establishment or process or from the development, recovery or processing of any natural resource as distinct from sanitary sewage. 
    Infiltration means the water entering a sewer system, including building drains and sewers, from the ground, through such means as, but not limited to, defective pipes, pipe joints, connections or manhole walls. Infiltration does not include, and is distinguished from, inflow. 
    Infiltration/inflow means the total quantity of water from both infiltration and inflow without distinguishing the source. 
    Inflow means the water discharged into a sewer system, including building drains and sewers, from such sources as, but not limited to, roof leaders; cellar, yard, and area drains; foundation drains; unpolluted cooling water discharges; drains from springs and swampy areas; manhole covers; cross connections from storm sewers, combined sewers, and catchbasins; stormwaters; surface runoff; street wash waters; or drainage. Inflow does not include, and is distinguished from, infiltration. 
    Milligrams per liter means a unit of the concentration of water or wastewater constituent. It is 0.001 gram of the constituent in 1,000 milliliters of water. It has replaced the unit formerly used commonly, parts per million, to which it is approximately equivalent, in reporting the results of water and wastewater analysis. 
    Multi-unit building refers to any building, whether residential, commercial, industrial or a mixed use thereof, the occupancy of which is two or more units. 
    Natural outlet means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface water or groundwater. 
    NPDES permit means a permit issued under the National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System for the discharge of wastewaters to the navigable waters of the United States pursuant to section 402 of PL 92-500. 
    pH means the logarithm (base 10) of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion concentration expressed in grams per liter of solution. It shall be determined by one of the procedures outlined in Standard Methods. 
    Plumbing inspector means the plumbing inspector of the city or his authorized deputy, agent or representative as designated by the mayor and city council. 
    Population equivalent is a term used to evaluate the impact of industrial or other waste on a treatment works or stream. One population equivalent is 100 gallons of sewage per day, containing 0.17 pounds of BOD and 0.20 pounds of suspended solids. The impact on a treatment works is evaluated as the equivalent of the highest of three parameters. Impact on a stream is the higher of the BOD and suspended solids parameters. 
    ppm means parts per million by weight. 
    Premises includes a lot or a part of a lot, a building or a part of a building, or any parcel or tract of land whatsoever. 
    Pretreatment means the treatment of wastewater from sources before introduction into the wastewater treatment works. 
    Properly shredded garbage means the wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch (1.27 centimeters) in any dimension. 
    Public sewer means a sewer dedicated to or provided by or subject to the jurisdiction of the city, consisting of collector sewer, interceptor sewer, force main and pumping station. It shall also include sewers within or outside the city boundaries that serve one or more persons and ultimately discharge into the city sanitary sewer system, even though those sewers may not have been constructed with city funds. 
    Sanitary sewer means a sewer that conveys sewage or industrial wastes or a combination of both, and into which stormwaters, surface waters and groundwaters or unpolluted industrial wastes are not intentionally admitted. 
    Sewage means a combination of the water-carried wastes from residences, business buildings, institutions, and industrial establishments, together with such groundwaters, surface waters and stormwaters as may be present. 
    Sewage treatment plant means any arrangement of devices, structures and equipment for treating sewage. 
    Sewer means a pipe or conduit for conveying sewage or any other waste liquids, including stormwater, surface water and groundwater drainage. 
    Sewer operation and maintenance account refers to the accounting entity within the water and sewer fund wherein all revenues, moneys and expenses of every kind arising by the operation of this chapter or any other ordinance relating to the operation of the wastewater treatment and sewer service system shall be segregated. 
    Sewerage means the system of sewers and appurtenances for the collection, transportation and pumping of sewage. 
    Slug means any discharge of water, sewage or industrial waste which in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period of duration longer than 15 minutes more than five times the average 24-hour concentration of flows during normal operation. 
    Standard Methods means the examination and analytical procedures set forth in the most recent edition of Standard Methods for the Examination of Water, Sewage, and Industrial Wastes, published jointly by the American Public Health Association, the American Water Works Association and the Federation of Sewage and Industrial Wastes Association. 
    Storm sewer means a sewer that carries stormwater, surface water and groundwater drainage, but excludes sewage and industrial wastes other than unpolluted cooling water. 
    Stormwater runoff means that portion of the rainfall that is drained into the sewers. 
    Suspended solids means solids that either float on the surface of or are in suspension in water, sewage, or industrial waste, and which are removable by a laboratory filtration device. Quantitative determination of suspended solids shall be made in accordance with procedures set forth in Standard Methods. 
    Unpolluted water means water of quality equal to or better than the effluent criteria in effect or water that would not cause violation of receiving water quality standards and would not be benefited by discharge to the sanitary sewers and wastewater treatment facilities provided. 
    Wastewater means the spent water of the community. It may be a combination of the liquid and water-carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants and institutions, together with any groundwater, surface water, and stormwater that may be present. 
    Wastewater facilities means the structures, equipment and processes required to collect, carry away, and treat domestic and industrial wastes and dispose of the effluent. 
    Wastewater treatment works means an arrangement of devices and structures for treating wastewater, industrial wastes, and sludge. Sometimes used as synonymous with wastewater treatment plant or sewage treatment plant or pollution control plant. 
    Water and sewer committee refers to a committee of four aldermen and the mayor, who serves as an ex officio member, appointed annually by the mayor. The water and sewer committee shall have the supervision, control and management, subject to the city council, of the maintenance, enlargement and operation of the combined waterworks and sewerage system of the city, and the extension of such system and the selling of services therefrom and the preservation of the property thereunto belonging. 
    Water and sewer fund means all the moneys or revenues of every kind arising by the operations of this chapter or any other ordinance relating to the operation of the combined waterworks and wastewater treatment system. 
    Water operation and maintenance account refers to the accounting entity within the water and sewer fund wherein all revenues, moneys and expenses of every kind arising by the operation of this chapter or any other ordinance relating to the operation of the waterworks and water service system shall be segregated. 
    Water quality standards are defined in the state water pollution regulations. 
    Watercourse means a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
    Waterworks system, water supply system, and water service system include all the system of pipes, boxes, cocks, taps, meters, connections, reservoirs, tanks, engines, property and all appurtenances thereto, whereby water is or may be supplied to the public or to private parties operated, controlled or owned by the city. 
(Code 1977, § 13.04.010; Ord. No. 88-1, 1988) 
Sec. 56-2. - Combined system established. 
    The existing waterworks system in its entirety, the existing sewage treatment plant, and the existing sewerage system, together with all future improvements and additions which may be made to any of them, are declared to be a combined system. The waterworks and sewerage systems shall be maintained and operated as a combined waterworks and sewerage system. 
(Code 1977, § 13.04.020; Ord. No. 88-1, 1988) 
Sec. 56-3. - Applicability of chapter provisions; enforcement. 
(a)  Every user of the combined system and every owner, occupant or person in possession, charge or control of any building, structure or premises supplied at any time with water through the municipal waterworks or water service system shall be governed by and be subject to the provisions of this chapter and such rules and regulations as may from time to time be adopted and approved by the appropriate governing authority concerning the use of the combined system. 
(b)  It is made the duty of the director of public works or his designee to enforce the provisions of this chapter and such rules and regulations as may be adopted. 
(Code 1977, § 13.04.050; Ord. No. 88-1, 1988) 
Sec. 56-4. - Compliance with chapter and with rules and regulations; penalties. 
(a)  Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter or any rule or regulation governing or concerning the use of the combined system, which shall have been adopted and approved by the city council, shall be fined not less than $5.00 nor more than $500.00 for each offense, except as may be otherwise provided by this chapter. The cutting of the water supply to any premises or the forfeiture of deposits paid or the imposition of any liabilities or expense otherwise provided for by this chapter or on account of any violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall not be held to exempt any such person from the imposition of the penalty provided by this section. 
(b)  The amounts provided for in this section shall be paid by the person owning, occupying or in possession, charge or control of such building, structure or premises irrespective of whether such person shall have been the one guilty of violating the provisions of this chapter, such person declared to be held responsible for any violations of this chapter. 
(Code 1977, § 13.04.060; Ord. No. 88-1, 1988) 
Sec. 56-5. - Violators liable to city. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall become liable to the city for any expense, loss or damage occasioned the city by reason of such violation. 
(Code 1977, §§ 13.12.065, 13.16.130; Ord. No. 82-3, § 8.3, 1982; Ord. No. 98-18, § 1, 1998) 
Sec. 56-6. - Disposition of fines recovered for violations of chapter. 
    All fines recovered for violations of the provisions of this chapter shall be placed in the treasury of said municipality to the credit of the water and sewer fund. 
(Code 1977, § 13.04.070; Ord. No. 88-1, 1988) 
Sec. 56-7. - Citations of pipe size. 
    When sizes of pipe are specified in this chapter the internal diameters of pipes are meant. 
(Prior Code, § 586; Code 1977, § 13.20.020) 
Secs. 56-8-56-32. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WATER 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 56-33. - Interfering with water mains, service pipes, etc. 
    It is unlawful for any person to interfere in a manner with any water main, service pipe, water meter, corporation stop or shutoff water system, or comprising part of such system, without permission therefor from the director of public works or his designee. 
(Prior Code, § 723; Code 1977, § 13.08.020; Ord. No. 502, § 1, 1963; Ord. No. 88-1, 1988) 
Sec. 56-34. - Right of entry of director of public works for examination, etc., of water meters. 
    All officers and employees of the city shall have free access at all reasonable hours to all premises supplied or furnished with water from the public water system or waterworks for the purpose of inspecting, installing, repairing, substituting, adding to or altering the pipes, fixtures, equipment or connections in the system; or for turning on or turning off the water service to any building or property or any part thereof; or for the reading of water meters; or for any other purpose consistent with the proper management and maintenance of the public water system or waterworks; or for the enforcement of this chapter and the ordinances of the city now in force and which may hereafter be in force regarding the public water system or waterworks; or for the collection of the proper rates, charges or taxes for water service furnished or supplied by, from or through the system. 
(Prior Code, § 727; Code 1977, § 13.08.030; Ord. No. 88-1, 1988) 
Sec. 56-35. - Obstructing access of water department officer or employee to stopcock, water meter, etc. 
    No person shall in any manner obstruct or cause to be obstructed the free access of any officer or employee of the water department to any stopcock, water meter, corporate stop or shutoff box, or connection with any water main or service pipe by means of any coal, lumber, brick, building material or by any other means, shift or device whatsoever, or refuse or prevent free access thereto by such officer or employee whenever such officer or employee shall desire access thereto. In the event that the owner or person in possession, charge or control shall refuse or fail to permit free access thereto, or cause to be placed any such obstruction, the water supply to such premises shall forthwith be cut off. 
(Prior Code, § 726; Code 1977, § 13.08.040; Ord. No. 88-1, 1988) 
Sec. 56-36. - Unauthorized interference, etc., with water meters. 
(a)  No person other than duly authorized officer or employee of the municipal water department shall be permitted to examine, repair or in any way interfere with any water meter installed in any building, structure or premises for the control of water supplied thereto. Any person not so authorized who shall tamper or interfere with any such water meter shall be subject to penalty. 
(b)  If it be found that such water meter is being tampered with or interfered with by any unauthorized person, the owner of the building, structure or premises in which such meter is installed or located, or the person in possession, charge or control thereof, shall be held responsible for such unauthorized tampering and interference, and the water supply to such building, structure or premises shall be cut off, and such water supply so cut off shall not again be turned on until such owner or person shall have paid to the water department for the use of the water system, the cost and expense of cutting off and turning on such water system as provided for in section 56-300 and the further sum of $500.00 as liquidated damages for and on account of such unauthorized tampering and interference. 
(Prior Code, § 728; Code 1977, § 13.08.050; Ord. No. 88-1, 1988) 
Sec. 56-37. - Flooding vacant property for use as skating rink. 
    The director of public works or his designee is duly authorized and empowered, from time to time, as he in his discretion may see fit, to permit the use of water from the municipal hydrants, free of charge, for the purpose of flooding vacant property, subject to the consent of the owner of such property, where it may be desired to use such property when so flooded for the purpose of skating; provided that no charge shall be made to any person for the privilege of skating on property so flooded. 
(Code 1977, § 13.08.100; Ord. No. 88-1, 1988) 
Sec. 56-38. - Fire hydrants. 
    All hydrants erected in said municipality for the purpose of extinguishing fires are declared to be public hydrants. No person other than the members of the fire department and employees of the water department, in the exercise of their duties, shall open any such hydrant or attempt to draw from the same, or in any manner interfere with any such hydrant or use them for any purpose whatever. 
(Code 1977, § 13.08.110; Ord. No. 88-1, 1988) 
Sec. 56-39. - Nonliability of city. 
    It is expressly stipulated that no claim shall be made against the city by reason of the breaking of any water main, service pipe, stop cock or meter; the temporary interruption of the water supply; or the breaking of any of the waterworks machinery or stoppage for necessary repairs. 
(Code 1977, § 13.08.140; Ord. No. 88-1, 1988) 
Sec. 56-40. - Interruption of service for repairs and connections. 
    The city reserves the right at any time to shut off the water in its main pipes for the purpose of making connections, extensions, alterations, repairs or cleaning. 
(Code 1977, § 13.08.150; Ord. No. 88-1, 1988) 
Sec. 56-41. - Extension of water mains. 
    The municipality may elect to extend its water mains along any public right-of-way except alleyways or other public ways having a width dedicated to the public use of less than 30 feet, within its service area on the following terms and conditions: 
(1)  Upon application being made for an extension of the water main, the municipality shall determine the necessary size, location and characteristics of the main and of all valves, fittings and other appurtenances thereto and shall make an estimate of the cost of the proposed extension, including mains, valves, fittings and all other appurtenances and materials and all other costs such as labor, permits, etc., including the municipality's expenses for supervision, engineering, insurance, taxes, tools and equipment, accounting and other overhead expenses. The determination of the municipality with respect to the necessary size and characteristics of the mains, valves, fittings and other appurtenances and materials shall be final if the city elects to go forward with the proposed extension; 
(2)  If the estimated cost of the extension is not greater than 11/2 times the municipality's estimate of the first year's revenue to be received from customers who will immediately attach to the extension, the municipality will make the extension without cost to the applicant except for feasibility, engineering, legal expenses and other costs connected with feasibility studies incurred prior to city making an election to go forward with the proposed improvements; 
(3)  If the estimated cost of the extension exceeds 11/2 times the municipality's estimate of the first year's revenue to be received from customers who will immediately attach to the extension, the applicant shall execute and deliver to the municipality an agreement conforming to the provisions of this section and shall pay in advance to the municipality the estimated cost of the extension (less 11/2 times such estimate of the first year's revenue from immediately attaching customers); 
(4)  Estimate of the first year's revenue shall be made by the municipality based upon the average annual residential metered water sales revenue in the prior calendar year; 
(5)  Customers who will immediately attach to the extension to be considered in the estimates provided for in this section shall be those who sign applications for a regular water service connection and also guarantee to the municipality that they will take water service at their premises on such extension within 30 days after the date water is turned into the main and whose water service connections are directly connected to the mains installed under such extension; 
(6)  Should the actual costs of the extension be less than the estimated cost, the municipality shall refund the difference as soon as such actual cost has been ascertained. Should the actual cost of the extension exceed the estimated cost, the applicant may immediately pay the difference or the difference may be used as an offset against any refunds that may become due as provided in this article providing there is a potential for such refunds; and 
(7)  All mains, valves, fittings and other appurtenances or materials installed in accordance with this section shall be and remain the sole property of the municipality. 
(Prior Code, § 730; Code 1977, § 13.08.060; Ord. No. 88-1, 1988) 
Sec. 56-42. - Water supply system; connection required. 
(a)  The owner of houses, buildings or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation or any other purpose and situated within the corporate limits of the city shall have an individual connection to the public water supply system within 90 days of notice to connect. 
(b)  Properties annexed to the city, which at the time of annexation are not supplied water by the city's public water supply system, shall not be required to so connect until such time as the public water main is extended to within 100 feet of such properties. 
(Prior Code, § 731; Code 1977, § 13.08.070; Ord. No. 88-1, 1988; Ord. No. 01-23, 2001) 
Sec. 56-43. - Private wells prohibited; abandonment required. 
(a)  Except as may be necessary to provide water to those properties specified in section 56-42, the use of private wells for potable water is prohibited. 
(b)  Any private wells located on parcels now within the corporate limits of the city, or which may hereinafter be annexed to the city, that are determined to be a potential source of contamination to the public water supply system shall be abandoned in accordance with the regulations of the state department of mines and minerals. 
(Prior Code, § 732; Code 1977, § 13.08.080; Ord. No. 88-1, 1988) 
Sec. 56-44. - Service to mobile homes and mobile home parks. 
    The municipality will extend its water distribution facilities to serve each individual mobile home or living unit and other locations where service is required for the operation of a mobile home park under one of the following provisions: 
(1)  Where a mobile home park owner provides the municipality with acceptable indication of permanency (such as paved streets, sanitary, electric and telephone facilities) and secures all necessary local and state approvals for the operation of such mobile home park, the municipality will install, own and maintain the distribution facilities in accordance with the provisions for extension of water mains, as specified in the rules, regulations and conditions of service. 
(2)  Where a mobile home park does not meet the requirements set forth in subsection (1) of this section, the mobile home park owner will make a deposit equal to the actual cost of extending the municipality's distribution facilities which will not be refundable for a period of five years. After five years, the deposit will be refunded in the same manner as are all other extension agreements provided for under extension of water mains. 
(3)  Service to each mobile home will be provided under the appropriate rate schedule in effect at the time. Bills will be rendered in the name of the occupant (customer) and will be mailed directly to the customer. 
(4)  Service for utility buildings, offices and for a predesigned number of mobile home sites not to exceed ten percent of the total sites within such mobile home park, which may be reserved for transients, may be served through one meter. Such bills will be rendered to and in the name of, the mobile home park owner or operator as a customer. 
(5)  The mobile home park owner or operator will be required to furnish the municipality satisfactory easements along driveways or other locations needed for placement of the municipality's distribution facilities prior to the construction of such distribution facilities. 
(6)  All other provisions of the rules, regulations and conditions of service will apply equally to mobile home parks as applicable except that in the event of any conflict these special rules relating to mobile home parks will be controlling. 
(Prior Code, § 733; Code 1977, § 13.08.090; Ord. No. 88-1, 1988) 
Sec. 56-45. - Unauthorized usage. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any water user or owner of real estate to whom water service is supplied or furnished by, from or through the public water system of waterworks of the city to permit any use of water not authorized or which is expressly prohibited by this chapter or ordinances of the city; or to furnish or supply water to any other person not a tenant or the agent of such owner or water user in or on such real estate as the case may be. 
(b)  Whenever any person violates this section, the director of public works or his designee may, in addition to the applicable penalties, cause the water service to the premises so owned by such violator to be immediately turned off, and the same shall not be turned on again until all delinquent water charges, or taxes, and all penalties and damages, and also the further sum of $10.00 for reconnection of service, have been paid. 
(Code 1977, § 13.08.160; Ord. No. 88-1, 1988) 
Secs. 56-46-56-73. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - WATER SERVICE AND CONNECTIONS 

Sec. 56-74. - Turning off water from building, etc., upon notice from owner, etc., that property is to be vacant. 
    Whenever the owner, agent, lessee or person in charge, possession or control of any building, structure or premises shall give notice in writing to the director of public works or his designee that any building is vacant or unoccupied, and request the water department to turn off the water, the director shall at once cause the water supply of such building to be cut off. When the owner, agent or lessee shall make a formal request that the supply of water be turned on, there shall be a turn on charge of $10.00. 
(Code 1977, § 13.08.120; Ord. No. 88-1, 1988) 
Sec. 56-75. - Street excavations. 
(a)  All water service installation not specified in this chapter shall be under the supervision of the director of public works, where street excavations are made, subject to the control and approval of the street committee, which is authorized to fix and determine all matters pertaining thereto and not fixed by this chapter. Any and all work except fill of street excavations may be examined and tested by the water and sewer committee if it deems it necessary or advisable, and any work not conforming to the requirements therefor shall be properly replaced and made to conform to the requirements at the expense of the party doing the work. Street excavations, filling, and resurfacing shall be done as provided in chapter 48, article III. 
(b)  All excavations for service installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city at no expense to the city. 
(c)  Backfilling shall be done as directed by the director of public works and every builder neglecting to fill as directed shall be liable for all damages or loss resulting therefrom. 
(Code 1977, § 13.12.070; Ord. No. 88-1, 1988) 
Sec. 56-76. - Liability of damages to water meters; examination of meters. 
(a)  All persons to whom water service is furnished or supplied by, from or through the public water system or waterworks shall be responsible for all damages done to a meter on their premises due to freezing or any other cause, including labor charges for replacement or changing of each meter. 
(b)  The director of public works or his designee shall, in all cases where the use of water is expected to exceed 40,000 gallons per month, examine such meters yearly, and shall examine all other meters periodically. 
(Code 1977, § 13.12.090; Ord. No. 88-1, 1988) 
Sec. 56-77. - Location of water meter; specifications for boxes or vaults for meters. 
    Water meters shall be located at such place, within or without the premises and in such manner as the director of public works or his designee shall direct. Boxes or vaults in which meters are to be placed shall be made in accordance with specifications prescribed by the director of public works or his designee. 
(Code 1977, § 13.12.100; Ord. No. 88-1, 1988) 
Sec. 56-78. - New construction. 
    Any new multi-unit construction shall have each of said units separately metered. 
(Code 1977, § 13.12.110; Ord. No. 88-1, 1988) 
Sec. 56-79. - Connection report required prior to turning on of service. 
    It is the duty of all plumbers, and any persons permitted to lay water service pipes or attach or place any fixtures or connections to make report to the city, as soon as such work is completed and before the water is turned on, of all connections made, together with the names of the occupants and owners of the premises. 
(Code 1977, § 13.12.120; Ord. No. 88-1, 1988) 
Sec. 56-80. - Only licensed plumbers to lay service pipes. 
    No person shall lay any water service pipe for the supplying of any building, structure or premises with water from the municipal water system unless he is a duly licensed plumber. 
(Prior Code, § 736; Code 1977, § 13.12.010; Ord. No. 88-1, 1988) 
Sec. 56-81. - Permit or order prerequisite to laying service pipe. 
    No plumber shall lay any water service pipe for the supplying of any building, structure or premises with water from the municipal water service system unless he has first obtained a permit for the doing of such work from the city and paid the permit fee provided in the city fee schedule in chapter 20. 
(Prior Code, § 737; Code 1977, § 13.12.020; Ord. No. 88-1, 1988) 
Sec. 56-82. - Plumbing requirements. 
    All service pipes shall be laid at least five feet under the ground surface. All service pipes extending from the water main to the customer's home/business shall be of copper or potable water quality, copper tub size (CTS) polyethylene tubing, rated at a minimum of 150 pounds per square inch ("psi"). 
(Code 1977, § 13.12.060; Ord. No. 08-04, § 2, 2008; Ord. No. 88-1, 1988) 
Secs. 56-83-56-107. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL 

Sec. 56-108. - General requirements. 
    All plumbing installed within the city shall be installed in accordance with the Illinois Plumbing Code, 77 Ill. Admin. Code 890. If, in accordance with the Illinois Plumbing Code or in the judgment of the director of public works or his designee, an approved backflow prevention device is necessary for the safety of the public water supply system, the director of public works or his designee will give notice to the water customer to install such approved device immediately. The water customer shall, at his own expense, install such an approved device at a location and in a manner in accordance with the Illinois Plumbing Code, Illinois Environmental Protection Agency and all applicable local regulations, and shall have inspections and tests made of such approved devices upon installation and as required by the Illinois Plumbing Code, Illinois Environmental Protection Agency and local regulations. 
(Code 1977, § 13.14.010; Ord. No. 92-3, § 1, 1992) 
Sec. 56-109. - Cross connection prohibited. 
    No person shall establish or permit to be established or maintain or permit to be maintained any connection whereby a private, auxiliary or emergency water supply other than the regular public water supply of the city may enter the supply or distribution system of the municipality, unless such private, auxiliary or emergency water supply and the method of connection and use of such supply shall have been approved by the director of public works or his designee and the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency. 
(Code 1977, § 13.14.020; Ord. No. 92-3, § 1, 1992) 
Sec. 56-110. - Survey and investigation; duty of the director of public works. 
    It shall be the duty of the director of public works or his designee to cause surveys and investigations to be made of commercial, industrial and other properties served by the public water supply to determine whether actual or potential hazards to the public water supply may exist. Such surveys and investigations shall be made a matter of public record and shall be repeated at least every two years, or as often as the director of public works or his designee shall deem necessary. Records of such surveys shall be maintained and available for review for a period of at least five years. 
(Code 1977, § 13.14.030; Ord. No. 92-3, § 1, 1992) 
Sec. 56-111. - Right of entry. 
    The approved cross connection control device inspector shall have the right to enter, at any reasonable time, any property served by a connection to the public water supply or distribution system of the city for the purpose of verifying the presence or absence of cross connections. The director of public works or his designee shall have the right to enter, at any reasonable time, any property served by a connection to the public water supply or distribution system of the city for the purpose of verifying information submitted by the customer regarding the required cross connection control inspection. On demand, the owner, lessees or occupants of any property so served shall furnish to the director of public works or his designee any information which he may request regarding the piping system or systems or water use on such property. The refusal of such information, when demanded, shall, within the discretion of the director of public works or his designee, be deemed evidence of the presence of improper connections as provided in this chapter. 
(Code 1977, § 13.14.040; Ord. No. 92-3, § 1, 1992) 
Sec. 56-112. - Determination of contamination; service to be discontinued. 
(a)  The director of public works or his designee is authorized and directed to discontinue, after reasonable notice to the occupant thereof, the water service to any property wherein any connection in violation of the provisions of this chapter is known to exist, and to take such other precautionary measures as he may deem necessary to eliminate any danger of contamination of the public water supply distribution mains. Water service to such property shall not be restored until such conditions have been eliminated or corrected in compliance with the provisions of this chapter, and until a reconnection fee in the amount provided in the city fee schedule paid to the city. 
(b)  Immediate disconnection with verbal notice can be effected when the director of public works or his designee is assured that imminent danger of harmful contamination of the public water supply system exists. Such action shall be followed by written notification of the cause of disconnection. 
(c)  Immediate disconnection without notice to any party can be effected to prevent actual or anticipated contamination or pollution of the public water supply, provided that, in the reasonable opinion of the director of public works or his designee or the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency, such action is required to prevent actual or potential contamination of the public water supply. 
(d)  Neither the public water supply, the director of public works or his designee, or his agents or assigns, shall be liable to any customer for any injury, damages or lost revenues which may result from termination of the customer's water supply in accordance with the terms of this chapter, whether or not termination was with or without notice. 
(Code 1977, § 13.14.050; Ord. No. 92-3, § 1, 1992) 
Sec. 56-113. - Remediation of contamination; customer responsible. 
    The consumer responsible for backsiphoned or backpressured material or contamination through backflow, if contamination of the potable water supply system occurs through an illegal cross connection or an improperly installed, maintained or repaired device, or a device which has been bypassed, must bear the cost of cleanup of the potable water supply system. 
(Code 1977, § 13.14.060; Ord. No. 92-3, § 1, 1992) 
Secs. 56-114-56-139. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SEWER 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 56-140. - Deposition of objectionable wastes. 
    It is unlawful for any person to place, deposit, or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the city, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any human or animal excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste. 
(Code 1977, § 13.16.020; Ord. No. 82-3, § 2.1, 1982) 
Sec. 56-141. - Connection of sanitary or industrial waste sewers to stormwater drainage systems prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to connect or cause to be connected any drain carrying, or permitted to carry, any toilet, sink, basement, septic tank, cesspool, industrial waste, or any fixture or device discharging polluting substances to any stormwater drain, natural outlet, or watercourse in the city. 
(Code 1977, § 13.16.030; Ord. No. 06-03, § 1, 2006; Ord. No. 82-3, § 2.2, 1982) 
Sec. 56-142. - Unlawful sewage disposal facilities. 
    Except as provided in this chapter, it is unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool, or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage. 
(Code 1977, § 13.16.040; Ord. No. 82-3, § 2.3, 1982) 
Sec. 56-143. - Toilet facilities required; hookup to proximate sewer. 
    The owner of all houses, buildings, or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation, or other purposes, situated within the city and abutting on any street, alley or right-of-way in which there is now located or may in the future be located a public sanitary sewer of the city, is hereby required at his expense to install suitable toilet facilities therein, and to connect such facilities directly with the public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, within 90 days after date of official notice to do so, provided that the public sewer is within 100 feet (30.5 meters) of the property line. 
(Code 1977, § 13.16.050; Ord. No. 82-3, § 2.4, 1982) 
Sec. 56-144. - Damaging or tampering with sewage works. 
    No unauthorized person shall maliciously, willfully or negligently break, damage, destroy or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or equipment which is a part of the sewage works. Any person violating this provision shall be subject to immediate arrest under charge of disorderly conduct. 
(Code 1977, §§ 13.12.065, 13.16.060; Ord. No. 82-3, § 6, 1982; Ord. No. 98-18, § 1, 1998) 
Sec. 56-145. - Right of entry for inspection. 
    The plumbing inspector, superintendent and other duly authorized employees of the city, the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, bearing proper credentials and identification, shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. The plumbing inspector, superintendent or his representatives shall have no authority to inquire into any processes, including metallurgical, chemical, oil refining, ceramic, paper, or other industries beyond that point having a direct bearing on the kind and source of discharge to the sewers or waterway or facilities for waste treatment. 
(Code 1977, § 13.16.070; Ord. No. 82-3, § 7.1, 1982) 
Sec. 56-146. - Conduct of inspectors; company liability. 
    While performing the necessary work on private properties, the plumbing inspector, superintendent or duly authorized employees of the city, Illinois Environmental Protection Agency, and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises established by the company and the company shall be held harmless for injury or death to the city employees and the city shall indemnify the company against loss or damage to its property by city employees and against liability claims and demands for personal injury or property damage asserted against the company and growing out of the gauging and sampling operation, except as such may be caused by negligence or failure of the company to maintain safe conditions. 
(Code 1977, §§ 13.12.065, 13.16.080; Ord. No. 82-3, § 7.2, 1982; Ord. No. 98-18, § 1, 1998) 
Sec. 56-147. - Easement rights. 
    The plumbing inspector, superintendent and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all private properties through which the city holds a duly negotiated easement for the purpose of, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, repair, and maintenance of any portion of the sewage works lying within the easement. All entry and subsequent work, if any, on the easement, shall be done in full accordance with the terms of the duly negotiated easement pertaining to the private property involved. 
(Code 1977, § 13.16.090; Ord. No. 82-3, § 7.3, 1982) 
Sec. 56-148. - Violation-Notice. 
    Any person found to be violating any provision of this article shall be served by the city with a written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time limit for the satisfactory corrections thereof. The offender shall, within the period of time stated in such notice, permanently cease all violations. 
(Code 1977, §§ 13.12.065, 13.16.100; Ord. No. 82-3, § 8.1, 1982; Ord. No. 98-18, § 1, 1998) 
Sec. 56-149. - Same-Penalty. 
    Any person who continues any violation beyond the time limit provided for cessation thereof is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction thereof, shall be fined in the amount provided in the city penalty schedule for each violation. Each day in which any such violation continues is a separate offense. 
(Code 1977, §§ 13.12.065, 13.16.120; Ord. No. 82-3, § 8.2, 1982; Ord. No. 98-18, § 1, 1998) 
Sec. 56-150. - Same-Revocation of permits. 
    The city may revoke any permit for sewage disposal as a result of any violation of any provision of this chapter. 
(Code 1977, § 13.16.110; Ord. No. 82-3, § 8.1, 1982) 
Secs. 56-151-56-168. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BUILDING SEWERS AND CONNECTIONS 

Sec. 56-169. - Permit-Required. 
    No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with or opening into, use, alter or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the water and sewer committee. 
(Code 1977, § 13.20.024; Ord. No. 82-3, § 4.1, 1982) 
Sec. 56-170. - Same-Classes; application; fees. 
(a)  There shall be two classes of building sewer permits: 
(1)  For residential and commercial service; and 
(2)  For service to establishments producing industrial wastes. 
(b)  In either case, the owner or his agent shall make application on special form furnished by the city. The permit application shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications or other information considered pertinent in the judgment of the water and sewer committee. The industry, as a condition of permit authorization, must provide information describing its wastewater constituents, characteristics, and type of activity. 
(c)  A permit and inspection fee for a residential or commercial building sewer permit and for an industrial building sewer permit in the amount provided in the city fee schedule shall be paid to the city at the time the application is filed. 
(Code 1977, § 13.20.028; Ord. No. 82-3, § 4.3, 1982) 
Sec. 56-171. - Adequacy of downstream facilities. 
    A building sewer permit will only be issued and a sewer connection shall only be allowed if it can be demonstrated that the downstream sewerage facilities, including sewers, pump stations and wastewater treatment facilities, have sufficient reserve capacity to adequately and efficiently handle the additional anticipated waste load. 
(Code 1977, § 13.20.032; Ord. No. 82-3, § 4.4, 1982) 
Sec. 56-172. - House sewer-Materials and slope. 
    The house sewer, beginning three feet from the building, shall be of cylindrical vitrified sewer pipe of the best quality, free from splits and imperfections. Spigot and hub ends shall be concentric. It shall be not less than six inches inside bore and three-fourths-inch thick. It shall slope uniformly one-fourth inch or more to each foot of run from the building to the sanitary sewer; it shall rest on a smooth and solid bottom, with the ground hollowed out for the hubs, and the soil rammed in on each side of the pipe; all changes in direction shall be made with long curves or bends; short bends and T's are prohibited. The joints shall be made tight with equal parts of Portland cement and sand, mixed dry, and enough water added to give consistency; the cement shall be mixed in small quantities and no retempered cement shall be used. All joints shall be cleaned out with a swab. This section shall not be construed as prohibiting extra heavy cast iron pipe, or other material approved by the city engineer. 
(Prior Code, § 587; Code 1977, § 13.20.040) 
Sec. 56-173. - Same-Alternate materials permitted when. 
    When the slope of one-fourth inch to each foot of run cannot be obtained, or when the ground is newly made ground or of a yielding nature, and also for that part of the house sewer which is under the building and extending three feet outside the wall line, or when the drain is close to trees and there is danger of roots obstructing the drain, the sewer shall be constructed of material similar to that required for the soil pipes. No iron sewers shall be permitted with less slope than one-eighth inch to the foot. 
(Prior Code, § 588; Code 1977, § 13.20.050) 
Sec. 56-174. - Same-Connection with proper Y required. 
    In the construction or connecting of house sewers, every building will be required to be directly connected with the junction or Y designed for them. 
(Prior Code, § 598; Code 1977, § 13.20.060) 
Sec. 56-175. - Same-When city to furnish Y's. 
    Whenever it may be found necessary to make a connection between a house drain or house sewer and the main sewer in the street, where no Y was originally placed in the latter in front of the lot, the Y will be furnished and put in by the city without extra charge, and under no circumstances will sewer builders or others be permitted to break into any sewer of the city for the purpose of setting Y's therein, or making any kind of connection whatever. 
(Prior Code, § 590; Code 1977, § 13.20.070) 
Sec. 56-176. - Same-Traps prohibited. 
    There shall be no trap upon the house drain or house sewer. 
(Prior Code, § 589; Code 1977, § 13.20.080) 
Sec. 56-177. - Same-Maintenance by owner required. 
    In all cases where connecting or private sewers have been constructed, the owner or occupant of premises having such sewer connections shall, at their own expense and at all times, maintain and keep such connecting sewer in good working order and repair. 
(Prior Code, § 602; Code 1977, § 13.20.090) 
Sec. 56-178. - Fixture size; free flow required. 
(a)  Every person, company, or corporation using the public sewers of the city shall provide such fixtures as will allow a sufficient quantity of water to flow into the lateral drain or private sewer and shall cause such drain, passage, or connection to be at all times adequate for its purpose and of such size and dimensions as to convey and allow freely to pass whatever may properly enter the same, and shall keep such private sewer at all times unobstructed. 
(b)  All connections with sewers or drains used for the purpose of carrying off refuse from water closets or slops from kitchens shall be provided with fixtures for a sufficiency of water, to be applied as to properly carry off such matter. 
(Prior Code, §§ 593, 594; Code 1977, § 13.20.110) 
Sec. 56-179. - Locating Y's, T's, and branches. 
    All sewer builders shall have the privilege, at all reasonable times, to examine and consult the records of the city showing the location of Y's and T's and branches, but the accuracy of such recorded location is not in anywise guaranteed by the city. 
(Prior Code, § 596; Code 1977, § 13.20.130) 
Sec. 56-180. - Sealing of ends required. 
    The ends of all sewers not immediately connecting with the plumbing fixtures shall be securely guarded against the introduction of earth, sand, or other material with a watertight and imperishable substance. 
(Prior Code, § 597; Code 1977, § 13.20.140) 
Sec. 56-181. - Excavations; safety precautions. 
    All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways, and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city at no expense to the city. 
(Code 1977, § 13.20.145; Ord. No. 82-3, § 4.13, 1982) 
Sec. 56-182. - Street excavations. 
    All appurtenances to house drains and all work thereon not specified in this chapter shall be under the supervision of the superintendent of streets, where street excavations are made, subject to the control and approval of the street committee, which is authorized to fix and determine all matters pertaining thereto and not fixed by this chapter. Any and all work except fill of street excavations may be examined and tested by the sewer committee if they deem it necessary or advisable, and any work not conforming to the requirements therefor shall be properly replaced and made to conform to the requirements at the expense of the party doing the work. Street excavations, filling, and resurfacing shall be done as provided in chapter 48, article III. 
(Prior Code, § 601; Code 1977, § 13.20.150) 
Sec. 56-183. - Backfilling. 
    Backfilling shall be done as directed by the sewer committee, and every sewer builder neglecting to fill as directed shall be liable for all damages or loss resulting therefrom. 
(Prior Code, § 604; Code 1977, § 13.20.160) 
Sec. 56-184. - Connections with cesspools and privies prohibited. 
    No connection from any cesspool or privy shall be made with any sewer. 
(Prior Code, § 603; Code 1977, § 13.20.170) 
Sec. 56-185. - Obstruction of sewers by builders prohibited. 
    No sewer, drain, or gutter shall be obstructed by any sewer builder for any purpose whatever. 
(Prior Code, § 599; Code 1977, § 13.20.190) 
Sec. 56-186. - Connection of surface runoff or groundwater prohibited. 
(a)  The maintenance and connection of roof downspouts, exterior foundation drains, areaway drains, or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer is prohibited. 
(b)  Existing roof drains, footing tile, or other illegal connections to the public sanitary sewers shall be disconnected from the sewer within 90 days after written notice from the city to do such work.
